The ambience and views were so spectacular (and there was a grand piano) that we didn't turn any of the 3 tv's on in 5 days. We had room service for dinner on two nights when we had early concerts to go to. As the room service comes from the menus available in the hotel's own restaurants (The Carlyle Restaurant, Bemelman's Bar and Cafe Carlyle), the food was first class and piping hot, not to mention on time and served with such attention to detail. Once again, we were offered the hotel's house limo on our two concert nights by the doormen, as they were available.There are so many people to thank from the front desk, to the housekeeping people, concierge, doormen, bellhops and elevator men. We felt these loyal employees all made us feel that we really were in a home away from home and not just in one of many 5 star hotels in New York. The Carlyle should never change it's winning formula and much is due to the employees, and also the beautiful upkeep of the main floor with the shining lobby, The Carlyle Cafe, Carlyle Restaurant, The Gallery and Bemelman's Bar. Interior design of the suites and guest rooms is also to be mentioned, as the furnishings and linens are so comfortable, and interiors were beautifully and noticeably updated in our Suite.I could go on, but needless to say, we can't wait for our next trip to New York and stay at The Carlyle! Thanks for everything!

This is hands down my favorite place to stay in NYC. It is a beautiful property with a fantastic staff. The rooms are elegant and the beds are exceptionally comfortable. The location is also unbeatable. I am always disappointed to leave The Carlyle and look forward to a return trip very soon!

I had a wonderful stay the first time I stayed here, until during my first visit I was obliged to move floor so that air conditioning systems could be repaired. Assuming that this was a once off, I booked one of the more expensive suites for a second visit. The air conditioning in the room was broken and the room was therefore sweltering. It was mended after a couple of days, but no offer of apology or recompense was made. On the same day I was physically pushed out of an elevator (which I waited a very long time for) by one of the staff who told me that he had another guest’s luggage to move. I spoke to the duty manager who told me he would “file a report” and then explained that the general manager was available by appointment only. In all the circumstances, my opinion is that the facilities and the service at this hotel far fall below what i was promised and that the hotel must fall back on fairer pricing to justify what has sadly become a tired and generic experience. All good things must come to an end.

The Carlyle is one of the few grandly old-fashioned hotels that New York has left. It has class: The flowers in the lobby are lavish and dramatic. It has elegance: The small elevators are still operated by employees who will punch in your floor number with their white-gloved hands. It has an enviable location, just a few blocks of easy walking away from the Met, the Frick Collection, and Central Park. It has amenities. (Chocolates at turndown, Kiehl's toiletries, plus they seem to replace that yellow soap every five minutes.)The hotel decor is a little dated, and the wait for the elevators can be tiresome, but all the staff were friendly and helpful. I didn't eat in the hotel so can't comment on the food, except to say that I wish the complimentary coffee (and muffins!) in the lobby arrived promptly at 6am every morning as advertised.If you need a great location and want to feel that you're floating along on a small fluffy cloud of customer service, you can't go wrong with the Carlyle.

This was our one of our favorites over the years, but its time to go to the Mandarin.We do the American Express fine hotels, and this place treats you like a second class citizen once they know your on the program. At breakfast, since tip is included, waiters are few and far between. The buffet was poor at best. The room and elevator guys were still great. Charged for roll a way bed (daughter came to visit), bar wanted a 35 dollar cover for each of the 4 of us after buying lots of drinks as music was coming... just a bunch of high maintenance issues that made it more of a C+ experience.

I've always wanted to stay here and so we did on a one night staycation when my daughter had an important party to attend and we thought it would be fun to pretend to be east-siders for a night instead of the west-siders we actually are and to make sure we didn't get caught in a blizzard if there was one that weekend so that my daughter wouldn't disappoint her very good friend. The hotel is in an excellent location to walk around the east side of manhattan and the presence of elevator operators and the intimate lobby makes this place feel more like a residence than a hotel. We had booked two connecting rooms for us and our 2 kids at a very reasonable weekend rate, and found ourselves upgraded to a 2 bedroom suite that included a steinway baby grand piano in the living room and 2 terraces. Amex Platinum might have had something to do with it.The rainforest shower was one of the best I've ever had especially considering it was on the 15th floor of a tall building. Bathroom amenities were top notch. The suite was decorated to simple taste and is a bit dated, but it was spacious and comfortable especially if you don't like particularly plush surroundings. It also featured a nice assortment of art and it is worthwhile to spend a bit of time perusing the book in the room telling you about the hotel's history. I had a spa treatment and the facility is classy; the fitness center is adequate and nothing out of the ordinary. The evening scene in the hotel was hopping at the bar and the cabaret. We greatly enjoyed the morning breakfast buffet; every item was elegant and perfectly prepared and the food on the buffet was fresh, even the eggs. i was a bit perturbed being charged $11 for a side of avocado (usually hotels provide it gratis upon request), but at least it was a very good one. Hotel was very nice about extending our late check-out to almost 6pm. The telephone operator (i think it was miriam) who took my wake up call at midnight was just as cheerful at 8am the next morning and wins my award for sounding really great after working the midnight shift. Kids got a nice package of amenities and we received nice cookies, sweets and fruits in the room. Living room could use a bit more light at night and the piano could use a bit of a tuning, but otherwise the place lives up to its storied reputation and we enjoyed a great time for our 24 hours at this hotel.

We stayed here a couple of weeks ago and enjoyed ourselves. The hotel is a little dated, but was still very elegant. However, the lead housekeeper Dee was so wonderful. She always made sure that we had everything we needed and was quick to take care of any needs. She helped make our trip that much better. Thank you!

My wife and I reserved a room and made a dinner reservation at The Carlyle as part of a special Valentine's Day package. Our room was quite nice and it included champagne on ice and several chocolate covered strawberries. Unfortunately, dinner was one problem after another. It took 10 minutes to get a wine list, my beef was significantly over cooked, our side dishes consisted of 2 kinds of potatoes, and we waited 40 minutes for our dessert before we walked out without ever getting it.

My wife and I travel to NYC often and we always stay at The Carlyle. Great staff, great location, and great service. One of the last "grand" hotels in NYC. Been staying there for years and have never been disappointed. There are newer, "glitzier" hotels in NYC but none with the class, grace, and history of The Carlyle. We love it.

We spent the weekend at the Carlyle. I booked a month in advance, directly with the hotel. A few days before our stay I received an email confirmation but with a rate that was 30% higher than my original confirmed rate. I emailed the hotel, and was informed that the rate had changed due to occupancy but that "as a onetime courtesy we will honour the original rate". On a confirmed booking secured with a credit card. This was a first in decades of international hotel stays. I emailed a second time, as the "onetime courtesy" really irritated me. The response I got then was that this must have been a glitch. Net net, I felt like the hotel was trying to pull a fast one. But we stayed there anyway, as we had a reservation at the Cafe Carlyle and it was all just too convenient. For some reason, our room was boiling hot and the heating system is positioned to blow directly on the bed. We spent the weekend with the window open just to make the room bearable (February!). All other points were fine - breakfast, staff, amenities, etc. It's a lovely old hotel, very grand. But we will not stay here again, as I am still irritated by the monkey business with the rate.

As always, a real pleasure to stay at the Carlyle. The staff is truly first rate and there seems to be dozens of them always ready to help and serve. really enjoyed the Isaac Mizrahi show at the Cafe Carlyle

I live in the neighborhood a few blocks from the Carlyle Hotel and while some work was being done in my apartment I needed a place to stay. I decided to try the Carlyle. I made a reservation online 2 days before checking in and It was a pleasant surprise that the hotel is also pet friendly, so I could stay with my pets. A major, major plus!I am staying in one of the tower rooms. Still here. The room is spacious, with a very comfortable bed, with a downtown view. I had to extend my stay, due to unforeseen work delays in my apartment, and the desk has been extremely helpful in accommodating my request so I could stay in the same room. Total stay 6 nights.The major attraction for me is that The hotel is quiet, no loud tourists here, reminiscent of the glamorous times. All staff has been very nice, unpretentious and extremely helpful. All the requests have been responded to fast. Room service, bill prepared and dropped of in my room, arranging the additional days in the same room, etc.It has been a wonderful experience. Sad to have to leave, but Next time I feel like change, it is staycation time at the Carlyle Hotel.

Staying at the Carlyle is always a wonderful experience. We have grown to trust this product. We like the location right off Madison Ave with plenty of great shopping. We upgraded our stay this time and loved the larger room. Staff always friendly and ready to serve. Then there is the Carlyle Restaurant a real treat. Don’t forget the fantastic breakfasts.

Completely loved our 3 night stay here. Staff were faultless and genuinely friendly. Outstanding female concierge gave us some really great tips as New York newbies. On arrival a double, rather than a twin, was assigned to us and we were upgraded to a tower room to ensure we had a twin room. Decor is elegant and understated - much less flashy than other 5* hotels. The bed was the most comfortable I've ever slept in. Small suggestion might be to offer environmentally minded guests the option of reusing towels.

From the moment you pull up our front, you are treated like you are their only guest. The rooms are beautiful and the beds... oh the beds! It’s like sleeping on a cloud! The staff is so friendly and helpful. As if all of this isn’t enough, it’s also home to the best bar in, well the world - Bemelman’s!

The Carlyle Hotel is the place to be in New York. This was the New York White House during the Kenndey administration. It's still ultra-classy, from the decor to the elevator operators. The restaurant is the best business dinner spot in NY. The rooms are exquisite, with great touches like heated floors in the bathrooms. Go, you won;t be disappointed.

This is one of the finest hotels in the United States. The rooms are bright spacious and very comfortable. The Carlyle offers every comfort you need. The staff is one of the finest group you will find. Friendly and courteous, they will strive make sure your stay is comfortable in every way. Please check out the piano bar, a great way to spend an evening.
user_name:
I4370UXanthonyb
New York City, New York

review_body: Upon arriving, everyone from the doorman, reception, bell hop and white glove, elevator operator were so gracious, welcoming and helpful. A very fine staff and a very pleasant atmosphere in the hotel. Service like this is a lost art form.Our room on the 14th floor faced towards Central Park. It was very spacious, immaculate and designed beautifully. We asked for a room with two beds which turned out to be twin size, but the Frette bedding soothed us to sleep. The room does not have sufficient lighting which could easily be fixed. The two, swing arm, reading sconces, one by each bed and one desk lamp which are more or less ambient, do not provide enough light for finding things in the dresser or for sifting through luggage.The writing desk with a gorgeous French mirror also serves as a lovely vanity table with ample space and 4 drawers. There are 2 walk-in closets with automatic lighting. Very large dresser with 6 drawers affords ample storage space.The room comes with bottled water, chocolates at turn down, and wonderful Kiehl’s toiletries. However, it would have been nice to have a kettle or small coffee maker in the room for a pick me up especially during the cold snap.The hotel is well located on the upper east side in a very upscale neighbourhood near top museums and high end, neighbourhood restaurants. That being said the NY weather was experiencing the polar vortex and we indulged in the fabulous Carlyle Restaurant. We took Uber to get us elsewhere Top of The Rock, etc.The Carlyle Restaurant for dinner offered a fine menu with some classical French food. The lobster bisque and mushroom soup melted in your mouth. The main courses of Dover sole meunière, striped bass and duck with orange sauce were superbly prepared. The bottle of Meursault complimented the entries. Four of us shared a slice of Opera Cake that made sweet, chocolate dreams for later that night.The restaurant’s breakfast buffet was fresh, presented beautifully, baked items were very flavourful and there was a great selection of foods to choose from. The a la carte menu is equally delicious if you want to be served.The Carlyle Cafe with the famous Bemelman murals was full both times, however, one can still hear the piano music in the Bohemian Pasha room with Kilim pillows and red velvet seating, its famously strong cocktails, teas, and light fare. It is also a fabulous place for people watching. We checked out of our room and were settling the account when we were alerted our flight was cancelled. The hotel said not to worry and the cheerful housekeepers refreshed our room and the ever so pleasant staff welcomed us back. My husband wanted to get back to work, but I secretly enjoyed another night at this ever so special hotel which will be my go to place whenever I’m in NY which is actually quite often.

The Carlyle attracts customers who like being recognized when they return, but also celebrities trying to escape glitz. Rooms are comfortable in an old-fashioned way. The restaurant is dependable but unimaginative. To be reassuringly personal, they still have lift operators even though the actual elevators have long since been automated. You can get equal comfort for less money, or something fancier for the same money. But the Carlyle aims to feel like old money and keep you in the family. Great location for the Met.

Born and raised in New York City, there is nothing like coming back to the city and staying at a New York Classic! This property breathes the good old days of New York but stays current in all amenities. From the moment you walk into the door, you are treated like loyalty. Doormen with white gloves and a bellman's cap, an elevator still run by a very friendly attendant. The rooms are beautifully appointed and the service is five star! Room service attendants are classically trained.I will definitely return!

My wife and I traveled to NY for the weekend to visit the Metropolitan Museum of Art and take in a Broadway play. We are so glad we decided to stay on the upper east side within easy walking distance of the MET. The rooms and corridors at first seem dated, but once you get into the whole back in time thing, the Carlyle exceeded our every expectation. The check in was friendly and smooth,and after a quick visit to the room, we made a visit to the concierge who was polite, knowledgeable, and very helpful finding a restaurant who could accommodate my gluten free wife ,and get us out in time for the theater. The recommendation was spot on and our evening went flawlessly.We slept soundly in a very comfortable king bed, and enjoyed a generous shower (unusual in these days where everyone seems to be singlehandedly saving the planet from running out of water) in the morning. We enjoyed the morning breakfast buffet (menu also available) in a cozy little study.The food was as excellent as the room. The amenities were only outdone by the service. At first it was weird having an attendant drive an automatic elevator , but once you put yourself n the mindset of J P Morgan in the 30's, the whole experience of being ridiculously pampered and waited on was well worth the price of admission and the occasional gratuity. We'd do it again,and probably will next time we visit NYC.

My daughter and I were in town for a medical consultation and added in some sightseeing. The staff were gracious and welcoming. Our room was clean, well appointed and very comfortable. We ate lunch in the hotel restaurant. The food was very good and the service was wonderful.

Friendly staff, good food (room service), prompt service. I had a problem with the heat. The engineer was responsive but I had to leave drapes open for the radiator to work. One night the room was 65-67. The next night it was 74.

Amazing! From the moment we pulled up in our car, the doorman, the bellman, receptionist, elevator operator, etc. were not only well trained and polite, but could not do enough for us. The fitness center was immaculate and well equipped. Our room was gorgeous, immaculate and very spacious. Room service was prompt and the food was delicious. Great location!

Quiet elegance rather than flash and dazzle. Loved the monogrammed pillow cases -- make you feel like an honoured guest, not just another booking. Love the white gloved elevator operators and the mail delivery tube running down from every floor. (Makes me really wish more people sent me hand written notes!) Amazing food. Lovely, comfortable room with great amenities and perfect fresh flowers. And of course the irreplaceable art in the bar and the gallery. Really, really loved this visit!

The first thing i want to say is that this is not a bad hotel. However, it is also not a particularly good one either and it is far from being on a par with the other top hotels in the City. What's a little annoying is that the hotel still thinks it's comparable with places like the St Regis or the 4 Seasons but its dated look, its lack of communal space and the fact that it seems to welcome pets better than it welcomes humans means that no matter what they do right (and they do a lot right) still leaves you thinking you are being short changed. Their pricing is also nothing sort of ridiculous especially in the spa, who seem to fill out numbers just for fun. The main dining room is like something from the 1970's and although the food is better than adequate you just feel like the entire place is caught in some kind of a time warp. As part of the Rosewood group i was really looking forward to staying here, and although its not a bad hotel I certainly did not feel that it was worth the money or that it was a place i would rush back to. The staff look bored, is there really a need to have a staff member operate every elevator? In the age of smartphones, I'm pretty sure guests can press a button in an elevator. They really need to give this place a decent makeover and more importantly provide guests with a proper lobby as there is no where to go and just sit and relax, and in a hotel that charges as much as this one, its just not acceptable.

Great looking hotel with nowhere to relax. When I asked the man who operated the elevator, I was told the space just outside of these lifts with a couple of sofas was where one could sit!! Really? Small and uninviting, only 3-4 people was all this small area could accommodate!I pretended to go to the Spa to look at their different treatments so that I could sit somewhere!Our suite was a fair size but the bathroom was old fashioned, tiny and lacked any modern amenities.Claustrophobic and inconvenient. Too much space is dedicated to storage areas.The breakfast is served in a very glamorous restaurant with at least half a dozen waiters hovering with nothing to do. On a couple of occasions we were quite shocked to hear them arguing very loudly with each other. One senior waiter asked another if he could get coffee for a guest to which he replied, ‘Why don’t you get it yourself?’. The waiters looked unhappy and moody accept for one who was a Frenchman. He was very helpful and it was a pleasure to talk to him.Not my idea of a hotel with such an amazing location and past! I expected exceptional service which was simply not there.As I haven’t been to New York for many years, I may have got the wrong idea of the behaviour of people in prestigious hotels in Manhattan.

More like a home than a hotel. Great location and staff. Wonderful amenities. Great food. The rooms are all unique. Water pressure in shower is awesome. Everyone is friendly and remembers your name. Always look forward to returning.

A fabulous piece of calm and elegance on the Upper East Side - THE place to stay in NY. Avoid Midtown and the tourist hordes and stay up here. The Carlyle is absolutely wonderful. My room was beyond cosy with a city view to die for. Have cocktails at Bemelmans and you get a refill. Legendary. The staff are truly excellent. Always smiling, always polite and charming. Cannot wait to be back in 2018 !

The best. Or very close. Excellent and mainly long serving staff which make the place. All departments are excellent but special mention must be given to front desk and concierge ( especially Jeff), and Islam and Mabrouck and their colleagues in the lower bar/ restaurant section ( sorry, forgotten the name). Only complaint..and it isn't really a complaint...is the out of date and patronizing " dress code" in the main restaurant which appears to only apply to men. Leaving that aside, the food and service there are first class . A great hotel.

I think it’s fair to say that the hotel needs a refurb but it is a lovely hotel and our suite was amazing! The staff are all super helpful and friendly and I love the Bell staff in the elevator! Wonderfully old fashioned!! I think they are beginning a major refurb next year and I can’t wait to visit and stay here again!! A first class choice in NY. One criticism is the Bar. I was not aware of the $25 a head service charge. I had the worst old fashioned that I’ve ever had and didn’t drink and was then charged an additional $50 for the two of us to sit there....

I stayed here with my grandparents and family - where they ALWAYS stay when traveling to New York. Set on the Upper East side of Manhattan, The Carlyle holds a beautiful history. The bar downstairs has an old school atmosphere, a wonderful escape from the hustle and bustle all over the city. Each room in the hotel tells it's very own story. You can clearly tell the attention to detail in every corner of every room, it is quite magnificent. Given that it rests on the Upper East Side, it is a beautiful location rich with history and close to museums, restaurants and shopping. The atmosphere is different from the lower side, but that is what makes this location and hotel that much more unique and special, it is a landmark. I hope that I have the pleasure of staying here again soon - absolutely marvelous!

We have stayed here a few times and have had nothing but great experiences, everyone that works here is professional and attentive. The rooms are all a little different but all nicely decorated and comfortable. The breakfast buffet has everything you could want . The lobby was beautifully decorated for the holidays. Love it here!

reception, welcome, service, room, comfort,breakfast, flowers, all better than good:rare and excellent ; perfect to be true.as every time, since our first stay in the nineties and many following.the only change is...little spoons no longer in silver! Yellow soaps still smell so delicate fragrance that you breath their flavour as soon the revolving door is passed!and by an extraordinairy chance on a memorable monday night at the café Carlyle we have been allowed, standing up in a corner of the room to attend the fantastic and unforgettable jazz band of Woody Allen in person and his prodigious friends, banjo, trompette, piano, contrebasse players. The show, music, attitude, even silences of Woody Allen so close to you are an absolutely unique experience that should normally be booked 4 months in advance!!!Magic New York, magic Carlyle, magic Woody. Even after a marvelous transatlantic crossing on board Queen Mary 2, this time in Manhattan will remain totally UNIQUE.

There is something about a historic hotel ... it's an energy and an essence. Best check-in experience I've ever had, elevator attendants are charming, and the bar at the hotel can't be missed. Loved the location. The rooms can use some updating but it's more aesthetics than amenities. I would like to see a power bar in the room to make charging of phones and laptops more convenient.

The Carlyle has probably one of the best locations in NYC. Walk to most of the major museums, Central Park, Madison and 5th ave shopping as well as many renowned and not so renowned restaurants. But what makes the Carlyle Great is The professional knowledgeable and friendly staff. Will surely return.

The hotel is nothing but a former shadow of what used to be. The management is more or less none existent. The bar was dirty, and smelled somewhat of dirty upholstery & clothes. The people at 2 different tables around us were vulgar & filthy talking. Rest assured there isn't a dress code. Anything goes!! Wow what a sad thing to see.

My first room had dingy gray curtains and ikea style furniture. Small and dark. Switched to an only slightly better room. It too was small, dark, and dingy. Neither room looked anywhe e love ke the rooms advertised. A complete overhaul of the hotel is overdue.

Very simply put : excellent! Service, rooms, quality are perfect! The attentiveness of the staff was perfect. The location of the hotel is also perfect. Highly reccomended for business trips as well as private or family trips.

There is no dining experience better than the restaurant at the Carlyle. The menu is varied, the food outstanding and the service impeccable without pretention or obsequiense. For an added treat have coffee and dessert in the lobby lounge or Bemelman’s. An awesome evening.
user_name:
Jack L
Oyster Bay, New York

review_body: Even when water started to leak from the ceiling of our closet The Carlyle staff was cool, calm and confident. We were moved to the room next door quickly by the valet staff and our clothing was cleaned, pressed and returned in the morning with a minimum of fuss or disruption.

We just returned from a dream stay at the Hotel Carlyle. This is the ultimate New York experience. When you walk in the door the second time you are greeted by name. The elevator operators (yes!! elevator operators) know what floor you are on. When you go to the dining room they know who you are. Fresh flowers in the room, a comfortable bath (and we had a powder room also), and quiet. We were on the 14th floor and had no street noise whatsoever. We found it very easy to get a cab, unlike our last stay (52nd at 5th) where we could never get a cab.So, the reasons to go to the Carlyle:1. Beautiful well appointed rooms, of a nice size for NYC. Beautiful wood floors, restful colors, comfortable furniture and bed. Just being in the room was relaxing. Well maintained.2. Very few rooms on a floor so little noise from the hall. As I said the rooms are quiet.3. Dining Room off the lobby with a great breakfast (buffet or menu service). Huge choice of different morning foods, beautiful flowers and Harry Benson photos on the walls. 4. Bemelman’s Bar. This beautiful bar has a jazz pianist from 5:30 to 8:30 and a jazz combo from 9:00 until. Full of interesting people, great music, great energy. 5. Café Carlyle. This is a supper club that seats less than 90 people and has a changing singer generally for a two week period. It is intimate and usually full. 6. Good value. If you want a hotel on the Upper East Side the Carlyle is right in the middle of the price range. This is not for the bargain traveler.7. If the weather is bad you just don’t have to go anywhere. With Bemelman’s and the dining room you don’t have to go out. 8. There are other great restaurants within a short block and dozens of great restaurants within a very short distance.9. One block from the Met Breuer and a short walk to the Metropolitan Museum and Central Park.10. Service, Service, Service. The staff is attentive, warm, and helpful. 11. Most excellent drug store (Zitomer) directly across the street for those things you forgot to pack.12. History. This hotel has an incredible history you will enjoy learning about.

Probably the first time that i'm reviewing an hotel while still staying for a few more days, but it's easy to make up one's mind when greeted with this level of service, the staff has been delightful in every single way and always exceeding expectations.The rooms are classic and very comfortable and the decor is superb and very elegant yet interesting, breakfast and food in general is very very good at the gallery and the wine and liquor selection is pretty great.A big plus is also the location, which is perfect, and the upper floors offer a breathtaking view that simply cannot be missed.

We stayed for a few nights at The Carlyle and have to say that everything was pure delight, from the suite we had, its view and embroidered pillows with our initials, the kind service provided, delicious breakfast as well as exceptionnal location. Thank you so much to the whole team for making our stay so special!

We go once a year and only wish it could be more. For more than 30 years and the lady that takes care of us in our 7th floor room is the same. Simply, she is wonderful. They are beginning renovation and I hope the family and natural elegance remains.

Great stylish hotel with many classical enjoyable features, no longer found in many modern hotels. Disappointingly no coffee-tea facilities in the room, and bathroom could do with some modernisation! Otherwise great stay.

The "Deluxe" room was worn out. The furniture is scratched. The carpet was stained. The bathroom fixtures appeared literally about forty years old.The fully automated elevators have operators. The cost of this anachronism could be much more productively used for badly needed improvements to the property. The elevator service is slow. Our stay was a major disappointment. We had always been more than satisfied with Rosewood hotels. Our trust in this brand has been broken.

An old tired hotel that needs to be completely redone. Shabby chic is not desirable ina hotel. It’s just shabby and needs repairing and a complete makeover. Spend the money. Charging 1000for a,n inferior room is gauging the guests.

Checkin was slow, only one person working the counter. I had tight dinner reservations and was coming to check-in directly following a red eye and then the office. I had to wait several minutes while the desk bantered with other customers making idle chit chat. In addition, there was no acknowledgment from the counter that I was even present - no "Just a moment sir", no eye contact. Nothing. At 8:45 am the following morning, loud jack hammering and drilling started through my floor and wall. I immediately called the front desk, who immediately forwarded me to the manager on duty, who said that there was renovations happening on the gallery below. No offer to look into the issue or change rooms. Not acceptable at 8:45, it continued through 10 am. I was unable to get a good night's rest after my red eye flight the day prior. I left this precise feedback verbally at the desk on checkout. An apology was offered, but nothing further. Booked through Amex Fine Hotels. Not Rosewood quality at all.

I have always wanted to stay at the Carlyle. It did not disappoint Located in one of the best Manhattan neighbourhoods it draws worldwide guests and locals The rooms are comfortable and range from Traditional to Modern in decor From the welcoming reception staff to the elevator operators you are made to feel at home Bemelmans is a great place for a drink and a meal. This hotel fulfills and exceed expectations

Having visited the Carlyle in the past, and being familiar with some of the great hotels of the world, I was looking forward to my recent stay there. My enthusiasm was misplaced. The rooms are extremely tired for the most part - and believe me, I know because I had the misfortune to experience several.More disappointing was the abominable service. With one or two exceptions, the service was slow, indolent, and disinterested. When I first had to change rooms late one evening, it took over an hour for the porter to arrive to move the luggage. When he did arrive he hadn't brought a trolley. When eventually the move was made, a number of possessions were left behind. When this was discovered, not all of them made it back to me and I left New York in the unusual situation of having a suitcase that was lighter than when I arrived!Even simple tasks like cleaning the room or replenishing supplies were not carried out efficiently, effectively or sometimes at all. Please, don't be wowed by the illustrious name of this once-great hotel. There are many places to stay in New York City. I have no doubt that most of them will be better than this dive.

I live in NYC and arranged for my family visiting from out of the country to stay at the Carlyle. I booked and paid for the room online and followed up with a call indicating that they would need an extra bed brought in for their young daughter. That evening my family arrived and they did not have the extra bed. I called the hotel and they wouldn't send a bed to the room without extra payment, and said they were not permitted to take payment over the phone. They refused to send the extra bed to the room (and it was past 11 pm). It was unbelievable. I have never had such poor service, and would have thought that i was at a holiday inn rather than a luxury hotel. I would not choose to stay or arrange anyone else to stay at this hotel again. Terrible.
user_name:
monicakarora
New York City, New York

review_body: We spent 5 amazing days at the hotel. We received amazing service, probably the best we have ever had. The morning buffet was truly amazing and everything was plentiful and delicious. We were upgraded to a one bedroom suite on arrival for free. I cannot wait to go there again soon. It is worth every penny. The toiletries were Kiehl's and included a facial moisturiser and lip balm which were full sizes. I am very pleasantly surprised and can't wait to go there again.

I have stayed in the hotel in June 2017. My feelings are mixed about this hotel. On the one hand it takes you back in the old times because it has kept its character -i.e. in each elevator there is a doorman who is dressed with black suite and white gloves and is taking you to the floor, the jazz bar is just amazing like the old times. The rooms are old, the floor the doors and the drawers are very old. It is a basic old bedroom. On the other hand the service is excellent. I must admit that the personell made me feel very comfortable even when i asked them to take me to a nwer room. The newer room was not really renovated but better than the previous one. If i remember correctly there is no gym. I wouldnt stay there again but i would definetly go again to the jazz bar and therestaurant. The food in the restaurant is really good,. Also breakfast is really amazing, If you like spacious and modern rooms dont stay there. P.S. The location is in a nice neighbarhood of New York just two blocks from central park.

I was surprised as to how large our room was. The lobby and entrance were beautiful. Staff were all very friendly. Good location on the upper east side. Close to the park and great shopping close by. Highly recommend!

My wife and I stay at the Carlyle when ever we visit NY. This hotel has got old world charm! Lift operators, a very tiny cosy lobby, nice gym, friendly staff, a spa, the famous Cafe Carlyle and Bemelmans bar. Cosy and comfortable rooms. Located One block from Central Park on the corner of Madison and 76th on the upper east side. A very nice part of NYC!We love this place :)

This is by far the most elegant place to stay in New York. Sadly during our last stay each time we exited the elevator to walk to our room there was an unbearable smell. We notified reception who sent housekeeping to hoover the carpet. The smell worsened the next few days. Each day we would complain and more freshning scents would be applied to the carpet. We then spoke with the manager who was aware of the issue but didn’t clarify exactly what the problem was. It was was evident that work being carried out, but why would establishment like this, selling a high end room be satisfied allowing a guest to stay under these circumstances with the scent seeping into the hallway of the room.Room was great - but for this price a shower in addition to a bath would be expected.Staff at reception were not as polished as usual.Great members of the team were Concierge - Stephanie and Waldo - thank you, Restaurants Gogo was fantastic, Eduardo made breakfast special, and so did Mizanur thank you Elevator gents - Sal, Adolfo, Frank, thank you - Doormen were fabulous as always

The Carlyle is a beautiful and intergal part of New York's culture and holds many stories having hosted the most exhalted names in politics, the arts, wealth and influence. I have been coming to this hotel since I was a little girl and I have a lot of memories built around the Restaurant, Bemelman's Bar, and the hotel itself. As mentioned many times in the posts, it is the hotel that hosted President Kennedy, British Royalty and, on my most recent stay, Roger Federer.We live close by and needed a place to stay for a few nights while our floors were being refinished. We booked a lovely deluxe suite and we were very happy with the spacious accommodations. The front office allotted us a large suite with an entry, a large powder room, a living room with a Steinway grand piano (which I actually enjoyed playing...very softly), a large spacious bedroom and a small master bath. On a high floor, facing south, we enjoyed sunlight all day long. The gentleman who checked us in was quite nice and friendly but I was surprised he didn't show us up to our room.In my view, one doesn't go to the Carlyle for sleek, large spa bathrooms or the greatest and latest in technology. Indeed, even the decor is somewhat beside the point. It's as if a rich aunt had a pied a terre in Manhattan and decorated it once with very nice furniture but never saw the need to bring it up to Architectural Digest standards. I personally love the hardwood floors beneath the large area rugs and the not necessarily perfectly matched furniture. I actually enjoyed the bathroom which I'm sure is not what you will find in the Four Seasons...it is like an old, apartment style bath...ours was mirrored but it was just the basics but I found the tub very relaxing and the whole thing had an unselfconscious charm.My problem with the Carlyle stems from the fact that this hotel needs to offer the type of world class service that really makes some physical quirks absolutely unimportant. When I think Mr. Federer chose to stay at the Carlyle as did the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge it is clear the Carlyle is absolutely able to offer an unsurpassed level of service. I like to compare the Carlyle to Claridge's in London. Another very particular style of hotel (but inarguably much more lovely) which will never need automatic drapery controls to exude elegance at every turn. At the Carlyle, though, I definitely get the sense that the level of service a guest receives is based on variables that should not exist in a world class hotel. The service was fine. I have no complaints...but it's not special. At no point was I ever made to feel special or valued which is what the Carlyle needs to offer to every guest. That's how other hotels surpass the Carlyle nowadays...not in glitz but in treating every guest like a VIP. I find, generally, that the top hotels in the US do not go out of their way to spoil their guests like their European counterparts. The Carlyle has an elegance that is unmistakable (and it's located in the best part of NY, without question, and it was meant to appeal, in the old days, to what was referred to as "the carriage trade.") But guests like me don't get that really personalized service such as a bed made to a particular specification or even an additional bar of soap. The days of fruit plates or an evening amenity appear to,have disappeared entirely. The suite was large and very residential in feel. I was as comfortable as could be but I was not pampered. At all.Two other little things that I would like to mention: the elevator service really needs to improve. Don't get me wrong...I love the small elevators which are still operated by employees of the hotel. The problem is only two elevators out of four are running. This is a problem I had years ago. They are so slow and so small...and on top of that, sometimes the elevator operator leaves his post to help out elsewhere in the lobby. Other guests and I joked how they hotel should pass out a time table for the elevators...the wait can really cause one to be materially delayed. I am not exaggerating.Lastly, I was appalled by how far the hotel breakfast buffet has slipped over the years. For many years the Carlyle buffet breakfast was truly special. In fact, fifteen years ago you couldn't enter the dining room for breakfast unless dressed really properly. The buffet used to be a feast. The dining room is a gorgeous place. The breakfast has now been reduced to your basic chafing dishes with soggy hot food, some really nice fruit, yoghurts,a few healthy choices a bit of smoked salmon. If you closed your eyes you could be anywhere with chewy baguettes and truly pedestrian croissants. Just awful and much too awful for the Carlyle. . It is entirely self service...nobody will even carry your juice to the table or come around to pour water. It appears only guests ordering a la carte are entitled to any notice. A cold cup of cappuccino was plunked at my side. If this wasn't the Carlyle I suppose I would expect less but it is the Carlyle and all of us deserve to be greeted by name and we all deserve to be treated as special guests. No matter what, Bemelemens Bar is heaven. I will always go there for the best cocktails, specialty drinks and excellent food. I'm glad that's in my neighborhood.
user_name:
Alexandra M
New York City, New York

review_body: The Carlyle is perfect for me as I am a "Museum Person". The location of the Carlyle is perfect as there are at least five museums that ate an easy walk. I also enjoy the shops and small restaurants that are so close. The service is impeccable at the Carlyle Hotel.

Was in 1108 with views of the park. Very smooth check in. Very friendly staff throughout the hotel. Breakfast buffet is A+++++. Excellent phone service re wake up calls. Excellent room service.....the eggs Benedict with smoked salmon was very very good but would have been better if warmer. Didn't sleep well the first night due to a loud tv in an adjoining room ( next time I'll call the manager on duty) but the second night was pure bliss. Top tier bath products BUT they need to have a shoe shine sponge!! An ultra top tier men's tennis champion was staying here during my visit and obviously the privacy and security features of this hotel are appealing to any high profile person. I used to live in a high profile Park Avenue building and I almost felt like I was back in my coop. Highly recommend the Carlyle.

I stayed here on a business trip, and it was a quality place to stay. It felt like a boutique hotel, discreet but still a decent size with all the amenities you'd expect, and faultless service. The rooms are a little small but I guess that's to be expected in Manhattan. The location is great in that it's right next to Central Park, and right in the middle of Upper East Side surrounded by all the great little restaurants and bars.

The location is great, right in Central Park, it was my first time and I will stay there again for sure. This hotel has so much history that even today it feels like you're part of it. The bar is awesome and drinks are the best. Friendly staff

My husband, myself, our daughter and grandson flew to NY for an unexpected funeral. I found out about the funeral on a Tuesday and we had to be there Wednesday. Our daughter got the plane tickets and I took care of looking up hotels. I knew I wanted a good hotel near LaGuardia, and also a hotel that had airport transport. After much research I went ahead and called the Carlyle hotel. I had a computer screen in front of me with a quoted price in case I needed that information. I also knew I needed a crib for one room. The woman who answered the phone and then transferred me to reservations was very courteous and kind. The woman I spoke to in reservations was also very kind, patient and helpful. She matched the price I had onscreen, and also made certain everything I needed would be provided. She took all the airline information and had the Concierge arrange for the airport pickup, with an infant car seat in the vehicle. The hotel called me back with all the information I needed for the airport pickup, and confirmed a baby car seat. As we were landing at midnight knowing we had reliable arranged pickup was a great feeling. After we got to the hotel our check in was smooth, and we felt we were treated as important hotel guests. By this time it was close to 1:00 am, and so to be treated so nicely and helpfully truly felt good. Our rooms were very nice, the bed very comfortable, and the crib was already in our daughter's room along with a lovely little goodie bag for our grandson. This included a cute little teddy bear! We did have free wifi, but were far too tired to use it. Our wake up call the next morning was an actual person who was very nice and made it a personable call and not a robo kind of call. After enjoying the complimentary coffee in the lobby, we checked out, and again, all very smooth and personable. I have the utmost praise for the Front Desk staff at the Carlyle and the Concierge who arranged our airport pickup and called me with all the information I needed. We only needed the one night at the hotel, but I would certainly stay there again in an instant because of the high customer care we received.

The hotel is beautiful and well located but it's the employees that make it a truly great hotel. This hotel is a classic, comfortable and elegant place to stay while enjoying Manhattan. Bemelman's Bar is such fun at night with top notch entertainment. The restaurant one of the best on the Upper East Side and the service in any area of the hotel, excellent.

The Carlyle is an incredible hotel, with outstanding personality. The rooms are very comfortable and well appointed, with a mix of classic style and new technology.Where the hotel really shines is the service and ambiance. The staff is excellent - they get to know you quickly and remember your preferences flawlessly. Of particularly great note is room service - we had several late night meals, and they brought extra treats several times (as well as a wonderful sense of humour). My favorite hotel in New York.

Took my daughter to NY and chose to stay here for the weekend. We left after the first night to go to a better hotel. They should let people know that the hotel is under construction! The staff is great, but the facility is ailing. Excellent location but it isn't a five star hotel.

This is one of the great NYC pre-war hotels. It is NOT one of those antiseptic cookie box places you find downtown. It's quirky. It's shabby chic, in parts, yet always tirelessly elegant. Do visit Bemelmamz Bar while visiting.

Excellent!! Stayed during daughters surgery and recovery. Hotel staff went above and beyond to make us feel at home. Their concern snd empathy was appreciated and welcomed. Comfortable, quaint room with superior linens snd bedding. We had a superior suite and it was spacious but it felt like home,We will definitely be returning in the near future but for pleasurable visit.

This is a classic NYC hotel, rates are great and its a bit old but it just fits with the vibe. Rooms are pristine clean and the staff is always attentive. It is a great hotel for celebrity spotting. You won't regret it

The Carlyle is under construction so room location is important. We had one across from hallway construction which was ugly. The room we selected was a "Deluxe King" but what we got was a shabby small room. Carpet had threads coming out of it, furniture paint was chipped, underpad stuck out more than an inch from both carpets. Staff was nice but the experience was not like our previous experiences. Do not recommend, try the Surrey

One of the shabbiest, most dysfunctional and overrated hotels I have ever stayed in, anywhere in the world. From the moment of arrival (room not ready until 5pm!) to the ugly, mismatched and dated bedroom furniture, miniscule bathroom, violently noisy 1950s era air-conditioning, inedible in-room dining, bizarre policy of using only one of four elevators at any one time, every golden rule of the high-end hotel business is broken, repeatedly. This time-warp establishment is 25 years overdue a renovation and ought to be immediately closed and the entire staff removed and replaced.

New York hospitality is at its finest in this classic hotel where no one is asking you where you came from to log into a file but because they really remember you as a guest. The bar is a classic and the staff is kind and personable.

This hotel has a jazz club that we thought would be fun to check out - we walked in and it was packed, no seats and standing room only. We ordered a drink, sipped on it for 5 minutes and left. For that I was charged $317 - turns out there was a $150 per person cover charge that we were not advised of until it came time to pay. It seemed a little suspicious that they took my credit card the moment we walked in, and now I know why. I raised a dispute with the credit card company and gave the Carlyle every opportunity to make this right, even offering to give them a hundred dollars for the 2 drinks - but no, they wanted all the money and refused to give even a partial refund. So having tried to be reasonable I feel it necessary to warn other potential patrons that this place is little better than a clip joint. Avoid the Carlyle, it's the kind of place that used to give New York hotels a bad name.

We had reserved a junior suite for our 7 night visit to NYC from London. When we arrived and shown to our room, we discovered it had a view over an internal site which was a builder's dump site. We asked to change to another suite and had to wait quite a while before we were taken to one that was barely better. It was very shabby: the chest of drawers in the bedroom had two handles missing (see pic); the upholstery in the sitting room was dirty (see pic); and outside our door in the the passage was evidence of building works with temporary paneling and uncovered life bulb (see pic). Furthermore the kitchenette had no kettle, no crockery, no tea, coffee or milk. I called housekeeping and when we returned to our room we discovered that only a kettle had been delivered. When we called to complain we were told that housekeeping only provides the kettle and that if we want the rest we needed to call room service. The room also did not have an iron or ironing board which again we had to have delivered. The breakfast service was inattentive and poor and the only time we got attention was when it came to the tab. The buffet breakfast was expensive and as I ordered poached eggs instead of the scrambled eggs which was all the buffet had on offer, I was charged extra on top of the buffet cost. When the additional cost of 3 cuppacinos was included, the total for two with gratuity came to c. $120 - for a mediocre breakfast with poor service! When I left the breakfast reatuarant on morning, the waiter followed me into the lobby to say I had not included a gratuity. The reality was that I had added a percentage to the total for the gratuity but had not allocated the gratuity between the waiter and the maitre d'hotel - basically as I am not familiar with allocating between two catogories of gratuity, especially when there was no service whatsoever from the maitre d'hotel. When I pointed out the gratuity had been added to the total, the waiter turned off and walked away without apologising. Finally, when we checked out at the end of our stay, there was a woman in front of us complaining about the state of her room and the poor service she had experienced. I could not resist telling her of our similar experiences, to which the check-out woman at the front desk said she would report our dissatisfaction to the hotel manager who would contact us directly. Needless to say, we never heard a word from the manager or anyone else from the Carlyle. In summary, this is the worst 5 star hotel experience we have ever experienced and frankly the Carlyle does not warrant a 5 star rating. Never again!

ok, this review may be all over the map, but there's a reason. First off, checked in early in the day so took a room that was available...it was not a renovated room, tiny, old and tired. So, they moved us...to a renovated room, higher floor new furniture, updated bathroom.HOWEVER this room had NO hot water...I have no idea how a hotel room can have no hot water, but true story. So, you're wondering about the "excellent" rating, well here it is. Another call to the front desk yielded us what they call a "tower room"...BAM there it is; totally renovated, nice furnishing, excellent (although small) bathroom...VIEWS FOR DAYS!!!! The rating goes for the last room, but really more for the staff and service...100% attentive and willing to do whatever they can to make your stay enjoyable. LOVED IT...it took a beat or two, but loved it.

The Carlyle, Rosewood Hotel did not disappoint! Keep in mind this is a landmark New York experience; therefore the property is older, yet magnificent. And, oh the history inside this Manhattan landmark! Stunning views of Central Park, and the historic guest list (and photos on the wall) is impressive, ( EVERY American president since Truman, the royal family including Diana, Princess of Wales.) The Carlyle completely embodies grace and distinction. No matter what, do not miss the opportunity to visit Bemelman's Bar. Ludwig Bemelman was the creator of the classic Madeline children's books. The Madeline murals cover the walls and the ceiling is 24-karat gold leaf! The murals are the only collection of Bemelman's work that is open to the public. The elevators are operated by stately "elevator men". Only two to three people at a time fit and the elevator man operates the elevator. Our room was quite large and elegant. Afternoon tea is served in the gallery and is a memorable experience. (Watch for celebrities in the lobby and bar!). Hotel is well located in the heart of Manhattan at 76th and Madison Ave. One of Rosewood Property's great hotels.
user_name:
Lynn S
Marshall, Texas, United States

review_body: My recent visit to New York’s Carlyle Hotel was somewhat disappointing. From the moment I entered the lobby, I could tell that the physical plant was in need of a major refurbishment. That said, the reception personnel were pleasant and efficient.My room, a one-bedroom suite, was large and generally comfortable, but it could have been cleaner. I found desiccated food debris (cauliflower, I believe) on the living room’s carpet. It had obviously been there for some time and was not removed during my stay (four days). Furthermore, the suite’s wood floors squeaked, as did the floors in the room above mine. The squeak from the room above kept me awake until my “neighbor” finally went to bed (around 2:00 a.m.). The suite’s furniture and decor were quite dated and worn. The living room’s sofa covering was torn and the wood floor needed refinishing. The bathroom was so small I could have used the shower, toilette and sink at the same time – seriously.There were four elevators just of the lobby, half of which were out of order. At times, this situation caused lines to form.In general, hotel services on Sunday were poor. I had to chase after housekeeping to have my room made up and meal service in the Gallery was indifferent, to put it mildly.The Carlyle is not up to the standards set at other Rosewood Hotels.

Fire tower stairs cluttered with room service trays, plates etc on steps, only used stairs because of the inadequate elevator service. 4 times resorted to the fire code violation stairs. Breakfast service lacked professional attention.

We just returned from a three night stay at the Carlyle and it was a disaster. Our room was the tiniest we have stayed in, in comparison to the St. Regis and Plaza Athenee etc. Shabby chic would be an improvement over this place, chipped furniture, tiny closet, pitiful toiletries, and windows so filthy you could hardly see out, but the service was the main complaint! So inconsistent with turndown one night but not the next. I recently had knee surgery and needed to ice it. EVERY day it was a battle to get ice, three calls and forty five minutes later it arrived. Same scenario every day even after a chat with the manager. The hotel has elevator "operators" that were totally unnecessary and some times we waited ten or more minutes to get a ride down. We took the stairs once and they were cluttered with dishes and other things that would have been a complete fire hazard had there been one. The Hampton Inn would have been an improvement. NY prices but NOT an Upper Eastside five star property. Rosewood should be embarrassed.

Incredible hotel. You cannot go wrong with a stay here. The service is impeccable. This hotel makes you feel special. Our breakfast, which was included in our rate, was really good - choices for all types of dietary needs/restrictions. Check in was a breeze, the elevator operator friendly, someone to assist at every turn. Looking forward to our next visit.

First time staying at the Carlyle. The service and staff at the hotel were excellent We had a deluxe suite which which was rather dated with old furniture and somewhat dark and dingy. There were crumbs and candy under the couch cushion and someone left what appeared to be an pair of shorts outside on the patio. Would probably not come back to this hotel with so many other options available in New York.

I stayed at the Carlyle for 4 days and it was a great experience. The service was excellent. The staff was responsive to all of my questions and needs. We needed a table and place settings for a party in our suite and they brought it up right away. The elevators are tiny. We really enjoyed the Carlyle lounge featuring Antonia Bennett. The room was spacious and the linen was soft. I really appreciated the water pressure of the shower and the Kiehl's toiletries. The location is great. It is very close to a subway, Lexington Ave, and East 77th Street. It is only a couple of streets from Central Park.

The Hotel Carlyle is mere blocks from Central Park and the Metropolitan Museum. The Met Breuer is practically next door. Surrounding all that are the glorious shops, galleries, and restaurants on Madison Avenue, a people-watching pleasure dome to boot.The service at the Hotel Carlyle is outstanding. While some of the rooms may be a bit spare in the charming decor department, the staff makes up for it. From the bell and elevator service, to room service to the bar, people remember who you are, what you like, and discreetly go above making your stay as pleasurable as possible. They are also very kind and patient with young children. Kiehls products aplenty stock the mirrored and chrome bathrooms.

A wonderful stay at the suite with a grand Steinway piano! The service was exquisite, especially the middle-aged elevator man. The restaurant had a beautiful decor and the breakfast buffet was very nice indeed.

The staff of the hotel could not have been more gracious during our recent visit. Our room, however, was tired and badly in need of refurbishment. The parquet floor near the front door was chipped and squeaky. Closet doors didn't close properly. The upholstered furniture had a musty smell. Hot water took a very long time to reach the shower, and the hallway had loose wires from ongoing renovation. Those issues were largely cosmetic. The bathroom was lovely--but the marble floor was very slick and the throw rug had no backing. That made it extremely slippery and very dangerous. Even with great care, it was hard not to slide across the floor with every step. We finally decided that the only safe thing to do was to pick up the rug and the bath mat. This is a serious accident waiting to happen. The bathroom urgently needs a non-slip rug.The hotel is charming and the staff was wonderful. But the room was extremely disappointing for a hotel of this price and character. The hotel is a gracious lady, but our room was very tired.

We stayed here during our time in NYC. Loved the vintage-luxury style around every single detail in the hotel.Our 180 degrees view from the 31st floor was insane, overlooking the city and the park.I was impressed with the bathroom decoration. All cover up with mirrors and of course the staff made their part with their sincere service and warm touch.
user_name:
theglimmertwin
San Jose del Cabo, Mexico

review_body: Nice friendly hotel with great entertainment, perfect location and great for singles, loved the piano bar.As a single woman I totally enjoyed my stay one does not need to go running around NY for entertainment a great bar.

My wife booked this hotel where she stays regularly. I expected the hotel would give her a large room, but we were given a standard room with a small bathroom and poor view over a rooftop undergoing construction. They did give us fruits and nibbles and service was good, but the room itself could be better. Also housekeeping can be improved - they should not be inconsistent when closing the curtains and blinds during turning down service - some nights they don't close the blinds, and some night they close some but not all, so I ended up having to check every night myself.

Agree with other reviewers that the service and food are excellent but the place is due for a remodel. Still, the Carlyle is well worth a visit. Stayed there in March with my wife and two young kids. The chief advantage? A two bedroom suite with a twin bed for each child, a kitchenette, and two and a half bathrooms! Not to mention the fascinating Cutler Mail chute, a relic of bygone days which completely fascinated the kids. They immediately bought postcards and mailed them to Grampa via this mail chute- one child waited in the lobby while the other dropped the postcard from several stories up.They have a private car service, which is nice if you need it. Great location near the Metropolitan Museum of Art and Central Park. The elevator operators (another odd anachronism) put me off at first, but they were very pleasant and professional and gave me a sense of added hotel security. A couple minor things: I was not pleased that the turn down service did not clean up the crumbs from all the nice cookies they gave us. They also tried to charge another family member for a room I had specifically asked to pay for.In sum, however, warts and all, it is a charming place, and I would stay again.

Not normally staying on upper east but did so for a company offsite...This is absolutely a New York classic...from woody allen playing clarinet on 2nd tuesday of hte month to excellent service to upper east side "locals" in the bar..Excellent food and drink and service......a very personal experience. Only downside: Two functioning elevators can mean long waits....and renovations aren't complete. I had a fantastic, but un-renovated suite, which well.... just very 1980's or older with a wiff of old carpet to it...this wouldn't put me off from staying again...but just ask for a renovated room,,

Love the Rosewwod brand, however this property is not up to the standard.The hotel has so much history, unfortunately it shows everywhere. Some of age shows in furniture and fixtures but too much of it is it structure; bathrooms, elevators, hallways, etc. Time to close and remodel.

It's seen better days and needs to be updated, but they're trying. We ordered room service often. Expensive. Sometimes it's probably better to pop out and pick up food in the neighborhood. The staff is lovely though and everyone is very helpful. Strangest shower situation. There must have been shower curtains, updated now to a glass enclosed shower. But one enters through the glass door and you can only turn on the faucet while standing under the shower head. If you get the initial temperature wrong, there's no place to hide.

I stayed for 6 nights at this fabulous hotel and would not talk highly enough about this place.Situated just off 5th Avenue it is close to most venues and only a block away from Central Park. The staff are always polite and friendly and address you by name . The food is amazing but the highlight for me was the Bar. Lots of Gold leaf on the surrounds and hand painted walls make this an extremely enjoyable experience.The concierge is there to help you make bookings for shows plays, restaurants etc. They also recommend certain places to go as well.I would highly recommend this hotel.

We had a negative experience on a previous stay and gave pointed feedback. This stay was perfect (and NOT because we alerted the manager in advance as he had requested). We were upgraded to a suite (thanks to American Express Platinum program) and had a pleasant/uneventful stay.

My husband and I live in New York and did a "staycation" at The Carlyle last weekend for one night. We booked thru Amex/Leading Hotels so were hopeful for an upgrade. Another perk of the program is potential early check-in, if available. We checked in around 2:30pm and were told our room was not ready but we could be upgraded to a suite after it had been cleaned. The front desk said they would call us to let us know when our room was ready. At 4:30p we still had not heard from the hotel so we went back and found out our room had been ready for about an hour. We tried to not be annoyed since they had upgraded us so we didn't complain and headed to our suite. Our suite, while quite large (full living room, full bedroom, 1.5 baths) looked like it had been last renovated in about 1988. The room was sparsely decorated which wouldn't have bothered me except for it was also incredibly worn. Furniture all chipped, painting had a hole in it, baseboards in need of painting. Our bathroom light switch had dried caulk running out of it. It was nice to have a large room but our suite needed some serious help. I could also hear every foot step of the person in the room above me. Another construction note - there are 4 tiny elevators and 2 of them were under construction during our stay. We had to wait for about 5 loads of people to go up before we could get to our room on Saturday night. I also had some problems with service. In addition to no one letting us know our room was ready, I tried calling the spa a couple of times and no one answered. We had to try the front desk and then they told us someone from the spa would call us back. Is that a huge deal? Not really, but combined with the state of our room, the elevator situation, the lack of letting us know our room was ready, it was just all a bit too much for the price of the room. I tried really hard to love The Carlyle but I just found it disappointing after hearing so many lovely things about it. The place needs an overhaul.I will note that Bemelman's Bar is a wonderful, neat place - my husband and I loved it! Great jazz and great atmosphere.

This is a hotel trading on past history. The standard and quality of furnishing in the room was poor and for a 5 star establishment......not nearly good enough. I did not have a single piece of furniture in the room that was not nicked, scratched or broken in some form and the bathroom needed an urgent and complete overhaul - from the leaking shower door; phone socket hanging off the wall, missing or broken tiles, dirty grouting and mould on the shower.....I could go on. The staff are great, the breakfast was superb, the atmosphere in the public areas is one of celebration - like a grand city hotel should be - but come on - sort yourselves out - and run more than 2 lifts when its busy!!

I went to NY for surgery & my Dr recommended the Carlyle since it was close to his office. My stay was exceptional and the hotel and staff could not have done anything else to make me feel more comfortable or welcome. Thank you to the Carlyle & your amazing staff!!!

Since 2010, this has been our go-to hotel when we come to NYC. We continually to choose the Carlyle because of it's staff and location. Having said that, my only consistent complaint has been that the front desk staff, one of your first impressions when you enter the hotel, can be very aloof and cold. I never receive a smile, 'welcome back', complimentary room upgrade, etc...As of July 2017, I will have stayed at this hotel four times in one year. While not a lot, a chain like the Peninsula notes and acknowledges a return guest with a smile, an upgrade, a note and usually something sent to the room. After our visit in April, the front desk manager reached out to me via email regarding a room issue. I took that opportunity to discuss my front desk observations, and the response was nothing but immediate, professional, gracious and appreciative. Lorena O., the Assistant Front Desk Manager, was thoughtful and thorough with her response. That's the Carlyle. That's why I will always return.From the moment you are greeted at the front door, as you pass Waldo and Stephanie at the Concierge Desk (and the other two wonderful gentlemen whose names I am blanking on), say hello to the attendants in the lobby and pop into the elevator, you are transformed into a completely different world. The Carlyle is quiet, discreet, and professional. The room service and room attendants are warm, efficient, and go above and beyond their duties to assist you. In February, my young daughter was ill and in the middle of the night someone was immediately in the room assisting us. In April, Jose, a room attendant, brought something to the room that he had also dropped off during July visit. These people are the face of this hotel.Waldo Hernandez, head Concierge, is the Carlyle. He has the best recommendations from services to restaurants. He has helped us obtain the most difficult of reservations and has been patient when our plans have changed last minute. Everyone on his staff is warm, funny and honest and helpful. They do not recommend restaurants because they have a special relationship with management and they are aways the first to inquire about a location that may be new to them. The room service and restaurants are beyond excellent and Bemelman's cozy and intimate (although it can get very crowded during the holidays). The recently renovated hotel rooms are spacious and elegant and always have one or two large closets. The bathrooms are on the smaller side (it's an older hotel) but include everything you need from bathrobes, to products, to an abundance of towels. Side note, the shower caps are the best in the world. If you get a room with a small kitchenette it can be very useful if traveling with teenagers or younger children...If you are looking for the latest, flashiest and/or most modern property in NYC, this is not where you want to stay. You stay at the Carlyle because of the staff and the location. When you walk through the front door at the Carlyle, it's like coming home to your own apartment in New York and seeing your family

Got it, old, famous hotel which is going through renovation/rebranding and whatever else you want to call it but I do not understand how service can be so bad from the front desk to room service. Rude! The only good spot is the restaurant at least service wise. I think this place needs new leadership team!

We stayed 3 nights at The Carlyle which was one of my favorite experiences in the world. Everyone is friendly and helpful. Our room was perfect as it overlooked the city on three sides with ample space, a little kitchenette and a little walk-in closet The first night, we visited the bar where Andy our bartender kept us hydrated throughout the evening. The beautiful concierge, Stephanie was so knowledgeable, professional and very personable. We ate at the breakfast buffet one morning and were served by Norbert, who was the ultimate in service! Never once did we feel out of our league, especially since this place is probably two stars above where we usually stay, because everyone made us feel welcomed. If you want to treat yourself to a weekend in NYC, I highly recommend staying at The Carlyle!

I stayed here in March for business, I love the Hotel, it is an iconic one and I love the surroundings. The service level in the last year has incredibly increased and I look forward to going back soon.

Because we were celebrating a special occasion, we were given an upgrade when we arrived. Our room was on the 8th floor and was very large, overlooking Madison Ave. The spacious room and bath were well appointed with high end Kiehl toiletries and lots of fluffy towels. It was cleaned several times a day as we never found it messy when we returned and wet towels were always removed quickly. Turn down service is nice with little slippers and a robe. The staff at the hotel was unfailingly polite, cheerful and friendly and we felt quite pampered. The location is perfect if you plan to visit museums as we did and we enjoyed walking through Central Park on the way to the Met. There's also great shopping nearby on Madison and Fifth Ave.If you go, do book an evening in the Cafe Carlyle for dinner and jazz! Yes, it's quite expensive but for once in a lifetime splurge you can't beat it. drinks are great as is the food. And the jazz performers change frequently so check the website or the New Yorker for details. We could not have been happier and will definitely return.

We could write a lovely story on the excellence and dignified service and luxury at the Carlyle Hotel because of the many facets of doing it right all the way, right away, the first time. First impressions and last impressions were consistent. The room upgrade to a suite was larger than the apartment we owned in nyc. Lovely! Heated bathroom floors were a nice, subtle luxury. (Note: iron and board aren't located in the rooms. Must call front desk.)We are planning to return with our children as the hotel is accommodating and courteous of families, as we noted in other visiting families. Bemelmans Bar--a must. The gallery is nice for a meal. The restaurant--we enjoyed the breakfast buffet each morning. Beautiful dining room with a quality variety for most any palette. Nice touches, too, like fresh pressed juices and smoothie shots. Again, there are so many nice attributes of the Carlyle Hotel. We were a younger couple (late 30s/early 40s) and were treated as well as the more distinguished ones. The best part of our stay was the staff. In Rosewood's signature style, the staff was courteous, very friendly and exceptionally accommodating. The staff is our most memorable part of our stay--from the front desk to the bellmen, elevator operators, captain and waiters, and the wonderful housekeepers.

I recently was fortunate enough to have lunch in the restaurant at The Carlyle Hotel. It was simply superb from start to finish. A wonderful room with atmosphere but where you can also hear your friends talk. The food was wonderful with the flourless chocolate cake from the dessert trolley a highlight for me. It was exactly the sort of flawless service and elegant lunch that I would have expected from The Carlyle and would absolutely recommend it to others. The Carlyle as a whole is just elegant and oozes old fashioned class and effortless style.

we have been to a few rosewood hotels but this was the first time at carlyle in nyc. we got our room upgraded to a nice suite very comfortable and with plenty of space (no nice view though). the service in general was great apart from a few hickcups : we waited for a long time the luggage at the arrival and the bathrobes were never available (we needed to ask for this a couple of times). these are minor details though. doormen, concierge and front desk did a gret job. this is classic school i.e. they always remember your name and always smile, the hotel has an intriguing bar inside where sometimes big names play live jazz music. the atmosphere is of the city you see in some old beautiful black and white movies. something from the thirties. the rooms are classic style and nothing is missing (our bathroom though was small compared to the size of the room). the location is a plus. away from the tourists herds which you can find few blocks away and at the same time close to the park and to the museum district. plenty of nice bars and restaurants around even with table outside during nice season. room dining is ok and the so is the breakfast. when you are back to the hotel from a hectic day out in the city you feel like in an oasis of calmness where the time has beer frozen.

How do I do this review? There are so many small things I could complain about if I was to compare the Carlyle with an uber modern hotel. But I'm not going to complain as it's old school shabby chic feel is what makes me and my wife LOVE it!Sure it needs a bit of paint and the plumbing isn't perfect, but it feels like home and reminds me of my Club in London. We had a 2 room rear facing suite. Good size. Comfortable bed. Great staff, lovely room service, good jazz in the bar, brilliant concierge, great location. Small but adequate gym.Only 2 elevators are working but I believe that is because of remodelling. The Easter bunny was there handing out eggs We stayed 6 nights and since we will be going fairly often to New York, I can report that I don't want to stay anywhere else!I love four seasons etc too but they just don't have the charm of this place!

How can I describe staying at the Carlyle? Its like staying at the home of an eccentric, rich elderly aunt who happens to own a property in NYC. The hotel is comfortable in an old school way.
