It reminds me of Baur au Lac in Zurich. It could certainly do with a refresh. We were lucky enough to stay in enormous suite which was amazing but really could do with a lick of paint! To be fair on the hotel they seem very busy in doing up parts of the hotel so I imagine it will be done in next few months.The main thing that stands out is the staff. Professional, friendly and helpful. They truly made our stay. From now on I am staying here when I am in NYC. Sorry Peninsula!

If you are looking for a very, very special weekend getaway, The Caryle is the most perfect place in New York City. My wife and I stay there as often as we can and everything and I mean everything is absolutely perfectly done. The front desk service is beyond 100%; the dining room ambiance and very creative and delicious food is my best kept secret and of course, Bemelmen's Bar is the perfect early and late night jazz spot.

We walked into the Carlyle hoping to have a drink and a bite at the famous Bemelmans Bar, but it was closed so we decided to try the main restaurant. We were seated side by side at a banquette along the wall, which is always nice because both people can see the room. It was especially good because the room is gorgeous and there was a huge floral arrangement in the center that was stunningly beautiful. My girlfriend had the white asparagus Vichyssoise with herb cream and I had the Lobster Bisque. Both were outstanding. Note: I saved the special White Asparagus menu, which is how I know the details of her dish. The service was professional. It was one of the most enjoyable lunches I've ever had and I look forward to a return visit.

Booked for a special anniversary and had a marvellous time in one of NYC's finest hotels. Excellent dinner in the hotel restaurant. First class experience. Shame that the Bar has such a high cover charge as it would have been nice to sit there in an evening for a relaxing drink bit otherwise we thoroughly recommend this hotel for a special stay.

The Carlyle has long been my favorite New York City hotel and our recent visit was probably the best ever. From the moment you enter the lobby you can sense the elegance and refinement of the establishment. The staff could not be more helpful or gracious. An air of generosity seems to permeate the hotel. Our room was large and comfortable with everything in working order. The toiletries were extensive and of the highest quality. The Wifi and cable were both excellent. There was virtually no street noise although our room overlooked Madison Avenue. The breakfast buffet had outstanding fresh fruit, orange juice to “die for” and the best blueberry muffins I’ve had in decades. We had dinner one evening in the Gallery; the food was excellent and the service both professional and warm. We also visited Bemelmans Bar, a charming room which recalls a time which seems to no longer exist. I can’t recommend the Carlyle enough.

The room was quite small, well appointed with nice furniture, linens, etc. Adjustments to heat and A/C worked poorly, when they worked at all. Room facing Madison Avenue was very quiet - impressive!Elevators slow(one was not working), though one has an attendant, which seems unnecessary. Great location near Central Park, subway, top Madison Avenue stores. Also fine restaurant (expensive) and famous Bemelman's Bar. We got a 3 nights for 2 price, but, for me, without that it's a bit over priced.

I travel to NYC monthly for work and pleasure and usually stay in Soho or Gramercy Park. On this visit, we were a group of 8 women celebrating a friend's special birthday and booked the Carlyle. I was very impressed! Our concierge Waldo was a big part of making our weekend in NYC such a success!! Waldo booked fabulous restaurants for us including Dirty French and Avra. Waldo also arranged for our group to go to Soul Cycle Saturday morning...not an easy feat for such a popular time and class! We had an amazing time, from the sumptuous buffet breakfasts, excellent service, elegant bedrooms and Bemelmans Bar, especially singing along with the David Budway Trio on Saturday night. I will most definitely return!

Great staff, lovely rooms, marvelous spirit. Still the best hotel in town!The restaurant is better than ever. It's a real treat to dine there.I have been staying here for fifty years and there has been small changes and improvements but no diminishment of basic quality.

From beginning to end, the Carlyle came up short. Told we had an early check-in, we waited 3 hours on arrival. The hotel was under renovation, which was not disclosed. The room finally available, there was paper still on floors from fresh painting and turpentine smells. The hotel changed the room with a weak apology and a room with paper thin walls where we could hear every conversation in the halls. 2 elevators weren't working. We couldn't get into the bar 2 of 3 nights due to overcrowding. When we did, we were charged $15 person cover, even as hotel guests. My wife scheduled a spa with facial and makeup. After the spa, she was told "sorry", makeup had left for the day. This is the last time we will stay here. There are so many better experiences in New York at these high prices.

Spent 5 nights here and left feeling pampered. From the amazing concierge to the white gloved elevator attendants ( especially Gustavo) the staff are warm and friendly. Close to the Met, Central Park and subway on 77 & Lexington. Our room was small but quaint and loved the jet tub, strong water pressure and the lovely Kiehl's room amenities. Lots of New Yorkers live in the hotel so it adds a residential touch and is dog friendly. You might just see a celebrity or two. Didn't have time to check out the lovely restaurant but will when I return. Thank you for a great stay!

Excellent service and facilities. Booked through Amex Fine Hotels and Resorts and we were upgraded top a suite with a second half bath. Included breakfast buffet was terrific. Dinner at hotel was great, although expensive. Enjoyed show in Cafe Carlyle and a drink in Bemelmans Bar..

From the minute we walked into the lobby we were greeted by everyone. We had made reservations with the restaurant and were running a little late. They were not upset at all and told us to go eat while they check us in. The restaurant was beautifully decorated and everything spotless. we had two steaks and mashed potatoes' that was worth every penny. We had wonderful cocktails and were then treated to a tour of the beautiful hotel from our wonderful server. We were then taken to our room that was incredible it was spotless and comfortable and spacious. The fresh fruit and water give it a perfect touch. We received a hand written letter thanking us for staying in the hotel. The morning after breakfast was included with our stay and again the buffet was delicious. It had great selection and with everything being fresh. All in all this is truly one of the best places that I have stayed at with the service being exemplary. We cant wait to have another show to watch just to be able to stay here again. We thank everyone so much again for making us feel so at home and welcome!!!!

My family of four had a lovely time at The Carlyle and can't wait to go back. Searching for an affordable two-bedroom suite in Manhattan that would accommodate our family had been difficult, so I was overjoyed to discover that the Carlyle had just what we needed. The lobby is lovely and the check-in was as easy as could be. The black and white pictures of the Beatles and Jackie Kennedy added that fun touch of history, reminding you of how many fascinating people have stayed at the Carlyle.The elevators are small, but the friendly elevator men were always a pleasure to chat with. Our suite was perfect for a family of four -- one bedroom with two twin beds and another with a king. The kitchenette was nice, although we didn't use it, but did appreciate having the half guest bath at the front of the room. The living area was spacious.The beds were comfy, and I was especially fond of the pillows. I meant to find out what kind they were, dammit. And whoa, prior to our arrival, we had made reservations at The Carlyle Cafe to see Woody Allen and the Eddy Davis New Orleans Jazz Band. What a fun experience in such an iconic setting! And when it was over, to just go right upstairs to our room? A perfect New York experience to be sure. The breakfast buffet was delightful, but you can also order off the menu. And the location? Shopping galore. It's also within walking distance of NYC's Museum Mile. Overall, next time I'm in town, I'll want to stay at The Carlyle.

An enjoyable hotel close to almost everything you would want to see in New York. You'll be pleased with the ambiance at the bar where we enjoyed very much a beautiful lady singing for us. Definitely, a place to try !

Great location. Hotel rooms feels as they have not been much updated since I stayed here frequently in the 1980s. First room change after 1 night. Loud "drilling" sound, ca. 5mins, woke me up 2am, sound came back every 1/2 hour or so. Next day - changed room. Got room 608 for 2 nights. 2nd night got severely bedbug bitten on right hand and arm, saw it on the way to the airport. Informed the hotel via email. 10 days later; the hotel have not bother to reply! Does this mean they don't care?? Bemelmans bar still very nice.

This is the best hotel and location in NYC, This is your home away from home.Check out the fabulous Bemelmans Bar for the excellent entertainment. Fabulous service, food, and rooms. Do spend time in the Spa too.

We stayed at the Carlyle Hotel while on our trip to NYC for the United Airlines half marathon. My husband and I both ran the marathon and we wanted to stay at a location with easy access to the start line. This hotel was just perfect. The subway station was just a 2 block walk and there were endless eateries within walking distance. The service and concierge were both super helpful and accommodating. The rooms are older but lack nothing! They offer Kiehls body and hair care products which was a huge plus to our experience! Loved the elevator attendant as well!! Will definitely stay here in our next trip to NYC!! Below is a view from our room looking over Madison ave.

Wonderful stay - great service in all areas, helpful and pleasant staff. Very nice suite, delicious breakfast buffet, lovely service. Enjoyed The Cafe Carlyle and the Bar. We are looking forward to stay at this hotel at our next trip to NYC.

The Carlyle Hotel and staff are the Best of the Best. My husband and I always stay there when visiting New York City. The food and service are also tops. Beautifully decorated and perfectly located, we highly recommend this wonderful hotel.

My room was beautiful. Unfortunately one had to step up to use bathroom so I kept light on in bathroom all night so I would not forget to step up. Extremely clean. Teeny bathrooms. The front desk seemed to be helter skelter. Not very professional. The dinning room has in my view an A+++++++++ rating. Superb in every way. Sadly the they use a limousine service, Empire in which the driver refused to turn off his radio and he gave me a roundabout tour of Manhattan. I lived in New York for many years so I know his route was totally incorrect and it took me 15 minutes longer than it should have to get to Penn Station.

It is too bad that the Carlyle has replaced the gleaming silverplate flatware and holloware for stainless steel. Hotels that take shortcuts should not be classified as five stars. To the very end the Waldorf Astoria employed stewards to polish silver flatware and holloware which is the mark of a true luxury hotel. The Algonquin Hotel also has beautiful silverplate flatware and holloware.

I recently had my first stay at the Carlyle and it was delightful. I found the public areas to be wonderful. The Bemelman's bar was wonderful. The buffet breakfast, included in our room rate was very good. I would add that this is an old hotel and some updates would be helpful. Overall a good pick on the upper east side.
user_name:
Don P
Indianapolis, Indiana, United States

review_body: The Carlyle is an amazing property with excellent service The rooms are wonderful and are all unique and always clean. The staff and the service they provide are without parallel. Despite the hotel's legendary history of hosting many celebrities and royalty, every guest is given a warm, genuine welcome and treated like a valued client.

This was my first visit, and will not be my last. In fact, it is now my number one choice for where to stay in NYC. The staff was very friendly and accommodating and the room exceptional. I had the glassed in balcony, which I loved, and the bathroom with heated floor, great water pressure, and perfect linens. I slept better in your bed than my own, and hated to leave. Bemelman's Bar was a great place to hang out, and the breakfast in the restaurant was outstanding.

First, you need to set your expectations to match the ambiance of the 1950s and '60s. It's old school JFK - think elevator operators wearing uniforms - with the right amount of modern amenities to not kill the charm. I felt like I was walking into the white glove era of the 1950s. The staff is terrific, bath products out of East Village (Kiehl's) are an unexpected luxury and the location can not be beat. The bathroom was small (it's New York) but that's a small price to pay. Worth exploring the history of the hotel before you visit.

The hotel is simply amazing and located near all the shops on Madison avenue and steps away from central park. The vibe, the history, and the location makes this a 5 star property. The rooms are a little dated but we didn't run into any major problems. The hotel bar is always lively and fun too. What makes this hotel truly special are the people that work in it. We've stayed in many nice hotels throughout the world - but something about the carlyle makes us feel like we are going home. The staff at the hotel is what makes this hotel so so good; Katherine at reception was warm and lovely and always made us feel happy. Margaret at Reservations was quick and efficient. The doormen was always eager to help. This hotel is a well run property. We look forward to returning back to our favourite hotel.

Absolutely wonderful as usual the staff is 100% attentive to every detail the rooms are comfortable strong showers great linens excellent room service very good management the location is perfect and the amenities are quite nice.

Definitely, the BEST place I've stayed. All of the staff was amazing. And the Café Carlyle is a MUST! Everyone there was so kind! I'm looking forward to my next visit, because they became friends. I really felt blessed not only to stay in such a beautiful property, but get to meet everyone at the Carlyle!

Stayed just one night for business. Was a late arrival, and arrived to discover they upgraded me for free to a lovely suite. The room and furnishings are showing age and wear, but the suite was very comfortable and well-appointed. This hotel is a grand old dame, and the staff provides impeccable service.

More home than hotel. First class in every way!Keeps pace with it's storied history and iconic guest list from JFK, Jackie O, Princess Di, Kate Middleton. Great lounge and terrific jazz entertainment. One of a kind Hotel!

Our hotel concierge recommended the Carlyle for low key jazz/blues while eating at the bar and restaurant. It was perfect. The food was very good, the service excellent and the music was great. We will be back!

My friend and I stayed at the beautiful Carlyle this first weekend of February. What a hotel. There is history in the walls, and Rosewood have managed to conserve the Carlyle tradition and warmth. Filled with a unique atmosphere and genuine service the hotel really made our stay memorable. Having tried other hotels in NY, there really is something unique about this one. On Friday we saw Isaac Mizrahi at the Carlyle café. The show was great and the room, sourrounded by beautiful wallpaintings, contributed in making it an intimate and wonderful evening. If you're looking for a authentic and memorable stay, I highly recommend this iconic New York hotel.

The Carlyle makes every effort to make me feel like a fond visitor. the location is perfect for me as I enjoy museums and one can walk to about five. Also the shopping is very nice with many lovely stores nearby.

Wonderful place! Loved the entertainment! Bring your wallet! The piano players were fabulous and the crowd was an international mix of cool and elegant people. They keep the lights dim which makes for a very sexy atmosphere. I'll go again the next time I'm in town.

I shall be very happy if I sall stay there for another time. My thanks to all persons, to all the stuff.They are very kind. The weather outside was very but! A day we had snow out, but inside the atmosphere.
user_name:
Lenis A
New York City, New York

review_body: I hosted a large family group at the Carlyle in a 2 room suite to celebrate a birthday. It could not have been better. The service was wonderful. The concierge helped me order flowers, balloons and a variety of other items which were all in the room when we arrived. In addition the hotel sent a complementary cake and fruit, both of which were much appreciated by my hungry guests. The Carlyle is well-located, only a block from Central Park and along Madison Avenue in the midst of great shopping. It is also an easy trip to Fifth Avenue, and many of the museums on the upper east side including the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Met Breuer, the Guggenheim and many others. Plus, the neighborhood is quiet at night so you are not disturbed by rowdy tourists.My only caution is that it is an old-fashioned hotel. The rooms are beautiful, but traditional. You will not find the modern aesthetic common in many upscale hotels. That was perfect for us, but it may not be to others' taste.I highly recommend the Carlyle.
user_name:
AmyTRS
New York City, New York

review_body: Outstanding legacy hotel but now requires update. I lived in New York for twenty years and the Carlyle was my favorite location for world class Cafe and lobby bar. During my January stay in the 33rd hotel tower room was small and dated --although with a great view North over Central Park. Hotel dining room service was excellent but expensive ( $100 breakfast for one ). The property needs to match accommodations level with other upper east side hotels such as the LOWELL. BG

The hotel, the location and the service is outstanding. The understated elegance and the sincerity of the service is unlike anything I've ever experienced. The hotel's Bemelmans Bar is famous, but I recommend enjoying your drinks in the Gallery outside of the bar. Introverts, like myself, can enjoy the music without the crowds. The Carlyle makes you feel like you are visiting someone's home rather than a sterile hotel. My massage was phenomenal, and our room was so warm and welcoming. We will be back.

First off, I love the Carlyle. I have loved it since I first stayed there over twelve years ago. They have been a top notch hotel since the Hoover administration and the ghosts that walk the halls and hang on the walls as photos are some of the greats of the 20th century- as an example, when I checked in this last time, one of the front desk clerks was on the phone talking about the "Jackie Kennedy Suite". Which is cute, until you realize, no, that was actually the suite Jackie Kennedy would stay in at the hotel.The staff is unfailingly courteous and professional, the rooms spotless, the beds insanely comfortable and it generally takes to the count of five to get hot water in the shower with brilliant water pressure. The food, while not exactly cutting edge, is delicious and the cabaret world class. But it does cater to an older, well-heeled crowd, so if you are looking for downtown excitement, this is not the place to stay. So, why not five stars? Because, as has been noted by others, the Carlyle needs some upgrading. It just seems a little...tired in some places and shabbily genteel in others. I just kept asking myself, don't the Rosewood people want to put money into this world class property to make it look as good as the people who work there make it run? The bones of the Carlyle are still brilliant, but it could do with some discreet cosmetic surgery.
user_name:
Chris G
Portland, Oregon, United States

review_body: Fantastic service and dining are to be had and if you ever want a romantic weekend,The Carlyle is the place! Classic, friendly , you feel as if placed in a time when manners and class counted in people. The Carlyle has both and more!
user_name:
D Z
New Paltz, New York

review_body: The hotel is very beautiful and has kept all his historical charm. Rooms are big for NY and I love the romantic ambiance of them. 2 big dressings!!The service is nice but not that professional. I have been affected to a different room when I checked in, which is ok if I didn't find out a gift for the person who was supposed to take it. I had called the front desk 3 times and waited 2 hours for them to come and pick up a gift that was not for me. No apologies from them, not a word. I was supposed to have a business folder documents in my room, I called to ask for it, they confirmed to me 100% that there is nothing to my attention but they found it 1 hour later and brought it.No need to mention that the initials on my pillow were the ones of another guest...Well I didn't feel welcome in that hotel.The only service which was perfect is the housekeeping, very good people and caring. Cleaning was perfectly done too.

The Carlyle was an excellent property to use while staying in Manhattan. The staff is excellent and the property is beautifully maintained. I will stay there anytime I go to New York. I recommend it highly.

I had been looking forward to my stay at the legendary Carlyle Hotel. The rooms are in desperate need of renovation and the service is lacking for a hotel of this supposed caliber. The rooms are filthy and the overall hotel is tired! The only positive thing I can say is that Bemelman's lives up to the hype and the Gallery service is outstanding.

My wife and I stayed in a suite at the Carlyle on New Years. From arrival to checkout, the staff was very friendly and helpful. The lobby, with its Christmas decorations, was beautiful. Although the hotel has a formal feel to it - elevators manned by white-gloved attendants, waiting staff in white jackets - the service was very good and we were treated with respectful formality, which was delightful. The suite itself was very spacious and the two bathrooms were modern and clean. This particular suite had a bad view (darkened brick courtyard), but we really didn't mind. However, if a view is important to you, perhaps inquire at front desk before going to your room; other suites may have better views. High tea/lunch was lovely, as was the breakfast (the breakfast buffet for $39 was lovely and reasonably priced considering what it includes). Some previous trip advisor reviews indicated slow elevator service. We were on the 5th floor and had no problems. Valet service was very nice. In fact, the valet/doormen let us use their limo to get across town instead of a cab, which we really appreciated. Overall, we had a wonderful time at the Carlyle and thank them for their hospitality. We look forward to returning!

Spent 4 nights at the Carlyle over Christmas in a suite. Superlatives do not do this Hotel justice. The Hotel does have some unusual features so if you prefer slick and fast the Carlyle would probably try your patience but if you are looking for charm,discretion and being treated like an old friend rather than a room number - this is the very definition of a hotel. We spent most of our time in the bar which has live music most nights and a very animated crowd at week-ends and as residents the manager always made sure we were accomodated to the best of their abilities. The common areas are gleaming, uncluttered and very dog friendly and the concierges & security were always helpful with cars, dinner reservations and luggage shipments. It's a credit to Rosewood that the hotel remains unique and individual and has not been smothered by corporate types. A fantastically expensive hotel and totally worth it.

We spent 5 nights over Christmas in Room 515 which is a classic suite designed by Ralph Lauren. It is super spacious with a lovely entrance foyer, 2 bathrooms, a well equipped kitchenette, open plan dining and lounge area and loads of closet space. The Kiehls amenities in the bathroom is a real treat. The king size bed was very comfortable with excellent linen which contributed to a great sleep every night. The double glazing in all rooms ensured a quiet space to relax. The lunch and dinner at the hotel was average, pricey though the service was good and friendly.

The Carlyle is absolutely stunning - the service is immaculate - the location is perfect -just the rooms are spacious, old fashioned and some are more than a little rundown. Compared with other Top-Hotels in NYC the hotel is missing views over the city, but the incredible nice bar makes up for a lot.

We stayed here for our wedding night (and the night before)- used it as a place to get ready and stay the night. The wedding was very close by at the Central Park Boathouse (so no part of it was held at the Carlyle). We live in NYC but wanted to stay closer. This is a great hotel (and well located for this purpose) where I would stay again, but the experience was kind of mixed, so I'll try to be balanced here.Good: The hotel is clearly an iconic place, and our two room suite was very beautiful. I still think this is a great hotel and classic place to stay with nice rooms. We brought back ~30 people after the wedding to hang out in our siting room for a bit and it worked really well. We took some photos in the lobby and they also came out really well. The staff was very welcoming on the day of the wedding and service was great- they decorated the room with roses and left a gift of chocolates and a hand written note. We very much appreciated it. Also a good location and helps avoid midtown.For improvement: It was kind of a challenge leading up to the wedding and I almost pulled the plug on staying there. They originally said they could let us know if early check in was possible early the week of the event and said it was likely, but no one would give me a yes/no answer when we finally did ask (which therefore means, don't plan on early check-in). I ended up buying the night before (another $900) so I could guarantee we'd have access to the room by noon (rather than 3pm) the day of the wedding. Clearly one was available the night before. When I booked the original room, they also said we'd be welcome to take some photos in the hotel (just had to confirm closer to the date) but the person I spoke to the week of the wedding was more stand off-ish about the prospect. We ended up doing a few photos there anyway and it wasn't an issue. We tried not to be too disruptive, so I'm grateful we were able to do so. Also 6 large bottles of water delivered to your room costs $120, for reference.I understand the hotel's perspective behind the above issues but my main concern is that I got different answers to my questions over time from different staff members. It seemed like they'd be happy to accommodate our two main requests early on when we booked but that wasn't the case much closer to the event. We ended up having a great stay (albeit at twice the price I planned), the photos worked out well, staff was welcoming and accomodative when we were there, but I also realized you're not going to get too much special treatment at an important, busy New York hotel around the holidays (admittedly in this case, one that was not hosting other things associated with our wedding). Knowing this from the start probably would have helped us plan better.

Booked a suite for 4 nights over Christmas 2016. Great UES location if you prefer to avoid the crush of people and traffic in mid-town. Nice big rooms, but furnishings and bathrooms are tired. Very attentive service. Ask for a room on the 6th floor or higher. We are on 5 and are parallel to a flat roof with construction materials on it and if it were a work day we would need to close the blinds for privacy. Forget about going to the Bemelmans bar for a night cap. Its reputation as a great spot means it was jammed solid with people every night with what I believe were mostly non-guests of the hotel. We couldn't get in the door of the place.

Only P.J.S. Would notice the few mis-steps. The room was lovely (the drapes could use a cleaning). The sheets were as soft as possible, the pillows perfect. Kiels in the bathroom along with the most delicious soap. Plenty of oversized towels and water pressure to knock you over. We had to ask for a second bath robe. Extra cushy slippers. One light bulb in the bathroom was out the entire stay. The sofa in our room looked a bit too standard hotel issue for the Carlyle. It should look like home. The doormen were wonderful from arrival to departure and in between. The room was made up the moment you left and yet you never saw anyone in the halls ...perfect! We were disappointed to miss the buffet breakfast. We had breakfast and the two servers arrived with everything and my husband spilled his coffee trying to make room for them. Having known how important proper manners were here in the past ... they did not serve from the left , clear from the right... in fact I asked for a napkin to be put down on the spill and they came with on to put in my lap. I explained I need another and spread out that on over the spill . It never dawned on them. It's all in the details... what makes a truly fine hotel. It's still glorious although I am partial but please don't let it slip away!

Everything about our stay at The Carlyle was perfect! From the moment we arrived, until the moment we left, the staff treated us like royalty consistently delivering exceptional services. The suite was beautifully decorated with attention down to the very smallest detail thought of. This iconic address is one of the very few that still represents real luxury, elegance and sophistication!Jade

The Carlyle is a New York institution; I feel bad speaking honestly about this hotel which is all reputation and no splendour. To say it's dated is an understatement. Only 2 of the lifts work, the suite we had booked was dated, chipped, worn and the furnishings 30+ years out of style. There were threadbare rugs and splintered furniture. The kitchenette was ancient and completely unstocked with basics such as cutlery. The master bath was small (there was a guest half bath) and had a single sink which was completely inadequate for a couple staying in the suite. The grouting around the bath and walk in shower was dirty and in desperate need of redoing. The pillows were awful - lumpy rubber filled and not even a comforter on the bed just a sheet, bedspread and blanket that we retrieved from the closet. The staff are all long term and so lovely and friendly. They are obviously popular with returning guests who seemed to mostly be in their 70/80s. Perhaps they enjoy the old-style rooms but I have to say I expect a lot more from a 5* hotel in NYC. Air conditioning 30-40 years old and noisy as hell to the point it woke us when it kicked in. Our room on the 8th floor looked out over the front of the building - the opposite building is undergoing renovation so our view was of scaffolding and tarpaulins. Not great. A fellow guest told us that rooms in the tower had been renovated but I cannot confirm this.We won't return sadly until the whole place has had a major facelift and I don't think there are any plans for this in the near future. Such a pity as I'd been excited to stay there.
user_name:
nycbfd
New York City, New York

review_body: i have been here for a work trip and i stayed for two nights. the last day i received the worst surprise ever: in the late afternoon when i claimed the lagguage i left at the reception in the morning they didn't find it. after at least 20 minutes of waiting i found it abandoned behind a sofa in the lobby. i was shocked.this never happened to me even in the worst hostel i went when i was young.5 star hotel means that the service must be flawless, as 5 stars means perfection in the reception, as i also i pay for this. this low end treatment means that the hotel is definitely overrated.

A musty smell, no Iron and no coffee maker, room was spectacularly 1990's.the little kitchen was great, but only had booze and candy. No Coffee Maker!?!?!?Very disappointed, when I informed the front desk they told me "They would make a note"...This is the last Hotel I would book into in NYC.

Staff, location, amenities, restaurants were all magnificant. We were upgraded to a suite which was incredible, your every need was anticipated and fulfilled. It was my first overnight experience at the hotel and certainly hope it will not be my last.

Fabulous upscale destination bar for pre dinner cocktails. We make sure to go every time we are in NYC. They also serve a light menu if you want to stay for dinner. Live piano makes the experience quintessential...

A wonderful hotel that makes one feel totally at home ...The service and staff are fantastic...very polite and attentive... there is nothing i can complain about. It is an elegant, classy and it is a pleasure to stay here.

Elegant yet comfortable atmosphere, attentive and friendly staff. Excellent dinner at the Carlyle Restaurant. Perfect location on a quiet side street just a few short blocks from the Met and Central Park.

This Cafe seats less that 80 people yet it features dinner programs with stars like Judy Collins and Woody Allen.Great way to spend an evening with your sweetheart. The food is five star. After the program and dinner great jazz in the lounge.
user_name:
Dudley H
Santa Fe, New Mexico

review_body: Great one bedroom charming apartment. Mr. Puglisi and Mr. Beretta were especially gracious. The entire staff starting with the doorman and the front desk were always available and helpful. Housekeeping always responded to any request. Elevator operators friendly and helpful.

Returned to the Carlyle on November 4th and 5th for a birthday weekend. From the car service on Friday to our Saturday evening at the Cafe Carlyle - perfect weekend.While our room could use some freshening (very clean and spacious) - the staff and service is always absolutely top-notch. And, there is in our opinion, no better bar on the planet than Bemelman's.A special shout out to the concierge staff for tracking down diet tonic for me.Bottom line, we're always extremely happy with the Hotel and find it hard to think about staying anywhere else.
user_name:
G1812GGbrianc
New York City, New York

review_body: Every facet of this short visit was perfect. We have no complaints or recommendations. All are doing a superb job. Congratulations to all for a job well done. Housekeeping did a great job as usual. Lovely digs!

This is my first Trip Advisor review--ever--but I was so saddened at how far the once great Carlyle has fallen, that I felt I had to write. I am a New Yorker, living in Hong Kong and I was really looking forward to my third stay (in the past under my husband's name) at the iconic hotel. My first night, I took my close friend to Bemelmans Bar, not for the music (as we had a lot to catch up on), but for the atmosphere, which I have always loved. To celebrate being back in my hometown, I ordered a bottle of champagne and three plates of food. The staff was very nice (as they generally were throughout my stay). I was told that the dim sum would take a while, but I assured them that that was fine as we were there for the long-haul. About 15 minutes after placing our order, at 8:45 pm, the maitre d' (I assume) came by to inform us that we would have to pay the cover charges ($50 for the two of us) or leave by 9:00 when a trio was apparently scheduled to play. It was a Monday night, and no one had mentioned this to us before we sat down or ordered (in fact, he placed an announcement card on the table only when he approached us). I explained the situation, but he dismissively said he could extend until 9:15, but "that's all [he] could do." I told him that I was staying in the hotel, so he took my name and left. The people (also guests of the hotel) sitting at the table next to us, leaned over to say that it was an outrageous situation and that we should hold our ground. Later, the man returned to say, as though he were doing us a favor, that we could stay since I was "a guest of the hotel." What should have been a perfect evening was seriously undermined by his behavior, which was also needlessly brusque. We weren't finished with our meal until 10:30 that evening, and the bill came to $300 (!), so I'm not sure what they would have done with us if I hadn't been a guest of the hotel and instead "merely" a local patron of the bar (which I have been a number of times in the past). When I explained the situation the next day to a manager (Sofia, I believe), she was apologetic and said she would talk to the maitre d'. Unfortunately--though I just wanted to enjoy the holiday and not have to complain--I had to talk to her again about the early morning, hours-long drilling in the room directly next to mine. It was scheduled work she told me, and the hotel wasn't at full capacity (as she admitted), so I wondered why the hotel would have put me in that room (which was quite charming and comfortable, I will say, in other respects). She did not have an answer. I spent three nights at the Carlyle, and each day, I thought I would receive a note or some follow up, but nothing came. I travel all the time, and I understand that hotels sometimes have problems. If the hotel had made even the smallest gesture to make these quite serious problems up to me, I would have chalked it up to bad luck and moved on. I even waited to see if someone reached out to me after my stay, because I did reiterate my frustration when I checked out. But not a word.

A delight to stay in a place with such memories and ambiance. WHile this is charming a plenty in too many details to count, it also comes with its age that takes away from the daily comfort one is expected. Above all the staff, concierge and service are top notch.

Its classic charm and history is what allured me to The Carlyle, not to mention that its a "5 star" luxury hotel. I expected great service and an updated room and thats not what I experienced. Most of the paintings and mirrors on the walls in my room were crooked upon checking in. Some areas in my room had not been updated and looked very old. The service was not up to par with a "5 star" hotel. I say these things because for the price and reputation of this hotel, the attention to detail should be evident and it was not at The Carlyle. There are other, better hotels in the area.Pros: My room was large, with a very comfortable bed and pillows. The toiletries that are provided are great, Kiehls. Bemelman's Bar is fantastic for a night cap and some live music.

Eight nights in this iconic hotel. Yes, the elevators are slow, the airconditioning noisy, the furniture worn but there is plenty of what other hotels lack so badly: sophistication, atmosphere, a real home away from home, a human touch to everything, old fashioned hospitality with an utterly professional staff, Away from the crowds in a pleasant residential area but within walking distance of everything one needs for enjoying New York City.After the Four Seasons, the Peninsulta, St Regis, Park Hyatt and Lotte Palace - our home of previous stays, the Carlyle is the only hotel we kept talking about when we were home, again. We shall be back.

We spend 7 days at the Carlyle. We have been going there for plus 30 years. Everything perfect and when something is not, they deliver inmidiately. Only sad issue: Dwight, our concierge, retired. But that is life. His succesors are as efficient as he was.

My Niece and I stayed at The Carlyle Hotel from 10-20-16 To 10-25-16,service was very good,Hotel room was very clean the bed and pillows was very comfortable the elevator operator was very nice the door man very nice,the check in/ check out Staffers was very professional.

I should have known something was up when we checked in and they said, "So, this is your first stay with us." Ah NO...this WAS our go-to hotel when in NYC and we've stayed there many, many times. Something has really changed for the bad at the historic and stately Carlyle. Elevator buttons that don't work (which would be OK if they just posted a sign), shower light bulbs that are burned out and need to be changed, a request for Ladies shower cap instead of one in the room and 53 minutes to get coffee and 2 bagels. UGH ! We'll try the Pierre next time.

The Carlyle isn't a hotel, its an institution! If you fancy staying away from the chaos of midtown Manhattan, get to the Upper East Side and stay at The Carlyle. The rooms are not ultra modern, but they are luxurious and the service is superb. Expect to see some famous faces if you stay here - the Piano Bar is an attraction in itself.

The Carlyle is my now fiancee's favorite hotel in the city and it's easy to understand why. Everything during our stay was beyond expectation. I planned the engagement surprise with Patrick in hospitality, who was a pleasure to work with. He went above and beyond for me by upgrading us to one of the best rooms in the hotel. We were overlooking central park on one side and midtown manhattan on the other. He decorated our room with framed pictures of us, pillowcases with our names embroidered into them, exquisite flower arrangements, champagne, rose petals...the whole nine yards. My girlfriend and I had drinks at Bemelmans bar, which just oozes old NYC class. When I surprised her with the hotel room, she was beside herself, crying and laughing with excitement at seeing the room, the view, and realizing that this was our moment. I couldn't imagine a better engagement. A memory we will share for a lifetime. I've had the pleasure of staying at many 5 star hotels in my life, but the Carlyle is up there with the very best. The service, the hospitality, the accommodations...all beyond description. It's safe to say we will be coming back.

One of New York's great old hotels, the Carlyle is well-positioned for the upper East side, museums, etc. It still offers luxury with a comfortable hominess but it feels a bit dated. This is partly style and partly amenities. Expect to queue at lifts but friendly attendants when you finally get one.

I recently went to New York for work and decided to go back to a Hotel that I haven't been to in years - The Carlyle. It reminds me of timeless elegance. With so many changes, sometimes its great to stay the same. From the time of check in to check out (it was just one night), the staff is professional, friendly and respectful. The bar is too beautiful for words - they seem to attract an older customer (and I'll define older as over 35 :-) My room was on the small side and the configuration was a little strange - but the bedding is top of the line and my time there was short. This hotel may not be 'hip' - I'm showing my age, I know - but I'll take timeless elegance any day.

During my six days I waited a combined total of 2 hours for the elevator. They only have 2 working to cover 34 floors. Several times I had to call three times and then found out there was no one operating the elevator at all??? Do NOT book here unless all elevators are working. This was beyond frustrating. Then, on my last night,I left my credit card in the restaurant. I was a guest of their hotel, but no effort was taken to contact me - even though my name was on the card. This was a very disappointing stay at a hotel I grew up going to. So sad!!!!

The Carlyle is a legendary hotel and it should be. Not just for its storied history, but because the bones of the place are phenomenal. Elegant understated design, gorgeous interiors in the common rooms and a culture of great service. As a frequent business traveler (often at the higher end hotels), I have in recent years been disappointed by visits to the Carlyle that should have been wonderful. Not wanting to go on and on, I will point out some highlights (lowlights?). The rooms are lovely but long overdue for renovation. The property was sold about three years ago and a complete room renovation was announced. Never happened. The buffet breakfast (and of course the Cafe Carlye bar/cabaret) are exceptional. However, regular meals here (restaurant or room service) are decidedly below average. This is unacceptable for a "five star" hotel with top-tier food prices. Even a basic burger or salad is notably not as good as the diner a block down on madison avenue (also pricey, but at least good). Another example is the gym. It's small and functional, which would be fine...if it were functional. Of the two ellipticals in the gym, today one was out of service and the reception on the TV on the other was all snowy. (The TVs on the machines never have good reception, even though they are cable). The gym had no towels (which is usually does, and the spa attendant said they low on towels today. Another guest who arrived as I was leaving looked at the empty shelf and said "Again no towels?" Lastly, while I use the business center in a hotel only occasionally for internet or printing, the Carlyle eliminated theirs recently and installed what appears to be a small retail space instead. I understand maximizing revenue and keeping costs down--and I also realize that in other contexts than Tripadvisor complaining about no towels, sub-par food and bad TV reception may seem whiny--but when paying top-dollar in NYC for a five-star experience, it is disheartening that the management of this great institution (and The Carlyle IS an institution) seems to be taking its reputation and its customers for granted. The staff are wonderful and seems eager to please...I just hope that management can summon the resources to keep the hotel up to par and improve those areas where they are clearly cutting corners.

I spent four nights at this great hotel in August. The hotel is exactly as the pictures show. The reception staff were really helpful and check in was problem free. My suite was on the fifth floor and was clean and had original features, which was great.The room was cleaned every day to a very high standard. Unlike other hotels I have stayed in this was the quietest, no late night door banging or ice machines whirring away disturbing your sleep. The hotel is close to the subway and Central Park. I must thank Jamie Lee whose help made this trip really special.

The Carlyle Hotel has become a special place for my little son especially as he has been going there during our weekend escapades to NYC. The hotel has an elegant old world charm and has had many notable residents and guests. The staff will ensure your needs are met and were so kind to welcome my son with little candy treats when we check in. For little guests they provide special kid's toiletries and bathrobes (so cute!) Kiehl's for adults, the rooms are furnished in Louis XV style along with some modern touches. Bemelman's Bar and Carlyle Restaurant offer beautiful meals and breakfasts, they didnt mind my little one went down in his Bonpoint Pajamas! I cannot repeat how kind the staff is and how this hotel for me defines old world NYC elegance. We love you Carlyle the Corvez Family

A 5 star price with a 2 star experience. Lipstick on a pig. The elevator attendant with the white gloves....really? After a long day traveling, shirt and tie for the dining room!This is an awful lot of money for a hotel that is hardly one to remember. What a let down. Not great.

I have wanted to stay at this NYC institution for a long time every time I visit NYC. Plus I had stayed at the rosewood London and absolutely loved everything about it and wanted to try its sister hotel in NYC.It has a great ambience by these were my sore points:-really slow wait for elevators but I know it's an old hotel- the snacks in the minibar were out of date by 5 months!- the room was really small although this is NYC but the proximity to the bathroom was just too close. We had a tiny balcony but not really any views- even though we are Amex members and always get upgraded there was no upgrade here- with NYC traffic it takes 30 mins to get anywhere past midtown down to soho to all the trendy restaurantsThe good points are:- the bemelmans bar has a wonderful ambience- the ala carte breakfast was fantastic- it's a nice change from soho and a great feel of the upper east side- close to Central Park for walks and all the luxury shopping on Madison and fifthWe later moved down to Greenwich village and it was a nice change and much quieter Overall loved it but expected way more as I had stayed at the rosewood London and was very impressed.

We booked the hotel thru Centurion and were delighted with our upgrade thanks to the front desk, but after we decided to extend there was a lot of confusion and disappointment in the allocation of our new rooms. We were taken to a room which was flooded and were treated rather insensitively despite taking two rooms for eight nights. We ended up waiting 5 hours and checking into the same room at 10pm at a higher price. We were promised different things which ended in unnecessary confusion and a lot of time wasted. Felt rathe exploited and disappointed!

This place is living off its past gloryWe've stayed here for the past few years and each visit the suites are in greater need of attentionAnd old woman that needs a terrific plastic surgeon Maybe even more!Internal surgery as wellPaint chipped Door handles in rooms lose or off completely Carpets dirtyLights not workingAir conditioning not working in summerElectricity outHot water outFood extremely mediocre Tired elevator attendants and even more tired elevators that seem to endlessly never arriveThe telephone on each landing I believe is for the soul purpose of begging the concierge to send up an elevator...please!!This hotel is tiredThe staff is tired The hotel now has a tremendous amount of tours checking in and checking out We've moved on across the street toThe Mark hotel Best thing we could have doneCheck out review of The Mark hotel my husband wroteExcellent hotelDon't know why anyone would stay anywhere else Don't stay at the Carlyle if you have any decent taste

I have visited New York on a number of occasions and decided to stay on the Upper East side. The location was fantastic and enjoyed walking in central park every morning and listening to amazing jazz in the evening. The hotel staff are extremely friendly and nothing is too much trouble I would definitely stay in this hotel again.

After my first stay at the Carlyle last summer, I decided to give it another try. This year's stay was better by half a star. A few niggles prevented a full five star rating, but the hotel is still quite lovely and I would gladly return.Last year's stay was probably predestined to not be excellent. I booked through a "secret hotel" online flash sale, which was for a Superior room, the hotel's lowest category, and I of course was given a room on the lowest possible floor (3rd floor). This year, I booked directly on Rosewood's website, using the hotel's complimentary 3rd night offer. I selected the next room category up from Superior, which was a Superior Tower Room. These rooms are on the petite side with a queen bed in about 300 sq. ft., but are on floors 23-33 with Manhattan skyline views. I requested a higher floor.Because I booked through Rosewood directly, the hotel reached out to me prior to my stay. I hoped for a super early check-in (I took a red-eye flight), and the hotel was able to arrange that (kudos to Jamie Lee!), although my assigned room was lowered from floor 33 to floor 23. Check-in was fine with the doorman, bellman, receptionist and elevator attendant all offering cheerful assistance. A shower was most welcome after my flight into Newark :( and my budget-minded shlep on NJ Transit to Penn Station :( and then 2 MTA subway lines to the hotel.The room, as expected, was petite, but I was gifted with a lovely enclosed terrace that very few rooms have (thanks again Jamie Lee!), affording 180-degree Manhattan views east, south and west, thus getting a peek at Central Park. One of the terrace windows opened. Even on floor 23 I was still higher that most of the surrounding buildings, including lots of luxe residences on Park Ave. and Fifth Ave. It was fun to get a glimpse of the roof-top terraces on these buildings, including the Surrey Hotel across the street. The Tower part of the hotel is narrower than the base; my floor only had about 5 rooms. The largest was a private apartment that seemed to have at least 2 enclosed terraces and primo Central Park western and northern views. I was hoping to run into these privileged residents but never did.The room was decorated in a classic style befitting a classic hotel (opened in 1930). Furnishings looked weathered (intentional?) and somewhat cheap, especially the cabinets in the bathroom. The bathroom was very small, identical to last year's, but well-stocked with Kiehl's products. The HD TV was fabulous with an infinite number of channels and superb clarity. A big plus: WiFi is now FREE! Last year, guests had to pay, so I often used the Business Centre. For now, the Business Centre is closed, but hopefully the free WiFi will remain once it reopens. A big annoyance: water condensation from the A/C would loudly drip onto the terrace glass roof in a manner that was too inconsistent to be white noise.Niggles: the Business Centre was closed, as mentioned. Supposedly it will be relocated eventually. For now, guests needing a desktop computer can use one in a non-public area off the front desk. I went to what used to be the Concierge desk, only to find a wall. The Concierge is now at the bottom of the staircase by the Carlyle Restaurant entrance. I miss the rack of newspapers, magazines and tourist literature. The elevators, which have attendants, are slow. Although there are 4 elevators, only 2 seemed to be in operation, and only one of these accessed the tower, the other elevator stopped at floor 17. Waits from your floor can be particularly long; there was a posted sign to call if your wait has been too long. What's more, one elevator I was in stopped at the 6th floor and then refused to budge. Luckily the door opened, so the attendant had to call for the other elevator to come get us. Later that day, the elevator was still being serviced, so someone in the lobby had to call for the service elevator to take me to my floor. Luckily, I didn't have to go out that evening, or I would have had to add an extra 30 min. travel time.I did not partake of any of the hotel's offerings this stay, although I had intended to visit the famous Bemelmans Bar and have breakfast at the restaurant like last year. Cafe Carlyle is closed in the summer. I did visit the Met, Met Breuer and Guggenheim as well as Central Park and shops on Madison Ave., all of which are convenient to the hotel. Once in the elevator I bumped into a top-50 tennis player in town for the US Open. Had I bumped into my favourite male tennis player of all time--who regularly stays at the Carlyle while in NY (according to US Weekly magazine and confirmed by an anonymous Carlyle staffer), who is out for the rest of the year due to injury but came into town for sponsorship obligations--that might have warranted the last half star.

This is a hotel that feels like home in a luxurious apartment in the Upper East Side, with amazing (though very high priced) breakfast, friendly doormen, elevator operators as in another era, and some rooms with amazing views. At its worst, with bad rooms (and there are some), or with work going on next door (there always seems to be renovations going on), it can seem no longer worth the money. But we always come back because of the atmosphere, location, and because of the amazing bar, with great music and a feeling that everyone is interesting.

I have stayed at this hotel a few times in the last 3 years and I have never been disappointed. Friendly, attentive staff, beautifully decorated hotel, luxurious, comfortable rooms and excellent dining options. Love the piano bar and also high tea. Great location for shopping on Madison Avenue.

I got ready for my wedding at one of the suites in the Carlyle. For NYC standards, the basic rooms are quite spacious and the suites are rather large. The staff is also amazing and took care of our needs in a timely manner. The only downside I would say is that the elevators are a bit slow, but that's part of the Carlyle's charm.
user_name:
mishtastic
New York City, New York

review_body: This place is excellent, especially after work where there is a piano player from 630 to 830. The French Chablis there is wonderful - fresh and clean taste. International, sophisticated and elegant. And the service is impeccable.it is located on the upper Eastside on Madison Avenue and you can stop in there for high tea as well after shopping.

American Express suggested that my family and I stay at The Carlyle. We had three rooms and stayed three nights. I was quite excited to stay there as I love staying in "authentic" hotels. I HAVE NEVER BEEN SO DISAPPOINTED. This hotel needs to be gutted! It might have been iconic in its day, but it's a modern day dump!!!!I could go on and on but I will let the pictures speak for themselves...BTW, I did complain to both Amex and the hotel. A nice, young lady from the front desk took my husband and I to look at other room options which were just as atrocious.

Before moving to NYC the Carlyle was our NY home... so when my granddaughter wanted a "real" afternoon tea it seemed the right choice. The price was in line but the sandwiches tasted of too many hours of refrigeration. the pastries seemed "store bought" and the crowd was a new group of millennials, casually dressed, and drinking too much. Where have all the blue haired ladies gone?
user_name:
David W
New York City, New York

review_body: This hotel is absolutely fantastic overall, the amenities, layout and service are fantastic, I would advise against ordering room service which is a little dissappointing but otherwise it is just perfect. details such as monogrammed linens are a classic old world touch.

My parents and I spent one week in July in this iconic history landmark. We occupied two spacious, luxury appointed deluxe rooms, located on the side street and very quiet. Location of hotel is great on very posh Madison avenue, 15 min walk from Plaza hotel. Hotel is elegant and smart, staff is very friendly, bathroom is supplied with nice Kiehl`s ammenities, breakfast is plentiful and delicious and Bemelman`s bar is great. We really very much enjoyed our stay and hope to return soon! :)

excellent location,away from times square and the tourist crowds,close to metropolitan-museum,charming interior,absolutely perfect and friendly service,great bar,impeccable housekeeping (nightly turndown service arrived exactly at 6:00pm ,every day),I'll be back!!

It deserves the money you pay. Central location with all the fashion designers stores nearby. In Luxury Madison Av. Very close to Central Park and the MET. Metro station nearby and a lot of market and grosseries. clean rooms, comfortable beds and many many services will comply with the most demanding requests. Real 5 stars. I Recommend it without second thought.
user_name:
U2510HKmariat
New York City, New York

review_body: The hotel is located in the upper east side in a very nice location. It is a nice luxury hotel with all the expected amenities. The rooms are spacious and nicely furnished. The air condition is loud and can be annoying at times. The bathrooms are small and somewhat awkward but they do the job. The Hotel has a decent restaurant and a nice bar area.After trying many other hotels such as peninsula, trump tower, 4 seasons, mandarin oriental, this is no doubt is the best value for the money and has become my place in New York.

The Carlysle has seen better days. Our king bed room has a collection of battered 1960's furniture. The wood parquet floor is coming apart covered by a Pier One stained rug. The toilet plugged twice. Dogs barking at evening. You need to call the desk for someone to operate the elevators, every time! The Commons rooms are small and worn. A trundle bed wa $75/night bottled water $9/a piece. The restaurant was among the priciest in NYC with barely average food. Here you pay for the location and a history of luxury that no longer exists.

Some staff are excellent and will go out of their way to accommodate your needs, some are lackluster and some downright rude. This hit or miss attitude makes it hard to enjoy the experience. For the price, there are other options I will use in the future.

We had a 6 night stay at The Carlyle two weeks ago in a 2 bedroom suite. Front desk was fabulous from the super easy check in after a red eye flight from Honolulu to their interest in my son who was eagerly awaiting the delivery of a package. The room was spacious with a big bowl of fruit for us and a plate of chocolates including a yellow chocolate taxi or the children. The location was brilliant, away from the hustle and bustle but close to plenty of restaurants, the zoo and museums. It was great being close to the quiet end of Central Park where we took the children to kick a ball, play in the playground (which has a small water play area at the entrance near the children's gate) and sail toy boats in the small lake. We did not visit the hotel restaurants but ordered room service every day which arrived in a timely manner and was delicious. We would definitely recommend this hotel to families looking for a quiet area of New York but within easy subway or Uber distance to all the attractions. The only downside was that the bathroom in the master was a little awkward with a small deep bath that doubled as a shower and felt a bit claustrophobic. This was not really a bother for us but if you were really tall or had limited mobility this could be a problem.

My partner and I had one of our most special dates at Bemelman's bar so we decided to spend the weekend at the Carlyle to celebrate. We appreciated how attentive the staff was to our needs and how hard they worked to make the weekend special for us. Sonal took good care of us and we appreciated the attention to detail. Although we tend to prefer contemporary hotels, the Carlyle is a refreshing balance of traditional old New York service with a modern touch.

I always wanted to stay at the iconic Carlyle so when my niece was pronounced terminal I took her on her first trip to New York. The staff at the Carlyle went above and beyond to make it the greatest experience possible. I could not imagine a single detail left undone. Everything was perfect and the staff saw to it that my niece felt like the Queen of New York City. I will never stay anywhere else. This is worth every penny. I give it 5 starts for value because the value was beyond my expectations.

When I began working, about 35 years ago, The Carlyle was my favorite luxury hotel. Everytime I was landing in New York,  being at The Carlyle , was a special moment. And to my modest incomes at the time, it was my treat. The problem is that the place looks  very tired now. If at least breakfast is still one of the best in the world, if the beds are comfortable and bathrooms still so elegant, the general aspect of the room is so dull!Service is also from the best to the worst, some days good, some days inefficient, some  days courteous some days arrogant as if Mr Kennedy or some other important guest was still awaited as in the old good days. As tou see, to my opinion, there is much to do to put back this hotel do a real 5 stars place.And I feel really bad about it.

From reception to checking out (8 days later) this hotel simply exceeded in the friendly and efficient service offered by the staff and the comfort of the amenities. With a great breakfast, clean and spacious room with an extremely comfortable bed, the week there was one great pleasure.Although the room décor is quite traditional, it suits the ambience of the hotel that is situated in the more sophisticated upper east of Manhattan. A short walk from Central Park and the 77th street subway station, the hotel is in a quiet and peaceful part of the great city.Surprisingly enough, although not cheap, the rates compared favourably with some other (lesser) hotels in the vicinity of Central Park with breakfast included in the package as well as a discount voucher for a spa treatment and one night's cover charge for the famous Bar.

This hotel needs renovation, its appearance is much improved.The rooms are good and clean.The best is its location near the station in the center.The staff is friendly and helpful.I will return very soon!

-Large room, especially for New York standards, however the hotel is definitely in need of a renovation while hopefully maintaining some of the classic appeal of the hotel. Some of the walls and carpeting in both the rooms and public hallways are stained and worn. Slightly loud since floors are hardwood so if you have someone remotely loud above you you can hear everything-Overall good service, especially tending to luggage, dry cleaning, and hailing cabs, etc.The elevators were malfunctioning but the hotel handled it well and were always accommodating. Bellmen, housekeeping, elevator staff all very friendly and attentive yet front reception/check-in were not always the most friendly and a bit of an air that as a guest we were simply privileged to be there-Bemelmans bar a great classic standard bar/lounge to partake in. -Remaining price (laundry/room service, etc) rather over-priced, even for New York AND Upper East Side standards. Too many other options in New York these days-Convenient location for East Side with proximity to park, museums, subway at 77th St

Elegant, classy, clean, graceful, charming are understatements for this hotel. I'm so glad that I picked this hotel out of all the rest. The location is wonderful. The blocks surrounding it are clean, safe and delightful. The doormen were sincere and genuinely helpful and pleasing in their greetings. Concierge was just as helpful. The room was delicate and lovely - extremely clean in every nook and cranny. They do provide free wi-fi, contrary to some websites reviews. This hotel pays attention to detail. My only suggestion to them would be to provide a coffee maker in the wet bar room of each hotel room. The restaurants/bars serve delicious food by super friendly staff. I can't say enough about their friendliness. Bemelmans Bar is ranked #3 of 10,000+ restaurants in NYC - and it's right there in your hotel. No doubt in my mind, when I return to Manhattan, I will stay in this gem of a home away from home. I absolutely loved it and was sad to leave and told them so as I left.

Sleep Quality is good, location is perfect, bad concierge service, bad behavior at the reception, the value of the hotel was not in conformity with the service level. If the details are very important for you , this hotel is not the place to be.

Just spent a week at the Carlyle Hotel and it was really great. The Hotel is art deco style and is beautifully kept and the reception area is quite stunning. The room,and all the warm and friendly staff make every effort to ensure that you feel at home and enjoy your stay.We had a fabulous room that was bright and airy and the location was very good a few minutes walk to the nearest subway station and being on the Upper East Side near museums, shops and restaurants.There is a lively bar and jazz club in the hotel and the dining area is charming.I couldn't recommend this hotel enough.

The Carlyle service and style remains a great tradition on the upper east side in a great NYC location. The rooms and condition of the hotel could certainly continue to be improved to a modern day luxury hotel without losing its charm. The style and upgrade of the rooms seems scattered and haphazard which is surprising for a hotel this level. They are currently working on upgrading the elevators which isn't surprising given their age but it can add a bit of hassle when you are in a hurry. They did their best to handle the inconvenience. Overall a nice experience but I will likely try the Mark or the Surrey instead on my next visit as they are similar price point with better upgrades.

First time for us and it was exceptional in every way beautiful room ( Suite ) immaculately clean , quiet , comfortable . Staff could not have been nicerLocation is one of the best in all Manhattan . Will be back .

Stayed here for a week and absolutely loved it. Traveled with two of my daughters and stayed in a two bedroom. I'm always Leary of a new hotel in New York because of the noise but it was very quiet in my room. I was never disturbed by housekeeping yet my room was always clean when we came back. My daughter had a birthday while there and they sent up a plate of cookies with "Happy Birthday" written on the plate and arranged for balloons to be delivered at the last moment.. Is it stuffy? Only if you allow it to be. We were there because my granddaughter is battling stage 4 cancer so our "dress" was very casual. There were however "designer" outfits everywhere, hair coiffed, and demeanor a high. Don't let it bother you as it is a big city and people are there for all sorts of reasons. What matters is the staff and how they treat you which was top notch!. Would I stay there again? Absolutely!

Everything was what I had anticipated and surpassed my expectations. There is old world elegance with today's upbeat style. The location cannot be beat as it is so close to the museums and shoppingIn fact the bus stops right in front of the hotel.

Are there less expensive hotels in Manhattan? Sure. Do they have the location, history, class and dedication to making you feel like a valued guest of the legendary Carlyle? Nope.The opportunity to use those iconic revolving doors, ride the elevators (with a white-gloved elevator operator, of course) that have whisked royals and celebs to their suites, savor the photos of well-known former guests on the walls, and enjoy a well-crafted martini at Bemelman's is worth every penny. Our room was large and comfortable, with a foyer, two walk-in closets, and a large whirlpool/shower. Some might prefer more contemporary furnishings, but we loved the fact that the hotel's decor is an homage to its history. Add in the stellar location so near good restaurants, Central Park, the Met and other Upper East Side attractions, as well as friendly and attentive staff, and you have the makings of a memorable NYC visit.

The best things about The Carlyle are its excellent Upper East Side location and its sincere staff. There seemed to be a veritable army of staff available at all times to provide gracious assistance. (This is the only NYC hotel I can remember that has elevator operators.)What The Carlyle needs is a facelift. While clean and welcoming, the furnishings and fittings appear to be circa 1960 -- staying here feels like visiting your well-to-do grandmother in the city who hasn't changed a thing since Kennedy was president. Also, it would be nice to have a coffeemaker in the suites. Ours had a kitchen but no coffeemaker. Simply put, while lovely, the property would benefit by becoming more current.

Hotel is very nice but old. Great location on upper east side which mean quiet for nyc. Hotel is quiet and not much going on so if your looking for night life it's not there. But all you have to do is walk across the street to the mark and you have a little more night life but really who wants that if your staying on the upper. I sure didn't.

The Carlyle is like a home away from home. First went about 10 years ago for a couple of weeks and spent Xmas with my family in one of the suites. Last year I spent on two visits about two weeks at the hotel. The service was brilliant, the food to die for. However, this year I was there for a couple of nights and I was put in a very tired room and nobody welcomed me back to the hotel. The front desk couldn't have cared that I had stayed there previously and hardly lifted their head. I'm also wondering how one can get upgraded for a view of the park. As always our meals in your signature restaurant were special and well attended. The lobby and flowers make me feel like I'm coming home.

The room was spacious, although the bathroom was tiny. The room was quiet and immaculate. The staff was friendly and helpful. Here you don't have to do anything yourself. They don't even let you press the floor button on the elevator. They have people who do that for you. The residential neighborhood is loaded with high end fashion shops and art galleries. Close to Met Museum and the former Whitney but far from the tourist sites of midtown. Altogether a relaxing stay.

Old style New York hotel with elevator operators, crystal chandeliers and exquisite waiters. The Woody Allen jazz band plays at the lobby bar once a week and breakfasts bring together the elites of New-York. Stay is a must if visiting NY, though only a one-time stay.The hotel needs renovation. The rooms are old, poorly equipped and with no sound proofing.However, the new owners are planning refurbishing soon, which would surely make the Carlyle #1 in NY again. Stay tuned.

The Carlyle is the quintessential New York landmark. Great location with proximity to the Museum Mile, shopping. Legendary service and the classic live piano bar that has memorialized Bobby Short. Food is exceptional though overpriced. The staff pamper you thoroughly. Overall the service levels justify the tab. Be prepared prepared to put up with a few quirks typical of an older property eg the noisy air conditioning

One of the best hotels ever but tell them no fragranced soaps if you are allergic. Great people great location great restaurant overall the best made me a rosewood chain fam as my number one chain. Recommend.

A nice quite dark bar to get you to unwind and chill, snacks on the bar are superb I especially like the cheese and jalapeño snacks. Free wifi and good drinks make a great rest stop after Central Park or the met. Well worth the slight walk to the beautiful hotel

I adore this intimate, luxurious property that is everything you could ask for in a deluxe hotel, from the warm and gracious staff to the mid-century, large-format New York photographs hanging in the lobby, to the exquisite décor in both the lobby and guest rooms. From the moment you arrive, the Carlyle staff treats you like a treasured guest. They are friendly and helpful. The rooms are spacious and beautifully appointed, with sumptuous bed linens, and a bright, mirror and marble clad bathroom.The Carlyle will always be my favorite New York City hotel.

Just the lobby alone exudes a time far past. The elegance of it all. The exquisite flower arrangements everywhere. The elevator staff ensures a smile on everyone's face. Large room, fantastic shower, great closet and superb bed. Unfortunately the breakfast service and quality were a big disappointment.

This hotel deserves its 5 star/diamond designation.Kinda unpretentious place, but what do you expect from a 5 star hotel?They have a great bar with live music starting at 8pm.Food was ok. Not too great, not too bad.Service was very attentive.
user_name:
T767TUrobertb
New York City, New York

review_body: We traveled from London to NY and stayed at this hotel for 8 nights! From the old style elevators to concierge there are many things that will make the experience special . its about 40 mins walk to Times Square . 5 mins from Central park which we loved !!! Food was okay ! Room itself was a little outdated . for the price you pay you would expect a little more than average rooms . Overall had a nice experience.

My girlfriend's favorite hotel is the Carlyle, so I wanted to surprise her by proposing after watching a show at Cafe Carlyle (Chita Rivera). Patrick Sewell, senior guest relations manager, helped me every step of the way with incredible ideas, attention to detail, small & big touches all conveyed with heartfelt & warm enthusiasm. He coordinated everything at the hotel with incredible professionalism, had the wonderful suggestion of placing framed photographs of us in the room, and included unexpected touches like monogrammed pillowcases for us to take home. I even had his personal cellphone in case I needed anything.We're both incredibly grateful for the perfect night that will always be part of our memories. And an unexpected but wonderful surprise: the waiter who brought champagne to our room (Ramon) sang a beautiful Spanish love song while pouring our drinks. Just an incredible experience.
user_name:
XavierNYC
New York City, New York

review_body: I have stayed at the Carlyle several times, usually in a large suite. Those are dated, but spacious. On my last visit, I was given an ordinary room. It was clearly a maid's room, left over from the days when the wealthy traveled with a retinue of servants. The tiny room with two twin beds was next to the service elevator, and the sound of room service carts being delivered started at 6:00 am and continued until I left the room at 8:30 am. The decor was from 1940, and not in a good way: painted (chipping) French Provincial furniture and a tiny partially tiled bathroom. I complained, and was moved to a like room on a different floor, though further from service elevator. For $600/night, one can find so much more pleasant accommodations in Manhattan, including across the street at the Surrey. Rosewood executives should take a tour before they allow their name to be used.
user_name:
KevinO932
Upper East Side, New York

review_body: Room was small but very clean. Hotel was very accommodating. Website was accurate. The car was parked by Valet and it did cost $50.00 as the site said.We were only there for 1 night but it was local to the restaurants we visited.

My two adult sons took my wife and their Mother to the Carlyle for a Mother's Day Brunch. We had a 10:00 reservation. We waited at least ten minutes for a table was a sign of trouble ahead. The hostess asked if we wanted coffee. It was more than ten minutes before we had water or coffee. One of us did the buffet and the other three ordered off the menu. We waited 40 mins for out food and shortly after we got our food they started breaking down the tables for lunch. They had a half dozen porters moving tables in and out. It was chaos. On top of that when we finally got our food my son and I had ordered eggs benedict and they were cold and then just to add the final touch the bill was wrong. Just an awfully disappointing experience on what was supposed ot be a special occasion.

I have stayed here a few times, for days! I absolutely adore the grandeur of it all! The artwork, the staff, the restaurant, the Bar! The tea time. The rooms, the service.. all outstanding! It is another level of customer service and old world professionalism unparalleled. It is expensive, and worth it. Go shopping on Madison Avenue, come back and have some tea. Go relax in your beautifully appointed room, and feel like a queen!

Entering the beautiful lobby at the Carlyle is like stepping back in time with the dramatic black floors and the gorgeous floral arrangements. The service is excellent.
