Just be prepared to be disappointed if you book a Superior Room as they are not very nice with furniture that reminded me os something from my childhood bedroom. There is a huge difference when you get into the next level room. When we were there last the business center was closed which created a problem for my husband who was in NY for business.

Can't say enough about our great stay. Everyone we encountered at the hotel was helpful and professional. The location is so convenient to the park, the Met and great shopping. We had a memorable lunch in the restaurant and a great night at the bar. The bar doesn't take reservations but you can call them 30 minutes before you come and they will get you seated if you are a guest at the hotel. Can't wait for our next trip to New York.

We've stayed here many times over the years. It is always spectacular. One block from the park, an iconic upper east side bastion of classic upscale cool and home to the best bar in NYC--Bemelman's. Ludwig Bemelman, author of the Madeline children's books, has artwork adorning the walls of the bar. Live piano and three piece ensemble most nights. Wonderful old world hotel all updated and so classically cool! Enjoy.

The name 'supper club' proffers an intimate calling card, don't you think?It has been 19 years since i last perched on this bar stool at the Cafe Carlyle in the hotel by the same name. Nothing has changed. There were the same tables and the same bar, the same paintings, those wonderful Vertes murals.... that's where i would sit. Its amazing how the moneyed-up crowd tuck into their oysters while the poor slobs wait outside trying to cajole their way onto the stools without making a prior booking.Amazing place.

One of the most classical New York establishments you can find! Went there for business, and loved it! Mostly just for the New York soul, that comes out everywhere. Many of the chain hotels have lost that and become too generic. Rooms need some refurbishment, but apparently they are doing/planning that. Service must be a challenge for them, as you find some people who are absolute gems around the hotel, and unfortunately also people who have been in their job perhaps for too long and dont like it anymore....In any case, I will definately go back.

The Carlyle is in Upper East Manhattan at the corner of E. 76th and Madison Ave. This is old time elegance with a great bar, a wonderful cafe where artists too numerous to name have appeared weekly. We saw Katherine Jenkins in an intimate setting (90 people). The staff is beyond 5 star, complete with outdoor bellmen, conceigere, and elevator attendants. The hotel is near 5th Ave. and close to Central Park. I would highly recommend a stay at The Carlyle.

We stayed on the 31st floor for 4 nights and the room had a great view of Central Park, among other things. The room was large (for Manhattan's standard) and the bed was very comfortable. The service was excellent, especially at the front desk and as well as the breakfast manager. The Carlyle gives such an aura of luxury from the days that had gone by, which we enjoyed very much. Although the breakfast was plentiful, but it could use a little variation from day to day. All in all, it was a wonderful stay and would recommend to anyone visiting Manhattan who enjoys some old fashion luxury.

I met a friend here for breakfast this morning and was so impressed. It was my first time at the Carlyle and I will certainly be back. The atmosphere and food were exceptional - but most of all the staff were amazing. The quality of service is out of this world and that combined with a truly impressive setting and the most beautiful music made it a highlight of this trip. It's a New York institution and if you like the traditional then make sure you visit.

We stayed her in Oct 2015 and what a great experience. The staff was friendly, the location could not get any better and I loved the jazz band that played at the Cafe Carlyle. Looking forward to spending another weekend here soon.

The service, costumes, menu, draperies, and even the 2 minute wait for hot water all harken me back to my childhood and the hotels that I visited in NY in the 1970s that had never been updated. The rooms have real keys, and the elevators each have an elevator operator who makes an effort to know your name. We had a view straight out to the building across the street--which is another nice reminder of the end of the 1930s...My favourite part was how the room is set up for a total alcoholic binge---there are THREE sets of window blinds---and TWO of the three are total black out blinds...and NO SOUND at all penetrates the room...I literally slept more hours in this room than i have in years--our room had a small balcony--and the windows opened fully as did the doors to the balcony--so the room is filled with fresh air. Thank you Carlyle.

The Carlyle's greatest assets are their staff. Gracious, knowledgeable, desirous to make your stay a good experience. Unfortunately, the hotel building does not live up to that standard. Perhaps it's the age of the structure, but there were problems in both rooms I stayed in. The first room, on the 11th floor was a bit worn - rug had a few "spots", the exposed hardwood floors were badly scuffed and several pieces of furniture were chipped. I assume this is one of the rooms that will be renovated soon. I decided to define the room as "shabby chic" rather than worn out. There were no blinds - just sheers and a set of drapes that would not stay closed.The big problem with the room, however, was that it was adjoining two other rooms. Where a door would have been, there was a (thin) plank of wood. I heard every word of every conversation in both rooms. When a cellphone rang in the room to my right, I reached for my own phone, it was that clear and loud. This went on for several hours until i went back to the front desk and asked if they had any other rooms available. The woman at the desk could not have been more sympathetic or helpful. As I was on my way out to dinner, she said, "Go and have a wonderful time. Don't worry about a thing. We will pack you up and move you to a better room. Just come back here when you return and we'll take you to your new room." The new room was on the 19th floor. "Newer" decor and had TWO sets of blinds on each window and a fruit and nut tray on the table. Quite nice, although the hot water faucet handle came off in my hand and the TV remote did not work and had to be replaced. HOWEVER....there was an adjoining room next door. Once again, the sound traveled so well that I could hear the man next door zip and unzip his suitcase. I enjoyed their discussion about the merits of the show they had seen. Every word of it. Since he and his wife didn't get to bed until 1:00am I purposefully avoided turning on the TV the next morning, knowing that I would have disturbed them. We met at the elevator later that day and they did mention that they heard my hairdryer loud and clear. Thankfully, everyone was good sports about the noise. Would I stay there again? Only if I could be guaranteed a room that did not join another - much less two others. Top of the line amenities are nice, but sleep is essential.

We don't come into the city as often , but decided a one night stay to celebrate my daughters birthday with a Broadway show would be fun. We have stayed in many fine hotels in the city- 4Seasons and St Regis etcAs we get a bit older and the city seeming more unsecure, an upper east side stay was a good decision for us. We booked connecting rooms, had to ask but we're grated a high enough floor to enjoy city views and a peak of the park.We were worried that the rooms would be typically city small but found the space very adequate for a one night stay. Renovated bathrooms , wood floors and walk in closets all things we like.We tend to enjoy smaller old school places to stay and the Carlyle was perfect. What set it apart is the service-from the moment you arrive and are greeted , to the elevator attendants you could want for nothing. But when you want something it was never an issue.Bemelmans for pre show light dinner and drinks and again for dessert and night caps was perfect. The breakfast sensational and again the service beyond reproach. We would put the service on par or perhaps better then many of the 4Seasons we have stayed. And this for us is the benchmark for quality service.The concierge recommended and arranged a great neighborhood Italian restaurant for dinner the night of our departure , the front desk allowed a very late check out-much appreciAted to freshen up after a long day at the met/shopping. Happily held our bags for a quick return pick up on our way to the train and home.Short but lovely stay. A real feeling of security when you stay and again outstanding service. We will indeed return.

The Carlyle Cafe Jazz Band with Woody Allen did not disappoint. They were all talented musicians. It was absolutely fabulous. The music, the dinner, the bartenders-the patrons there, Just a wonderful experience that my husband and I will never forget!
user_name:
gymtandrink
Point Pleasant Beach, New Jersey

review_body: I am fortunate enough to stay at the Carlyle Hotel frequently and it has yet to disappoint me. As always the hotel saff was superb. The doorman Emilio gave me a super warm greeting upon arrival. "Hi Mr. Bick, welcome back". Team members like Emilio make guests of the Carlyle feel special. When I got to the front desk I was lucky enough to be greeted by Sonal Nayyar from guest relations. Sonal is always so personable and takes the time to get to know clients of the Carlyle. This attention to detail makes guests of the hotel feel valued.On this stay I was lucky enough to have room 1515. Room 1515 is a newly renovated deluxe king room. In addition to beautiful décor and lighting room 1515 has a fantastic bathroom with a separate soaking tub and rain shower. Definitely one of the nicest bathrooms I have seen in the hotel. The room also features a small private terrace which looks East with a city view. This is one of the things I love most about the Carlyle, you never know what kind of a room you are going to get. Although all of the rooms I have stayed in at the Carlyle have been beautiful, they all seem to have different characteristics and variety. This is a refreshing change from the cookie cutter formula most hotels use for their rooms. As I was leaving my room for dinner I received a phone call from Patrick Sewell of the Guest Relations Team welcoming me and checking that all was ok. Again, another example of the team at The Carlyle making sure their guests feel valued. As always thank you to Team at The Carlyle for going above and beyond to make your guests feel special.
user_name:
Ross B
New York City, New York

review_body: My daughter and I flew up to NYC for her prom dress and we stayed at The Carlyle. We had a great time. Our room was perfect, the staff warm and friendly and this property is surrounded with fun restaurants to visit. Central Park is one block away and an easy walk. If you go to NYC stay at this property. It was a great experience. Thank you to all the staff that made it fantastic.

Don't be seduced by the wonderful reputation that Rosewood deserves and think this property is on-par with other properties in their portfolio. This is an old school hotel with some polish in a few places. Perfectly fine as an older 4 star hotel but not anywhere near the calibre of their properties in MX, London, etc. Love the Upper East neighborhood and access to the Park but it's living off past glories.

I have been a frequent visitor to New York for the last 40 years but have never stayed at the Hotel Carlyle, on Madison Avenue. The reason for choosing this hotel was the location being near to the apartment of our friends.We booked a superior room for the 7 night duration on a room only basis.The entrance lobby to the hotel is small, quite elegant and I suppose would be termed as discrete. Our welcome on arriving, from the concierge and reception was warm and professional and we were quickly processed and shown to our room.The room was a good size with a partial view of Central Park, well furnished with a large comfortable double bed. The refrigerator for the mini bar was a little ancient and the bathroom was also showing signs of age but nothing unacceptable. So the facilities were overall ok to good.However, the general atmosphere of the hotel was, in our opinion slightly frigid and bordering on being false to the point of being made to feel uncomfortable. We had no desire to loiter/use the common areas. Maybe because the common areas are small and dark, they (to us) felt uninviting. The elevator operators were pleasant enough although not all were consistent in their attitude to guests and the front of house ‘greeters’ acted in a manner that I expect many would now consider embarrassing.We booked to eat in the restaurant the one free evening we had. The experience could only been described as average. Room excellent, table setting and linen excellent, food was not good, service was unnecessarily overbearing and unjustifiably overpriced. We booked at 2000, a perfectly reasonable time but immediately felt we were being rushed through our meal. There were several tables occupied but the restaurant was probably only 40% full. The most unforgivable and bizarre error was removing our wine glasses when there was still a half a bottle of wine remaining. The practice of keeping your wine bottle out of sight and away from the table is one I find unnecessary and very irritating. The only reason we discovered that the wine had not been finished was when another waiter came to table to fill our glasses only to discover they had been removed. This has never happened to us before and can only be judged as unprofessional.Overall the Hotel Carlyle is ok. If you are on business or have made this your hotel of choice over the years I am sure you see benefits in this hotel which were unable to appreciate. I can imagine to some people, the hotel is like a good quality comfortable ‘old shoe’ warm, familiar, with old fashioned traditions. However, I would throw the shoes away and buy another pair with the same craftsmanship but questioning the value of some of the old traditions.We very much enjoyed the location of the hotel and surrounding area but we would not choose to stay in the Hotel Carlyle again.

Best location ,lots of bars ,restaurants a lot of shopping around. Subway was just two block away so you never need to pay for taxi. We loved the hotel to.Amazing bar resturant and I loved them New York cheesecake and a bloody Mary. I had the breakfast buffet too but little pricy and not that many options. Rooms are little small but as soon as I asked for larger room they moved me to the bigger room for no charge. I liked them rates and I really recommend this hotel is officially for tourists.

Personally I didn't see what the fuss was about. The hotel was perfectly acceptable despite their inability to fix my cable tv access. Fortunately this was a business trip and we had a reduced rate otherwise I wouldn't have been v impressed.

This is my first time staying at the Carlyle. It was an interesting place I mean typical New York hotel small rooms but good service. I was here on business and will have to be close by the only thing I wish was the Wi-Fi was better. The only other thing I could offer is that the food options close by are kind of lacking so be prepared to walk.
user_name:
Moearoundtheworld
New York City, New York

review_body: The hotel on the Upper East Side can only be defined as stately elegance. My wife and I prefer midtown among the hustle and bustle, yet we were pleasantly surprised that the Upper East Side has some hidden jewels of restaurants located within its confines. We prefer contemporary as opposed to "old world charm" but the hotel is so steeped in history we had to give it a try. The furnishings in the room may leave a bit to be desired ( at least our room) but the hotel is elegantly decorated. I now know where the Ritz Carlton learned their customer service from - The Carlyle. We were treated exceptionally well. The food from breakfast to dinner was exemplary and Bemelmans bar needs no introduction. 5 star rating from people who ordinarily book their vacations at a contemporary Mandarin Oriental! Highly recommend The Carlyle!

For my wife's 30th birthday, I decided to take her to NYC. What a great choice when choosing the perfect setting. The Carlyle is first class! From every detail, to all the amazing staff members that we encountered every day they spoke to what the Carlyle stands for, a first class experience! Waldo at the concierge was fantastic! We were lucky enough to get snowed in and stay an extra night! Thanks for the great memories!

I stayed in this hotel for a couple of nights in December 2015. The hotel is beautifully decorated, the room was spacious, clean and very welcoming. The bed was comfortable. Breakfast was in a nicely decorated spacious dining room. The quality of food and the variety of options was to the top standard.

Absolutely love the vibe of this hotel! It is so nice to stay in a charming, elegant hotel and not one decorated in a stark and austere manner, as all the "hip" hotels are today. Beautiful flowers and details throughout the common areas and room. The service is beyond impeccable. Genteel, refined, and pure elegance throughout!

We stayed for 4 nights during the winter storm, perfect place to be stranded in New York City!! The Bemelmans bar was so fun and lively with the jazz band playing, it felt like we went back in time to the 50's elegant but casual at the same time. The service at the bar was outstanding! The rooms were very comfortable. Due to the storm the restaurant was booked But the hotel staff promptly sat us at a room next to the restaurant and bar. The food choices were limited. We ordered the burger, not exactly what we wanted for dinner but as I said the choices were limited. What a surprise! The burger is one of the best we have ever had! Cook to perfection and the flavors outstanding! Beautiful hotel, great service, good food, comfortable bed. We are definitely coming back!

This is one of New Yorks great hotels - tradition, location, service, comfort to mention but a few of its attributes. Would I recommend - yes! Would I return- yes! The Carlyle might not be the trendiest place to stay but just oozes quality and style.

We have had another fabulous stay at the Carlyle. Our suite was spacious and extremely comfortable. The staff are always courteous and helpful. And the location is great. We enjoyed breakfast in the hotel dining room and drinks at Bemelman's Bar. Altogether a wonderful trip, and we hope to return.

We went on october 2015. We have been going for almost 30 years. Simply the warmest and best service you can have in NY. You feel simply at home. Breakfasts in the room and drinks at the Bar, a must !!!And if you need concierge service, the best.

Indeed, The Carlyle is quintessential New York, and The Cafe and Bemelman's Bar are worth the visit, but the hotel's rooms and service are disappointing for a hotel of this caliber and price. There was mold growing on the shower head and on the grout, the paint was peeling in the shower, and the spa tab did not work; the linens were average. I'm glad that I had a promotional rate; it's certainly not worth the regular rate. The neighborhood is the best, though: quiet, away from the tourists, and close to the park.

Our stay at the Carlyle was fabulous.....the hotel is, without doubt, the best address in New York. This iconic hotel represents luxury, classical chic & sophistication.. A suite with park view is essential as the views are amazing. A cocktail in Bemelmans Bar is mandatory & dinner in the Carlyle restaurant was a fabulous experience, the food is amazing. I have stayed in many luxury hotels worldwide & The Carlyle is in my top 5.....possibly top 3.

Have stayed here many many times. I love this hotel. The service the classic and timeless decor...the concierge team is spectacular. Feels like home away from home. They are great with my children as well. Perfect location.

Excellent and timeless service, food, and quality across the board....I have been coming to the Carlyle since I was a child and now my children enjoy the same tea service, comfortable rooms and on occasion suites that are tastefully appointed and cozy.

My wife surprised me with a trip to New York for my birthday. We were booked into the Carlyle on the upper east side. I cannot speak highly enough about the staff and the hotel itself. It was like entering a special zone where you were treated like royalty. The room we had was on the 10th floor with views over Central Park, It's style was vintage but everything was of superb quality. The Carlyle has a world famous cocktail bar and separate jazz club. Little touches like the lift men who were immaculately dressed including white gloves make it special. Special praise has to go to a Jamaican called Patrick. He gave us so many helpful tips and useful advice. Have a drink in the piano bar, full of New Yorkers but go early evening as there's a cover charge after 9 pmThe Carlyle is not the cheapest hotel in NY but the experience was the BEST.Totally recommended.

This hotel was a lovely stay. It is in a great location next to Central Park and many stores on Maddison. Staff is amazing and very accommodating. Room service is very efficient and the food is delicious. I did visit the restaurant several times and all times is was very slow. Waiting for a menu to delivering my check, the wait is too long for a hotel like this. I expect to be seated with a menu and for the check to be delivered shortly after dessert. This hotel is definitely capable of 5 stars if the service was a bit quicker. I would definitely recommend this hotel but I would not recommend eating here if you have less than an hour to spare.

I wanted to see what the Carlyle was all about so I booked a pedicure at the salon. The hotel is very old and could use a fresh coat of paint. You are greeted in the lobby by a gentleman. There is no bar area in the lobby. The elevators are manned. I am told it is 'Old New York'. I was not very impressed with the salon. It, like the hotel, appeared outdated.

There is a sophisticated, understated elegance about the Carlyle. It comes only with years of background in quiet service and attention to detail. It is not a brand spankin' newcomer to the NYC offerings. If you want flashy and new, look elsewhere. This is where celebrities who don't want attention can find soft spoken service, and olde money can be discreet.

For our 10-year wedding anniversary we chose to go to NYC. The Carlyle is situated perfectly in the Upper East Side (UES) of NYC. It is so quiet in the UES compared to midtown and within walking distance to great museums and Central Park. We will always choose the UES when visiting NYC. Check-in was seamless with Alessandro. We booked through AMEX Fine Hotels and Resorts and he described the amenities that came with the package. Sadly, there was no upgrade with this stay b/c they were fully booked (US Open). Before our arrival, we almost changed our reservation to a suite because The Carlyle was running a special on suites, but we liked the view that the Tower Room was going to provide so we left well enough alone. Our Tower Room had sweeping views of NYC and it was quite a sight at night. It was exactly the view we were looking for when booking this room. To our amazement the windows opened all the way. There were locks, but they were ineffective. We enjoyed a fall breeze in the room. It was beautiful, but I would have been a nervous wreck if we had children in the room. As previous posters have stated, both the room and bathroom were very small and a bit rundown. There was a tear/run in the carpet that ran the length of the room. Also, the bathroom's plumbing needed a tune up. The sink faucets leaked and the bath/shower were so slow to drain that while taking a shower you would have water fill up in the tub up to your knees. I couldn't wait to get back to our home steam shower to feel pampered again. Breakfast buffet was included in our rate and it was delicious. The staff was very kind and helpful. However, be prepared to pay $10 for a cappuccino that is not included in the Buffett. An Italian dining next to me was given a check for his coffee and he gave it back to the waiter saying "this is outrageous I just ordered cappuccino". I think they comped the charge. We ate dinner one evening at The Carlyle's restaurant to celebrate our 10th anniversary. The food was good. The place was empty and that was disappointing. It lacked the ambiance of which I was hoping. Our server was strange. Our server sounds like the server described in the previous poster's review. When this "captain" asked us what kind of wine we wanted to order he made the comments as follows: "I can tell which people have money. This one lady sat down and ordered a $200 bottle of wine and I was shocked I said, "you go girl"". It was instantly awkward. What was he saying? Did we not have money? Did the lady ordering the $200 bottle of wine not have money? Did he realize we were guests of The Carlyle? We got all dressed up for our special dinner. To ease the awkwardness we began to talk to him about our overseas travels to assure him we weren't just some random bums who just walked in off of the street. This dinner was the most disappointing part of our trip. There are too many restaurants in NYC and we won't be back to The Carlyle to dine for dinner. Also, one morning we ordered room service and the food was good, but the service wasn't up to par. The gentleman delivering our order got it wrong three times. He seemed visibly irritated which is unacceptable. Bemelman's was great! The David Budway Trio was outstanding. We would go back again when in NYC. Housekeeping was great! A kind housekeeper helped my husband and gave him a bandaid when he got a blister on the back of his ankle. She was heaven sent! Thanks a million!!! We enjoyed the elevator service. We didn't find that this service took too long. The men running the elevators were very informative, kind and helpful. Finally, we would like to thank the concierge who comped a bottle of Prosecco that I ordered when he learned it was our anniversary. He also sent up cheesecake. We so appreciated this kind gesture. All in all The Carlyle is beautiful and in the best location, but she is lacking in ways that if rectified can make this jewel sparkle again. I'm hoping that day isn't too far off.

Sadly this hotel really did not meet the usual Rosewood standard. Tired looking rooms, lacklustre staff, average food. Location was good though - very close to the park and lots of lovely shops and restaurants nearby. I won't be returning. NYC has much better hotels to offer.

Check inI hold a special place in my heart for the Carlyle. My mother and I stayed there for a week on my first trip to New York in 1974. It is an elegant icon of the upper east side and a bye gone era. I saw Bobbie Short there several times. So when my wife and I decided to do an east coast tour for our 25th wedding anniversary, we splurged on the Carlyle for 2 nights rather than impose on friends. While it is still an icon, it is a bit long in the tooth and does not deliver the value one would expect for the price you pay. The lobby is still the same spectacular art deco place with shinny black marble floors. The front desk clerk was polite and checked us in efficiently. She explained all the extra benefits and amenities we were to receive for having booked through Amex Platinum Travel. This is a great deal if you have a Platinum Card. They give you an upgraded room (if available), free breakfast for 2 ($70), a $100 spa credit, one night’s cover charge waived at the Bemelmen’s Bar ($50) and 4pm checkout. However, the Spa was closed due to “unforeseen circumstances”. My mind is still running wild thinking what those might be. She told us that we were receiving an upgraded and recently renovated room. A charming bellman took us to our room. They still have elevator operators despite having automatic elevators. It is an elegant touch but it can make for a long wait in the morning.The RoomThe upgraded, recently renovated room turned out to be tiny, about 180 sq ft or 12 x 15’ exclusive of bathroom and closet. Dominated by a king bed, it also had a desk, bureau and chair. It was tight, cramped quarters and actually a challenge for 2 people to navigate.Within less than a minute after the bellman left, my wife discovered the sink had some small food particles stuck to it. Upon further inspection, we both notice that it was covered in soap scum. Additionally, the shower floor looked dirty especially around the edges. A maid showed up promptly and cleaned the sink and scrubbed the shower. It turned out that problem with the shower was a poor grouting job. Candidly, if a contractor tiled my shower in that fashion, I would ask him to redo it. The reason for the soap scum became apparent upon first use of the sink. It would not drain. We notified the front desk on our way to dinner and the problem was resolved by the time we returned.After this first experience, I could not help myself. I checked under the bureau and the floor of the closet. Both were very dusty. The Carlyle holds itself out to be a super luxury hotel and I hold it to that standard. What you would over look at a Best Western, is frankly inexcusable here. Someone needs to have a serious talk with housekeeping.One of the oddest things in the room was the light switching arrangement. One switch by the door controlled the overhead light, both bedside lights and a wall plug between the windows. The problem with this arrangement is that if you want to turn on the bedside lights, the bright overhead light has to be on. This means that you have to get out of bed to turn of the bedside and overhead lights. Oh, if you happened to be charging a phone or computer using the plugs, they go off as well when you kill the lights. What electrical genius thought that one up?Finally, the thermostat is a bit antiquated. You not only have to set the desired temp but you have to determine if you need AC or heat. So if you want the room at 70 and it’s 76, you need to be sure to flip it to AC. Otherwise you continue to bake. Once we were instructed on its use, the room temp was fine. The bed was very comfortable and they use great linens and towels. Also, the room was fairly quite. We could not hear any street noise. However, we could hear doors and even quite conversation in the halls. Thank heavens our neighbors were quite. Did I mention that we were paying $765 a night pretax for all this?BreakfastFrankly, the breakfast buffet is sublime and if we were paying for it, it would be worth the $35 cost. Great smoked salmon, cream cheese and bagels. This is the only buffet where the scrambled eggs were moist and perfectly done. Even the oatmeal was excellent, another rarity on a buffet. There were excellent fresh fruit and juices. The breads and muffins were top notch. The coffee was great. The service was, well, iconic. You know you are not in Kansas anymore. Bemelmen’s BarSimply wonderful! The jazz trio was superb; just a joy to listen to. Best of all, they played at perfect volume. You could have a conversation and hear the band. It was an elegant crowd with several beautifully dressed women. It is the quintessential hotel bar. Obviously, it is expensive but worth it.Café CarlyleThis is a great New York supper club and was home to Bobbie Short for about 30 years. It hosts some very talented, intimate acts. We saw John Pitzerelli, an amazing guitarist and his wife. She has a beautiful voice and together they make wonderful music. It was a charming show. The only gripe I have is that I think if you are staying at the hotel, you should be able to make a reservation at the bar (less expensive) as well as a table. If we don’t show, charge us. And did I mention that we were paying $765 a night? My charming wife was able to negotiate a table as the bar was full so it worked out. It was a wonderful way to spend our 25th. Again, it ain’t cheap. But if you have never been, go once. There is no place like it. ConclusionThe Carlyle is still an elegant New York icon and I am glad that we returned for our anniversary. It was very special. The Hotel sent is a small congratulatory cheese cake that was excellent. They also credited the $100 spa credit to our total bill as the spa was closed. But I have to say that the room was disappointing for the price and its condition was inexcusable. Did I tell you it was $765 a night? I suspect there are issues with the building that make renovations very challenging. It has to be over 75 years old. Nonetheless, I know there are other 5 star hotels in the area that are hundreds of dollars less expensive. It breaks my heart to do it but I rate the hotel 2 stars. I do this because, to me, there is no such thing as an average super luxury hotel. It either lives up to its billing or it’s below average. It is not on the same level as the Ritz Paris. I would not discourage someone from staying there but be forewarned some rooms do not deliver the value for which you will pay. I would not pay $765 for our room again. But it’s still an icon.

It sickens me to detail a terrible situation which I experienced while at the Carlyle. But the way I was treated after my stay and then the insincere follow-up by management has been insulting At the outset, I will credit the hotel manager for refunding one night's stay for my nightmare of a visit. But beyond that, I have experienced nothing but feckless attempts to remediate what should never have happened. As a long-time patron of the Carlyle and as a very lucky traveller who has experienced memorable stays at five star hotels for over twenty years, I cannot believe this great hotel would be so cruel to a guest and lie about any attempt to rectify their disgrace.As a resident of Manhattan, I have always considered the Carlyle my go-to place for celebratory dinners in their beautiful restaurant and I've spent countless hours enjoy drinks and piano music in the Bemelman's Bar. Whenever a guest comes to New York or when I meet a friend for lunch, the Carlyle has always been my first choice. Thanksgivings, graduation lunches and even my husband's proposal of marriage were all at the Carlyle.Recently I had a huge flood in my apartment and needed to relocate. Or course, I booked a suite at the Carlyle and moved in for five or six nights as an immediate and temporary solution. While I residence, I planned a subsequen one-month stay to coincide with the extensive work needed in my apartment. During this five/six night stay, I experienced an number of minor disappointments such as the shoddy condition of the furnishings in the living room (where a desk drawer pull fell off I to my hands (for example) and the lack of amenities I typically receive at world-class hotels. We had no water one evening, the TVs didn't work because the hotel depends solely on local cable service, some of the towels were ragged, and so on. The size and layout of the suite was appealing and the bathroom was new despite no hot water. One evening my daughter, son and a friend went down to Bemelman's bar for drinks and some light refreshments. ( The bar offers some delicious food options as well as amazing cocktails. Furthermore, the different pianists who play are excellent and a pleasure to listen to). For no conceivable reason, other than my family not dressed as sleekly as some other guests, were singled out and treated in a deeply humiliating manner. The server, brimming with sanctimony and judgement, ignored my family in such an extreme way, it was almost comical if not so downright saddening and humiliating. You cannot imagine how much they were treated like unwanted dirt. I do not exaggerate. As a life-long New Yorker I Know a thing or two about mean and dismissive waiters who serve guests based upon their Louis Vuitton handbags and cashmere sweaters. It was not my [grown] children's imagination when they came back to,the suite with deep dejection apparent. I asked them what had happened and they told me about the poor service that indicated they were absolutely targeted by the waiter. In fact, once he learned they were in-house guests, the waiter was shocked and his attitude changed. The waiter judged my family based upon snobbery. By the way, no group should be sneered at, ever! When I reported this to management, I was scolded for suggesting our waiter mistreated my family. They indicated I had a prejudice against the waiter and was making baseless claims! I couldn't believe it! I was not looking to get the guy fired: I was just communicating humiliating and uncalled for treatment which, despite a large bill for drinks and food, had caused sadness. The managers determined I was to be labeled a trouble maker based solely upon the same waiter's own version of the truth Secondly, one morning when my son needed to leave at seven AM the door knob to our suite fell off. If I had not caught the door before it was closed, we would have been trapped. I called the front desk and they were dismayed. They said someone would be up immediately to repair it. After we had breakfast and we returned to our room, at about 8:45, no one had repaired it. A nasty, aggressive engineer told us it was not his job to repair the door: that task was the carpenter's job and he didn't start work until 9:00am. [I would also like to add, as an aside, each morning when we tried to leave at 7:00-7:30, the manned elevators did not respond to our call for the elevator. We had to call the front desk to ask them to send the elevator man to our floor. More than once we were told he couldn't respond immediately because he was getting a cab for another guest. Now, this isn't an Inn in a little town. This is a luxury hotel in a major city claiming to operate with full service 24 hours a day. This was another thing I didn't complain about.] when the world's nastiest and most aggressive unapologetic engineer told us, basically, too bad I don't fix doors, I lost my patience. However, after I complained, the manager told me I had accused the hotel of endangering my family and that the hotel created a liability. I never said such a thing. I was treated with a haughty attitude and was basically, once again, called a liar. After this debacle, and be use we had extended our stay for another night, my husband called to ask for a small and reasonable discount for our final night's stay. We had not received any apologies or "bottles of champagne" so my husband felt this would not have been treated as an outrageous request. Well, the manager basically called my husband greedy. I know what he was thinking, betraying a terrible prejudice based upon his false assumption. Nevertheless, I proceeded with my plan to stay at the Carlyle for my subsequent month-long stay (which would have created revenue of $1500 per night.) one might ask why? Well, the Carlyle is still the Carlyle and after years of fun and festive occasions, including having used their event space for a number of catered luncheons, we just chalked it up to a horrible one-off. Plus it is utterly conveniently located, close to my apartment.On the Sunday night, two nights prior to our check-in date, I received a call at home from an irate manager from the Carlyle. He said "due to your complaints, you are not welcome at the Carlyle and we will not honor your reservation." I was shocked. The manager berated me and refused to listen to anything I had to say. He acted as if I had behaved in a materially offensive way or had destroyed property or had made any sort of a scene at the reception or in the lobby. I made a one or two agitated phone calls out of frustration and disbelief but my claims were valid, they were handled inappropriately and I was out of patience.. My reaction was never over the top and I never treated anyone on the hotel staff as remotely poorly as the waiter had treated my family. The manager accused me of berating his front office staff. This is not true. Now this manager was berating me in the most base fashion until I was I tears. I now was left stranded for a month' sl long stay. I had to evacuate my home within two days and now I had no place to stay. I was told I was "banned for life" from the Carlyle. He called me some sort of racist (which was absurd, an insult and a lie...especially since I, myself, have experienced discrimination and ignorance.) i told him he was absolutely incorrect and I had not even encountered any opportunity by which such a remark could have even entertained. I had made my reservation through Platinum Amex. He further insulted me by telling me if I didn't cancel through Amex, he would charge me as a no-show even though he was the one cancelling our reservation. And to top it all off, he told me he was calling Platinum Amex to "tell on" me. When I asked him, as a gentlemen, to refrain from adding to my embarrassment by refraining from making such a call, he told me it was his right to do so and he would.Well, not long after my stay a manger did contact me by email. After a few email exchanges, when he did keep his word and refund us for one might of our stay, he dropped the matter: you see, he offered to speak with me on the telephone to get the details. After what used to be referred to as telephone tag, he never did. I called his office, as instructed, but he was never available. Then I would receive another email asking me for my availability and then he never called. And so on...well, it grieves me to no end that my thirty year relationship with the Carlyle ended in such a terrible and nightmarish manner. I pass there several times a week. I'm so sad we wont be having our traditional Thanksgiving dinner there: the last meal I had with my mother before she died was at the Carlyle. I missed my chance to take my daughter and her new husband to Bemelman's for champagne while listening to the piano (I myself am a pianist myself and especially enjoy these first rate performers) I will never understand why a polite, dignified, well-traveled, educated woman was disgraced by a man who twisted everything that happened to,his own purposes.
user_name:
Alexandra M
New York City, New York

review_body: I stayed on the 31st floor and had an amazing view of the east side and a bit of the Metropolitan museum of art. Even my bathroom had a view! My room wasn't as outdated as the other reviews lead me to expect, my room was more than pleasant and while it did have a sort of "older" sense of charm it still seemed updated. The bathroom was really cool and covered and mirrors, but the only downside to that is that during the sunrise, thanks to the window, the morning sunlight reflected off of the mirrored walls sort of makes you feel like an ant under a magnifying glass. Blackout curtains in the bathroom would be a good move! The customer service was outstanding and do try the bar and restaurant, they are so worth it.

My fiancé and I stayed again at the Carlyle Hotel and we weren't disappointed. We stayed on the 22nd floor in a corner room with gorgeous views of the city. The hotel was fully booked but we were upgraded to a beautifully appointed room with a king bed (which we requested at the time of booking but could not be guaranteed). The bathroom was slightly smaller than our former room on the 32nd floor but was meticulous.Once again we were greeted with a beautiful arrangement of roses and late in the evening chocolates were brought to the room. The Carlyle continues to be old New York at its best. Bemelmans bar was hopping with a mix of a young hip crowd and older elegance.The staff was gracious particularly the elevator operators whom I've read in previous reviews were not given the credit they deserve. This is a classic graceful hotel and it is wonderful to walk in and not experience every modern amenity known to man.....including modernizing the elevators which you can find everywhere else in town.This is a luxury hotel and for the best experience it is best on the higher floors with gorgeous city views.The breakfast was delicious ...yes expensive but we expected it.My recommendation is to expect top quality ....know your expectations in advance and enjoy this brilliant experience....and yes a little research on the rooms and location will only enhance your delightful stay.Finally.....the location is excellent particularly if you love to stroll Madison Ave. and enjoy lovely spontaneous outdoor/indoor dining along the way.
user_name:
eoc109
New York City, New York

review_body: I booked the Superior King with the Madison Ave. view 350-400 SF. Ran $650 per night. The view was wonderful I had lots of windows and I enjoyed having them all of the shades open. The bathroom was teeny tiny and shower/tub combo. Felt very constricted. Luckily I was staying by myself. I did enjoy the Kiels bath products! The room was small but well appointed. It could use a little updating though. The bed was very comfortable and the internet worked very well. I had a meeting upper east so the hotel was convenient and of course the iconic Bemelmans Bar is why you hang out here. Rosewood Hotel group does a nice job. The rooms could use a face lift and larger bathrooms would be a great addition. I did enjoy my stay but its no St.Regis….Location is great and it's my favorite part of town.

We imagine we aren’t the only ones for whom planning a New York trip calls to mind the Manhattan imagined for us by Edith Wharton or Truman Capote or Nora Ephron. This tony Upper East Side landmark is your chance to live in a literary rendition of the city, all Deco classicism and Jazz Age glamour that’s also the height of thoroughly modern sophistication. Though the fact that The Carlyle houses one of the city’s most precious gems would be reason enough for us to stay, plush designer suites, cozy, music-centric restaurants and one of the best concierges around ensures there is plenty more to love. - Katie Drake, Gather-Mag.com

It's definitely a new and unfortunately lower standard with the new owners of Rosewood Hotels. From the first impression at the front desk with attractive but totally naive and unprofessional young clerks to the faded guest room furniture, it's gone downhill. The beautiful dining room no longer has a dress code so many would be trendies dine in wrinkled T-shirts and bluejeans. Service staff there also failed to notify us the breakfast plan on our Amex Fine Hotels and Resorts program was for the buffet only, not the ala carte which we ordered with the same items as the buffet.

I was on a two night business trip to New York and could not have had a better hotel. Staff were extremely attentitive and friendly, rooms were fantastic and I gad a most wonderful meal and cabaret in cafe carlyle, with buster pointdexter (New York dolls)

This hotel's history and reputation carry it a long way. Roger Federer has a suite named after him (and stays here), Woody Allen comes to play the piano Monday nights, but most celebrities, indeed most of the clientele you'll encounter at the Carlisle are likely to be elderly. The downstairs piano bar and jazz lounge are intimate and lively, in an understated way. You will encounter guests with dogs which is not for everyone - they let canines stay in all rooms. Location one block back from Central Park is terrific (Museums and Madison Ave), however you'll be very lucky to get a spectacular view from your room as the vast majority of this hotel's rooms are below the top of the buildings on the opposite side of the street: rooms with 'good' views start at $1,300 a night according to front desk. Service: no complaints about front desk, bell desk (energetic) and concierge (efficient). Restaurant staff however on more than one occasion got too pushy about the gratuity part of the breakfast bill where there is not just a gratuity line for the server but also one for the captain.The hotel has some limousines which will take you as far as 57th street for free (gratuity expected for the driver of course), but sadly one of these drivers spoiled the hotel's reputation by making us feel we really, really needed to look after him if he was to oblige by taking us a few streets further than 57th Street, but he was adamant he would not come off Madison Ave, so he was knowingly going to leave us 5 Avenues from where we needed to be, high heels etc. The look of disgust on his face when we asked him just 5 blocks from the hotel to stop so we could get in a taxi that had pulled up alongside us was unforgettable. We were helping him get back to serve other guests, and he still expected a tip when he had offered lousy service… welcome to NYC. But the main drawback is the elevator frequency. The hotel was running at 100% occupancy when we stayed, and the white-gloved elevator operators could simply not cope at peak times… nobody should have to wait between 3 and 7 minutes (no exaggeration) for an elevator in any 5star property. For this reason this hotel is no good for busy working professionals.

The service is unequaled. I love that the property is spotless. I have been staying there for 50 years and never have seen a spot of dust! Every room looks fresh and is comfortable. I have tried other hotels over the years and always regretted the decision.

My room was beautifully furnished and immaculately clean. I liked that the room was a little more creative than many minimalist luxury hotels and included some quirky accent pieces. I even had a small balcony from which I could see midtown and Central Park, which was simply stunning. The bathroom was a good size and the shower was powerful. It was the small touches, though, that impressed me the most. The large, walk-in closet; the Kiehls bathroom products; the thoughtful turndown service; the extra-plush slippers.Throughout my (short) stay I found the staff to be courteous and professional.The only criticism I have is that to charge $15/day for wifi in this day and age, particularly given that the room was close to $1000/night including taxes, is completely unacceptable. The rest of the experience was refined, and by contrast the pay-per-day internet system felt tacky and outdated. The Carlyle is not for budget-conscious travellers. However, wifi-aside, I thought it was lovely. Without question the nicest hotel room I have stayed in in New York.

We returned to this hotel with our children after a great stay some years ago. Oh dear, how it has changed. The first night our air con was faulty and made such a noise that we were unable to sleep at all. We reported it in the morning and were told that someone would look at it but no apology or other comment was given.After a long day out we returned to find our room had not been done, beds still unmade etc. We called housekeeping who came and then said they might as well do turn down to save them coming back and plunged the room into darkness.That was the last turndown we had in four days though the room was at least done in the morning on the other days. My husband had joined us from a business trip and given in some laundry - 2 days later there was still no sign and when it returned a pair of trousers were missing. Again no apology - just an insistence they were never sent even though there was a charge for them on the bill. They arrived the evening before we left with no explanation, refund or apology. The front desk staff were distinctly disinterested and we even witnessed one girl rolling her eyes to heaven after a complaint from a guest in front of us. Deeply unprofessional. The hotel was full of tennis players as it was during the US Open and the manager was certainly on hand to attend to them but not the other guests, many of whom were having similar experiences. On a plus point the restaurant was good, delicious brunch on Sunday in particular, but we were overcharged twice on our bill though this was rectified when pointed out. Porters were also extremely helpful and charming.All in all a sad demise of what used to be a grand hotel. Have just got back from another stay in New York at a different hotel which only served to emphasise how far this one has fallen.

I have stayed in the property in the past, and it was always flawless, from service, to food to rooms, nothing bad to say about it, but last year I had a terrible experience involving the hotel.Someone used my credit card in that property without my consent, over US$13,000.00 in debits there, I immediately contacted the property, and was advised to dispute it with my credit card company, which I did. Since this was only a small part of an Identity Theft case I suffered last year, the case has been dragging since, and the CC company states that the Property considered the charge valid, since the card was swiped there.I was so frustrated with this been going on for a year, that about 2 months ago I took a trip to NY, to visit the hotel, and inquire about the investigation, this is one of the last debits I have yet not been reimbursed for. I was greeted by the accounts receivable manager, that was always very courteous and helpful, and when inquired why they let someone use a credit card in a different name, I was told it was hotel policy not to ask for ID's, since they don't want their valuable guests to feel uncomfortable. She has been kind enough to forward my case to their executive team, which I am thankful for, but I still haven't heard back from anyone else. I would be really pleased if someone in Management could get back to me, so that we could finally come with a positive solution for both sides!Thank you!FS

Yes it is dated but it is comfortable and welcoming. Slightly old fashioned and needing an update. The staff are very good and cannot do enough for you. For a NY hotel it was quiet, not even any noise from the corridor/street/upstairs (amazing with the wood floors).We normally stay in FiDi so this was quite a change for us.

The Carlyle is my favourite in New York! It's location, the history, the style, the service, the spa, the suites and THE BREAKFAST! Not to mention the elevator rides that always result in a great discussion or the late night drink in the Bowery bar that can result in anything ;) Try to get a room as high up in the tower as possible, the views are fantastic!

The rooms are so old , I had a suite which had a small kitchen with appliances from the 70's and zero functionality! The doors are so thin you can hear everything that happens everywhere, the mattress wasn't comfortable , the towels were thin and not soft. Definitely not a top nyc hotel. Staff doesn't really make an effort I was appalled by the bad quality and the high price.

The hotel is not posh like the newer places in New York city, but what it lacks in new and shiny, it more than makes up for it with the small touches such as plush slippers at your bedside or a lift attendant who greets you with a smile. The higher the floor the better the view of central park and the sprawling city. Its location is a little off the beaten path in a way that you would desire, but a quick walk to adventures galore. My wife and I had a great time exploring the neighborhood.

I have had the opportunity to stay at the Carlyle Hotel in excess of 15 times so far in 2015 and I have some impressions on this Fantastic Hotel and it's Awesome staff I would like to share.First, it goes without saying that the hotel itself is beautiful. The lobby is gorgeous, as is the Carlyle Restaurant, the Café Carlyle and Bemelmans Bar. The live music at Bemelmans is always superb and I regard Tim and his team as the best bartenders in NY.I have had the opportunity to stay in standard rooms as well as suites. In each case I have yet to find anything but beautifully decorated, spacious rooms, some with spectacular views of Manhattan or Central Park. The rooms are also kept extremely clean thanks to a first class housekeeping team. Another of the Carlyle's greatest strengths is it's superb staff. What makes the staff so special is that there is a consistency in the level of service provided across all members of the team. From the moment you pull into the Carlyle parking garage (which is located conveniently steps from the front entrance) you are treated with warmth and respect. The parking lot attendants are friendly and diligent.The doormen always have a smile or kind word. The front desk staff is top notch, Moamed, Larry, Marina and others always provide me with a warm greeting, "Welcome back Mr. Bick". The team at the front desk excels at making repeat clients feel special and welcome. They take their jobs seriously and make it a point to chat with me when I arrive, they make the experience personal for me and I appreciate it. Paul, who frequently helps me get my bags up to my room is great.The elevator operators are also always warm and courteous, they recognize the fact that I stay at the hotel frequently and always say "welcome back"Patrick Sewell my "Guest Relationship Manager" is another standout. The fact that he makes it a point to greet me when I arrive and talk with me for a few minutes makes my experience at the Carlyle very special. Over the past eight months the fact that Patrick has taken the time to get to know me (and my family) has made me feel a sense of home when I am at the Carlyle. Patrick is a terrific people person who fosters loyalty amongst the Carlyle clients. When Patrick is not at the hotel I have had the pleasure of working with Sonal Nayyar. Sonal also excels at her job and is extremely friendly, polished and diligent.In summary, the Carlyle is a world class hotel with a world class team. They excel at making their client base feel special, they personalize the guest experience and reward loyalty. This is not true of so many hotels these days, that is what differentiates the Carlyle and makes it so special.
user_name:
Ross B
New York City, New York

review_body: My wife and I were married at the Rosewood Hotel Georgia in Vancouver, and wanted to try more Rosewood properties as the level of service in Vancouver was top notch. Although we tend to stay at more modern or newly renovated hotels (Peninsula in Paris & Chicago, Hotel Arts in Barcelona, Mandarin Oriental in Boston and Vega), we were excited to experience the old school charm of the Carlyle.We arrived around 8:30am after a red-eye and the front desk informed us that some guests had checked out early and that they should be able to get us checked in as soon as housekeeping was through with them. Rather than change clothes and start touring the city, we decided to have breakfast close by (Sant Ambroeus) so that we could properly unpack and freshen up before heading out. After breakfast (maybe 10:30am), we came back to the Carlyle, and front desk advised us that they were still getting the rooms ready. So, we sat in the lobby, and caught up on emails, etc. At 11:30am, we checked again and received the same answer. So, we decided to get some fresh air and walked around the neighbourhood to check out a few of the fitness studios that we would be frequenting over the next few days. We came back at 1:30pm, and still the room wasn't ready. This was starting to get annoying. We had been walking around the heat of NYC in our jeans and jacket and used up half a day of our 5 day stay just hanging around. It would have been fine if front desk had told us that the room wouldn't have been ready until 3pm (normal check-in). Then, we would have changed into our shorts and headed to midtown or Soho and come back in the afternoon. But, the expectation was set up that it would be ready around 9ish or 10ish.We finally got checked in around 3pm. The room was OK, very well kept, but as expected, very old school. Probably due to the outstanding service we received at Peninsula Paris a few weeks ago, my wife has developed very high expectations when it comes to hotels, so she provided feedback to the front desk about our experience in the morning. We received an apology at that point, but that was about it.But, the next day, we received a nice gift (chocolate and a bottle of wine) and a written apology from Sonal (guest relations manager) in our room and that they would do whatever they could to make the rest of our stay enjoyable. Then, on day 2, they upgraded us to a bigger corner room with better views. We ran into Sonal at the spa, and she's got to be one of the most friendly and professional hotel managers we've come across (and that's a lot).So, although our stay started off with a bad taste in our mouth, the Carlyle went over and beyond our expectations to make amends. We were also very impressed with the Kiehls products in the rooms. We haven't been in the restaurant yet, but notice that it is quite busy, despite not having a lot of visibility from the street so I'm thinking it must be very good. Would definitely recommend the Carlyle to others, especially for the service.

This Hotel has the charme and feeling of a bygone era. From the Lift attendant in the elevators (day and night) to the decor of the rooms, you forget that you are in 2015. Of course this may be annoying to some people that like the supermodern facilities with state of the art amenities, but in my opinion, once in a while it is nice to experience a property like this. Rooms and bathrooms have an old style look, but they have been updated, so you have all you need in a 5 stars hotel. Location in the Upper East Side is second to none, one block from Central PArk, not far from Metropolitan and Guggenheim Museums. While you stay, pay a visit to the Cafe Carlyle or to Bemelmans Bar for a jazz performance, if you are lucky Woody Allen may be performing as he is a regular. Service is very attentive.

Like walking into a 1930's movie - this hotel has quiet, pleasant rooms, the upper floors have wonderful views over the city, along Madison or over to Central Park. The food is delicious and the staff couldn't be more helpful or informative.

We are regular visitors to NYC, having always previously stayed in the financial district. We decided to stay at the Carlyle for a long weekend as a complete change as we wanted to experience an alternative location, whist retaining somewhere quiet and residential.The Carlyle certainly has much pomp and ceremony. The service was good although at times it did feel as if three people were doing the job of one just to extract more tips from you.The lift men were a throw back to a different time, although a novelty, completely unnecessary.The room was certainly considerably bigger than I had expected, and had the feeling that it had been a studio apartment at one time. There was a small kitchenette (which was massively in need of modernisation), and a couple of walk in wardrobes. The bathroom was small (and mirrored on every wall which was a little strange), it was a shame that some of the space from the wasted walkin wardrobe hadn't been shared with the bathroom to make it more comfortable.I had concerns regarding how noisy the room would be as it had wooden floorboards and interconnecting door (my pet hate), it was however very quite.The house keeping was a little hit and miss and was obviously dependent on who was doing it.I guess it is typical of this type of hotel in NYC, but I did miss not having the usual coffee machine in the room for a cup of coffee first thing in the morning which in my experience is typical of the more business hotels in NYC.

Our room was charming, the staff, extremely helpful, and the hotel feels like a timeless and classic apartment building. The breakfast/dining room is beautiful and the food is delicious. The bar is famous and a great place to listen to live music and have a drink in a historical and magical setting. An absolute must if you are in NYC.

Old world touches like a manned elevator, wonderful piano bar with great talent performing live, delicious buffet breakfasts and very spacious rooms and bathrooms. Definitely our hotel in New York City from now on!

This hotel is my favorite in NYC. The rooms are quite large for NYC, and the service is exceptional. It is low key but very refined. One block away from central park and located on Madison Ave for shopping.

The Carlyle is for me one of the best hotels in NYC. I come often and I enjoy every stay. It has this out of time ambiance with lift operator and old school and outstanding service. Last time, I was there with my new born baby and a nanny. The hotel was helpful and caring. I highly recommend it. Needless to say the rooms were super clean, the bed very comfortable and the breakfast delicious. With the Plaza, the Ritz on the Park and the Pier it's one of one of the best high end hotel in NYC.

We have stayed here before and the hotel staff still goes out of their way to make your stay great. The rooms are beautiful and housekeeping does a fantastic job keeping the rooms clean. Love that they have the elevator operators. Patrick in Customer Relations was wonderful. We were celebrating our Wedding Anniversary and the Champagne and dessert sent to the room made it even more special.The restaurant's wait staff was friendly, courteous and prompt and the high tea was fabulous as well.In Bemelmans Bar Sharif and Laurie are the best! You always get excellent service and they are very helpful and friendly. They really make your stay even more enjoyable.
user_name:
gymtandrink
Point Pleasant Beach, New Jersey

review_body: We stayed at the Carlyle while my dad was a patient at New York Hospital Cornell. It was a stressful time so the fact that the staff at the Carlyle were so welcoming and accommodating made a difficult time more bearable. The room service was wonderful - delicious, hot , and again served with a smile. I would not hesitate to recommend this hotel and if we have a need in the future, this is where we will be staying.
user_name:
Elaine B
Ocean, New Jersey, United States

review_body: I have stayed at The Carlyle a few times and every time I return it feels like I am "going home." The staff are so welcoming and good at remembering who you are and what you have done that day. Everything about the hotel is so wonderful and enchanting. Highly recommend.

We are from out of country and have been fortunate to visit NY now three times, staying in four different hotels, three of which were luxury hotels amongst the highest category, and price point - out of all these, the Carlyle easily exceeded the others.Here's the reasons why:- exterior to the hotel is welcoming, pleasing in appearance, NY feel to the exterior- staff is exceptional - friendly, professional - never patronizing, always helpful- the decor is not off-putting, no offensive art or nudity on the walls, style is tasteful- classic fittings and finish - the hotel is modernized, clean, and classic- bedroom is roomy, courtyard view is silent in busy NY - wonderful respite- beds are comfortable, bedding wonderful - a great night's sleep- room layout is thoughtful and well-planned - families now easily accommodated with two-bedded rooms- location is accessible to sites in a wonderful neighbourhood with lots to doWe'd try to stay with the Carlyle before but had not been able to owing to the previous lack of rooms with two beds for a family of four. However, we will NOT stay anywhere else having experienced this level of classic service and lodging in Manhattan.What a wonderful hotel - couldn't they just be everywhere? Even room service was faultless, the cleaners expert, the staff, the hotel - easily the best stay we've had, and we researched just about every hotel under the sun before flying into the Big Apple.

The Carlyle Hotel is an experience. Gorgeous hotel. It is not cheap, but we got the MSK price which helped- my dad is getting treated there. Beautiful rooms, not all have a pantry, (kitchen) but most have a powder room which is a half bathroom. (Very useful) and we stayed at a one bedroom with a king bed, my mom said it was the most comfortable ever. I paid for a cot which was also comfortable. For the pantry, we paid $36 to remove all the alcohol and got a microwave which served as a kitchen. We also got plates and utensils. We couldn't always go out so it was great to have 24 hour room service, pricey but delicious breakfasts. I used the 24-hour gym too which was not big but had what I needed. Daily maid plus turndown service also great, can't get that everywhere these days. If you want to feel special and get pampered this is the right place, it was also quiet and very close to Central Park, also great.

Pat and I stayed here several years ago accompanied by another couple from our Island. It is truly one of the outstanding hotels in the United States. Rooms are superb, bar is historic, and restaurant is exceptional. Perfectly located.

This hotel offers a truly gracious experience from the wonderful, quiet neighborhood to the beautiful lobby with gorgeous fresh flowers, to the spacious rooms with nice toiletries. The staff is attentive and helpful. Great play to stay to for its charm and opportunities for relaxation.

Home to our favourite Upper East Side cocktail bar with Bemelman's famous illustrations and the most divine service we've experienced in a hotel for quite some time. They have really mastered old world Manhattan here and maintained it. A historic building full of warmth and chic. The rooms are a tad tired but the location and the overall ambience is lovely. Close proximity to UES shops and Central Park. Not ideal for businessmen - this is definitely for a romantic couple or family looking to explore museums and galleries. Close to great restaurants and wonderful bars. A delightful stay!

I stayed two nights at this hotel. The shabbiness of the hotel wasn't the worst part of my stay. After I booked, the hotel sent me a questionnaire regarding my preferences. This is their attempt at perceived personal service. I arrived at the hotel at 3 pm and was told I had a room on a low floor because the higher floor rooms were not cleaned. I said I would wait for a higher floor as it was a priority request of mine. I waited. The young lady I was dealing with approached me after 10 minutes and said the only room available was the original on the low floor. Why? They're not cleaning the other rooms today. What! I did get a high floor after speaking to manager.Other issues with this property:Worn rooms. I paid for a deluxe king. Can't imagine what a standard looked like.Hot. The elevators were the worst. The air conditioning was poor.Internet $15/day for paying customers. People off street can go to bar and get free internet codeFront desk most poorly trained group I've ever encountered. Dont stay here. There are so many other hotels in NYC that deserve your money.

I always enjoy my stays at the Carlyle Hotel. I come here every year for a set of meetings and always look forward to it. The Carlyle is one of those hotels where the staff remembers you year after year. The old-world charm of the hotels extends from the entrance on 76th street up to your room. The hallways are covered with antique prints for example and wonder tapestries grace some of the public areas. The rooms are spacious and well appointed. Each one has its own flavor. I love the high flow, high power showers and always ask for a bar of soap to take home with me as I greatly enjoy it's scent. The staff is polite and helpful. If there is a problem, they take care of it. While you are there, you should make sure to stop in a Bellmans Bar for a cocktail or scotch over the weekend, you won't regret it with the live jazz playing in the background.I'd live here if I could.

We've stayed at several Rosewood hotels and they have all had excellent service. What sets this one apart is the need for a complete gut job on the interior. Age has it's charm but this place really needs some serious work. We had a suite and the main bathroom was tiny. It had a single sink with a bidet right next to the tub/shower. I had to have my husband help me out of the shower because I couldn't get my foot over the tub without falling on the bidet. The tub was a jacuzzi style so the sides were higher. The furniture looked very worn, however, the bed was fairly comfortable. It was very clean and the maids were very friendly. In fact, all the staff were superior. The food was top notch as well. I can't imagine that Prince Wm and family stayed here. What must they have thought of NY? There must be some other better rooms. Our view was of the air conditioning system and the parking garage. We love the neighborhood and would stay here again if we could be assured of a better room.

From the beginning to the end, the staff was superb-- the front desk, lobby and elevator folks, cleaning crew, restaurant and room service, the concierge(s), and everyone we met. They treated us exceptionally well, and my whole family received top notch service.The decor was a wonderful art deco return to the 1930's, and this pervades the lobby to the rooms like a nostalgic stroll into period luxury. We loved the appointments, the art, and the decor, all of which were a significant influence on our choice to stay here.The one blemish on this otherwise lovely experience, was the excessive mold in our shower and tub area. It was in the caulking around the shower door, as well as the tile grout in various places. I asked for this to be addressed at the front desk, and it was not. Perhaps the only opportunity to fix it was to put us in another room that was not available, but I still think more should have been done to address this situation-- since mold in a bathroom is below the dignity of a hotel of this caliber.We would certainly consider staying at the Carlyle again, but I would like to know that our experience with mold was just an unfortunate anomaly, coupled with an unfortunate oversight in addressing it for us.

Stayed here for one night only at Easter and had a good time. Old world charm and good level of service, especially the unexpected lift porters. Public areas were much better than the room which was a bit old and crusty, but still nice. Absolutely fab location and not too far away from the action.

We booked the Carlyle for a Mother/Daughter trip. From the time we walked through the front door we were greeted warmly at every turn. The room was comfortable. We stayed on the 31st floor and the street noise was far in the distance. The room had twin beds and the view was beautiful. We had a late night snack in the Gallery, outside of Bemelman's Bar. We also ordered late night room service of raspberry and coconut gelato. Although other reviewers have criticized the elevator service, we loved it. We never waited for an elevator and the friendly elevator operators were a charming addition to the overall nostalgic experience. Additionally, we had a fantastic breakfast in the dining room on our last day when we were leaving for the airport. The choices on the buffet were extraordinary compared with other hotels. Overall, my daughter and I were able to step back in time and enjoy this historic hotel. We walked through Central Park, saw a play, and window-shopped for hours. The Carlyle made our Mother/Daughter trip a warm and wonderful experience.

My husband is not a fan of NY because he is always there on business and stays near Times Square. I was thinking if I could get him to another part of town he might like it a little better. The Carlyle was just what the doctor ordered. The view from our tower room was awesome—we could not stop looking or taking pictures. The bed was super comfy, linens are gorgeous, we were able to crank the A/C down appropriately. Loved the Kiehls products, the real shower cap, the great water pressure. (People seem to complain about the bathroom size at the Carlyle. Ours was small but the lovely towels, terrific water pressure and constantly replenished products more than made up for the space.) The gym is bright and very well equipped with weights exercise bands, magic circles, a rowing machine, etc. in addition to the usual hotel gym suspects. I had a fantastic massage in the spa by Claudia. We there through AmEx Platinum Fine Hotels & Resorts so were treated to the buffet breakfast—which was delicious and a quick option. (Gratuity is sometimes not included with the AmEx breakfast—it was here. We did not even have to sign a check...was very convenient.) We enjoyed Bemelman's Bar which I guess requires shoes on feet at all times. [I had kicked off black patent leather heel under the table and was asked to put it back on because there were "people in the bar." It was the oddest request ever...especially in light of the customer wearing sequin flip flops with her feet on a bar stool, which I find more offensive. But I digress.] The WiFi appeared to be on the fritz for most of our time there...came back online the day we were leaving. It is normally paid but free with the AmEx Platinum card plan. I found the staff to be lovely—especially Jennifer and Amet (sp?) at the front desk, and Jeff and Waldo at the concierge desk. Being close to the park, close-ish to the subway and in a quieter part of town made for a very successful weekend. We would definitely return.

This hotel is very traditional. I found all staff to be outstanding with their service and very pleasant. We were on the 7th floor; Room is small as is the bathroom. We had no view. Lighting needs to be improved. Tea room is very traditional. They offer coffee in the lobby in the morning. Good location for walking. Furniture is similar to what my parents had brought over from Ireland. Cable box needs to be elevated because remote cannot make contact if you're in bed. All in all it was comfy we got it at a good price; nothing outstanding-would I pay more probably not.

The Carlyle superior rooms are large by NYC standards. The chipping paint around the old radiators and the look of the tired baths betray the age of the hotel. The hotel is clean and rooms quiet and comfortable. The very small elevators contain elevator operators. The elevators are automatic and can operate without an operator. The presence of operators slows the frequency of elevators. The soundproofing of the aging windows is among the best I’ve experienced in a hotel. The need for major room renovations (at last on the 9th floor where we stayed) makes this less than a four- or five-star hotel. The Carlyle is a decidedly lower-end Rosewood managed property.

I stayed at the Carlyle for 3 nights thanks to a "Secret Upper East Side Hotel" online flash sale. From the sale's brief description, I guessed the hotel to be the Mark, but it turned out to be the Carlyle. The hotel has long been on my radar, but this was my first stay. The sale was for the hotel's cheapest, lowliest room, the Superior, so my opinions of the hotel are from this "steerage class"vantage point--think of where Leonardo DiCaprio's room was in the movie "Titanic". Many presidents, royals, and celebrities stay here, including Mr. and Mrs. George Clooney very recently, but of course they reside in the luxury upper level suites. From my view, the hotel seems to be resting on past laurels.The 34-story hotel opened in 1930 and sits on the corner of 76th and Madison. The Surrey hotel, where I've stayed before, is across the street, with the Mark one block north. The Upper East Side is known for its old money residents in doormen-accessed buildings. There are permanent residents within the Carlyle building.
