For tourists, the main attractions are the Met and Guggenheim museums, Central Park, and high-end shopping on Madison Ave. Well regarded restaurants are not a strong point, nor is nightlife. The only subway is the local 6, which can be oppressively crowded.My initial impression of the hotel was not good, because there was no doorman to greet me. One finally appeared as I was dragging my luggage out of the taxi's trunk. From then on service was excellent. The doorman read my luggage tags and announced my name to the front desk, where check in was quick and friendly, even offering a beverage. There are four elevators, but they must be staffed by an attendant to function, so only 1 or 2 are in use. Many times, people were sitting on the lobby chairs and sofas waiting for an elevator. The elevator attendants were the only sour spot service-wise. They were for the most part unsmiling, which you would be too if you were stuck in a hot confined space all day in a hot uniform complete with white gloves. One attendant was constantly fanning himself.When booking, I had optimistically requested a higher floor room with an exterior view. While I got the exterior view of Madison Ave., I was assigned the absolute lowest floor that housed guest rooms, the 3rd floor. The spa, beauty salon and small fitness centre were also on this floor. My neighbours included a gentleman who I think was a hotel employee and a nanny in charge of an infant and an active toddler. I don't know where the parents were, probably on a higher floor. I was rather embarrassed to call out my lowly floor number whenever I used the elevator going up, and the looks of disgust from guests and the attendant for having to stop on my lowly floor when boarding the elevator going down caused me to take the stairs down after the first day. I would have taken the stairs up too, but they are locked between the 2nd and 3rd floors.My room, a Superior King, was a decent size, with lots of natural light pouring through the 2 windows overlooking Madison Ave. There were actually inner and outer windows, which provided good sound insulation--I only heard the occasional siren--better than at the Surrey. There was a vase of fresh rosebuds, the TV had lots of channels. the closet was walk-in and housed the safe and minibar within. Negatives: old style, old looking decor (like a guest bedroom at your grandma's house), a TINY bathroom with all its walls mirrored to try to make it look bigger, and the biggest faux pas--you have to PAY for Wifi. I paid for the first day, then used the Business Centre, which you have to walk through the Gallery dining area to get to.The hotel has 4 dining areas and lounges. The Carlyle restaurant serves all 3 meals, the Gallery serves afternoon tea plus food. Bemelmans Bar is famous for its murals and nightly jazz and seemed very popular for the UES upper class. Cafe Carlyle is famous for its cabaret dinner shows, but is closed in the summer. I only tried the Carlyle for breakfast and did their buffet, which was decent but not terribly extensive. Service was great, almost cloying, but things were not replenished quickly at the buffet. People watching was very amusing--lots of hoity-toity folks. I also had room service one night and it was fine. As stated before, well-regarded dining in the area is not a strong suit. Cafe Boulud in the Surrey is perhaps the best known local fine dining restaurant. I found the "famous" J. G. Melon restaurant unpleasant and overrated.I noticed taxis do not always queue at the hotel entrance on 76th--the doormen sometimes have to go to Madison to hail one. At check-out, I needed to get down to the Peninsula on 55th, so the doorman offered the use of the house car. The driver was efficient but unfriendly.Overall not a bad stay, but for me there are better choices in New York., such as the Peninsula. Past laurels only get you so far, at least in steerage class, and paying for Wifi is an abomination in this day and age.

I stayed on the 5th floor with zero view. It was quiet but you you could hear the door open on the other rooms in the floor. Each is is the old school key so every time the metal entered or turned a lock, you could hear this. Seems minor but I guess the rooms are jut not sound proof. The service is great and Patrick, the head of guest relations is wonderful. Breakfast is top rate as well. I would go back bug would ask for a room not surrounded so close to so many other doors.

I stayed in 610 and i gotta say for such a historic hotel it looks like something out of the stone age. #1 my room looked something out of the mid-evil era or like a dungeon. #2 the stairwells are seriously a "DANGER ZONE" like i almost tripped coming down the stairs on a plate and a glass cup which i could have sworn By new york city law via FDNY that thats a complete fire violation! i would hate to be in there during a fire. i advise to take the elevator which is also a hazard because when i got in and we was traveling down the elevator made rattling noises and kinda stalled for a minute VERY DANGEROUS!!! but i must say they have very friendly elevator attendants like Gustavo he was very nice and warm. #3 WHERE IS SECURITY????? i have been to various hotels and this is the first one Ive seen that does not have security in the lobby which to me is very unsafe especially with all the bag boosting going on i dont know if my stuff would be safe there or not. also i never seen security checking the floors but when i come outside there standing at 2 different entrances as if that make sense i don't know who there boss is but he needs to go back to school again or get demoted or something for his lack of security knowledge. also it takes for ever for them to let you in a room #4 the price to stay at this hotel is a joke i mean lets be serious the hotel looks really out of date and looks very old and its not worth the price. this place needs changes seriously. like they use keys for gods sake when in other hotels they use cards. its 2015 not 1960 anymore. NEVER GOING BACK!
user_name:
Jtaylar321
New York City, New York

review_body: The hotel is well situated in UES very close to Central Park and has a nice classical charm about it however does feel a touch dated. The elevator service is a nice touch but certainly feels like it is in the wrong era. The rooms are very comfortable, well presented and maintained by staff. Not having wifi provided for guests was a huge disappointment for such a well reputed hotel.

I've been coming to this hotel since I was a child (well over 40 years) but within the past few years and especially this trip the rooms seem 'tired' and in need of a major overhaul. our room floor creaked, our room smelled like sewage the entire 4 days, the furniture in the room was chipped, the floor had a piece of wood missing but was left in the room tossed aside and seemed to be ignored by housekeeping, large crack in the wall that had been painted over very sloppily, maybe the worst was a VERY loud air conditioning unit that woke us up during the night when it began cycling on, and the decor is OUTDATED, (the front desk did tell us renovating will be begin at the end of the year.) the powder room by the bar is in need of updating and at the very least paint and new wallpaper, the bar celing molding needs paint as well. the location is great and the bar is always a treat but the rooms especially need attention.

I surprised my fiancé by booking a fabulous room for his birthday on the 33rd floor. We had breathtaking views of the city and our room was spectacular. The bed was dreamy and the bathroom was divine....especially the shower.The room was updated beautifully and even though we had many plans, we found ourselves lingering ,reading the morning paper and enjoying the charm of a lovely, timeless and classy hotel.We enjoyed a wonderful dinner in the restaurant and loved both the piano bar and the jazz later in the evening.In addition the flowers in the lobby were exquisite as well as the beautiful bouquet of red roses in our room.We had no problems with the elevators and the staff clearing enjoyed working at the Carlyle and expressed their respect for the quality of the management of the hotel openly. Bottom line....we loved it
user_name:
eoc109
New York City, New York

review_body: The Carlyle is an elegant, superbly located hotel oozing Old World charm. We had a very spacious room with a very comfortable bed as part of a promotion - "stay two nights and receive a third night free." The room was enhanced by a large walk-in closet with plenty of hangers and room for luggage. Amenities included a well-stocked but expensive mini-bar (but no coffee equipment), Kiehl's toiletries, plush bathrobes and slippers, and our choice of newspaper delivered every day. The marble bathroom had a roomy bathtub plus an extra large shower with a hand-held shower head as well as a large overhead one. While serviceable, the room furniture was a bit on the shabby side (nicks, dings, flaking paint) and needed to be refreshed. The bar top marble needed its water rings removed. The murals,atmosphere, and drinks of Bemelman's Bar can't be beat (be aware of evening cover charges). We also enjoyed a delicious tea inThe Gallery, as well as breakfast and dinner in The Carlyle Room. All staff members make you feel welcomed, are helpful, and try to resolve issues that arise. We were pleased to avail ourselves of the house car service to take us to a dinner reservation in Midtown on Saturday night. Not many hotels have manned elevators any longer.There does seem to be a bit of a disconnect between the desire of staff to resolve issues and the ability to get things taken care of, i.e., a never remedied slow-draining bathroom sink. Similarly, there needs to be better communication between The Carlyle Room staff and its kitchen (and perhaps among the kitchen staff) to avoid long waits for dishes ordered from the breakfast menu plus a big lag time in refreshing the breakfast buffet of simple items such as bagels. Overall, our visit was a very pleasant and memorable one at this venerable Upper East Side landmark.

I had not expected to stay in NYC but due to weather I would not be able to meet my connecting flight. I had not been in the city before and I was able to call from the the airport and reserve a room and a car service. The room was immaculately clean and the bed was perfect. I wanted to see the city so I ordered room service as I checked in and they delivered a perfect burger with fries. I was even able to to share an elevator with a celebrity. The only downside to my stay was because the room was older my charger plugs did not fit well and my phone did not charge overnight

We checked in at 12:30 and the room was ready! Upon entering we were shown the dated "kitchenette" complete with Formica countertops and old tiled floor, stove but no pots and pans...go figure. The tiny bathroom had a dated tub with small shower head to match. Toilet bowl filled with that blue disinfectant you see at a cheap motel. The decor consisted of painted pine furniture, lumpy pillows in need of replacement and dark brown furniture of Bombay and Co quality. The Piano Bar was lovely but charged us $35 pp to sit at a table at 10pm. I would recommend a visit to the Piano Bar BEFORE 9:30pm to avoid cover charge but would not recommend this hotel as a luxury or 4-5 star hotel. I might add GREAT LOCATION close to the park, shopping and Columbus Circle!!
user_name:
Dalocopa
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: This is the perfect place to stay in New York, so comfortable and welcoming, a home away from home but the hotel must solve the elevators problem... I waited also around 15 minutes back from a run, was sweating in the lobby (sorry not pretty) as there was only one elevator attendent on duty, I could not find the stairs by the way, it's absolutely crazy... I know we want to keep tradition but there are things best left in the past...So too would return but I would find out where the stairs are....Beside this, the hotel is a gem! 5 stars all the way!Oh also, one last negative point: ditch the charge for Wifi, that is just unacceptable these days either...

This hotel is in a great location on the Upper East of NY. This is near to central park and a number of high end boutique stores. I stayed for three nights on a work trip and travel to NY often so I am looking for different things to your average tourist. The rooms are comfortable, great linen, lots of mirrors, good layout and excellent supply of Keils cosmetics which I thought was a nice touch. I was on the 18th floor, I didnt open my curtains the entire time I was there so I'm unable to tell you if i had a view! There is wifi available in the rooms at $14 a day, this was a good high speed service so I had no issues paying for this. The hotel has 4 elevators however they are all run by men and frankly this drove me crazy, not only is having to make small talk with a guy in a lift annoying there was an awful delay when calling a lift. One morning after a run I waiting 15 minutes for a lift as there was only one guy working who was also delivering there morning papers. Perhaps this would bother someone on holiday but for me it was an annoyance. I would stay here again though as I slept well and the hotel location is a lovely escape from midtown.

The hotel lobby is very nice and beautiful and so is the dining room. Our room was quiet with a view of the neighbor's apt. windows. Our room was large with 2 closets and a tiny bathroom. The linens and towels were luxurious. However, the furniture in our room has seen better days. They were all really worn, old, tired and needed to be retired. They looked like they all came from Housing Works. The furniture really needed another new paint job. The desk chair needed to be replaced altogether, the back was coming apart. It was more shabby looking than chic for a 5 star property.

Rather, an elevator operator does it for you. As it might have been when rope elevators were new and possibly dangerous 160 years agoBut this one thing epitomizes the place - old school, and vigorously hanging on to every scrap of old school dignityLike boarding school, many rules apply: No shorts No electronic checkout No getting your own ice etc...In fact, had I not been busy, I would have explored more things I could not do hereThat said, the place is in a perfect location for upper east side stuff (shopping, museums, central park), and has the best and classiest jazz bar in the world attached (Bemelmans). And the rooms are great, showers powerful, internet fast (but you pay for it), and service excellent
user_name:
christopher k
New York City, New York

review_body: Very nice classic hotel. Located just one block from Central Park, easy access to all midtown.Really cool bar downstairs, and even elevator attendents.Very polite attentive staff.We will be back again and again.

We always look forward to staying at the Carlyle. The experience is unusually pleasant. This upper east side hotel has the older charm of days gone by, a welcome change from today's more standard upscale hotels. Of special note is the bar (great piano players and full strength, well-made drinks) and the dining room. Service is also excellent, all around. And for those that care about such things, the shower caps are the finest of any hotel around the world. (An awesome plus for me!). This is a very special place.

My wife and I spent two nights at the Carlyle and took our dog with us, too. We were in NYC on business and wanted a comfortable place with excellent service. It was our first stay at the Carlyle, but we were familiar with the hotel and with Bemelmen's Bar from when we lived nearby. This stay exceeded our expectations. The staff was wonderful. Our room was comfortable, and the view was amazing.
user_name:
jimkny
New York City, New York

review_body: We had a pleasant stay at the Carlyle. It was nice to be on the Upper East Side where it is calmer and it is an older, elegant hotel. The room was quite large with hardwood floors and a large closet. The bed was very comfortable with lovely linens and great pillows. Nevertheless, I think that in light of the competition in the high end hotel market in New York, there were a few things that should be addressed. The bathroom was tiny with no room to place your toiletries and the room had a shower/tub configuration and was bit tired. My rooms in the past at the Carlyle have had this tub/shower combo so I assume that all the rooms have this. If they decided to renovate and increase the bathroom size and upgrade it, there is plenty of room to do so. I definitely think this is something they should consider soon. In addition, there was a large, dark stain on the way of the hallway to my room. At these prices, I was quite surprised that this had not been addressed. We still had a very nice stay at the Carlyle and would consider it in the future.

This hotel has the old school charm of NYC. I get tired of your standard run-of-the-mill, super modern, no character hotels. This place has character. Little details like actual keys instead of a plastic card to access your room, beautiful solid wood quality furniture, plush beds, gorgeous fabric window treatments, hardwood floors with oriental area rugs, make you feel like an actual person put thought into appointing the room. The staff was very accommodating, I did have an issue during my stay and the staff made sure that the problem was solved and that I was happy and satisfied.

Located in the swanky upper East Side, near the best shops (think Ralph Lauren, Tom Ford, Carolina Herrera and more on Madison Ave), our experience is always perfect. The Carlyle's rooms are very comfortable, with all amenities; perhaps not as spacious as a Hampton, but with much more character. And quiet. The bed/linens very comfortable. We've stayed in king bed-rooms and suites. All lovely and welcoming. Some views are better than others. But it's a grand hotel. The bar, Bemelman's, is the absolute best....with exceptional music starting around 6:00 p.m. (you might want to come a bit earlier for a good table). Google Bemelman's to find out why it's so wonderful....he's the artist who did the illustrations for the famous Madeline books. The bar interior is fabulous.Their cafe hosts some fabulous entertainers, including recently Alan Cumming....and often on Sunday nights, Wody Allen and his crew. This is New York at its finest. Not to mention the best maitre'd - Carlos, in Bemelman's.

We had a lovely classic style room in the Tower. Professional excellent customer service is apparent everywhere you go at The Carlyle from check in to check out. Our room was not ready upon arrival, so were were treated to a drink and tea as we waited a very short amount of time. We attended Tony Danza's opening show that evening at the Cafe Carlyle and had a wonderful table and dinner - unfortunately the air conditioning was not working making the intimate space even more so. We also enjoyed delicious buffet breakfasts during our stay - don't pass on the crossiants or fresh fruit selections. We celebrated a special birthday during our stay and can't wait for another special occasion to return to The Carlyle!

The suite we reserved and prepaid for was unavailable so we were downgraded to a regular room. The staff was lazy and lackadaisical. In particular, the doorman let his limo driver buddies PARK (not load) and take up all the space in the loading zone so we had to carry our luggage to the hotel from the garage down the block. This problem persisted into our departure day, and space was made available only after I made a big stink! (We had 16 pieces of luggage to load in and out of the car) No one seemed to care whether we enjoyed our stay or not. Also, room décor and lobby décor is tired and not particularly clean. This place needs a good scrubbing!

I had a pleasant and relaxing stay at the Carlyle. The service was outstanding. The room was beautiful, and it felt like I was staying at my own apartment on the Upper East Side. When I checked in, the concierge provided me with a map and a lot of guidance on public transportation. The front desk also recommended a wonderful breakfast spot in the neighborhood, just steps from the hotel. Every question that I had was thoroughly answered. When I left, the restaurant staff prepared a wonderful takeout dinner for my trip. I will definitely be staying at the Carlyle when I next visit New York.

Have stayed multiple times and honestly feel like this hotel is home. Service, staff are exceptional - very friendly and very professional.Our room was very clean and spacious and very quiet. No issues sleeping in at all.We love this hotel.
user_name:
G1812GGbrianc
New York City, New York

review_body: I am always reluctant to write a negative review but I feel that it is important to address some recent service issues regarding our last visit in April and our upcoming visit which I have just canceled for Jun 19.On checkin on our last visit we were warmly welcomed by a guest manager who escorted us to our suite. It was not the category I reserved and moreover could best be described as shabby chic with an emphasis on shabby! The bathroom was tiny with a shower/tub combination which I abhor. I called down to the front desk and the girl who answered the phone told me that this was in fact what Amex platinum had booked for me so I asked to speak to guest relations manager. He said he would look into it and call me back. In about 15 minutes he called back and said that Amex had made a mistake but in looking at our previous booking we had booked a higher category suite so he would upgrade us to one on this visit. If this had been the only glitch I would have overlooked it. The next day I was on the elevator with an elderly woman and another guest manager. She was complaining loudly about the unacceptable suite she had just been taken to and that it was not what she had booked. As we got off the elevator the guest manager turned and looked at me, rolled his eyes and shook his head. I was surprised by his lack of respect for this guest. The next morning I went to the dining room for breakfast and when I asked for a menu was told that I was Amex platinum and as such was to eat at the buffet. I responded that I was aware of my amex benefits but that I wanted to order from the menu. After 10 minutes , with no menu forthcoming I gave up and went to the buffet. With that you may wonder why I chose to book here again. Well we have been loyal customers for many years and have had many happy family visits here.We were already making memories with another generation with our 18 month old granddaughter so I wrote it off as an unfortunate visit with better hopes for next time. This week I got an email from the hotel welcoming for my upcoming visit and was shocked to see that I was again booked in a suite category that was not what I reserved. I immediately called room reservations and was told by the clerk that I had booked that suite. I am looking at my amex website with the confirmation for the higher level suite. She basically tells me that it isn't her problem and that if I wanted to change it I needed to call platinum services. I told her to cancel my reservation.For got to mention that on the April visit I was in fact not upgraded but on checkout charged the rate of the suite we wanted. After talking to platinum card services Steve stated that he would look into the situation and call me back. After looking into it he said there appeared to be alich between the Carlyes website and amex That had just happened to occur for my past two reservations.He stated that he was going to contact the hotel and that he would make sure my reservation was canceled for next week. He then booked me at the St. Regis where we have stayed in the past. I am very disappointed at the decline in service at this property but we won't be back again until improvements are made. This hotel could take some instructions in customer service from another Rosewood hotel, Mansion on Turtle Creek in Dallas. We stay there monthly and it is nothing but perfection in every category. Sadly, this is not the case for the Carlye.

This was my first time staying at the Carlyle Hotel. I must say that I was disappointed in the service. I stayed 3 nights. On the third night I needed to call housekeeping - the garbage can in the kitchenette had not been emptied once during my stay. Also, the housekeeper during the day left a damp cleaning rag in the bathroom sink.Upon checkin, I was asked what newspaper I would like during my stay. 2 out of the 3 days had the wrong newspaper delivered.I was expecting much better from the famous (and expensive) hotel. I will not be returning to The Carlyle.The wifi was very slow (and expensive).

I think I am very crafty old Hector because I have chosen to review this hotel BEFORE I have checked out ensuring red carpet treatment for my early morning departure. Barbary Apes will wait upon me in the lobby, Tahitian ladies of the dance will waltz me to my limo, smiles will abound, 'he has left! ookoo, loopoo', will be sung in Balinese lament. How can one fail to give a joint (how local) like this five stars? According to one of the many splendid taxi drivers who whisked my sacred person about this truly great world city, 'Pope Francees, he stey khere!'. Now, as I am not of a left-footed persuasion, the visit of the Pontiff means little to me. Perhaps his Holiness, famous for his love of the ascetic, found the bare floors to his liking? I know not nor, with all due respect to his Reverence, do I care. When I marched into my room, I thought that the room might indeed be one that His Massiveness would like because it reminded me of my nana's (however hard I try, I just can't come across as of the people can I?), forgive me your Awesomeness for I have sinned in semantics, grandmothers spare room. That is to say chintz partout with a little hint of the art deco in every fitting. The light fittings, the plugs and the bathroom just howl 'George bloody Gershwin' at you, the 1930's New York Romantic Movement revisited. Black and white marble halls, all understated and beloved, little jasmine flowers poke their gentle heads from beneath the rosary of the Sacred Heart of a cloistered world so long seperated, hey Pope Francis, did your Hugeness stay in my room? Does your spirit lie within the (obsolete) jacuzzi? Is this a subliminal conversion? What is occurring? Happiness has pervaded my every pore.....The bathroom is the highlight of any Carlyle room not because I had the opportunity to view my Hellenic body in perpetuity (y'know, when mirrors face one another and the image is projected into infinity) but because it's so damn 1930's and hell, I love the 1930's.......Arsenal FC won the league title five times in the 1930's. The bathroom, with all due respect to his Utterness is a religious experience not just because of the fittings but because, on seeing how Helles had become Hell I am resolved to change my ways and drop to welterweight. God I loved this hotel. Forget that you have to pay $15 for wi-fi, $23 for a pot of coffee and a miniature whisky costs the same as a bottle from just over the street ($17) - expect to pay, enjoy the flagellation! Accept the punishment! If Pope Frankie can take it, so can you. The staff, the marble, the Pope, the waist.........the city, all Damscene in their might.......I am converted. See you at Mass.

It's a very posh hotel. The rooms are comfortable. The hotel's bar is always a great choice of good music and food. Also , the location is a positive point, next to Central Park and to the good shops. The elevators are a bit old. The hotel is very charming. It's always my first choice in NY

I booked a night here to celebrate New Years Eve with my wife, and by god we weren't disappointed! From the minute you step through the door you are in a world of elegance, charm and luxury. The service from the entire hotel staff was amazing; from the friendly Bellboys in the lifts, the extremely knowledgeable concierge, the happy room service team and even the maids who decorated our room with rose petals - they all helped to make us, and our stay, feel special. Our room overlooked Central Park and the view was spectacular - do whatever you can to get a high up room! We spent the evening with Steve Tyrell at the Café Carlyle - a completely memorable occasion that is impossible to put into words! And if you ever get chance even to sip a drink at the Bemelmans bar you should go for it - the classiest joint in town!Only slight downer was the slow and very expensive wifi connection that you had to pay for... each day!! Not free, or even 24 hour access! But I guess if you have the $$$ to pay to stay you have the $$ for wifi.All the food that we had at the hotel was awesome! Breakfast was extensive, lunch in the interior lounge fabulous and the room service was spot on!This is a hotel I would highly recommend for a memorable occasion!

We chose this hotel due to its location on the east side of Central Park, away from the rush & push of the 5th avenue area etc. Rooms are comfortable and calm despite the hustle of NY, furnishing simple elegance with lovely bathroom which was a little small. Here there is a bell boy in the lift, & you feel they are happy to help you in any way, very relaxing oasis in this big city. Beautiful dining room which is used for breakfast, it makes it feel a real elegant affair. Cafe Carlyle is an institution, as well as Benelmans bar, both worth a visit. Special place with lots of history.

The Carlyle is full of enchanting NY history. When staying here, one simply feels like royalty. The food is exquisite and the maid service is very tidy. The bemelmans bar is my favorite in the entire city. A must visit, even if it is for one evening. A true New York City classic.
user_name:
Alexa S
New York City, New York

review_body: As a regular NY visitor, I was disappointed with my stay at the Carlyle. Whilst service is impressive, my room on the 30th floor, was tired and small, needed a refresh and the bathroom was particularly poor. Seems strange in this day and age to pay as much as they charge and be standing in a bath for my shower! Have to admit, won't be back in a hurry. Too much choice to need to go back.

In a way is just another good five star luxury hotel with its own pros and cons. In reality, The Clarlyle is a living monument, a temple, a piece of history, a unique classy elegant remain of New York City "Golden Age". If you didn't experience the Clarlyle, well you can't say you're a complete NYC lover, you're not yet a real "Manhattan chauvinist". This once in a lifetime "Wasp Grand Hotel" is definitely worth a trip and a stay.

You should know before you are entering the Carlyle Hotel what you are expecting. This Hotel is more than an overnight stay. Every corner, every room, wherever you are, you feel tradition. The Carlyle is a perfect stay to discover NYC. The location is perfect, the room are clean, nicely decorated, comfortable beds, small, but very nice and beautiful equipped bathroom. If you prefer ultra modern Hotels with all kind of fancy things, than the Carlyle is not your choice. If you like a warm welcome with a big portion of living tradition, you should stay there.

Just returned from a 3 night stay at the Carlyle. Our room was very quiet & the service was top notch. The staff were friendly and helpful. For such a large hotel it feels very private. We didn't eat at the restaurant but we listened to jazz at the cafe & had a great time!

This review is for the spa. A lovely relaxing afternoon in the hands of an excellent masseuse, pampered by friendly staff, great variety of treatments. Well worth the price. Next time I will be sure to stay for dinner at the famous Carlyle dining room, the menu looks great.

On my birthday celebration in NY, at the top of my list of things to do was to go back to one of my favorite places when I lived in the city for over 20 years - Bemelman's Bar at The Carlyle. I have seen so many amazing talents over the last two or maybe three decades. This night was to see one of my favorites, Loston Harris. He has been playing there for years and he is magical. The room was abuzz with conversation but people were wildly tuned into the beautiful sounds of what he does on that piano. Of course, with a place like this you always get to enjoy the side show of women who are desperately seeking the attention of wealthy men. Very entertaining. I so love your talent Loston and the experience every time I am at The Carlyle.

Another perfect stay at our favorite New York hotel. It was flawless. Many thanks to the excellent staff. Chuck, our captain in the Restaurant did a splendid job spoiling us.All the newer staff members are doing fine jobs.

I was booked for 4 nights but checked out after the very first night because of the terrible attitude of the old timers at The Carlyle. I am an Indian, and I got the distinct impression that they would rather not have me there. I have a long stay in NYC planned for August, so when I asked the old gentleman at the reception about the Carlyle Residences and if they are attached to the hotel; he very rudely told me 'I don't understand what you are saying' and gave me the visiting card of a lady I should contact. Coincidently, the same gentleman was at my hasty checkout and he 'mistakenly' charged me for breakfast even though my room rate was inclusive of breakfast. When I pointed out the same, he did reverse the charge. Obviously, I'm never going to even consider seeking foot inside that hotel. Terrible would be a gross understatement.

I have been staying at the Carlyle for over 15 years and normally have a good experience. However, this visit was quite disappointing. At 2 am, about the time bars close in the city, the service door which room service uses started slamming. This woke me up. After calling the front desk and asking that they kindly stop slamming the door... Nothing was done. Now it 230am and Im wide awake. I hear 2 Russian woman walking down the hall talking and laughing loudly. They stop at their door which is directly across from my door. They proceeded to ring the door bell for 15 min while continuing to laugh and talk loudly. When i called down again and asked the front desk to intervene, a hotel staffmember finally showed up to let them in the room.Then the music started blasting. It was so loud that the pictures on my wall were shaking. Throughout the night-morning several men joined the girls in the room. Even though I complained throughout the night, the manager failed to act. At 7 am I gave up and went downstairs to have breakfast. I confronted the manager and demanded a new room for the remainder of my weeks stay. No apology was given and i had to move my own bags as the manager was too busy to arrange.This is not the kind of service or environment I usually encounter when staying here and hope it is not repeated.

The nostalgic charme, private atmosphere and great hospitality makes this place to a very special, warmly getaway. Sonal Nayyar is just the perfect guest relations manager - warm hearted, very caring and very well organized ( what I love as a german :o)

This property is always a pleasure to stay in, no matter which room you are in. Our family of four recently spent the weekend in a 2-bedroom suite that was really charming, well-appointed, tasteful and so comfortable. The service throughout the hotel is excellent and always discreet but available, and the fabulous bath products are a special treat. I feel like I am at home when staying here, but in NYC. The location is our favorite especially since we adore visiting Zitomer's, Clyde's, and all of the great shopping in the area.

In the past I have lived in Manhattan, moved, had a condo for get away...the best, is to just leave it to the Carlyle! They are the best; love the neighborhood; love the hotel and excellent service, which is becoming a lost art elsewhere. I agree, specify where, views you would like, however, the amenities are lovely: Frette, Kiel, and I order the Carlyle soap for our home so that can maintain that lovely aroma. I go there alone and love it; or with my husband...all is good. Just returned from 5 nights which included Woody Allen, I know he is controversial, however, it was packed; met a lovely couple from France at the bar.., The Carlyle is elegant, but friendly. Everything is either there or nearby, enjoy the neighborhood, shops, staff is amazingly great....that is our "go to place". Much better than owning a coop for us, since it is often a last minute trip. Always accommodating.When booking, ask what your view may be...doubt that you want a suite with a wall outside the window, but, up to you to ask and make certain. Relax and enjoy luxury at its finest! Gail Hughes Galli

I stayed at this hotel with a friend . I'm from New York City and it was always my dream to stay here. It is a very elegant hotel in a quiet way. As everyone said in the reviews it is one of the few hotels around the world that have a white glover elevator operator. It was quite something to see it these days. You will feel like in a set of a classic movie hotel. We stayed in a renovated room and it was very nice and modern. The only problem was that the room was very noisy. There was a noisy coming from somewhere and it was hard to sleep with it. I complaint after a night with no sleep and they gave me earplugs that solve the problem. The other thing was the pillows . There were way too hard! the next day I got a soft one.Location location and location. This place is the best place to be in New York . You are near all the tourist spot and places to see in New York. My friend is from out New York city and he was so happy that we could walk almost everywhere or a short taxi ride from the places that we visited. You can see so much of New York like that.We went to the bar and I felt like I was in a Woody Allen movie. The drinks are way too expensive remind me the prices that you see at the Ritz in Paris but it worth the visit.
user_name:
LilianaCastillo
New York City, New York

review_body: We stayed here for a weekend in a suite and absolutely loved the old style of the room, the bathroom, etc. etc.. We had a Premier Suite, although it didn't seem that Premier compared to some of the pictures I saw of suites containing a piano. It appeared to be a renovated room but the AC was very loud, we turned off the AC at night and just used the main room's AC, but this should really not be an issue at this price.If using the Amex package, the free breakfast buffet is by FAR a better value than $50 towards room service. We got a minimal in-room breakfast that was $130, and couldn't believe how much better the buffet was (not to mention the people watching, quite the regal set). I still get a kick out of in-room breakfast, but the buffet is both cheaper and better.They need to put a few of the waiters at Bemelmans Bar out to pasture. Our first night we had some drinks and food. I'd heard about the Clooney-backed tequila, and tried one of the mixed drinks that featured it. Was great, then asked the bartender if we could try a small sample of the tequila... he smirked as if that was the dumbest thing he'd been asked that night. "The bartenders won't do that for tequila, maybe for wine, not for liquor." Okay, fine, not to mention that maybe a thimble-full of tequila might be an exception for a $200 tab on a $1300/night suite, but whatever - we ordered a full shot. Tasted fine, not that distinct, then on the final tab saw he'd brought us a Patron shot!?!!? The attitude plus the error of bringing the wrong drink was... look, it's not that big of a deal, until you realize that the service in the rest of the hotel is *spectacular*, so something like this sticks out as extremely rude. I'm not sure if it's managed differently, but I've seen other reviews mentioning poor service here, it's a shameful weakness to have considering how high the bar is maintained elsewhere.The service in the hotel was excellent. I did find the concierge outmatched on 2 occasions dealing with last-minute requests - I'd heard of their legendary service and partly was curious to see if they lived up to the reputation. Not quite, although for dinner reservations they were very competent. No real complaint, they did their best and were polite and professional about it.The lady raved about a spa service treatment - atmosphere and actual treatment were both spectacular, so highly recommended.Overall definitely worth a visit, we look forward to returning - the atmosphere, plus the history of the place is simply unmatched.

The Carlyle is a throwback in time. Our room felt like staying on someone's home as there were wood floors with carpeting. The room was clean and well appointed. It was probably the quietest hotel I have stayed in in NYC. We enjoyed our stay. We ate breakfast at the hotel on two mornings and the food was excellent. Although the breakfast was served buffet style, waiters were supposed to bring drinks and incidentals. We found the waiters to be generally snooty and unhelpful. Just getting coffee was quite an ordeal. The waiters seemed to be there more as a decoration from a bygone era rather than to assist customers - very disappointing.

We have just returned from a long weekend stay at The Carlyle, a trip we booked to attend Debbie Harry's last performance during her residency at Cafe Carlyle. Rosewood Hotels was offering a 'stay for three pay for two' promotion, so it seemed like an excellent opportunity to give this venerable New York institution a try.Before even setting foot through the door The Carlyle impressed me. There were a few occasions after making our reservation when I needed to contact the hotel by email, and whether it was the reservations department or the concierge desk, replies were always very prompt, professional and courteous. The outstanding service continued to impress us upon checking in, where we were warmly greeted, escorted to the lobby, and enthusiastically welcomed to the hotel by the charming clerk who checked us in. Waldo, one of the concierges, went above and beyond the call of duty trying to help us locate an iPhone lost on our flight or at the airport. We greatly appreciated his tireless efforts.I cannot recall having stayed anywhere else in the world where white-gloved elevator operators are on duty at all times: this is an extravagant service that certainly sets The Carlyle apart from other five-star competitors. It truly felt like stepping back in time for the 30 second ride up to or down from our 19th floor room. Our room was the only aspect of the hotel that we found a little disappointing. We booked the base-category (“Superior”), and despite the front desk clerk promising she had assigned us the best room in this category, it was small and showed some wear, and the view was uninspiring. Some of the furniture could have used a little maintenance, and the ceiling in the bathroom had peeling paint. At a five-star property with such a renowned reputation (and a price-point to match), perfection is expected. The 19th floor hallway too showed signs of wear: scuffed walls, frayed/stained carpeting, and elevator panel trim-work falling off. We have stayed in much larger and more luxurious suites elsewhere for much less. I was very surprised to discover that The Carlyle charges $14.95 daily for in-room wifi. When even Holiday Inns are offering this service at no charge, it seems petty of a very pricey luxury hotel not to include this service in the room rate.Despite the room’s shortcomings, we did appreciate the attention to detail in the appointments and amenities: Frette sheets and bathrobes, luxurious down duvet and cushions, Kiehl’s toiletries, and evening turndown service with bottled water and chocolates. We slept well in the very comfortable bed, although on our second night we were awakened by a boisterous group in the room next to us (soundproofing between rooms is not very good: bring earplugs).The dinner show at Café Carlyle was a night we will never forget. The setting is intimate (read: packed like sardines), the food was quite good, cocktails were well-prepared, and Debbie Harry’s performance was incredible. What a treat it was to enjoy such a dynamic performance ‘up close and personal’! It was a very expensive evening, but worth every penny. Be sure to stop in at Bemelmans Bar: cocktails are pricey but the setting is sublime.We also made good use of the small but well-equipped gym. This was a necessity given the hotel’s proximity to so many wonderful restaurants and bakeries! Because there were a number of specific restaurants in the area we wanted to visit, we did not have a chance to try the The Carlyle Restaurant or The Gallery, but both look lovely and the menus are appealing. Overall we greatly enjoyed our first stay at The Carlyle and we would definitely consider returning on a future visit to New York City. We loved the Upper East Side location with its easy access to great shopping, fine dining, and Central Park. If we do return, we will choose a different room category for a little more space and perhaps an interesting view. The reason we would return is, once again, the exceptional service from everyone with whom we came in contact during our stay. We felt safe, secure, pampered and cared about throughout our three night getaway. It is easy to understand why this has become the preferred home-away-from-home for royalty, celebrities, politicians, and travelers seeking a plush sanctuary from the hectic city.

We stayed in a 2 bedroom suite during spring break with my 2 stepdaughters. The Good: The room was lovely. Bathrooms fairly small (but its NYC) but spotlessly clean and attractive marble and glass. Staff were always friendly and helpful, especially the concierge. The hotel itself is beautiful and historic, with the lovely Bemelman's Bar and very intimate dining area. The Bad: the mattress on our bed was terrible. I was sagging so much on one side I kept rolling toward the edge of the bed. Pillows ok, not as good as they should be in such a fine hotel. There was a fruit basket, but we much prefer the milk and cookies that were left for the girls every night at other hotels we stayed in. The Ugly: the elevator operators were awkward and made us uncomfortable. They were all very nice and friendly, but it was strange to see these men in a tiny box all day wearing white gloves and pushing buttons for you. I hope they change that in the future. No bueno. All in all, we had a very pleasant stay, but the bed was a huge discomfort. Not sure this place is worth staying all the way on the upper east side for, but it is gorgeous to look at. Wish they would turn their attention more to the comfort of their guests and less toward outdated customs.

There is no question the Carlyle is all about New York history. And evokes a bygone era that if often nice to get back to. You feel it ....from the caring doormen ....friendly desk staff....lobby staff who have been with the hotel staff since( I won't give away their age) and even old fashioned elevator operators. The decor is elegant as if your 1940's movie is about to begin in color .... In real life. I even took advantage of the house S class Mercedes for a short jaunt although I squinted and imagined myself in a Duesenberg. So why doesn't this magic translate to the rooms. I am sure there are some amazing suites that perhaps I have not seen ...but at the standard and deluxe levels they are always a let down. Apartment like translates to your grandmothers apartment that no one has touched in decades. They are just plain run down AND dowdy. Except for a huge flat screen tv. There so so much wasted space where there could easily have been another lounge chair. The bed sagged so much to one side I thought I would roll off. They make the best of the VERY small bathrooms with plentiful Kiehls products...slippers and luxurious towels. I was pleased with housekeeping. But then...two closets and no iron. It was wonderfully quiet. Another But ....then I was as at the back with no view whatsoever. I have had spectacular views here. Finally. ...in the scheme of crazy NY hotel prices....there are some deals to be had at these categories of rooms. Everyone should try the Carlyle and maybe a little live entertainment which they are famous for at least once in their life. Walk up Madison on a warm night and really go back in time. If you are lucky ...you can splurge for a larger upgraded room and make it a 5 star experience.

Me and my wife went for first time to NY and we decided to stay at this hotel, everything was wonderful, the location was very good, central park was a few blocks away walking and also the metro service, upon arrival we got a free upgrade to a suite, the room was very nice with beautiful amenities, and most of the staff was very polite, the hotel was full of art, and had very nice restaurants and facilities,we would love to visit NY again and of course to stay at the Carlyle again.

Just superb!Very friendly reception team and porters.The bed and linens were so soft and luxurious we went for a nap and woke up 6 hours later. Luxury Kiehly toiletries and very soft and fluffy towels in the bathroomThe only flaw in the whole hotel I could find was that I could not switch on my bedside lamp without turning on the overhead lights.

Was looking forward to staying at the "world famous" Carlyle Hotel and was very disappointed. If your looking for modern updated rooms, then this is not the hotel for you. All the employees were wonderful and it was a warm homey hotel, but in need of a desperate upgrade. It reminded me of my camp days when the wood floors creaked and if your not careful you got a splinter in your foot. Furnishings and carpet were stained and needed cleaning. Bathroom was one of the only good features. I enjoyed the rain showers and heated floors. I think they really need to reduce their rates until they modernize the rooms.

The Carlyle is an amazing hotel experience. It defines understated elegance and epitomizes uncompromising service. It is a beautiful, classy property befitting of royalty and that's how you are made to feel when you stay here. The food is amazing starting with a delectable and extensive breakfast buffet in the morning in a jewel of a dining room with unobtrusive but always there at the right moment waiters. No visit to the Carlyle is complete however without a nightly stop before bed at Bamelman's Bar. Simply put, an hour or two in Bamelman's transports you back to the golden age of NYC. It's the best bar for live music in the city and certainly the richest atmosphere, the best Manhattans (go for the Perfect) and always offers an evening to enjoy and remember. The world famous Cafe Carlyle on the top floor also offers world class performers in their twice nightly supper club shows. The hotel has a gorgeous spa and i enjoyed starting my day with a world class massage. Rooms are lovely, immaculate, well equipped and spacious. Fluffiest towels in the world! I think the Carlyle offers the best deal in the City for all that it offers and consistently delivers and I've made it my home away from home whenever i'm in NY. If you want to feel like you own New York City, stay at the Carlyle.

The Carlyle is a unique NYC experience. It is a great choice if you are looking for a hotel in this area. Obviously, the Carlyle is somewhat expensive. But, it is a historic hotel and you will feel it as soon as you walk in. The least expensive rooms are pretty small. It is worth it to upgrade one or two categories, as you will get a little sitting area and some more space. You might have a foyer with nice wood floors, a larger bathroom, etc.Each room is decorated individually and the ones that I have seen are all very nice. The rooms are well kept, but are showing some age. In my most recent stay, the bed was not up to current luxury hotel standards. The furniture in the room was a little worn. You have to keep in mind this is not a brand new hotel. It does have a wonderful luxury feel.

I have stayed here many times and it is a comfortable, well located hotel with excellent facilities. However on this trip some public areas were closed to the public because of a movie production.For example the access from Madison was closed and two 70 year olds were sent back into the snow to slip and slide to the 76th street entrance - not a good experience. Furthermore the daily charge of 14.95 for the internet seems a little mean when the room rate is 450 dollars plus all those NY city taxes.

I love this hotel... and you will, too. The rooms are not big, at all, so we upgraded to a suite. The suite made it a bit more comfy (but the price went up a bit, naturally). Housekeeping and room service attendants were very professional and attentive-- and very sweet. We had dinner in the room one evening and breakfast one morning. Very good!! I really like the lobby bar (Bemelman's) for cocktails and good food-- where Woody Allen was playing his horn one evening while we were there. I'd have liked to have seen him and his band, but it caused a great deal of inner conflict for both me and my son (with the open letter in the NYTimes submitted by his young daughter, Dylan, and all)--- so we did not. I'd like to come stay again in April where the great Judy Collins will be playing down in the bar. All in all, this is a quaint and quiet little hotel with superb service on the upper East side of Manhattan where a good number of the more 'refined' celebrities stay in when in NYC-- :)
user_name:
Reta G
Santa Fe, New Mexico

review_body: We booked Christmas Lunch here and it was amazing. Beautiful dining room and food rather good, service excellent and the Christmas carols were memorable.We had a look through other parts of the Hotel and they looked very interesting. It is an old world style which was so beautifully done made nice and cosy on a very cold day.
user_name:
Maggie K
Sydney, New South Wales, Australia

review_body: now this is my kind of hotel! wonderful attendants and very helpful staff all around. our room had beautiful wood floors and everything from the lamps, curtains, bathroom, and the large foyer entrance was elegantly done! it was my second visit to NY and i wanted to get away from the hustle and bustle from the previous area we stayed at which was Times Square. i kind of wanted to stay at the hotel room and just relax but who goes to NY to do that? i can only imagine the view of Central Park from the rooms that were higher above us. i would definitely stay here again if i come back to NY.

We had a fab stay at this friendly, luxury hotel! This was a our second stay in the last 5 months. The hotel has all the luxuries one would expect in a top 5 star City hotel and the staff were super friendly and attentive. We took a larger room with a large bathroom and separate walk in shower which came with all the 5 star extras. The breakfast and bar live up to the legend! Great upper east side location in a shi shi neighbourhood! Looking forward to going back!

Arrived in mid-winter during a cold snap and really enjoyed this property. The Carlyle has a lovely ambiance, provides good value, has outstanding service and a beautiful décor. A lovely hotel and a quiet place to rest and relax after a long and busy day of business.

I used to stay here with my family as a child and had many happy memories. The hotel, and rooms were outstanding, it was simply the place in NYC to stay. The hotel proudly claims that all presidents, Heads of states and ambassadors have stayed he. This is true however sadly they no longer do. I was warned by friends that it is not what it once was, I refused to believe them and booked anyway, what a mistake.I arrived at the front desk looking forward to a long weekend birthday break with my wife, we had flown from London. Upon arrival the hotel couldn't find our reservation. It took me literally 30 minutes of having to go through a very dismissive receptionist to a sub manger eventually on to a manager to eventually get it sorted. I felt I had to prove that I had a reservation (which of course I did). I went up to my junior suite which was a serious disappointment. It clearly has not been touched in a long time. It was clean but frankly that's where my compliments end, I literately have nothing else remotely positive to say about it. The sofa, floorboards, walk in cupboard and curtains were shabby. The tiling grout was crumbling off and bathroom sanitary ware looked like they hadn't been replaced since the 80's. I'm not going to go on you get the point......When I arrived we went to do some shopping, came back for an afternoon nap after our long flight. When we awoke our room was freezing, (-2 outside) there was no hot water affecting both the radiators and shower (not the best when you've just come off a long flight).On our 2nd night we were awoken at 4am by a very happy lady saying "this is your 4am alarm wakeup" WE HADN'T BOOKED ONE!! I mentioned this to the front desk the next day and they kept telling me it was on the 'system' and 'in the computer' that I had booked one. They didn't apologise onceTo say this was disappointing experience would be an understatement it was a disaster from start to finish. It frankly makes me sad, as I say I had wonderful memories from my childhood.
user_name:
Alex P
London, England, United Kingdom

review_body: The Carlyle is famous and popular, but not a worldclass hotel, even after allowing for the generally atrocius quality of New York infrastructure Pros:- great location, although it takes a bit of a walk to the heart of NYC- outstanding five star service- superb breakfast in a luxurious room- nice common areas with distinct Old World charmCons- outdated room design badly needing some renovation- the bed is too soft- THEY CHARGE FOR WIFI. In the XXI century. Even the third world is past this stage by now. Btw, wifi is also dreadfully slow.- the heating is from the 60's, blowing cold and hot air at the same timeOverall enjoyable luxury, magical moments but at this pricepoint it is a mediocre deal

I love the bar at the hotel. We also had the opportunity to hear and see Tommy Tune in the dinner venue. They really know how to pack the people into a small space!! Our room was just worn out - definitely needed updating and the air conditioning was a joke. They immediately sent maintenance when requested to deal with the air conditioning but it was to little avail. The vent blew directly over the bed and their homemade attempts to redirect the vent was not very effective. Hate to say such things about such an institution because we would stay here again - just make sure that you spend the extra to stay in an updated room. The overall ambiance of the hotel is incredible! Be prepared to spend some money because everything is pricey as you would expect in such a grand place.

The Carlyle is, quite simply, a perfect hotel - with impeccable, friendly service, consistently very good food and a lovely ambiance of effortless elegance - all delivered without fanfare or fuss! It is a timelessly elegant hotel and delivers old world Upper East Side charm, charisma and values. Its location on Madison Avenue is excellent for shopping (obviously!), art museums, great restaurants and Central Park. I have stayed here so very many times. In fact, for quite some time back in the 1980s, my husband kept a spacious permanent suite at the Carlyle - so it really was our "home from home" whenever we were back in town, visiting New York from our home in Paris! I even kept my cat Leonora at the Carlyle for a while, and there was no problem at all about her living in our suite - in fact, half a dozen beautiful little fine china dishes, decorated with flowers and butterflies, were provided (without my having to ask) for the service of her cat food. Now, that is real, genuine style! The food in the restaurant is consistently very good, and sometimes it is excellent - though perhaps not always. I can recall just one or two disappointments, but not many! Sunday brunch and afternoon tea here were always a delight. One evening, before dinner, we sauntered into the bar for a quick glass of champagne and who should be sitting there, looking extremely comfortable and content, but Dustin Hoffman. That's the Carlyle for you! Inimitable and very highly recommended!

They must be trained very well, plus they must hire happy people because I've never seen a more accommodating staff! from the elevator operators (who has elevator operators?) to the bar staff, front desk, room service, everyone. I even ran into a maintenance man who was smiling and singing. The concierge got me into a restaurant I couldn't get into...the room was beautiful, clean, spacious (premiere king room), updated modern bathroom (great "rain shower") and even though on the 4th floor overlooking Madison ave, it was quiet! I think must be double insulated windows...could not have been more pleased. Food was excellent (room service) and loved bar ambiance/piano player at the happy hour. Just a wonderful experience, felt very well taken care of.

One of us grew up just blocks from this hotel and we have stayed a couple of times when visiting New York to see parents/in-laws. Both times, we have found the service welcoming and highly professional and friendly. The rooms are comfortable and kept clean during the stay. This year we took advantage of a stay three nights, pay for two special, so our room was smaller than the room we had stayed in previously. it was also a little on the dated side and could have used some freshening up. Also, in the bathroom there was no accessible rack for the towel coming out of the tub/shower. On the whole, these are minor concerns. The room was clean, the bed very comfy, and the service fine. And when you find good, professional, and friendly service in New York, you keep coming back. The location for us is convenient in meeting family obligations. Otherwise, there are trendier areas in New York in which to find a hotel, but if you want the feeling of elegant, old New York (or you grew up nearby and that is what you are used to), you cannot go wrong at the Carlyle.

I generally don't review restaurants or food establishments but afternoon tea at The Caryle's Galllery was a big let-down. Having experienced high teas at other prominent tea rooms around the world, the Gallery does not measure up. The photos on their website are misleading. The actual venue is not in the fashion of a traditional tea room setting. There are two lounge type areas and a sophisticated dining room that is in a separate area. We were seating in an upper lounge area adjacent to the lobby which does not live up to the intimacy of a fine tea room. The lounge area needs a serious make over as well. There was faded wallpaper on the walls and a set of old pillows on banquettes. It was very dark and dated. It lacked the sophistication and elegance which we were expecting; especially at that price point. We were offered a choice of a lunch or tea menu, expecting that afternoon tea was only served from 3 pm. Other patrons were having traditional lunch items and not tea, which detracts from the ambience of a fine tea room. The sandwiches lacked sophistication and were dry. The scones were very disappointing as they should be the edifice of the meal, but were small and dry as well. The strawberry preserves were the saving grace of the condiment plate as the clotted cream tasted uninspired and packaged. The cream lacked flavour as well and was of a hard consistency. I'm not huge on petit fours or small cakes, but they tasted like they were at least one day old and lacked flavour. Three selections per person were served; although their size was also small. The strawberry tart was adequate, the almond medallion lacked depth of flavour and we couldn't taste what type of chocolate the final offering was supposed to deliver. Overall, the service was borderline coordinated and the staff seemed somewhat impersonal.I tried the cinnamon spiced tea which was a little overpowering, kind of like those cheap red cinnamon heart candies at Valentines day. Save your money and go to The Palm while in NYC for high tea.

The Carlyle defines the old-school elegance that has been lost throughout the years. Restaurant is phenomenal....Bemelman's Bar is the PERFECT place to end a New York day. We had a suite with a small kitchenette....felt as though we had our own beautiful apartment in the middle of the UES. Cafe Boulud is less than 1/2 toward Central Park and Zittomer's, right across the street, is a NYC landmark pharmacy not to be missed. (Don't let the word pharmacy confuse you....it's much more)! Word of caution ~ the concierge forgot to call in our SUV for the airport. With two daughters in tow and lots of luggage, had it not been for Uber, we would have missed our flight. If you need a larger vehicle, double check to make sure you'll have a one ready!

This is as good as it gets. Quietly elegant, dignified, and discreet. The hotel is the epitome of comfort, no cavernous spaces and every seat is inviting. The rooms are modern, stylish and handsomely appointed. The staff is impeccable, attentive and not the least bit solicitous.Bemelmans Bar is a classic - one if the best spots for lunch there is. Every space in the hotel has a unique appeal which combined with the quality of the staff makes this property one of the finest there is.

This Hotel was a wonder experience. It still retain the old guard of what hotel should be like.The Service was impeccable, The food was excellent and the Staff was there for You.The rooms were delightful, and well done in the decor. It was block from Central Park, Shopping, and the Neighborhood.I heighly recommend the experience in Staying at this Hotel. Very memorable.

Thanks for another excellent stay! Everything perfect as always ... Truly a home from home. The Carlyle sets a standard which consistently puts it at the very top of the best hotels in the world. Always enjoy staying there and look forward to returning.

Every year or two, my wife and I travel to NYC to visit my brother. In 2005, we stayed at the Carlyle. It was wonderful. After that, we began staying in so-called luxury hotels in mid-town (my brother and his family live in Murray Hill). After a series of relative disappointments, we returned to a suite at the Carlyle for Christmas this year. Accommodations and service were truly first rate. We may never stay anywhere else in NYC.To provide a frame of reference, we traveled to Miami for the Orange Bowl the following week. We bucked up for lovely accommodations on South Beach. Our Carlyle experience was twice as good for half the price. Regarding luxury accommodations, I think the Carlyle represents good value for money.Here was our Tuesday, 12/23/2014: We got up late, strolled up to Nectar for a late breakfast, strolled over to the Metropolitan Museum, where we spent the whole day, strolled back to the Carlyle for early cocktails at the Bemelman's Bar, showered, got dressed up, and walked exactly one block for dinner at Cafe Boulud. Perfect day.
user_name:
Michael H M
New Orleans, Louisiana

review_body: We did not stay here but have made dinner reservation for New Year's Eve.Our experience here was like a dream. Everything, starting with ambient, service and of course food was just perfect. It was the small things and responses to our requests that made this Occassion memorable .We enquired about moving to the bar after dinner service, and the staff went out of their way to ensure we get a table in an already full bar.impeccable service, cosy surroundings and the live jazz band made this New Years celebration memorable beyond our expectations. What made it even more special is the New York people who were there. So easy friendly, outgoing and engaging. Experience we will talk about for a long time to come. On my next visit to New York I would definitely love to stay here. I love this place

We stayed in New York for one night after travelling on the QM 2 from Southampton, had a great time in the hotel. The service and quality was excellent and the food was also supurb.The breakfast buffet is to die for, the best in America, would certainly stay in this hotel next time we are in New York. Thank you Jennifer for taking care of us at reception. Good Job.Alec and Lita BromleyBolton, UK.

This is a truly lovely hotel. The location is perfect: close to Central Park and within walking distance of shopping areas and museums like MoMa, yet quiet and out of the hustle and bustle. The staff are polite and helpful but not intrusive, and the whole place is luxurious without over-doing it. Food is nicely prepared and breakfast in particular is abundant, freshly prepared and lots of choice is available. My room was extremely comfortable. I would have liked tea-making facilities, but these were provided when I asked. Wi-fi is paid: surely this could be free if you're already paying to stay?Two things were annoying: firstly waiting for the lifts (I would rather press the buttons myself than have to wait because the one lift with a member of staff is busy!!). Secondly, at busy times in the bar/ restaurant. For example when we wanted tea, all the tables in the bar were taken so we moved to the restaurant which had space but wasn't officially open until later. No-one was available to take our order (despite asking three different people). We realised that there has to be a system otherwise things can't work and that this involves the restaurant not opening until 6, but it's a few metres away from the bar, and we just wanted a cup of tea while we waited for the car to the airport!

We have stayed many times at the Carlyle and each visit is always memorable. Giovanni and his entire team do a marvelous job and their attention to detail is what makes The Carlyle stand apart from the rest. Our recent stay was to celebrate a birthday and anniversary and the staff was terrific, as always. We had dinner in the restaurant, enjoyed a show and dinner at Cafe Carlyle, lunched in the gallery and ordered room service. We also booked massages for our parents this visit at Sense...and they loved it. Thank you, Robert and Toni

A very special hotel in Manhattan. Old world charm and courtesy with very friendly and helpful staff.Our room was quite small but very clean and comfortable. The cocktail bar is a very atmospheric place to have a drink although we could not get in on the first night at 6.00pm because it was packed.The restaurant is expensive but you certainly get what you pay for.The hotel is close to other bars and restaurants and central park.We would go back.

Stayed four nights and every minute confirmed our decision to stay at the Carlyle. Yes, drinks are $20 in Bemelmans but there is only one Bemelmans. Steve Tyrell's 2014 Christmas show in the Café Carlyle is his best. The elevator operators, bellmen, doorman, concierge and desk staff are all class acts themselves and the smallest detail is their first thought. Stay in the nicest room you can afford. The steps up in the "below suite" categories make a difference. Treat yourself to the New York we miss in most hotels and stay here!

We were excited to stay at this iconic hotel. It has a charm that is classic and elegant - but it is old, and could use a little TLC. We stayed for 4 nights in a one bedroom suite - the living room was lovely, but the master bedroom was underwhelming as the furnishings were very old and the room was very drafty. The bed was comfortable and that's a biggy for us. We chose this suite since the bathrooms had been recently renovated. Having a powder bath was a plus, as the master bath is very small. There was a kitchenette, and it was adequate, but we didn't have a need for it. The gym was small, but it has what one needs. The breakfast room is beautiful and the food is good with a lovely buffet. Overall the staff at the Carlyle was very friendly and helpful - the Concierge desk was one of the best we've experienced...so friendly and exceptionally helpful. The staff in the breakfast room tended to be on the stuffy side. It is a classic in the city, which is why we chose to stay - but we will probably stay elsewhere for our next visit.

This hotel is awesome. Very quiet. Beautiful views from the Tower rooms. Staff is very friendly. Lots of history here. The bar is best hotel bar around. The hotel is in a quiet, safe neighborhood with plenty of shopping and good restaurants within walking distance.

My wife and I stayed at The Carlyle on a recent visit to NYC for business. This storied hotel is really a special place, and it very much lived up to our heightened expectations. I have made a visit to the Cafe Carlyle a regular stop on my periodic visits, and decided this time to make a stay at the Carlyle a part of the experience. We are very glad we did. We felt very much "at home" amidst the consistently professional and pleasant staff. We liked the elevator assistant, the housekeeping staff, and front desk staff. Our room was spacious (wow, that was a surprise considering NYC's otherwise usual definition's of "spacious"), and everything went smoothly. Two minor quibbles: 1) the glass door on the shower was odd and made turning on the faucet very awkward and 2) the front door to the hotel (a revolving door) felt very cramped and crowded. We found that the doormen and other guests congregated right at the outside entrance to these doors. This really is unacceptable and the space should be kept clear for entry/exit. Again, small quibbles to an otherwise wonderful stay.

It is not often you encounter a hotel that immediately feels like your home. At the moment I entered the hotel, I felt that this was going to be good, and it got even better. When I entered my room, which was beautiful and stylish, I felt at home. It is probably the first time i took the time to unpack everything I had and put it in to drawers and the wardrobe, since i was now living in my "second home" as it felt. The service is the best, and the elevators is still run by machine men, who drive the elevator up and down the floors! The bar has to be used every day, and I believe this is the place where JFK met marlin Monroe for dates!

We recently spent 4 nights at thee Carlyle for my wife's 60th celebration. The Carlyle is well located close to upper west side shopping, restaurants, museums and not too far from 5th avenue shopping. Our room was a very large corner room on the third floor overlooking Madison Ave. - an upgrade. While it is close to the street level the soundproofing of the windows was excellent with very little street noise and we had a nice feeling of being close to real people on the street. The bed, linens, pillows etc. were sumptuous as was the overall style and quality of furnishing and decorations in the room. Our bath room was well equipped and luxurious but very small for two people with typical kits of bathroom stuff. Our floor which has the spa and a small gym was extremely quiet. The advantage of the third floor became evident as we realized the manually operated elevators were, while charming to have an elevator man, very slow. The trip up & down to a higher floor would have been a challenge to one's patience.The hotel appeals to Europeans and Latin Americans. All the staff were very helpful and nice. I can see how someone could find them a little stiff, but we did not mind that. The overall style of the hotel is a bit dated but I like that, being a bit dated myself. It lives up to its billing as a luxury hotel and deserves its 5 stars.We did not eat in the restaurant or take advantage of the Carlyle Room as there were too many other options nearby and in NYC in general.

My first visit to New York, a 5 night 6 day stay...a birthday gift from my husband. We visited in mid October 2014 which was the most perfect time, not too cold or too hot...just RIGHT! The trees still had their leaves and were filled with the gorgeous colors of fall. Our trip from the airport to the Carlyle in the early evening was about 45 minutes. The experience of riding a cab over and making our way to the Carlyle was eventful in itself. My eyes were wide with wonder and enjoying every aspect of New York. New York and it's constant buzz of people and cars and buildings and more people in such a tight denomination,such a fast city, was such a wonder to me as I am used to seeing more space and people in flip flops and sweatshirts as everyday wear over the boots and coats and scarves and hats that every New Yorker was wearing.Carlyle is so close to Central Park, a quick 5 minute walk and you're there! That is why I chose it I wanted to stay near the park. The hotel itself looked very welcoming and everyone from the door attendant to the elevator attendant were so polite and welcoming. Our room was a suite decorated with comfortable furniture that made me feel like I was visiting someones home over a dreary hotel room.Had a suite to unwind in. We did not receive any fruit upon our stay which would of been nice but oh well, the fully stocked mini bar was nice.The bathroom space might have been a bit tight but it was definitely comfortable.We each had our own closets for our clothes and the temperature in the room was very comfortable. Did I mention that I loved the showers here,the water was soft and the shower felt like a spa it relaxed me so much I looked forward to it every evening and morning. Housekeeping was wonderful leaving the chocolate treats and turning down our beds at night. The room was very well appointed and relaxing, we enjoyed our stay here very much. We never made it into the restaurant or the bar here as all I wanted to do was be out seeing as much of New York as we possibly could. I had a very pleasant stay here. Yes it is an older more quaint hotel but it's charming because of that and it's located in the heart of Manhattan and 5 minutes from some of the most beautiful areas in NY how can you not enjoy it. It was a wonderful stay a wonderful place to rest after a long and busy day sightseeing.
user_name:
TFinHB
Huntington Beach, California, United States

review_body: As a surprise my wife booked a weekend stay at the Carlyle in celebration of our 15th wedding anniversary. The hotel rates itself as 5-stars. It is antiquated. Devoid of its touted amenities and a sham operation. Not only did we experience the sense of elitism but the staff displays an attitude of condescension. I went to breakfast alone on one day. The maitre'd seated me. I chose to partake in the buffet. When I returned to my table I it to be occupied by another party. I approach the maitre'd whose only reply was " you must be quicker" and walked away. The most troubling chain of events precipitated when my wife fell seriously ill and required the aid of a "concierge doctor" who made a house call to our room. The charge of $500 was acceptable "only in cash". The hotel would provide the appropriate advance, if necessary. The physician did not provide appropriate medical care. Upon our return home the next day, my wife was admitted to a hospital and more specifically to the intensive care unit in serious condition. Since her discharge 5 days later I have called the Carlyle Hotel , General Manager and Director of Operations four times but have not received one return call.In addition, we received NOT ONE call inquiring as to my wife's condition.
