We stayed with a package deal that included dinner and a show at the Café Carlyle. The check-in itself was a wonderful experience. Then guided by a white gloved elevator attendant to one of the most beautiful rooms ever. We had a killer view of the New York skyline. We spent the afternoon exploring Madison Ave. and Central Park, right by the hotel. When we returned a beautiful display of fruit and pastries were in our room. This to help us celebrate our anniversary. We then had a wonderful dinner and show at the Café Carlyle. A perfect "New York" kind of evening. Go if you can for a once in a lifetime stay.

Opened the door to the lovely room and expected good things. Disappointed by everything from the dirty carpet, shabby furniture and unclean bathroom to the ridiculously expensive room service and the never-working room key. One bright spot was the ever present, always African-American, white gloved elevator operator who had a master key and could let me into my room, despite three attempts to get a working key.Have no plans to stay here again --- NYC has too many lovely, first rate hotels to deal with this ever again.Comfortable beds and a gracious receptionist are the only reason I am giving this 3 stars.

My husband and I stayed here sadly, for only one night. The hotel is absolutely beautiful. From the time you enter, there is a peaceful, elegant ambiance. The staff are all super professional yet friendly and helpful. I really wish we could have stayed longer.

My husband and I wanted to show our four children NYC!! We'd just had our first trip the previous year and knew this was a city we wanted our children to experience. Little did we know how we may have ruined it for them to ever go back. You see we booked two rooms. It was our first time not squeezing into one. Upon our arrival we were told our rooms were over booked and we'd be given a suite. That was great! The suite however wouldn't be ready until 7pm. We had 4 hours to wait but we could see it would be well worth it. They graciously held our luggage and pointed us toward the bar area. It's was so quaint. Although a bit pricey, the service was impeccable and highly attentive. Later we found the hotel had paid for our food and drinks for the inconvenience of waiting. We were granted access to a stunning posh one bedroom suite to freshen up in. We of course hit the Central Park and time fly by. At 7pm they took us to our suite and we were flabbergasted. The size, luxurious furnishings and view!!!! It had a full kitchen along with a living room and dining room. We had four nights in what was a premier deluxe suite!! They treated us with great respect and appreciation. I'm afraid the children may never have it so good!! Hahaha THANK YOU to the Hotel and it's competent staff!! We maintained pleasant attitudes upon their struggle and they certainly rewarded us! I enjoyed seeing Tom Selleck in our hotel lobby too!! He looks great!! (Btw if you walk out of the hotel on the corner of 77th and Park Avenue you'll find a fruit and pastry vendor selling breakfast items ( juices too) for $1-$3.00 per item!! Coffee too Save yourself a little $ )

We stayed for but a brief moment. Overnight in Manhattan for a local celebration. But even that momentary glimpse underscored the tradition expected and elegance delivered. There is nothing technologically showy or flashy here. Millennials may not approve...but the fine appointments, the gracious service, the classic decor all combine to score a great overnight stay!

We have been looking for a really nice hotel to stay in for our 1-2 yearly family visits to NYC after Essex House got a new owner and the service level there went down as did the quality of the breakfast. The Carlyle is truly great. A dignified and quiet hotel. Only one block from Central Park, which we do like as we try to go for a run in The Park most days after breakfast. The service it truly outstanding. Couldn't be better. House-keeping is really excellent. I do appreciate that they still have evening turn-down service. You feel so pampered. The gym is great, good equipment and machines. The buffet breakfast is truly awesome and the service is out of this world, truly extraordinary. The staff at the Reception Desk and the Concierges are most helpful. The bathrooms are small, but well kept and equipped. I do not like that the hotel charges extra for WiFi. (We had it included in our room rate, but still.) Include free WiF with unlimited number of devices for all guests. And then I do not like that you are charged extra for e.g. latte, cappuccino and so forth when you have the full breakfast buffet. The buffet breakfast is so expensive, that I think that all kinds of coffee should be included. We had a suite with rooms not facing 76th Street and our room was really quiet.

I stayed here with my mom and teenage daughter for a long weekend trip. It was a great location a block from Central Park. Ask for room on floor 18 or higher to get a great view. The service was impeccable! From the door man, elevator man, front desk staff and the wait staff in the restaurant. The Breakfast buffet was really good and they remembered our drink preferences from the first day. Called us by name in the restaurant. I don't usually stay in hotels of this quality - more the Holiday Inn/Delta Hotels/Sheraton kinda gal but this hotel is impressive! We were able to walk most places....time square took some time though. Discovered it was only a $13 cab ride so did that a few times. It is in a nice quiet area and was a close walk to The Met and the American History Museum. Only downside is the rooms only offer a king bed or 2 twins and a rollaway if needed for a third person. Each room is different which is nice....no carbon copies here. Bathroom was smaller but beautiful. Hard to argue with a hotel that hosted the Kennedy's.

I have stayed at this landmark hotel countless times and am never disappointed. Didn't want to pass on the opportunity to congratulate the hotel and its staff for staying a cut above the rest. As ever a joy to stay at a home away from home.

Just back from 6 nights at the Carlyle.We booked a package with Expedia and price seemed too good to be true. We had some concerns that the room may not be that good.We needn't have worried. The room was spacious, comfortable, quiet and clean. The hotel was in a good location two blocks from the subway. Staff were courteous and helpful throughout.Can't moment on restaurant or bar as we never used either.The Carlyle was a great base for us

I have been coming to the Carlyle since 1990/1989? First as a single young girl, the for business then as a married woman and now as a divorcee. I travel to NYC several times per year and this year alone I would have stayed a total of 30 nights! I have always been treated incredibly well and I have always been a loyal customer, but during this stay (10 days) I have had enough. I was given a suite on 9th floor, good size, usual Carlyle old fashioned decor, the suite didn't look like it had been prepared to the usual standard, my fruit basket was two depressing red apples and two tangerines, not a single flower. The lights In the suite were not plugged in, there were no drinking glasses by the mini bar the blind in the bathroom was broken, so was one in the bedroom and the only shelf in the bathroom was broken too! After my complaints some things got fixed, but more and more things went wrong. After smelling smoke in my room the next day and after a thorough investigation by security I was told I was on a smoking floor! Didn't they know me well enough by now to know I don't smoke? Finally my daughter was having surgery and I told them I couldn't get back to a room that stunk of smoke so they agreed I should move, only I was taking her to hospital and the coming back in the afternoon to put her to bed. The manager agreed to move everything to a new suite for our return from hospital, they even told my travel agent who at this point got involved from the UK. On my way back to the hotel, with my 12 year old woozy from a general anaesthetic I called the hotel ahead in order to make sure the key to the new suite was ready, only to find out that 6 hours after leaving the hotel nothing had been done. I was at my wit's ends, I am not going to bother you with the sequence of the conversations with front desk management, travel agents etc etc, i will only conclude with this: I finally settled my daughter into the new room on Thursday afternoon and I have not had a single message from anybody apologising, or asking me if everything was ok or anything else, I didn't even even get two apples and two tangerines!!

I am not reviewing accommodation - this a review of the Bar off the hotels lobby. And what a wonderful experience that is. A dim lit space with tables and table lamps, white coated waiters and fabulous music with piano player singing with back up vocalists and other musicians. It's the type of NYC experience I look for. Cover charge $25.

Stayed at the Carlyle for 6 nights and I have to say that it live up to its reputation. Service was top-notch and there was always someone around to ask if we had questions. At first, i wasn't too sure about the elevator guys but I came to love them after a day or so. They are really classy employees. Restaurant, Cafe, and Bar were excellent and Molly Ringwald was terrific. We were celebrating our 60th birthdays this year and they gave us some extra special treatment, which was greatly appreciated. We loved the location of the hotel and everything is easily accessible. Just be careful, the meals can be a little expensive but they are absolutley top-shelf. All in all, we loved our stay and will likely come back next year.

My stay here was paid for by my hosts, so my view is not jaundiced by the ridiculously high prices, but if you're paying your own way, you'll probably want to know that breakfast at the Carlyle will set you back $40-50 for a pancake or a waffle. Coffee is $9 a cup. And you're invited to tip both the wait staff and the captain, separately. Of course you will get a ballet of waiters setting dishes down simultaneously before you and your companions, if you like that sort of thing. The suites are relatively spacious for a New York hotel room, and the appointments are comfortable enough, but to get to your room you'll need to watch the elevator man (yes, there is an elevator man to push the buttons on the elevator that you could easily push yourself) slip into his white gloves and show you the respect of a house slave, which might be nice if you like to feel like a plantation master. If not, not. The service is on the whole excessive, bordering on obsequious. And it would be nice if all the lamps in the room worked and if the TV remote didn't need batteries. On the other hand, the screens are large in both bedroom and living room. The location is convenient to the Met, Whitney, Neue Galerie, etc. For $800 a night, you might expect free wifi, but you will be disappointed with both the price and the signal strength.

Then you have to spend time at the Carlyle Hotel. From the wonderful ambiance of the building to the incredibly friendly and attentive staff, you can't go wrong when you need a place to stay while in New York. It didn't seem to matter what your station was in life, they treated everyone with courteous attention, friendliness and warmth. The fact that I am disabled and need a scooter to get around didn't phase them. The security staff assisted my husband and I to enter and exit the Hotel without a hitch. You can't go wrong by choosing the Carlyle for your stay in NYCity!!

There are many luxury hotels to choose from in New York, but few that give you the personal attention and touch as The Carlyle. From the minute we made our reservation to the day of our check out their attention to detail was exceptional. My husband and I were celebrating our 25th anniversary and "all" the hotel staff made an effort to congratulate us. The personal monogrammed sheets were such an exceptional surprise. The service truly made you feel as though you had a home away from home. The suite decor was beautiful and the morning breakfast buffet was delicious. The location in the upper east side is perfectly located in the middle of high end shopping, great local cafés, the park and museums. I would highly recommend it for couples. The hotel is located between Madison Ave and Park Avenue.

Stayed a night here because it was connected with a place we were visiting in NYC, and then got bumped up to a suite. I am usually pretty blase about hotels, but this was an amazing experience. The suite consisted of a bedroom (with an original Picasso on the wall), a living room with a grand piano, two bathrooms, and a small kitchenette. My only quibble was that the alarm clock/radio was hard to figure out and went off early in the AM (a time the previous guest had set). The hotel is quite pricey (our room was discounted, but the breakfast was the most expensive I have ever had at a hotel.) The hotel has a rich history (JFK used to stay there), and it was truly a memorable experience.
user_name:
Robby71
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: We booked a room (via the hotel website) at the Carlyle for four nights a couple of weeks ago. What we wanted: a pretty, luxurious room and the good service you would expect from a luxury hotel close to Central Park (we are widely travelled professionals, youngish, and have stayed in luxury hotels in Paris, London, and Venice, as well as in NY, Boston, Philadelphia, D.C. etc.). What we got: the ugliest room we have ever stayed in and the worst service we have ever experienced. From the moment we checked in (our room wasn't ready at 1:30p, even though they had asked us when we would be arriving, so we were told to go away and come back, literally), and throughout the full four days, we had inferior service, an ugly room (the first room was so dark and depressing and poorly furnished - maybe redone back in the 1980s -- that I said I just could not stay in it. When we complained about the room, a woman at the front desk took us up to a room that had not yet been completely renovated; she then told us to stay in the room in which they had put us in and she would find us a room and get back to us. When she didn't get back to us, my husband went down asked another man at the front desk, who said "well, did you book through a discount website?" The second room, although larger, was the same (we didn't want a larger room; we wanted a prettier room). The ugly 1980s chintz curtains were literally falling off the curtain rod, the room was furnished with furniture that looked like it had been purchased at Walmart in the 1950s (see photos), and the bathroom was so contrived as to have to step all the way into the tub to turn the water on. This was not a luxury hotel stay. I don't know to whom The Carlyle is giving the luxury rooms, but it surely was not us. The staff was terrible; the entire four days, all we were asked was "what floor?" although we did get a '"you're welcome" when we said "thank you," and they said good morning and good night. I'm still in shock. I had always wanted to stay at the Carlyle, and it was a huge disappointment in every way.

Our room wasn't ready when we arrived but the front end person invited us to wait in the lounge or bar and have a drink at their expense. Then she escorted us over ther. That's great service.When our room was ready we had been upgraded to a very nice and comfortable suite. Again that's great service. Is it expensive -- yes. But it's a nice experience that won't be forgotten.

the room was wonderful, the area was fantastic. All good, except dogs are aloud in the hotel and we had a little yapper in room next to us. I'm sure if I complained it would have been handled; but only for one afternoon I was doing emails. This was both business and pleasure as we were there for our daughters wedding tasting at the boathouse. Husband had business and daughter and I did spa!!

Enjoyed a week at the Carlyle. The hotel staff was always helpful. Our stay was made better by the attention of Anthony in the restaurant and Stephanie, the concierge. All of her recommendations were perfect and wonderful. Our only reason not to stay is access and accomodations for guests using a wheel chair. The main entry doors are too small for wheel chairs, there were too many steps in lobby, and wheel chair guests are sent to the basement and back of hotel service areas, to get back to Lobby. We entered and exited via the service entrance. Not exactly the entry or exit we expected. Learned future bookings will include a call to hotel and ensure it can accommodate guests with wheelchair accessibility and its special needs. We understand the planned renovation will address this issue.

History does not make this hotel any better than any other in New York City. This is another hotel pretending to be first class and it is nowhere near first class, nothing special. Make history, my fellow readers, and stay at another hotel, for you as the paying customer will make history. The Management of this hotel has one aim, to profit off of it's history. There is no longer a valid reason to consider staying at this hotel. I assure every reader that this hotel is nothing special and it's owners are profiteering off of its history. This place is DEAD. no question about that!
user_name:
dlockwood
New York City, New York

review_body: One of the benefits of travelling is that when you find a place that you love, it really is like finding a home away from home. We stumbled upon the Carlyle many years ago and has since become our favorite hotel in New York City. The staff is among the best in New York City. It makes our children (and my husband and me) feel extra special, appreciated and welcome when we arrive and everyone says, "Hey, Dr. and Mrs. Hardy! It's so nice to see you back." Or "Welcome back, girls! What adventures do you have going on this time around?!"Once you become a regular here, much more so than at other hotels we've frequented, the staff is always accommodating and ready to help with rates and special amenities. The restaurant is grand for each and every meal and Bemelman's is the best bar in New York City. The only issue I think some people may have is that the bathrooms tend to be small and connecting rooms are sometimes hard to come by. The Upper East Side location is not super convenient to much, except the Whitney Museum (it is literally a block away), the Met and Central Park, but that is usually the reason people stay here. It has a decidedly residential appeal. In very close walking distance are some of Manhattan's finest restaurants.If you are looking for an upscale, old New York hotel that is more of a home than a hotel, then you will find all you need at the Carlyle as many suites have kitchenettes as well. We love staying here!

I've stayed at the Carlyle around two dozens times over the last several years and it's been wonderful every time. From the bellmen, front desk, room service, restaurant, concierge, all staff make you feel welcome and cozy at this lovely traditional NYC landmark hotel. It's simple and elegant, reserved yet happening. There may be "better" hotels in the city but I have no reason to go anywhere but The Carlyle.

Celebrated our fortieth anniversary with six nights at the Carlyle. Our stay was beyond amazing in a most luxurious, understated way. This historic hotel offers everything you need for a wonderful stay. Loved being on the Upper East Side with the beauty of Central Park a block away. What a great way to enjoy the vibrancy of the City with good walks, a taxi or subway nearby. The Carlyle was such an elegant place to come home to after a day enjoying all that New York has to offer. Staff was particularly professional yet very welcoming! We hope to make staying at the Carlyle our annual anniversary celebration.

This Hotel has been my Favorite for Many Years, as I frequent it for weekend stays in Manhatten, as a great place to stay for touring the city, Fine restaurants, Broadway shows, and all the Fun of Fall and Winter in Manhatten. The Hotel has beautiful rooms, great services, a wonderful restaurant and a Bar/Nightclub with fabulous entertainment. Inquire as to whom is entertaining and the various scheduled performers.

Hotel is old world chic. Our Manhattan experience was enhanced by staying at this great old world hotel. Minor problems with belhop and housekeeping did not distract from overall quality of stay at hotel.Bemelmen's Bar was exceptional; great music in an intimate old world New York room.Overall, service was inconsistent for the high price paid to stay here. Despite lapses in service, our overall stay was highly enjoyable.

Loved the Carlyle.Fabulous hotel for people watching.Beautiful decor in public areas. Velvet on the walls and the couches.3 lifts with a full time doorman in each.Very low key bar for night time entertainment.Beautiful marble floors and plush seating.Exquisite service where everyone remembers your name and your floor number.More like a home than a hotel. Very intimate. Rooms a little dated but hardly worth a mentionas so much as overwhelms with class and warmth. Upper East End location so a wonderful respite from the clamour and noise of mid-town but still easily accessible.

I loved everything about this one of a kind "swanky" hotel. It was like a magical retreat back to the time of elegance and wonderful service. Plus the Sense Spa is stunning! Everyone there makes you feel like a celebrity, pampered and special. The entrance sets the tone as so very stunning. You feel like you are in a private oasis. Can't wait to go back!

A good and durable long-term love relationship has at its heart, this one fact: Rather than caring only about looks or an idealized image, personality and compatibility matter ABOVE ALL.Check-in at The Carlyle is more courteous, reassuring, efficient and mind soothing after four hours in a car - so much so that it's almost a mental spa experience.Once your bags are in hand with one of the uber-competent bellmen, it's all about the gentleman who runs the lift at the Carlyle. If his name is Allen, you are in luck, my friend. Every time we have the good fortune to encounter Allen in the elevator, he remembers my daughter's name - and if she is with a friend whom we have brought with us on a prior visit, no matter how long we've been away, he somehow remembers her name, too. And then Allen invites my daughter and her pal to sit down on top of each other on the little corner seat and Allen sweetly croons a song from Porgie and Bess to her and her girlfriend all the way up to our floor, or all the way down to the lobby. Allen has the warmth, charm and personality of your very dear and favorite uncle. Allen is a true and irreplaceable gentleman.Gustavo, who is younger, newish, sometimes mans the door, sometimes runs the lift, carries your heavy bags around cheerfully, speaks sincerely, looks you in the eye, smiles, asks if you are enjoying yourself - and actually listens to your answer and asks follow-up questions - also remembers you every time he sees you, like you've only been away for the afternoon. Gustavo is the prompt, courteous utility outfielder of The Carlyle - what ever it is, if he can't get it done for you, he will immediately run to get you the person who can....Peter, the European Maitre d' is exceedingly formal, deferential, serious, reminds you of Mr. Carson from Downton Abbey. I consider it a personal "win" if I can get him to almost smile. He runs the dining room with the quiet, discreet precision of a champion sheepdog trainer. He nods and some formally dressed gentleman silently, unobtrusively jets away to refold and replace a napkin almost before you've moved from your chair.And Charles - the truly fantastic and mid-western, raised on a farm, Charles - trained at the CIA to be a chef, who is also an incredibly knowledgeable sommelier (and will, kindly, smartly, guide you toward a superior wine choice for your meal despite it being less expensive - this is good service!) - is also a superbly warm, personable and engaging room captain for the dinner hours....I don't know about you - but I love this sort of service and think it is growing increasingly rare, regardless of the price point at which you are being racked in the competitively expanding world of modern hoteliery. And as someone who stays in hotels all over the world no less than a dozen times a year, I am telling you: Nobody, anywhere, has got it all pulled together the way The Carlyle does....Which leads me to the most significant complaint that can be made about The Carlyle: The food is not exactly inedible - but I've never been able to finish any breakfast or dinner there, in all the times we've stayed, and always because the food preparation was So Very Poor. The menu is tantalizing - but the preparation and presentation look like something bland and overcooked and bluntly prepared, like a 1950's "steak and a Rob Roy" cliche. The food - even breakfast - whether you eat from the smorgasbord, the a la cart, or ask for special preparation - mediocre, EVERY time, EVERY season. Nothing fresh, nothing flavorful - just mediocre food. Mediocre in the Cafe Carlyle, mediocre in Bemelmans', especially mediocre in the dining room (we recommend drinks before dinner and wine with dinner - it really is the only way the food seems tolerable, especially at Carlyle prices...). My husband and I eat there more than we should considering what food snobs we are - but we get comfortable at The Carlyle and fail to reach escape velocity, or we're going downstairs to see a show and eat in the bar, and every time (not kidding) one of us turns to the other and says "I thought we had a deal: we will NOT take meals at the hotel...". I keep praying there will be a food upgrade, that this will change - it doesn't. Six years in now, and it doesn't.... Let me say, in fairness, I have zipped into NYC for day visits, dined in the upper oval of the sumptuously appointed Gallery room and had a perfectly lovely though not impressive or unique lunch. Solid salads, predictable but flavorful appetizers and sandwiches. It is a superb drink destination - creative with a strong, over sized pour (one drink is usually plenty) and the desserts are adequate. My husband and I love to snuggle in a banquet for a nightcap before bed after the girls have gone to sleep.Much of what I love about The Carlyle is the predictability, the comfortable lack of unpleasant surprises, the military precision of the service personnel combined with their warmth and knowledgeability which hints at staff longevity. Perhaps the hotel is loyal to a long-time chef who has lost his ability to cook even the plainest of steaks without turning them into gray, baseball mitt-grade leather, the mere scrambling of eggs into a rubbery, dingy looking, flavorless mess on your plate.... Bad coffee, boring teas, but good and plentiful butter.We must discuss the physical plant. The facility is - well, plainly - old - and in serious need of upgrading (which is promised to commence next year - there is talk of trying out several designers, including a rumor of taking style cues from Ralph Lauren whose gorgeous and enviably designed flagship mens' and women's shops are just down the street from the hotel).The lobby is one of the best in all of NYC - invitingly stepped below street level, festooned with truly creative, fresh and attractive floral arrangements that never fail to WOW. The public spaces are consistently immaculate, gleaming and seem warmly welcoming in style, chicly appointed, a fine marriage of established and modern.Most of the rooms and suites with regard to decor and ambience are beautifully shabby-chic,no two seem alike. They are worn but clean, and as durable, timeless, elegant, refined - as classically old New York glamorous as Ms. Elaine Stritch who was a long time resident, the World Famous Doyenne Chanteuse of The Carlyle (prior to her death in July). The furniture in the rooms is occasionally hilariously out of date, visually tired, sometimes strangely mismatched as if bought at a yard sale featuring style hits from the 40's through the 70's (a gold flocked, white painted Versailles arm chair with a chrome and smoked glass side table? Yup - Really.)Many of the suites saw time as small efficiency apartments in their day and are accompanied by a full, walk-in galley kitchen (no cookware available but the appliances and small sink still work). The bathrooms are an artifact of their era - tiny, practical - and in an attempt to compensate for their smallness they are lined - fully - floor to ceiling, even the cabinets, with mirrors (front, back, sides). Regardless - the bathrooms are immaculate, well appointed with excellent and heavy towels from either Frette or Yves Delorme (who makes all of Hermes' bath linens) and provided with plentiful Kiehl's cleansing amenities. T-H-E best showers I have had anywhere, period - great pressure, solid-consistent volume, easy temperature regulation, I could camp in there for a week.Among the ways we love The Carlyle: location, location, etc. Can't get enough of the perfection of this location (including being across the street from the mysteriously money syphoning labyrinth known as Zitomer's - the mad love child of a high-end pharmacy/department store coupling. Give the thrifty teenagers 50 bucks, send them safely across the street, see them three hours later proudly toting a dazzling array of really interesting cosmetic finds, jewelry and fabulous Zitomer tchotchkes).The Carlyle is walking distance to a fat slice of everything that is great about New York: museums, park, music, restaurants, shopping, quick cab down to the theater. I met a man there last year who finally bought an apartment in the Carlyle after bunking there every time his family flew in from Cincinnati, 6 times a year, to see the middle child at NYU... It was just too convenient and cost effective he claimed.. The door men are spot-on prompt about getting you a cab - very little waiting unless it is rush hour or there is some attention (and cab) hoarding event nearby - which leads to this: My child posse have scored sightings of Jagger AND Gaga there ( a Very Big Deal to the kids!).Among The Carlyle's most significant charms (the only real contender on the upper East side now that they are no longer in competition with the exited midtown hotel draw of Feinstein) is the fact that it is home base to both the Cafe Carlyle and Bemelman's musical venues, regularly featuring no less than the has-no-peer exceptional jazz guitar genius, John Pizarelli (saw him there this year doing incomparable bossa nova set with Brazilian bossa-wunderkind,Daniel Jobim; and where Pizzarelli is regularly accompanied by members of his equally genius family - his father, Bucky, from who he learned much-much, and his smoothly suave, stand-up bass slapping brother, Martin - and, when we're really lucky, his phenomenally beautiful and almost siren-voiced wife, Jessica Molaskey).Word to new patrons: If you plan to see a show at the Cafe Carlyle - be prepared to be socially engaged with the other patrons among whom you will be seated cheek-to-jowl with the merest of walking space between you and your hindmost fellow guest - and yup, the food will be mediocre, the service hectic - but that's kind of a wacky part of the charm. You're going to sit with someone from Jersey on your left (who may ask for the remainder of your butter) and the lady in full-on Hermes on your right will have come in from Italy just to see this show. It's going to be cramped, overly warm, and is not for the claustrophobic. The drinks are stiff and usually prompt, the wine list is fine, your bread roll will be cold but early - relax, the music will be great, the room is kookily but enjoyably intimate like a speak easy. There are no "bad" seats, so set an example and be great company for other strangers.

For years, I've admired The Carlyle from afar. It's where the stars and presidents of yore rested their heads, and where my beloved Woody Allen plays with his jazz band on Monday nights. Even while living in New York City, the Carlyle was still a place I longed to stay. So, when on a whim, my boyfriend and I found this hotel at an unbelievably low rate (4th of July weekend), we went for it.The staff was amazing. We waited for not more than five minutes while they tried to find our reservation, but they upgraded us for our "inconvenience." As a result, we got to stay in a breathtaking corner room. The hotel is old and classic and the room reflected that. I loved that aspect of it. My boyfriend is a fan of modern flare, so he was not as in love as I was, but even he had to concede that The Carlyle lived up to its legendary reputation. The coffee downstairs, which is complimentary every morning, is really good. Nice bonus.

Great classic and elegant hotel. The staff are the best that we have ever experienced. We had trouble with our air conditioning. They did the best they could to accommodate us. Everything else was great. We walked all over the city. Central Park is very close. The concierge (Waldo) was very helpful. He arranged a driver for us which was a great way to get around Manhattan and learn about the sites and the city. Ask for Mike Richards to drive you. Great guy, good driver. Very knowledgable and friendly. Bemelmans Bar is absolutely fantastic. Drinks with great music create a special atmosphere. Can't wait to go back!

First time staying at this elegant hotel. I was not disappointed. Beautiful decor. Our suite was spotless and classic. Bed was soooo comfy. Waitstaff was very pleasant as well as accommodating. Breakfast buffet was over the top. Could not imagine anyone not finding something wonderful to start the day. A truly pampering experience.

My wife and I spent three nights at what I can best describe as the classiest hotel I have ever experienced. I have to admit that I am mostly a "Holiday Inn budget" type of traveller but since we were celebrating our 25th anniversary I wanted a unique experience. The staff at the Carlyle hit it out of the park! From the professional service at check in, to the extremely attentive service by all staff I couldn't have been made to feel more comfortable and at ease. A special note of thanks to both Jeff and Robert the concierges who were both extremely helpful and epitomized professionalism. Hope to one day return and take in more of what this hotel can offer

This is a wonderful staff and beautiful place to stay, all around. The hotel is classic in style, with beautiful antique furniture in the rooms. But the overall feeling is light and spacious, and rooms are more updated than anywhere I've stayed. The beds are soft and comfortable. And the large windows offer excellent views.

I have had the pleasure of staying at the Carlyle sixteen times this year, each one of those stays was fantastic. The hotel is beautiful and in a fabulous location, less than two blocks from central park.I have stayed at many hotels and this is a special place that lives up to its reputation.The bellman are very attentive, the valet parking is excellent (the lot is 10 yards from the entrance) The front desk staff are always friendly, after only a few stays they started to remember me and greet me with a "welcome back Mr. Bick" They also seem to reward loyalty, on more than one occaision I have received a handwritten note from the manager thanking me for my continued patronage. The attended elevators are another feature that make guests feel special.The rooms are clean, spacious and beautiful, I have had the pleasure of staying in many of the rooms and have yet to be dissapointed. Frette Linens, Yves Delorme towels, great mattresses and dependable climate control make for a very comfortable experience. The bathrooms have the best water pressure of any hotel I have expreienced. The Caryle soap is awesome and the Kiehl's products are the best. The housekeeping staff is supeior, they take pride in their work and go the extra mile. Another great feature of the hotel is that no room is exactly the same. The rooms I have stayed in have all had ample closet space as well.The entertainment at the hotel is fantastic. Bemelmans bar is an intimate venue to see live music such as the Loston Harris Trio or Chris Gillespie. Bemelmans has great drinks and food as well. The Cafe Carlyle, a bit more formal is also top notch and attracts great acts such as Steve Tyrell and Alexa Ray Joel.The Carlyle differentiates itself from other hotels by being intimate, classy and dependable. The building is beautiful, the rooms are comfortable and the staff is highly attentive. The fact that they also go out of their way to remember repeat clients means a lot.
user_name:
Ross B
New York City, New York

review_body: We are simple people and our expectations are not exceptional. Having said that, this hotel is rated a 5 star and Frommer's rates it as one of the best of the best, therefore, one would assume that there would be a lot of attention to detail.Here is our experience. Upon using the bathroom for the first time, I discovered that the toilet had feces in it presumably from the previous guest which tells me the toilet was not cleaned by housekeeping prior to our arrival.The first time I went to use the complimentary body lotion, I opened the cap and noticed that the was lotion smeared all over it. It was clear it had been used and wasn't replaced in between guests. The bathroom smelled terribly during our entire stay. I couldn't put my finger on it but it was bad enough to make me sick to my stomach. I only used the bathroom when absolutely necessary and applied my makeup using the mirror in the room.It was impossible to shower without getting water all over the bathroom floor. The shower door didn't shut properly.My husband noticed white particles all over the floors and asked me if I had dropped something. I hadn't. The particles were still there when we checked out 4 days later. Noone vaccumed the floors prior to our arrival and during the 4 days that we stayed there. The elevators are small and operated by someone at all times. Although there are 4 elevators, it did not appear that all 4 were being operated. This means that it takes forever to get an elevator and when it finally arrives, you and 10 other people are trying to squeeze into a very small space. It's rather uncomfortable!Overall, it was just ok.

So I have never written a review but in this case I have too. First, when we got to the hotel it took quite a while and a few trips to get someone to lock the door to the room that was attached to ours. Then we had to stuff things behind the headboard because it banged every time we moved. We asked for it to be fixed but it was never done which lead to a bad sleeping situation. I tried to take a bath and when I turned on the jets stuff shot out, it must have been mold because after I cleaned it out and attempted another bath I noticed mold under the soap dish and hand rails. The guy you ask questions too for recommendations was very helpful but one day a staff member was in there. Now I am 6 months pregnant, he asked me how far along I was and he said "wow, your big aren't you". Who says that!!! The last night we were there, we called the front desk about 4 times trying to get them to quiet our neighbor from singing and smoking really late at night. (Which the walls are super thin and you can hear everything from a dog bark to a microwave go off). Nothing was ever done and we ended up leaving at 2am. I told the front desk how unhappy I was and he just said "sorry about that". The guys who operate the elevators are super nice but I feel bad for them. It's cramped and super hot in there. We will never go back...plus I know one of the maids ate my grapes, they don't just go missing haha

After waiting for hours for our room to be ready since we flew red eye from California, we were so disappointed when we got to the room they gave us. The room is over looking Madison Avenue but since it's in the third floor we can see the people walking and they can clearly see us. We feel like we were prisoners because we can't even leave the drapes open. We travelled twice a year and we are lucky enough to be able to mostly stay in nice resorts and hotels so these experience and setting is upsetting and disappointing. I was so excited when we left California since I have read nice reviews about Carlyle but this is not the upscale hotel I was expecting. In my opinion it is better to spend the money going on vacation to Hawaii, Florida, Las Vegas and the Carolina's. We called the reception/front desk and requested to be transferred. We were told that nothing is available but that they will try to move us the next day since we are staying for 5 nights. Another reason why I'm so disappointed with this hotel is because of the uncaring attitude of the front desk staff. They know that we flew red eye and that we were waiting for our room but they are clearly waiting for the check.-in time (3:00 pm) even though hotel room is ready. I will make sure not to stay in this hotel again next time I vacation in NY.

I was lucky enough to spend my birthday here! Room upgraded to the 30th floor with an incredible view! Staff was so nice and accommodating! I loved the elevator attendants. Loved the bath products (Kiehl's). Had lovely night of drinks in Bemelmans bar and we had Roger as a server. He was very nice and remembered us the next evening. The martinis are priced around $22, but they are generous on the portions! The music in the bar was amazing, too. It's a magical hotel! I hope to go back soon!

We went to the Carlyle for my first trip to New York. My partner had been to NYC a few times but never to stay in somewhere like the Carlyle. It really feels like you've stepped into an old film with its elegant furnishings, beautiful 30s-40s interior and attentive service. Our room was clean, stylish and comfortable with a fabulous view across Central Park. The shower was incredibly powerful,just what you need after a long trip from London. The plumbing was a bit dodgy sometimes but it hardly seemed to matter as there was hot water aplenty and wonderful Kiehls toiletries to enjoy.A highlight was a visit to Bertleman's Bar which has a lovely demi-monde feel with its gorgeous painted walls and subtle lighting. Chris Gillespie added to the retro ambience with beautiful piano playing, even playing some Rogers and Hart at my request. I feel honoured!Staff could not be more attentive or helpful. All in all a wonderful place to have as a base for exploring New York. I really did feel like an old movie star. Thank you. x

This is our tenth or so semi annual trip to NYC and we have tried other hotels, but the Carlyle is a consistently gracious place to live for a week at a time, while also being a good value. Hotel management attempts to maintain a classic residential "feel", while making guests feel unique and pampered.

Just another wonderful stay at this beautiful nyc landmark with outstanding service. We were upgraded to a larger suite with a grand piano which my husband loved playing! The breakfast buffet in the gorgeous dining room was delicious and we loved having drinks at Bemelmans listening to the incomparable Chris Gillespie.

Our recent stay at this grand hotel lived up to , if not exceeded our expectations. Our superior king room was beautifully decorated, spacious, and surprisingly quiet. We slept in twice during our stay due to the peace and quiet in this oasis of calm, in the heart of the upper east side. Walking distance to exceptional dining, Central Park, and great shopping, but there is a car service if you want to wander a bit further afield. Thanks to Lori in Bemelmans bar, and Waldo the concierge who made our stay even more enjoyable with their wonderfully personal service. We will definitely be back.

I came here after purchasing a TravelZoo dinner voucher. Typically, when purchasing one of these types of vouchers, I have gotten used to the restaurant short changing me on the amount that they offered. That did NOT happen here. I was pleasantly surprised by the amount of choices I had for Appetizer, Entree, & Dessert. The wait staff was extremely courteous and I appreciated their making small talk with us and other tables (it showed they had personality). I ordered the Crab Cake and Lobster Thermidor. All I can say is WOW! The crab meat was so extraordinarily fresh, and the sauce that accompanied it was delectable. However, the Lobster dish transported me back to when I was a child and Thermidor was my absolute favorite dish to have at a local restaurant (that has since closed). I truly appreciate the dining experience here and look forward to coming again!

I've been to many hotels in New York. But this is the best.Discreet, stylish and elegant. It's obvious to see why this hotel is favoured by celebrities. The meticulous attention to detail is astounding. From the welcoming chocolates and champagne to celebrate our anniversary, to our beautiful room, we were treated like royalty. But the best thing about the Carlyle is the people who work there. All its staff are wonderful. But its concierge is the best I have experienced at any hotel. Waldo and Dwight, take a bow. One bad thing about our stay is knowing that every other hotel I'll go to in the future, won't match the standards of the Carlyle.

Hotel is outdated, dirty carpets,motel furnishings,unattentive staff,rooms smell old and musty,dirty curtains,creaky floor boards,furniture look like they came from thrift stores headboard was very dirty and i took a picture,tiny bathrooms .Waited in the bar for a drink 20minutes,waiter forgot what we ordered came back after 20min.This is not a 5 star hotel,Hardly ever a doorman in attendance.Unless you shell out $800 and up in a Tower room, it is a dump,compared to the Pierre for the same price room were we usually stay,do not recommend

My wife and i spent a night last week in New York and returned to the Carlyle after a twenty-year hiatus. We were very happy that we did so. The staff was warm and welcoming and its small size make it a very comfortable home-away-from home. The public spaces are beautiful as always, but our room showed its age and our bathroom was tiny. We will definitely not wait twenty more years to come back.

My wife and daughter are staying at The Carlyle this week in anticipation of my 17 year old daughter participating in some professional theatre training next week and moving to NYC next month to attend a dance conservatory. I wanted to make their arrival special, so I called The Carlyle's concierge asking if he could assist me in having chocolate covered strawberries (their favorite) delivered to their room, thinking that he could help me arrange a delivery from a nearby confectioner. The concierge, instead, suggested that their room sevice department could possibly do what I wanted and connected me with Kimberly (I wish I had asked for her last name so I could write my thanks to her directly) in the Room Service Department. KImberly said that she thought the pastry chef would be able to do what I wanted. She was so patient with me, took my dictation for a note that I wanted to accompany the berries, and even advised me that she would ask the pastry chef to try to create a "ballet theme" to the strawberries...Well, Kimberly and the pastry chef outdid themselves!!! My daughter immediately emailed a photo (and, of course, posted it on social media) of an incredibly creative and delectable presentation of a dozen assorted chocolate covered strawberries set against a chocolate sillouetted backdrop of a ballet dancer. I have posted the photo here. The creation was a big hit with my wife and daughter and on social media. Thank you, Carlyle staff, for your time, thoughtfulness and creativity in making something so simply special.

For my first visit to New York City is was hard to make a decision on a hotel. After reviewing all the Hotel ratings and comments I settled on The Carlyle Hotel. I was excited about the visit and was all set to go. Once I arrived I was greeted and the staff was right on top of things. They were interested in our visit and gave us details on what to expect. One expectation that they set was that the Dining area was being services and would not be accessible during the weekend. They did make us aware that room service was available and the Bar would be open. We were now off to start our New York City visit for this special wedding anniversary - "which a mentioned to the staff once I arrived." Off to our room which was UPGRADED by the Management staff just because. As we started to make plans for a quick lunch... we started out of our room. As we made it to the elevator we ran into room service with a 'cart'. Me noticing my last name on the card, I stopped him and said is that for our room. He stated YES!...what a surprise from MR. BEAR and the staff at the Carlyle. 5 Large Chocolate Covered Strawberries, Chocolate Cake and a bottle of champagne. Thanks Bear and the Carlyle staff for a great visit.

The AC was not working so at 2am on our delayed arrival we got a suite on the 31 floor with views over Central Park back to AustraliaWe went back to our dog box suite the next dayThe position is great , the bathrooms are tiny and we won't go backThe teacups were not replaced till we askedEven has lift car operatorsHad a spa treatment and they put on a tip and charge a fortune for phone callsAlso did not follow up a rebooking request POOR form

My wife and I stayed at the Carlyle from July 12-14th. We had asked for an early check in, which would be available (if the room was free) which it was not. However, not a problem as they held our bags and we headed out for a walk in the park and some lunch. The front desk treated us perfectly and that shows me that they care about who they are serving. They called us to let us know our room was ready.The room itself was large and we were "upgraded" to as room with a walk in shower. That was a nice touch. Sadly, the walk in did have some very visible mold or mildew which I did notify the housekeeping about the next day (some areas, not all). It was cleaned, but it was "still there" if you know what I mean. The shower walls need a good scrub. The bath amenities are excellent!!! Turn down service was also very nice as we did this once as we declined the next day due to just needing the room for us.Great location! We did not go to any of the shops or restaurants in the Carlyle but they appeared very nice from what I saw.The doormen are top notch and on the ball. Had a doorman go all the way up to Madison just to wave us down a taxi. The elevator operators are also very nice.Back to the rooms. Bed was comfortable and the rooms were very quiet...a huge bonus. On the carpet we did find a pill. It made my wife wonder how often they actually vacuum the room. Overall it was very nice and the Hotel continues to carry on the old school charm.My wife and I would gladly stay again.We were in room 1005 on the 10th floor.

The Carlyle is a classic New York experience. The rooms are very comfortable, and have hardwood floors with area rugs. Some suites even have a grand piano! The staff is very accommodating and genuine. You feel as though you are staying in an elegant mansion. Truly a wonderful experience and well worth the expense.

Now I get it. I know why people love this place. The location, the ambiance, the staff - The Carlyle has it all. They've thought of everything. It's pricey, of course, and I can only ever afford to stay there in the summer when rates dip. But whenever I want a summer getaway in NYC I'm checking The Carlyle first. It's nice to see how the 1% live.

White-gloved elevator staff lends an unusual ambience to this NYC historic hotel. Immaculate quiet and comfortable rooms except for some water damage cracks in walls. Water pressure in shower was minimal. Loved the free daily newspapers delivered to your door, plush robes, Kiehls toiletries, free wifi and water bottles. Buffet breakfast has all you could ask for although specialty eggs are extra. Expensive but worth it for a special treat. Great location to UES museums particularly the Metropolitan.

I just love the Carlyle. It is real old fashioned service, still with men in the lift, ready with a smile and a positive word every time you get in. You can't help but have a bounce in your step everyday when you stay here. The same staff have been here for years, and greet you by name every day.The beds are the best I have ever slept in. Like a big firm hug! The bathroom is old world glamour of mirrors and marble, but with a bath and shower to die for. A wonderful range of Kiehls products, including lip balm, shaving foam for the men, creme de corps body lotion, and wonderful soap, shower gel, shampoo etc. all replenished twice a day if necessary.Best breakfast ever. Buffet is wonderful. Everything is kept fresh and tastes amazing. Or you can order a la carte. The eggs benedict, the pancakes and lobster omelette all recommended. The bar at night has great atmosphere and is a real New York stalwart. Location is amazing for uptown shopping, Central Park and the Met. I really feel like I am living the New York dream when I stay here.I always have a room in the tower between floor 27-33. These are smaller rooms, but the views are magic. Definitely recommended.

My husband and I stayed here for our twenty-fifth anniversary trip to NYC. I loved the history behind the hotel, and I was certainly not disappointed with the service or accommodations. Absolutely stunning room! Wonderful location, and very helpful staff. I highly recommend it!

Check in was seamless at the multilingual front desk. Our room was huge with TWO walk in closets, maid service TWICE a day, "you can hear a pin drop" quiet rooms, and excellent location for shopping, walking in Central Park, museums, and restaurants. We went to hear singer/actress Megan Hilty in the Café, and she was fabulous, but the food was average at best, and in my opinion, if the waiters have to ask you to move your chair every ten seconds so they can negotiate the landscape --- then it's TOO CROWDED! Checking out with our car in the adjacent parking garage was a bit clumsy. Lastly, it is overpriced, if only because you can get the same for half the price. However, that being said, we like the Carlyle and we'd return.

Have just completed a four-night stay at the Carlyle. The experience was excellent in all respects, and I have no hesitation in recommending the hotel. What distinguishes it above all is the sense of discrete, refined luxury. This creates a air of quiet contentment which is a welcome relief from the hustle and bustle outside the revolving doors. The decor is understated and elegant, witness the lobby and elevator area. My room was spacious, well planned, with a comfortable bed, and well stocked bathroom (bathtub and separate walk-in shower). Despite being directly on Madison, the room was remarkably quiet, so I had the best sleep on a two-week tour of the US. Bemelman's Bar is an institution both for residents of NYC and visitors, and should absolutely not be missed. The decor and atmosphere is unique.Staff, from the elevator attendants, to the bar, restaurant, and concierge, were unfailingly pleasant and attentive.For those who have no need of see-and-be-seen, noise or bling, this is a perfect address in New York.

The Carlyle is a high-class, very traditional hotel, now managed by the Rosewood chain, that added to it an impeccable service. Its location, next to the best NYC museums and art galleries, to some very special restaurants and on Madison Ave in a very nice area, gives you the comfort of quietude and a presence in the world. Its bar is maybe one of the best in NYC and the Carlyle Café, where you can dine at the sound of very good music is superb.
user_name:
Carlos Leoni S
Rio de Janeiro

review_body: My fiancee and I disagree on this one, but I think the Carlyle is an overpriced, stuffy antique. It's very formal, and sitting down for breakfast in the hotel restaurant/cafe is like having dinner on Downton Abbey. My other half explains that this is the point.The rooms were nice, but we were paying 1k a night for a small suite that had windows with a view of a wall(inside). No terrace or view out, and we were there almost a week. I finally told my fiancee that we had to change hotels because I was losing my marbles.The bed was too soft for me, and the decor fo the room felt very old (although not out of place).Great gym staff, they have a trainer on duty who offers to help and guide you, pretty cool.The quality of the food was great, but a boring menu with few options.We saw Neil Young check out of the hotel along with what appeared to be a significant percentage of the Saudi royal family.Hector, the manager was sharp as a tack and extremely helpful. He helped us switch rooms early in the stay and took care of several personal issues my fiancee and I had.The only real negative that I can stand behind, besides the price (and hey, its NYC) is the water. There is(was) construction outside and maybe it was connected but on our last day my fiancee took a bath. She put in some bubble bath, so it was foamy. She didnt realize until she get in the water, but it was brown. And then the water that came out of the faucet was brown. After 30 seconds it cleared up. Disgusting. We called down to the front desk to inform them, and they said they would look into it. No one ever called us back(but we did check out 2 hours later). i also told the front desk about it whenI was checking out, but it was a hurried check out and we left quickly, so maybe they didn't have time to address.

After escaping from a bad home away rental we found ourselves at the Carlyle for a wonderful birthday and anniversary week in March. The Carlyle is an old-fashioned hotel in many ways, perhaps best exemplified by the small elevators with gracious, formally uniformed operators. But our room was lovely and the level of attentive service from all of the hotel staff was consistently spectacular.
user_name:
Mac L
Santa Fe, New Mexico

review_body: Everything about this hotel is 5 star . The check in experience , concierge , breakfast , flower arrangements and bar. Large traditionally furnished bedroom, quiet and very comfortable, bathroom and amenities were first class. Beautifully prepared fresh fruit and the only good scrambled egg from a buffet that I've ever had ! You can order a la carte too.The bar has atmosphere and live music . This is an elegant hotel about 15 blocks north of Central Park South and very close to the park itself and the Metropolitan and Frick Galleries.

The Carlyle is perfectly described in the other reviews... beautiful, discreet, quiet, peaceful and elegant. I recently returned from a 4 night stay with my two children, ages 10 and 12. We had just spent a week in London (Athenaeum Hotel) and the differences were interesting. The Athenaeum had wonderful, inexpensive touches for the children... an afternoon delivery of cookies and milk, a concierge to suggest child appropriate activities, etc. I am definitely not looking for child-pandering and my children are quite comfortable in an adult environment, however, a Carlyle-initiated touch of fun would have added to their visit. I was also troubled that an addition of a cot to my room would cost an extra $75 per night. Given the room rate, this seemed like a bit of a nuisance charge. The hotel was an amazing treat for me, however, my children were ambivalent. I wish that they would have loved it as they loved the hotel in London.

Without taking up two pages, I will make this short and sweet. We have stayed at The Carlyle many times and have had a marvelous and frequently exceptional experiences. This time it was more than we could have imagined. We took our granddaughter on her first trip with us to NYC. I asked the hotel to fuss her up a little. And boy did they deliver. Sweets and gifts at check in, sweets at check out and during the stay, the entire staff made our grandaughter feel as if she was the only one in the hotel, she befriended Stephanie at the front desk. The sincere kind conversations with her not only gave her a fabulous experience but will reinforce her desire to travel more. This is something you cannot buy and for that we thank the entire Carlyle staff.There are many nice places to stay in NYC, but there are many things that separate The Carlyle from the rest. It is a quiet hotel, almost no off the street traffic, Quality, elegant decor. And MOST of all sincere friendly staff, not the over the top twelve thank yous., They just do everything they can do to make your stay an experiance.The Carlyle is the hotel that we compare all other hotels. (None have reached so high)With thousands and thousands of touches by the hotel on a daily bases, sure we have had a hiccup or two, but they have never failed to repair, replace or make better some how. And with such superior service, these hiccup are very minor.If you appreciate superior service You deserve to try The Carlyle.

The carlyle is one of New York's legendary hotels. From the countless list of celebrities who stay here to Bellman's bar, everything seemed magical. We were in a superior room on the tenth floor facing Madison. Could see the park which was a real treat. Although these rooms have not recently been renovated (front desk used the word refurbished) the room was lovely with original hardwood floors throughout. A very nice touch for NYC. The bathroom is on the small side and does not have a separate bath and shower (most 5 star NY hotels do), but that didn't take away from the fabulous jet tub that was provided. Very large with great water pressure. Bellman's bar was a real treat. The drinks are a little pricey but taste great and you get to listen to some of the jazz great perform live. WHAT IS THERE NOT TO LOVE?? I will for sure stay at the Carlyle again next time I am in the city. I normally stay at the Mark across the street, but in my opinion The Carlyle stands out in regards to its history, service and grace.

Do you want to experience New York City without all the hustle bustle 24/7? The Carlyle Rosewood hotel is in a residential area (Madison and 76th) It is stunning. The filet mignon at the restaurant is the best I have ever had. The service is outstanding. If you love history, this place is steeping in it. Jackie O used to have an apt. here. Ask for a tower room with floor to ceiling windows and views of central park. Julia Carey, the national sales director, showed me all of the different room types. All amazing! This is your hotel in New York. Quiet, peaceful dreams here.

Once we divested ourselves of an apartment in NYC, it was the best to just stay at the Carlyle where everything is lovely & works! Love going to NYC for a few days; stay there; be nearby most things I need; stay in the most comfortable, place, with all the services one could want. Agree the restaurant is high priced and last time the quality of the food had gone very down hill, but not the prices. However, there are many restaurants nearby in every price range and all are good in one way or another. Love just being able to walk to most places. Staff is most accommodating; rooms are elegant, quiet, just a peaceful place in the middle of a very busy city. Best for me whenever NYC is on my agenda!Gail

My sister and I stayed for two nights. While the renovated bathroom was small and not particularly luxurious, the room was a good size, with lots of storage space and nice furnishings. It was very quiet.Breakfast is extremely expensive, but a very nice treat. For a tea lover, it was great to get good quality tea leaves in a proper pot. Service was very good. after breakfast we asked to see the famous bar with its murals by Bemelman (of the children's Madeleine books), and were given a private tour.The atmosphere of this hotel is rather European - understated, not glitzy, but a very pleasant respite in such a busy city.

Every December we travel to NYC for a long weekend. For the last four years we have gone to the Café Carlyle for the Tyrell show and always lamented that we should stay at the hotel. We stayed this year at the Hotel and it was fantastic! The room was great and the service was top notch. Plus there is no better bar to hang out in than Bemelman's. The breakfast buffet was great. Very old school in the dining room. I would not suggest showing up for breakfast after taking a walk in casual/workout wear. We will definitely be back.

Love that they have elevator operators and doorman! Front desk is great and so is the maid service and room service! Only complaint-the service in the dining room and bar is awful. The waiters, waitresses, bar tenders just awful. Great rooms but eat somewhere else!
user_name:
gymtandrink
Point Pleasant Beach, New Jersey

review_body: Stayed for four nights for a long weekend. This hotel was exceptionally quiet. I never heard a peep from the hallways or any other rooms. Spacious rooms (for NYC) and clean, with lovely bathroom. I appreciated having a hotel away from the bustle of Times Square, but still within easily reachable distance. Loved that Central Park was literally steps away. Very good coffee available in the mornings. Disappointing that WiFi service was not included in the cost of the room. I felt slightly uncomfortable in this hotel lobby but can't put my finger on why.

Second time we visited Carlyle and still nothing to complain about. It must be the absolut best hotel in NYC. Friendly staff, superb breakfast and wonderful bar. And of course Cafe Carlyle with Woody Allen playing jazz on mondays, don t miss it!!

A very classic hotel yet so updated,the bar with jazz music was owesome ...Well located, good food, a place to come again...The people who work there are very well trained, always in the look for your needs

Simply, the best. This was our first stay at the Carlyle. Traveling to NYC about twice a year, we have stayed in about a dozen properties over the last fifteen years. Old faithfuls are the Waldorf-Astoria and the W. This is our new number one hotel in NYC!Views of the city and park are phenomenal. The reception staff are top notch, kind, courteous, and friendly. The bar staff are also very attentive. Housekeeping is the most professional and attentive I have seen. Looks like management is at the top of their game, because this type of service does not just happen magically. Our thanks to the entire hotel staff and management! The staff (we found out that many have been there for decades), and the location (Upper East Side, 76th and Madison) are super. However, what sets this property apart from the rest is the attention to EVERY small detail. With a long history we read about on line (Google it to find out more), this place has been the home to many presidents, royals, and celebrities. But even the commoner like me felt like royalty here. When you want to feel special, this is the place!Before we left for our trip, we received an email asking us about some of our “preferences.” I almost did not fill it out, as so often you fill out these types of forms to find that the information is never really used to make the stay special. They actually DID use the response form to welcome us like royalty, with every little detail attended to.When we checked-in, we were greeting with a lovely, friendly, professional who made us feel right at home. We inquired about spa treatments, but since we had not really planned ahead, I didn’t think we would have any luck, especially since we wanted massages for three people (all at, or near the same time). The front desk made a few calls and by the next morning, they had it all worked out and we all enjoyed massages at the super spa. A couples massage for us, and one for a friend.Other things to do at the hotel include a piano bar that has artwork by the famous Children’s book illustrator and writer of the famous Madeline books, Ludwig Bemelmans. The bar is named after him. It seats about 100 and was alive with jazz Saturday night. There is also a café that has famous singers and entertainers, but check in advance. They were sold out for our weekend, as I did not know how much there was to do at this special hotel and did not plan ahead as I should have.The lobby is nice and simple, and relatively small, with some high end shopping, a sitting area, plus a restaurant, the café, and the bar. The elevators are staffed 24 hours a day with uniformed elevator operators that keep a human eye on the security of the building. They are also equipped with cameras, but the human touch is a nice luxury from by-gone days and adds a level of security and safety, as they are very aware of who is coming and going, and seem to know the guests.Now, on to the room. Our beautiful large room had a superb view, a desk, sitting area, large TV, huge window with magnificent views, a walk in closet with mini-bar, safe, and lots of hangers. The bed was fantastically comfy and we slept like babies. The bathroom had heated tiles, heated plus white towels, a bidet, a shower/jacuzzi, robes, and slipper that actually fit! The bath products are generous portions of Kiehl’s. They smell terrific and are super! We indulged in room service for breakfast because the view was so nice, we did not want to leave the room. We were treated to outstanding surprises each night when we returned from dinner or shows, each very thoughtful, and special. Our stay exceeded ALL Expectations. In two words, BEYOND OUTSTANDING!

Our favorite hotel in one of the greatest cities on the planet. This hotel has got the charm of an old 5 star property. The concierges at this hotel are the best I have come across anywhere. We were stranded and late due to the storm, and they assisted us in some many ways during our three day stay. I have seen the same faces at the concierge-desk for years; I love it and a big thanks to the team. We had greater rooms, although only one of them was updated (they are nicer). The rooms are all different and have got character. The bar is cozy and provides ambience that stand out with fantastic drinks. They have a courtesy car that is available several hours a day; a nice touch! The location on upper-east is also great with lots of nearby restaurants and shopping as well as the proximity to the park where I jog every time I am there (the best park in the world). When all the rooms are renovated, you will not find a better 5 star boutique hotel anywhere in NYC!

Outstanding and discrete service with splendid attention to every detail. The gold standard by which great hotels should be measured. Elegant rooms. Superb food. Bemmelmans Bar is ideal spot to meet.The staff anticipate one's needs. Securing a stay in one of the unique suites in the upper floors is a real treat.

We stayed at The Carlyle Hotel for my birthday weekend 12/28. Were upgraded throughAmerican Express Platinum to a room in the tower on the 23rd fl. with a terrace overlookingDowntown and the West Side. It was magnificient. We attended the late show at CafeCarlyle to see Steve Tyrell. Again, premium seats through AE Platinum. Steve performeda song for me for my birthday and we were so close he held my hand. What a greatnight. Breakfast the next day was great and we had late check out at 4pm. All in alla memorable experience. This was our second time at The Carlyle and I highly recommendit.

We have been staying at the Carlyle for years, and it never disappoints! It is the epitome of N.yC elegance. The staff welcomes you like old friends and is attentive to every need. The rooms are large and beautifully appointed. The entire atmosphere evokes an era of charm and sophistication. And of course, the location is superb!

This was our first time staying on the Upper East Side. We found The Carlyle location to be perfect. The hotel definitely feels like Old NY, very art deco and exceptional well kept. The rooms are large for NYC standards and they have done a great job providing modern amenities (like enough outlets) in an old building.

We checked in quite early at this charming and old-style hotel and were greeted with proficient courtesy and grace. No fuss and no 'sorry your room is not ready sir' attitude. They told us to wait about an hour for the room to be 'finished', and stored our luggage. We walked to a nearby cafe, called 'Ambrosia', not knowing that it is the top cafe in the City, AND, the most expensive too. $20 for 2 cups of coffee and a croissant! Ouch! On return to the hotel we noticed the neighbourhood is chic and genteel, unlike downtown. Yet, Central Park is just there! Strawberry Field as you walk into the Park. Magical. The heat was dissipated as soon as you enter the hotel lobby, leaving the world behind. This is a hotel with history and style that the modern ones can't emulate. Even the lift has a 'lift-man' controlling the wood-panelled 'machine'. Later I learned that some floors are occupied by 'residents'. Service was excellent and the room was spacious and well appointed. Branded toiletries are a treat and the power shower a bonus. The concierge was so charming he tried to book 'The Book of Mormon' for us, but sadly it was sold out for that week. He also gave us tips about shopping and the train tickets to The Hamptons, where we were headed that Labour Weekend. Hectic you can imagine, and he even tried to use his credit card to buy the tickets for us, but we decided to take a cab to Penn Station to buy them ourselves. All in all, a top establishment that will go on forever! Unlike other transient things, e.g fast fashion, fast cars and fast chain hotels!

I should have written a review long ago. The hotel stands right in center of the Upper East Side, surrounded by good apartments and restaurants. It's only a short walk to the Met and the Central Park. Its bar is lively and caters for the residents of the fine neighborhood. The service is up to five-star standards. The concierges are professional and enthusiastic. But nothing beats the hotel's atmosphere. The 83-year-old establishment once served as the "love nest" of JFK and such connection between the hotel's old and new guests is truly memorable.

We stayed at the Carlyle for 5 nights and on the whole, the experience was a positive one. The best thing about the hotel is the location on the Upper East Side which makes it close to most things a tourist wants to do as well as being only two blocks from the green line (Subway) on Lexington. We loved the elevator attendants and in particular we loved Frank, an older gentleman who has worked at the Carlyle for over 17 years.The there were only three downsides to our visit. The first was the shower. As an 'over the bath' style shower, it has a glass spray shield. However that shield was ineffective as after showering, toilet and half the bathroom floor were soaked. The second criticism was that the walls / adjoining door were paper thin so we could hear even the most casual conversation in the adjoining room. This made it frustrating when the neighbours came in late and/or were louder than normal conversational volumes. The last criticism was the pricing of food and minibar. During our stay, we choose not to dine at the hotel at all and much preferred the nearby 3 Guys Restaurant and Diner which is only half a block down Madison Ave.Overall, while it was an okay experience, if we return to New York again I think we would 'roll the dice' and try a different establishment rather than blindly return to the Carlyle

Here for Christmas it's a older hotel with quaint rooms and furnishings. Service is lovely and impeccable. Not cheap but a lovely location on the upper east side and one block from 5th avenue and Central Park. Lots of beautiful places within an easy walk. worth a visit for the experience... And the old fashioned service.....

Despite the the fact that this is an older property that does not overwhelm in any physical sense, our stay there was memorable, and I would say singular, for its attentive but not intrusive service, and simple, wonderful elegance that made us feel amazingly comfortable and at home. It is the best staff I have encountered anywhere in the world, helpful, knowledgable and kind. The location is just right, and our youngest son will always remember the walk from the C to the Museum of Natural History through Central Park in the Snow. There are less expensive places to stay, and we certainly cannot stay at the C on consistent basis, but, for a time when you want things done the right way, this is the place.
user_name:
David F
Atlanta, Georgia, United States

review_body: Spent my birthday here and found it as luxurious as ever. First class service, wonderful decor, friendly staff who were always there to help, and Belmelman's Bar fun and lively, with good music. All very pricey, but, hey, this is New York at its finest! Can't wait to go back again.
user_name:
jmselig
Los Osos, California, United States

review_body: This luxurious hotel is still delightful to stay at.It offers old-fashioned charm & total comfort but it is very expensive.The location is excellent, being right on Madison Avenue - and near Central Park, so you can easily walk to many places from the hotel.Some of the staff have worked there for years.The Spa is fabulous, with really well trained beauty therapists.The Consierge is staffed by very helpful and knowledgeable people.The only drawback was that we had to wait ages to be served every time we went for a snack or tea/drinks as there clearly are not enough staff working, at this busy time of year (December). And there was seldom a manger around to check on this.

I had a nice stay at the carlyle. we had a good size room with ample wardrobe space and Its in a great location.I will love to see a newer bathroom with a bigger tub and his and hers sinks though.overall, great stay, great staff and good food.

We arrived this evening but I thought I would write a review while I have the time. Our room is spacious, clean and elegant. We had a few minor needs (cable, ice, extra bedding) and the staff has responded very quickly and efficiently. The location is terrific. We are looking forward to a few more days at the Carlyle.And, the Keihl's amenities are a great luxury.
user_name:
Ca_jenvn
Palo Alto, California, United States

review_body: Toilet ran water. Called four times. No one seemed to understand the problem. Returned from the theater to find a portable toilet in our room!! $700 a night for a portable toilet!! No washcloths in room. Had to call maintenance because the safe didn't work. Could not rest in the afternoon because the next room hosted a trunk show. Very loud. No one from management ever called to see if our problems were resolved. Very bad experience!!

Charming, elegant. Located in the best region of Manhattan, close to the central park... the only problem was the size of the standard room, that could be bigger.... I didn't tried the Spa but it looked superb!

It's not clear what exactly is going on at this formerly venerable establishment, but it is clear that the staff is not overwhelmed, stressed which is played out in confusion, frustration and anger. Perhaps the Carlyle is undergoing some sort of management reorganization and the staff is being left to run amok without skilled supervision.The problems seem mainly to exist with the dining room staff where there is a complete disregard for pleasing the patron.
