When my friend and I were seated for dinner our first night there, a woman sitting next to us stated that she had been waiting for half an hour for a menu. She mentioned this to us when the bread basket was delivered to her table followed a minute later by her entree. This should have been a tip off. We were mis-directed to the bar vs. Carlyle Cafe. The following morning, I was publicly threatened by the Maitre D' and told sharply, finger in face "not to complain" following a private comment I made to my friend. Later the Maitre D' apologized, but said he was "stressed" because he had 100+ patrons to serve. He did not seem to understand that stress did not justify his behavior. While waiting for a table. When my friend asked if there might be more eggs coming to the buffet table, she was told sharply by a wait person that people were busy in the kitchen and it would come when it came. We were excited to experience the Carlyle. Bemmelman's Bar was a delight, but the sadly the rest of the experience could only be termed nightmarish. We could not wait to get out.

Stayed just for a weekend. An elegant, quiet escape in the middle of one of the great areas of NYC. Would recommend to anyone wanting to stay on the upper East Side. Expensive but worth it if one needs to relax a little between exciting NYC attractions.

I love visiting the Carlyle as a legendary hotel in New York. My room was remodeled and being on a high floor offered wonderful views on central park. Service was very attentive. It was a little bit odd to have someone from the staff inside the elevator to push the button and sing the number of the floor you are reaching. Restaurant prices are high but room service are outrageous! More than $60 for a burger (once you add all the charges...) seems a bit too much for me! Just went across the street to Jean Georges and had one for $29.

Staying at the Carlyle is like stepping back in time. PErfectly preserved it exudes the true elegance of the Upper East Side. Monday nights with Woody Allen and his Jazz Band. Not to mention the finest cocktails.. I defy anyone to find a better Old Fashioned in the city. Perfectly appointed rooms and exceptional service.

We went there for Judy Collins and it was an amazing concert! The meal, which you are compelled to have, not very much so. The lobster bisque smelled bad and was inedible, the meat ok but nothing to write home about. outrageous prices, poor service and so and so ambiance: dark, old scuffed furniture, low ceiling, very nice paintings on the wall, the only nice thing about the room. We expected much more, better food and better ambiance.Nothing to write home about!

This is a lovely, classy hotel with everything you expect from a 5 star hotel. The staff was very friendly and helpful. The interior is impressive while also providing a cozy, warm atmosphere. I loved the amenities in the bathroom and the beds were sufficiently long for me as a tall person.

My cousin got married here last month, we didn't actually stay here; we stayed at St. Regis. The night before the wedding we hung out with my cousin in her room, ordered room service, kicked off our shoes and made ourselves comfortable. There aren't many hotels that offer the service, privacy and home away from home feeling the Carlyle offers. Her room had hardwood floors, a small kitchen, windows that open and great service.I read some of the other reviews and you need realize this is not your ordinary hotel. Some of these employees have been working here for 30 or 40+ years. There not going to run your room service orders to your room, some of them are over 60 or 70 years old. Let’s face it, this place isn’t cheap and the clientele could be kind of snooty in this neighborhood. Overall, most guests were interacted with were very pleasant and we found the hotel staff to be extremely professional and very courteous.If you’re planning a wedding or large family celebration, consider the Carlyle hotel. You’ll be the only wedding they’re hosting that night, not 1 of 5 or 10 going on at the same time.

Poor service; had to repeat things 2-3 times. Terrible food (e.g. tough steak/frites). High prices. The dessert menu was composed of mostly "out-of-stock" items.Dark ambiance. Used to love dining at the Carlyle. Will no longer return.

We stayed at the Carlysle for about a week at the end of August for a family shopping trip in New-York. Every hotel has its weaknesses, of course, but for this hotel, it is not its impeccable location. We had a large suite on the 15th floor. The layout of the suite, the terrace, the view it offers is incomparable to any hotel we've been in NY. Room service is good, but not more than that, bedding is...well it depends if you like pillowtops! The good thing is that the hotel will do anything to let you have a good bed, so no fault here. Now, let's talk about the A/C: its noisy, wherever you put it, and its uncomfortable. The thing is, its not all the hotel's A/C: the MTA has a large fan underneath, and some private homes as well, so if you want quiet, well...be patient, because the hotel cannot do anything about it. The breakfast service is great. Great staff, beautiful room. Very luxurious, and there is also a lot of sighting. The concierge service is really first class: give them your card details, and let them do it! The staff is friendly (just as they should) and super careful. All in a very very good experience, and we will return.

There are many positives, all overshadowed by an AC that sounds like a small aircraft landing in the room which additionally seems to pumps cigarette smoke into the room. The hotel clearly still allows smoking in some rooms, and pumps the residue through to your room. Not acceptable and over rides many many positives.

The Carlyle is located in the heart of the upper east side. It is close to fine shops, restaurants and the Metropolitan. The room was comfortable with one minor negative. When the air conditioner was on it blew right on the bed. The buffet breakfast was outstanding.

We love a hotel with character and this one has it all. Grand lobby reminiscent of 50's. From the moment you are greeted by the doorman to the moment you leave, everyone treats you like royalty. Our visit was perfectly arranged by Liana, who saw to all of our needs and exceeded our expectations. The rooms have the perfect mix of yesterday's luxuries with all the amenities of today. Everything is elegant without being pretentious. My wife enjoyed her spa experience very much. We understand why presidents, celebrities and royalty come to the Carlyle when visiting the Big Apple. We had a perfect stay.

This hotel is well located with a good access the park and shopping area. My wife and I were having a blast last weekend when we had our wedding anniversary there. The staff were friendly and help us out to make our stay the most enjoyable. I will definetly be back

Staying in New York at the Carlyle and couldn't be happier! The rooms are fantastic. Everyone who works there from the housekeeper to the elevator operator we the nicest people. The location is close to the park and in the middle of the best shopping in the world. I can't say enough great things about this hotel. I have not one negative thing to say. Stay here if you can!!!!!!

The location is very nice, and only a few blocks to the 6 train for visiting other parts of the city. Rooms are nice (bit dated - but more of a style preference for me) and bathroom was very large (2 twin bed room). Elevators are slow and cramped, but you get there. We booked through Expedia and paid about a 1/3 of the regular rate. If I had to pay the full rate, I would probably go elsewhere. If I got the same rate, I would definitely stay again.

Great location. Our room was a good size. The entire hotel was clean and well maintained. Be sure and visit the bar. The paintings on the wall are fantastic. The pianist was very entertaining and friendly to the patrons. I have to mention the concierges Waldo and Sarah. They were both a great resource which you need in NYC. Waldo was super friendly and very informative. He was professional but treated us like friends. We would definitely return.

Please note that i don't normally complain,but this hotel left me compelled to put pen to paper.We arrived and were greeted by the doorman who was nice enough,then we checked in,which was rather rushed with minimal information provided. We were escorted to our room by a really nice gentleman,but the only thing was he could barely carry our luggage and his English was limited.Out of two keys only one was working which he took and was never replaced, when we asked reception they said we should have asked for another key! Wifi is not free ( $14.95 per day) but is free in he lobby and business room- which was not relayed to us arrival.1st night sleep was atrocious as there road works outside and every time traffic pasted over the section it sounded like thunder- no need to complain as next night barriers had been erected to stop the traffic passing over it(begs the question though why this hadn't been done earlier).Second night looking through menu found a card stating that we're entitled to complimentary breakfast? When we enquired the receptionist apologised and stated this had been for the previous guest (barring in mind that the rooms are turned over twice a day hard to understand why card hard been left there),receptionist was happy to honour the complimentary breakfast for the duration of our stay but then her manger turned up an said no that we had booked with Expedia and were not entitled to it! We mentioned that check in had been poor regarding the info given, to which she stated that this was standard for a five star hotel not to provide free wifi,but totally dismissed the fact level of service given was lacking.She was willing to offer us one days breakfast,we turned up at breakfast and were asked " why are you here",then when escorted to the table we were asked if we were guest of the hotel? On leaving the restaurant we were presented a bill- the manager hadn't relayed that we had been offered a complimentary breakfast, the staff tried to deal issue with reception but they were busy so we were asked to liaise them-no doubt all standard of a five star hotel! All very embarrassing to say the least. Oh yes forgot to say you are given complimentary tea and coffee and muffins, but nowhere other than the lobby or your room to consume it, we found ourselves loitering in the lobby to access the free wifi while drinking our drink(was given the distinct air that this wasn't the done thing).On checking out we were presented with a bill for the drinks at out complimentary breakfast, buy this time we weren't really surprised at all so we just paid and were glad to leave.Though this is a beautiful and charming hotel I feel that the staff(middle management and above)may take this for granted, the hotel obviously caters for certain clientele, so if they are going to open up bookings via third parties such as Expedia then they must be will to accept those guest and treat them in the same way, there was a vast difference in service.Having stayed at other five star hotels in a number of cities unfortunately we didn't feel that the same standard of service was extended to us which some what marred our 1st experience of New York. In short by all means Stay here but don't expect any kind of honesty.

If you and your family seek a glitzy,flashy hotel with a noisy bar scene and an ostentatious clientele, this hotel isn't for you.If, however, you've ever wondered where graciousness, sophistication, and attentiveness have gone in New York City, then you haven't stayed at the Carlyle Hotel. You will find all of that, and more, here in this upper east side gem. This is a hotel for ladies and gentlemen, and their children. Here you will find a quiet, discreet check-in. Prompt and efficient room service. A housekeeping staff that genuinely takes pleasure in your pleasure. And it's all wrapped up in an ambiance that, when you come back to the hotel after a day's work or sightseeing, makes you feel like you are home again--safe, ensconced in your own private world with a staff that simply wants to look after you.Ever wondered what Cafe Society was like in New York decades ago? A visit to Bemelman's Bar or the Cafe Carlylee will transport you back in time, and you will remember it, and want to experience it again, and again. You needn't go to London for a proper high tea; just wander over to the Gallery. My strong suggestion: Check into the Carlyle and let the hotel and the staff do what they do best--treat you so well that you really don't want to leave.

It seems that others had trouble with the A/C, room booking, noise, and the service. We got the (im)perfect storm: all of these. This was not a bad experience for a nice hotel. This was a bad experience for any hotel. Too many great options in NYC to bother staying here. When we arrived, we were welcomed with a room with two twin beds. My reservation (via hotels.com) explicitly said One King Bed. We were told we "were in luck" as there was a room with a King that was $100 more per night. Terrific?! I had a meeting I risked being late to so I decided to hold the discussion until checkout - I did not expect there would be so much to talk about then. The $100/extra per night room was really....something else. They were doing heavy construction in the room next to us rendering the room off limits all day. After a day of work and meetings I was looking forward to a little rest and quiet. I stayed at the wrong hotel for that. Add in the mystery stains on the toilet and they were really on a roll. We went to a show and decided to get a drink at the lobby bar before we checked in for the night. The first drink took 20 minutes to order. We got a wild hair and decided on a second drink....we went to wrong bar for that. After being ignored for 30 minutes we tracked someone down for the check. All we wanted at that point was to sleep...we stayed at the wrong hotel for that. The A/C in our room was broken and the room was hot. A maintenance man came up and we mentioned all of the construction next door to help him diagnose the problem. He flippantly told my wife there was no construction next door - construction we had witnessed and heard throughout the day. Nothing like a lie and some attitude at 1145 in a hot hotel room. I wish I had a picture to post of the A/C unit they were going to put in our room to keep us in there. It looked like a vacuum cleaner from the 60s....sure it was a 5 star vacuum cleaner from the 60s though. The A/C problem was irreparable but we were again told we "were in luck". A "comparable" room was available. At 1145 when all your guests want is a place to lie down, what on Earth difference does it make that we get Superior, Deluxe, Suite, etc? The replacement room was fine for the 7 hours we were there. If you're counting, that was three rooms we were moved around in less than 72 hours. The next morning the front desk was very apologetic but lacked authority to do anything about it. They promised the manager would contact me. He did later that night and offered to give me the $200 back from the "upgrade" to King. Given we booked and paid for a King, this was not a concession but a requirement. He said he could really take care of me if I stayed there when I returned in December (something I'd mentioned to the front desk in passing). I requested that he look into our issues from this stay and try again. I rarely review and rarely complain. This was a chance to show off for my wife and they blew it so I blew it. If anything worthwhile is done, I will update this review. If for some reason you've narrowed it down to the Carlyle and another place, I hope my experience is useful. I wish I'd read a few more reviews before I booked.

I use to be and old client of this place, i was dreaming to come back, what a mistake i have done.The only good things is the working class, the maid etc , the management is inexistent, since this hotel , belong to a foreign group china , the bath room a museum piece , aged of 30 year , shower an antique piece, i was surrended by noise , automatic hammer , i was at 1701 , at 1901 , they make a renovation,the open the window, throuhg the stones on my terasse ,a stone of one pound fall in my coffee table , and rebound , i could be kill: guess the answer of the GM a gentlemen named Giiovanni, handsome italien guy , he has organised a saucer team , for the hotell staff and other manager was a polo guy, we could do nothing is not our problem but the contractor, after all you have been not hurt, conclusion i should be at the emergency room to have the rigth to speak about, This hotel is a shame , good woorking class so badly mismanaged, this chaine Rosebud bought by China people , dont care about hospitality , they expect only good return, so going on this place you will be hightly disapointed, by the lack of maintenance ,the management blabla, with nothing behind , the lack of honesty when you book the a room , he should be a paradise , for exemple i have book the 1701, and i my arrival they put me on the 1801, one day of struggle, to get the right suite ,never said about the renovation one above and one next to the 1701.The regular Laundry is terrible , fortunately , they have an other one who is excellent. The menu of the room service an other nigtmare , winter meals, hot pea soup , etc.Conclusion, i you want survive in your stay avoid this place who is mismanage,nobody but nobody is responsible , your only chance is the working class, terrible false good reputation. Good luck if you try , but in case watch your insurance accident. I will add i have travelling all around the world , my last was in far east for 3 i have never see such a nasty awfull .place.jj.aumont 39 chemin des hauts crets geneve switzerland

This is a beautiful and very comfortable hotel. My husband and I spent 5 very active days in NYC, exploring all that the city has to offer. The hotel is located on the Upper East side -- a little more laid back then some parts of Manhattan (Time Square, in particular, comes to mind) -- but still in the midst of the Manhattan activity. We found our room at the hotel to be very comfortable, relaxing and QUIET. We awoke each morning rejuvenated and ready for yet another activity-filled day in the city.

We do a yearly trip to celebrate our wedding anniversary and for the first time we brought our kids with us - they are 4.5 and 1.5 years old. The Carlyle is elegant, refined, and beautiful. We booked a deluxe suite which wasn't available so we were upgraded to a gorgeous premier suite. It was absolutely gorgeous but lacked a second bathroom (one of the reasons we got a suite in the first place) and so we were placed in a cheaper superior suite (and credited the difference). It's hard to say what we loved the most - the hotel itself is beautiful, the location is absolutely fabulous, and the staff is wonderful. I think the latter edges out the other two, because the staff is really just terrific. Everyone from the bellmen to the front desk staff to the elevator operators to housekeeping was absolutely top notch. I was so impressed that they remembered us, our kids, and our needs from almost the moment we checked in. The suite was spacious for our party of two adults and two children, and everything was decorated so nicely. Beyond all of this, the location was great - quiet and yet close to so much. We had a car with us and even found street parking a few times.I'd recommend this hotel to couples and families - we always felt welcome and well cared for. We are all trying to think of reasons to return to the Carlyle soon!

Often i go to the jazz bar. Its always great. Even if crowded the know me so they treat me well. Spent 20 k ther just this year! Got a suite and it was nice and suck luxury! Cost me 1000k that night but, did not care. It was worth it .
user_name:
Classact10
New York City, New York

review_body: We recently stayed at The carlyle for 1 night and then returned for 5 nights on a work incentive trip. The room we stayed in on the first night was very small, and the air conditioning was extremely noisy, very small bathroom, with no views other than looking into another building. It was located on the 12th floor. The beds were very comfortable. The second room we had was on the 22nd floor a gorgeous corner room with gorgeous views, large spacious room and spacious bathroom, although shower was over the bath. There are no tea and coffee making facilities, but there is a mini bar with some snacks and alcohol - expensive. Room service cup of tea was $36.00 !!!, we asked for an electric jug and cups to be delivered to our room so that we could make our own tea in the mornings !!! We found that for a hotel of this standard the bathroom amenities were not always replaced and on two occasions we had to phone down for out water which was supposed to be left at turn down, some days we got chocolates other times we didn't. The staff were very helpful, but quite stuffy, especially the white gloved lift attendants. The reception area lacked atmosphere. The hotel is located in the district with all designer shops. There is a small mini mart across the road if you want to buy any snacks. Close to Central Park. I think if we went back we would stay at The Plaza, which is more centrally located and still very elegant and grand but had more atmosphere.

We made our reservation through Hotwire for 1 adult and 2 children (14 years old). It was in the reservation not possible to make a request on the type of bed for the guests. However, in the confirmation the following was stated: "You are guaranteed the number of beds corresponding with the number of people in the reservation" (which has also been presented as a copy to the hotel). So far so good! Upon arrival, we were informed that there was only one bed in the room, but they could offer a roll-out bed for an additional charge of USD 75 per night. Great message after a 16 hour journey!! Of course I had to say yes to the roll-out bed - alternatively sleep on the floor! After several discussions with the hotel, the presented solution is to give us the extra bed free for 1 night (!!) and offering to give me a written confirmation for the additional charge. It may be so that the third party has overpromised or misinformed me - alternatively made an incorrect reservation towards the hotel. This is in my opinion beside the point. The Carlyle chooses to let a certain number of rooms to be booked through their cooperation partner (probably to have a certain level of guaranteed coverage), and takes absolutely no responsibility for the poor customer experience we are given. Obviously, for us as the guest, it is irrelevant who did what, incorrectly. And it goes without saying that the hotel could have gone the extra mile, if customer satisfaction was of importance - instead of referring to "the fine print". For me this has been like flying Ryanair, where you are charged extra for every little piece of extra's - the only difference is that you actually expect that when flying with a lowfare airline and NOT from a hotel of Carlyle's supposed standards. It is also a surprise to me that The Carlyle chooses to cooperate with a dishonest third provider. In the corporate environment integrity is increasingly important - also when selecting third party providers for their business, but appearantly not for this hotel.I travel a lot in my job, and fortunately I have never experienced something even close to this!

We stayed at the Carlyle for 5 nights during a Thanksgiving break. It's classically elegant, and old-fashioned feeling (a white gloved gentleman operates every elevator). And it is in one of the most perfect locations on the Upper East Side.While I can't fault it for anything, we found it just wasn't a great fit for us - parents with a college aged daughter on her Thanksgiving break. It is a terrific example of the grand old New York hotels of the mid-20th century, but if you are looking for a place that has a little more warmth (from the room decor to the restaurant service), and personality, I think there are better places to stay. The Peninsula Hotel for one - though it lacks this wonderful Upper East Side location.

The Carlyle is everything New York and more...absolutely AMAZING! We stayed at the Carlyle for 8 days during the 4th of July holiday. From the moment we checked in---wait, correction---from the moment we booked our trip to the wave good-bye, the service was top-notch. Every i was dotted, every t was crossed...detail!detail!detail! The room was immaculate, updated, and spacious for our family of four. Gorgeous bathrooms and plenty of closet space. In their entirety, the hotel staff upholds the reputation of the distinct Carlyle. The concierge team are in a class of their own (thanks Waldo!!), just like the hotel. We were able to take in the city without a hiccup or glitch. All our needs and wants were met with warmth and perfection. Centrally located to museums, great shopping, delicious restaurants, Central Park, etc made the Carlyle the ideal hotel for us. We've been going to New York for the past ten years and haven't stayed at the same hotel twice. However, the Carlyle will definitely be our choice of accommodation again and again and again....

My family and I just returned from our second stay at the Carlyle. Manhattan can be a hectic place, but walking through the doors at the Carlye gave me a sense of relaxation. From the conceirge to the housekeeping staff, the answer was "yes." The service at the hotel was second to none. The hotel brings a sense of elegance and style to probably one of the most elegant and stylish cities in the world. I used the gym each morning and also enjoyed the amenities at the spa. The best word to describe the hotel would be classy and we look forward to future stays.

I wanted to share what an amzaing experience we had this weekend at the Carlyle, If your looking to spend a romantic week-end without your kids, in a high end hotel with views of central park and shopping on 5th avenue this is the place, The Hotel was quiet, beautifully decorated with very attentive staff. The beds and pillows were super comfortable and the bathroom spotless and large. Bethany at reception was a darling, beautiful smile and went out of her way to help move our room to a higher floor with a view. Breakfast was a little pricey for the amount of food on the plate but it's to be expected in a 5 star. They have a car service that will drop you off at your favourite department store and the concierge is very savy. Fantastic property.

The Carlyle Hotel has established a reputation for luxury and being first class. They certainly live up to the billing. From the moment you pull up to the entrance, everyone who works there understands what they need to do to make you stay pleasurable. From the bell man to the front desk to the elevator operator, they are all first rate. The rooms are not cheap, but you know you are in a historic hotel, who was built upon service and style while you are there. We will definitely be back.

The Carlyle hotel met all of our high expectations. We also looked into the Surrey and The Mark in the Upper East End and choose the Carlyle based upon other reviews.The Carlyle is old New York, classic and wonderful; whereas, the Mark was trendy. I'm so glad we made the right choice in The Carlyle.Our room was immaculate on the 21st floor with an expansive terrace. Housekeeping serviced our room twice daily. The elevator operators were welcoming and added a wonderful feel for a classic hotel.We had drinks in Bemelman's Bar and listened to a wonderful jazz trio. The hotel is in a wonderful location with easy access to the museums and shopping.We will be returning.

We were at the Carlyle for a one night stay prior to surgery at HSS. We drove up to find a movie filming at one entrance of the hotel (Restaurant entrance). We were greeted warmly as we left our car at the hotel's main entrance and were ushered into the hotel's beautiful foyer. Staff could not have been kinder nor more welcoming.I believe we were upgraded to a larger room that was more of a junior suite. The room faced a courtyard and was blissfully quiet. Bathroom was beautiful. Turndown was lovely with chocolates left bedside. Slippers were left by my side.We decided to dine in the hotel. I had wanted to hear jazz but knew Cafe Carlyle required dressier clothing so we opted for the hotel bar that has nice jazz playing from 5:30 on. It also is quite a happening place and was a bit loud so we moved to a quieter room next door where we could enjoy the music and dine. Food was excellent and the best beer we've ever had.We loved the attendants in the elevators and being greeted each time we used the elevator.The hotel is pricey and I would say for a very special NYC visit - this is a first choice. (Especially for the upper East side.)

I am not kidding with the title, I have seen personally Queens, Princes and other royals during my stay at The Carlyle! The last Queen I saw was the Queen of Denmark! The best of this Hotel is that they treated us with the same professional standards as the Queen of Denmark. If you like to feel pampered, important, greeted by your name, and you have very high standards, this Hotel is for you. The location is perfect! One block from Central Park and all the brands I like are right there at Madison Street. I enjoy sitting down in the afternoon, sipping a glass of Champagne served by the most Professional servers, friendly, polite and yet still with the formal service I enjoy, at The Gallery. I like to see all the interesting people walk in and walk out. The rooms are lovely decorated, all renovated with all the amenities needed. I like to call The Carlyle, my home away from home! Love it!

My wife and I attending an event in NYC and found our stay at The Carlyle perfect. The staff is gracious and attentive. Rooms may lack the bells and whistles of more modern properties but make up in the proximity and understated elegance of Upper Madison Avenue.Booked with the AMEX program and received the breakfast , late checkout and amenity- definitely made this worthwhile.
user_name:
GeneDC
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: I enjoyed one of the best weeks of my life at the Carlyle last spring, and I'm thrilled to be returning in a few weeks. I'm really surprised this hotel isn't in the TripAdvisor Top 10, because it is my favorite NYC hotel by far- and I've stayed at many of them. The first thing that sets the Carlyle apart is how beautiful, quiet and dignified it is inside the public lobby areas. Rather than other hotel lobbies that are packed and filled with tourists coming in and out, the Carlyle truly feels like a private home that gets to be yours for the duration of your stay. But then when you want a livelier, nightlife atmosphere, you don't even need to leave the hotel- Bemelmans Bar is hands-down the coolest bar in the city!Yes, the Superior rooms are small and the bathroom especially tiny, BUT the decor of the room is simply GORGEOUS- I would love to have my own room at home decorated the exact same way! Just stepping inside this beautiful room made every day a joy, especially after housekeeping and turndown service made it look even more immaculate. :) Amazingly for NYC, the room was so quiet and I slept perfectly every night. I also requested a room with a view, and got a fabulous 8th-floor room overlooking the Madison Ave shopping!The food was beyond delicious! Best caesar salad I've ever had, and every dish I tried in the Carlyle Restaurant was fantastic. I was also able to order afternoon tea service via room-service, which was such a treat!Another standout was the Yves Durif Salon- I got a fantastic haircut, and a blowout that looked amazing two days later!The staff is the best I've ever encountered at a hotel- I felt truly pampered, and all requests were attended to immediately. When I first arrived and found that I'd been put in a connecting room, the staff met my request to move to a non-connecting room right away, and I was still able to get the higher floor and view that I wanted.The location can't be beat- Upper East Side shopping and dining at its best! I loved grabbing delicious meals at nearby The Mark Restaurant and Sarabeth's, and also walking down Madison and window-shopping was a blast. In short- the Carlyle is the best in NYC and I can't wait to return!

I used to live in Manhattan, I know the city very well. The location is great, but I expected the service and the rooms to be up to a $700 a night hotel. I asked for a quite room and I was given a room facing a work zone on Madison, small with no bathtub. I complained and I was moved into a nicer room on a higher floor The room was ok but I could clearly hear my neighbor even stirring his coffee. Absolutely not worth the money.

I chose this hotel as a surprise for my husband's 40th. We requested a superiour tower room preferably with a view of the park, and got one, so we were delighted. The room seemed a little small, but that's New York. The bathroom was elegant, also small, but the Kiehl's toiletries were a winner. The bed was incredibly comfortable, with beautiful bedlinen. This is what you're paying for!The manager sent up some cake and fruit to celebrate my husband's 40th, that was a nice touch. The staff were very helpful and genuinely pleasant and friendly. There was no snooty attitudes here, and that really makes a difference. The prices of food, drinks and room service meant we didn't spend any money in the hotel at all! But if you can afford to spurge, I'm sure it is worth it. I'd recommend this hotel if you're minted, or if it is a special occasion, as it is a real treat to stay here.

We had a great stay at the Carlyle. Everything about it was fantastic. Unfortunately, we were in town for a wedding and did not get to experience the hotel and its facilities to the fullest, but from what we did experience, it was amazing. It is timeless and classic. The ambiance makes you feel comfortable and relaxed. Great location near the park for a quick morning walk and great recommendations for breakfast/coffee close by. I have always heard so much about Bemelman's Bar and was so excited I got to experience it. I thought I would only go in for a drink, but then 2 hours later we were still sitting there absorbing the jazz trio. It was great and loved walking around looking at Madeleine story line. Fantastic stay. I cant wait to come back soon. I hope.
user_name:
TigerSB26
New York City, New York

review_body: The Carlyle never disappoints. I recently had the opportunity to stay here again on a business trip to NY. Once entering the hotel, a calmness immediately is felt, escaping from the hustle and bustle of outside. They always remember my name, making me feel welcome every time. I highly recommend The Carlyle to a traveler wanting privacy, service and a home away from home.

Room is spacious, offer many tv chanels, they offer very good in room dinning, breakfast is good as well. Services are attentive and the staff recognize repeat guest very well. Hotel is old but overall maintenance is very good, room still looks fresh as well as lobby. Concierge offer good direction and assistance. Only one thing is not good is their lobby cannot receive mobile phone signal i believe because the heavy wall of the building. Really recommend this hotel!

Another JEWEL we stayed at would be The Carlyle Hotel in NYC. We originally found this hotel on Hotwire.com and then upgraded to a room with a terrace. SEriously I haven't seen movies with this nice of a view. You could see almost all of Central Park and the surrounding hotels were a bit further away so there were just incredible views all around. Staff were extremely kind and we especially loved the touch of the bellmen in the elevators (although I'd recommend to the hotel that they put fans in there not only for guests but those poor guys dressed to the nines sweating it up in those hot elevators)! Room service was amazing and we enjoyed the BEST jazz trio on Sunday evening after a jaunt out with friends at Carnegie Hall. Another place we've stayed that we'd be more than happy to go straight back to. Loved it.

Once you enter the hotel, you know it is different from other fine hotels in New York, it truly makes you feel like you live here. The service amiable and well mannered. Delicious food, incredible hair salon, knowledgeable staff and guests that truly did not get a special rate to stay at the hotel. A delight and a great way to stay in such a magical city!

Not the first time we have stayed here but a noticeable " commerciality" has recently crept into the atmosphere of a once distingusihed aristocrat of hotels - or that is the first impression you get when you check in. Their first objective is to do a trade with you and get you into a higher price room. Maybe that's the instruction from Rosewood head office to maximise room yield but it surprised me that their intent was so explicit. After we got thru that step ( and it actually suited us to upgrade to a large suite for an extra $500 night) , they were charming. The suites are large and impressive...beds superb. There are several "buts" however: the breakfast is outrageously expensive and rather pedestrian in both quality and service; no overnight shoeshine; its outsourced and will cost you which seems petty to me; the doorman is probably the most disinterested member of his profession in New York city; luggage retrieval is a bit of a lottery; and be careful to find out if your room overlooks the noisy construction site on the side road. Its overwhelming advantage is its location; all the great galleries and museums are within a short walking distance and so are the best shops ...so it is a perfect santuary come 4pm on a wet afternoon.
user_location: Timbavati Private Nature Reserve, South Africa
user_name:
NoelG993
Timbavati Private Nature Reserve, South Africa

review_body: We stayed at the Carlyle in room 1206 for one night on May 12th 2013 for the first time in our life. Obviously we had a very high expectation to this hotel with its historical fame and reputation. But we walked out of the hotel next day unrested and disappointed. The room has no privacy what so ever from the next-door neighbors, loud TV and conversations going on throughout the evening. Yet the worse thing is the bed which is old and sinking. Both of us couldn't get to sleep because we could find a comfortable position in that bed, what we got next day was the pain in the back. Indeed every single detail in the room look tired and some are inappropriate, for example, the water faucets in the shower cannot be reached easily and is dangerously located in the other side of the shower door.
user_name:
JOSEPHINE H
New York City, New York

review_body: We took our 3 and 22 year old children for a family weekend. The two bedroom suite was beautiful, spacious and very quiet. Gigi at the front desk made sure it was perfect for us! The toddler amenities were adorable. Just a block away from Central Park near the Levin playground entrance and a short walk to the zoo at Central Park. We love that the common areas and lobby at The Carlyle are not crowded, makes it so easy to get in and out. The Bemelman Bar is amazing and a great way to end the evening. This is our favorite place to stay in the city!

This was our first trip to New York and we were really looking forward to our stay. On arrival, we were made to feel really welcome and were swiftly booked in and shown to our room. The room was at the rear of the hotel and was nice and quiet, with no traffic noise whatsoever. It was well appointed with 2 walk in wardrobes, a small kitchen and (sadly) a VERY small but well equipped bathroom. We ate breakfast at the hotel, but took the remainder of our meals elsewhere. Breakfast selection was really good, however the buffet was seldom piping hot and could have been supplied with hot plates - tepid food served on cold plates becomes inedible very quickly. So why the but?? Tipping is not a way of life in Europe, I'm happy to tip when I've experienced exceptional service, an outstanding meal or someone's gone the extra mile. I don't agree with tipping just for the sake of it. To be given no option other than to add 15%, 18% or 20% to an already inflated bill is really irritating. I realize that this isn't just an issue at this hotel, but right across the hospitality sector in the USA. The first hotel that bucks the trend and offers everything gratuity free will, in my humble opinion, be onto a winner!

Great restaurant, bar (Bemelman's), accommodations, makes for a wonderful stay....take a tower room if available....staff is superb!......late afternoon cocktails with lovely piano in bar is perfect way to finish day, and begin evening......plus ghost of Bobby Short still very much in residence

Style, service, luxury, quiet, sophisticated, charm and elegant all come to mind after a stay at The Carlyle. Upper East side location close to Central Park enhance the stay even further. The bar is a delight.

We chose The Carlyle for this short trip to New York as we'd heard about its gracious service and we like the location. The service is on one level excellent - attentive, kind and gentle - very much of a bygone age. However some practices belong in the past and should be consigned to history. One of these is using lift attendants. As soon as you say what floor you want, the attendant turns and faces the wall as if they weren't there. I've heard of discretion but I found it rather uncomfortable - it just seems wrong nowadays to tell somebody else to press a floor button for you but in many ways the lift attendant at the Carlyle acts as a metaphor for the establishment. I do like very good service but I don't expect the person delivering the service to be submissive in any way and I found that some of the staff (not all!) were submissive - just wanting to blend in with the walls.We had a two bedroomed suite which was well-appointed and adorned with fresh roses. One gripe was that our bathroom was tiny - one of those spaces where a kitten couldn't have been swung! My other criticism would be that it was a bit shabby. Many of the hallways and walls looked like they urgently needed a refurb.We only ate room-service breakfasts at the hotel which were always perfect and delivered on time, so our experience of the catering was very positive.So in summary yes it's a grande dame but I didn't really warm to the hotel and there were aspects which I wasn't that keen about, so I don't think I'd return here with so many other upper-end options in New York.

We have stayed at The Carlyle a few times a year for many years. All staff always acknowledge you, but it is not over the top, they make you feel as if you are at home. Sure, over the years, we have had a small issue or two, but they respond and fix, quickly and not so apologeticly that you don't need sugar the rest of the day. I like that. The service is not forced, it is genuine. The lobby is not filled with people, so if feels like YOUR hotel, not anyone who happens off the street. They are also very descrete, you will never know if a very public person is in the hotel, I like this as there is never a disturbance. As our granddaughter says.....I LOVE IT!

If crown molding feels like home you, you've come home at The Carlyle. A staff that's calm and self-possessed. Modest public areas and gracious guest rooms. Breakfast buffet heaped with smoked salmon, meats and cheeses, fruit cups, eggs and many breads. Orange juice that you know was squeezed within the hour.

Really excellent and attentive service, fantastic phone operators, beautiful room. But!!! To tell that the air-conditioner is noisy it's to tell nothing! To fall asleep I have to use earplugs o turn it off. Thanks God, we're very tired every evening and the other family members don't suffer. One more thing - the breakfast for three of us costed next to 200 USD, it seems to me overpriced. Today we tried Cafe' Boulud, same street, on the corner, a Michelin star, half of the Carlyle breakfast + with tips included, and for a European it's rather imbarassing to calculate every time the tips amount, I understand the tradition, but still...

A gorgeous hotel, the staff was extremely professional and friendly and welcoming at the same time. The beds were very comfortable. The spa was wonderful. The Bar was beautiful and service excellent. Nothing much I could say that I did not like about it. I can't wait to go back again! Our stay was too short! The room was large and amazing and spacious.

The Carlyle made our trip to New York a pleasure. Situated just of Maddison Avenue within walking distance to midtown attractions and close to Central Park.On checking in with a very polite and welcoming reception we were told our rooms were not quite ready but we did arrive a little earlier that the checkin time due to our scheduled flight time, so this was not a problem. Our luggage was taken and stored for us whilst we ventured out into the city.We were allocated room 910 which delighted when we first walked in. The size of room was more than adequate with a walk in a wardrobe which also housed the minibar. The bathroom was a little small but this was masked by the mirrors on all four walls. The only slight critisicm was that there was no space between the bedroom and the room door leading onto the corridor.The public areas of this hotel are a return to a bygone age and such a pleasure to be in. A member of staff is always close by and on the whole looking to attend to your needs. I say on the whole because when I just wanted a drink at the bar in Bemelmans I had to wait when being the only person there. When served for the first time however each visit to the bar (after my wait) the bar tender did remember my order.Cafe Carlyle was a delight with a good meal and excellent entertainment, thank you to the restaurant captain and the waiting staff and a very big thank you to Herb Alpert and the band for a wonderful night of jazz. Knocked Ronnie Scotts of its perch.This hotel is expensive but it is quiet, beautiful and a joy to stay in.

This last stay was my 15th or so over the span of 8 years but there was absolutely no guest recognition at check-in or during the length of my stay. My room was so small that there was no furniture other than the bedside table for the hotel to use as a mini bar; my book had to share space with crackers, chips, sodas and such and I felt like I was sleeping in a mini supermarket. I had to request a shower cap and a laundry bag, as both were missing. No flower (yes, one) until day 2, no fruit, no magazines. My room had a connecting door to my neighbor and we kept eachother awake all night as we could hear eachother's phone calls, tv etc. What happened to this hotel? Have budget cuts been applied where they shouldn't have? This is no way to treat guests if you want them to leave happy. I was deeply disappointed.

our 3rd stay in 3 years -this occasion a few minor issues that need to be addressed by the management asap. My wife and i booked a superior king room which was lovely except there was an inter - connecting door to the next room. The 1st night the occupant had a racking cough and it sounded if he was in the room with us so i asked when he was leaving - the next night, so decided to stay put. On monday we heard a gentleman check in around 11 a.m and shortly afterwards a lady arrived, after a few minutes it was like we were on the set of a porn film, lots of graphic and highly explicit sex all to the background of Nora Jones. After the transaction she declined a shower and left.We are no prudes and each to their own its the soundproofing thats the issue here, oh and the tv didnt work despite the best efforts of maintenance.On a positive note the staff are a delight and the hotel a taste of the old New York, the bar and band superb but add the cover charge to the drinks bill and you need a deep pocket.Next trip to New Yoprk and we will rebook.

We have stayed in many of NYC's best hotels and the Carlyle ranks right up there. Rooms are large and luxurious with all amenities. Service is excellent, including check-in/out, housekeeping, dining, etc. The restaurants and the location cannot be beat. Walk to everything! Lots of closet space and a wet bar. We will definitely stay again.

Just returned from a weekend stay at The Carlyle. It was our first return since 2008 when we got engaged there. The property seems to have just gotten even better since our last stay. Service was outstanding and attention to detail was excellent and the place is so classy. We stayed at Four Seasons New York in November 2012 and much preferred The Carlyle. The property is much smaller and has much more of a boutique feel than the Four Seasons. We used the fitness center and spa and both were excellent. Spa services were outstanding. The spa is small but cozy and well maintained with a terrific front desk staff. Fitness center is small, but adequate with four state of the art treadmills, dumbbells and other machines. There was an attendant available for anything you might need. There also some personal training going on so that is available as well. White-gloved attendants work the elevators, which is a nice touch and must cost the hotel a fortune to maintain. Some reviewers seem to think it is a bit much, but we enjoyed this service and feel that it creates a refined atmosphere. Always having a friendly face greet us when the elevator door opened and announcing our floor when we arrived was appreciated. We felt truly special as guests. The décor of the hotel is stunning. Rooms are mid-century modern and charming. We stayed in Room 705 which was a deluxe room and was very spacious and even had a heated bathroom floor and WIC. Common areas and hallways are beautiful. Bed was extremely comfortable. Bell staff were very helpful. Concierge was also very helpful. In particular, concierge Waldo as extremely helpful, pleasant, informative, enthusiastic and responsive. He set up all our reservations even before we arrived and made a few revisions during our stay…he was just a text away! Location is perfect – right in the heart of great Madison Avenue shopping. It is tucked away from the hustle and bustle of the tourist areas which makes it much more relaxing than other properties that are closer to more of the action. We spent some time in Bemelman's Bar listening to pianist/vocalist Chris Gillespie, which we always enjoy. Chris plays jazz standards, show tunes, etc. between 5.30-8.30 p, and creates a nostalgic atmosphere reminiscent of days gone by. The bar itself is usually quite crowded and loud at times with all the martini drinking, but the maître d does a nice job of assisting with seating and comfort. Service in the bar is outstanding. Breakfast was buffet style in the Carlyle Restaurant, a stunning room. Service at breakfast was excellent and maître d Patrick was most gracious. We did not dine at Café Carlyle although the concierge offered to get us a table to hear Woody Allen. Unfortunately, it did not fit in with our plans, so we had to pass. All in all, this is a stellar, one of a kind property that anyone seeking an exquisite Upper East Side experience should not miss. Much better than the FSNY. Thanks to the entire staff at The Carlyle for a most enjoyable and elegant stay. Check out the photo I posted which says it all.

A picture says a thousand words, so I’ve attached a couple to give you a sense of what $550/night (before taxes) gets you at The Carlyle. If I had seen the room photos before booking, I would have reserved elsewhere.I was greeted by Larry at the front desk and I cannot recall a worst experience checking into any hotel. Everything started with “No” and ended with “I’m sorry m’am.” I think he is most comfortable checking in old men than he is younger women.I tried the spa, which was fabulous, got one of the best blow dries at the salon and beautiful massages during my stay. What I did not appreciate was that my masseuse’s tip was automatically added to my bill which would be handed to me with a “I hope it’s ok I added 15% to your bill” for a massage that is already $200/hour. After the second massage I asked about this practice and was told it’s because Europeans don’t tip and this is one way to make sure they do. Wait, I am not from Europe.One other thing I reproach the hotel is not making any distinction between guests and non-guests when it comes to the hotel bar and restaurants. There is rarely any space to sit and have a meal or a drink. So your default option is room service if you don’t feel like going out. The steak is $60 on the room service menu, with delivery charges, taxes and tips, you get a $100 steak delivered in your minuscule room, how’s that for value?Also, there was a wedding reception the weekend I was there and the walls being paper thin, it was impossible to get any sleep before all the other guests were passed out. And that was a little after 3 a.m. Front desk could or would do nothing about it. They were actually not very receptive to hearing about it.The positive are the location, the concierge services are impeccable (I got a table at excellent restaurants on very short notice), love the Kiehl's guest toiletries, finally, Frankie and the other lift men make up for the dated space that the elevators are.I would not go back because I believe that at that rate, I can be much better accommodated elsewhere in NYC.

We just got back from a 3 night stay at the Carlyle. The service was wonderful and this beautiful hotel is wonderfully situated just a block from Central Park and close to many museums & restaurants on our itinerary. The rooms are not large but they are very pretty and the staff works to keep you happy. No matter the request, you are treated courteously and all issues are resolved as smoothly as humanly possible. We had a continental breakfast delivered to our room each morning and it always showed up at the exact time we had requested the night before. The coffee was good and hot and the pastries, fresh fruit & fresh squeezed juice were delicious. The bathroom was also not particularly large but it was outfitted with everything you could possibly need and it was a very nice shower. We had a balcony outside our 21st floor room and the views of the city were spectacular. We also had an Irish coffee in the bar the afternoon we arrived and enjoyed our warm drinks. The doorman was always happy to chase down a cab or lend us an umbrella. The elevator operators though unnecessary were so very kind and friendly, we learned to enjoy seeing them as we rode up and down. All in all a truly exceptional experience. The big price tag here is warranted by the attention to detail. Be sure to visit Zitomer's drugstore across the street - another throw back to an earlier, more gracious time.

We have stayed here six times, the service is great from the front desk, elevator operators,house keeping, waiters the rooms are beautiful the food is good, we mostly had breakfast but lunch and dinner you are in NYC there are so many great restaurants that we did not eat in much .

I have just returned from a 4 night stay here & would make the following pointsThe GoodFabulous view from room on 31st floor. 2 walk in closets with ample hangers (something many hotels get wrong)Super, quiet location in best area of NY for shopping, museums, galleries, nice restaurants & interesting architectureHelpful concierge who booked restaurants for usThe BadA giant cockroach in the bath on our last morning. We had to drown it & then flush down lavatory as bath didnt have a big enough drain. This was a horrific experience, & even though the hotel took some moneyoff our bill it really spoilt the end of this special trip Poor housekeepingShower gel & shampoo was not replaced 2 days running & we had to call down for them both timesMats & slippers only left out on first evening, disappeared for the rest of stay but by then we couldn't be bothered to ring down.As others have said, room itself was small furniture tired, but we were happy with location & view, if we had been on a lower floor would certainly have wanted to move.Small extras such as laundry bags/shoe shine kit/laundry price list which we have always had in 5 stars in Britain or Europe were missing.

I live nearby, and I love the Bemelman's and the Café Carlyle (plus the coffeee and panini at Sant Ambroeus across the street). But I stayed once, coming in late at night, and even though they gave a few hundred dollars off the regular price, the room was still small and ordinary.

We chose to stay here for 2 nights as part of our US tour. We thought we'd pay a little extra for something special. From the reviews and photos (how they get those angles is anyone's guess!) it seemed to be a classy place. However on arrival our Classic room was a huge disappointment; it was on the 9th floor with a view of a brick wall about 30ft away - nice. This also made it dark and dingy. For $495 a night this seemed a bit of a joke. I asked for a different room and for an extra $25 per night we were moved to the 19th floor which was at least level with the other rooftops so a bit brighter but the view was still uninspired. One good thing was the shampoo/shaving products they were top class, however the jacuzzi bath probably hadn't been used since the 1930s as when we tried it lots of crap from the pipes came out - bits of copper and dirt etc. By this point we were ready to leave. The $14 A DAY! for WIFI in the room makes the place feel 'cheap - no frills'. Breakfast was poor. The fruit I had was dry and the pastries small and not very fresh. We had stayed in the SOFITEL in Washigton DC the previous 3 days and breakfast was fantastic in all respects if not just as pricey - $60 for two at both hotels. The other annoying thing was the lift attendants especially as the lifts are tiny there is not much room for anyone else! However there seemed to be some very 'special' people staying at this hotel, some I think live there...you know the sort of people who are too precious to press a button on lift. I got the feeling the Carlyle is more of a club/institution you pay to be there rather than what you get. Thing is they don't realise - you can't buy class! The staff were very attentive especially the receptionist & concierge who were great but we felt some of the others were too friendly/in your face ogling for a tip all the time, a little disingenuous - maybe that's just NY culture?! On the last night we were going to go to the bar as there was some jazz playing - i had taken a jacket and some smart clothes especially as this was mentioned on the website, however we were informed it would be $25 each to get in the hotel bar after 9pm! Even though we had spent over $1000 with them in 48hrs...it just felt like an insult to us, so we went out instead. If your going to stay here make sure you are on floor 20 or above, specify a view, eat out, take lots of $ bills for tips!

It was very nice, but it did not entirely match my expectations. The room was elegant, but did show some signs of wear. The views were fantastic, which made the room special. The bed was extremely comfortable, although it wouldn't be the best pick for light sleepers because the walls were a bit thin and the door rattled.There wasn't a comfy common area to sit and read (if you didn't want to eat/drink), so it's not ideal for solo or business travelers IMO. The service was certainly acceptable, but not exceptional.The location of the hotel is super, particularly for shoppers or museum-goers. I have no real complaints, and had a pleasant stay, but I did not feel "at home" or pampered in any particular way. And I think that's the experience I had expected from a NYC "grande dame" hotel.

I stayed 6 nights here last week, my 8th such stay in the last five years or so. This was the worst. The people in the next room smoked all week and the smoke not only filled the corridor but circulated my room 24/7 through the ventilation system. When I mentioned it to a porter I was met with a shrug and a giggle. Hot water took over 5 minutes to reach the tap every morning. But my biggest irritation is the $14.95 charge for wifi in your room. I stay in many great hotels around the world and the only time I can remember being charged for wifi in recent times was a not so great hotel, a travelodge. It is so petty. On the whole the lift staff are friendly but there is a tendency to snobbishness in the rest. I am sure there are many people for whom this hotel is the epitome of style and luxury; but personally I like luxury to serve my needs, not test them.

The room size was generous, but the furniture, lighting, bathroom and carpet are in need of renovation. The room was quiet but very dowdy. We asked for and quickly received a coffee pot so we could make coffee in the morning, but they wanted to charge us for cups. Every other Rosewood we've stayed at has had self serve coffee service.The location is excellent and the service was terrific. Once renovated, this will once again be a five star hotel.

“It happens from time to time that the well-known Grand Dame hotels from NY to London to Paris and further afield end up disappointing. Not the case here. First of all, it is hard to beat their enviable curbside appeal on East 76th street / Madison Avenue; but mostly the old-world style meets panache factor is unparalleled in this town's hotel choices. The public spaces are grand yet intimate, rooms are generously proportioned and elegant, and the restaurant and Cafe Carlyle are venues many insider-New Yorkers frequent themselves. Gym, full-service spa, excellent breakfast: check check check. The refurb they are about to undergo will make this property sing; I look forward to returning to experience it all!”

Built approximately in 1930, The Carlyle carries significant and timeless ambiance in true New York style. The staff is impeccable, catering to a guest's every need. Though you may sight a celebrity lingering in the lobby or riding along in the elevator with you, there is never a stare or a gawk, The rooms are spacious and are timelessly classic. While the Carlyle staff and its guests have impeccable manners. The location is perfect, away from the maddening crowds, yet only blocks from Fifth Avenue. Bemelman's Bar timeless and a perfect place for meeting friends for drinks or a romantic rendezvous. The restaurant's elegant setting and atmosphere with overtones of hushed conversation serves something for everyone. The escagot is deliciously mouth watering and the souffles arrive at your table bubbling with hints of what is to come. Almost but not quite, am rethinking about sending this. Hush.......tell only your very best and dearest.

We stayed at the Carlyle over the Christmas holiday, and it was fantastic. We try to stay at the Carlyle once a year, and I figured it was time to write a review. The rooms are wonderful, with good views. We typically get a terrace room which is amazing. It has a huge terrace overlooking the City where you can hang out at night and enjoy the views or have a meal. Just fabulous. The soap at the Carlyle is simply amazing too. I've never used a soap so wonderful in my life. The elevator operators are a really nice touch. Throws you back to a more gentile time in history. The Carlyle is my favorite hotel in New York City and I highly recommend it.

Back in July me and my boyfriend stayed in the hotel for only 3 nights as we were travelling on to florida but was the best 3 nights ever! We were so impressed from being checked in till when we checked out. We flew from the UK so after a long flight it was perfect to relax in. To be honest I miss the hotel more then New York! We have recommended your hotel to family and friends back home. Hope to come back soon. Definitely felt at home staying with you.

I don't understand why The Carlyle only rates 74th on TripAdvisor. It's fantastic. A gracious and luxurious place to stay in NYC. We enjoyed 10 days staying with The Carlyle and, from breakfast staff to last orders at Bemelmans Bar you cannot be more at home and treated specially. I'd like to add praise for the martinis too - definitely the best in town. The hotel's location is great - and what a way to start or end a day than by walking up or down Madison. You are within easy walking distance of everything Midtown, even though you might think that at 76th you are too far up the east side. The hotel offers its own driver to take you about if you wish. Many brilliant restaurants of all descriptions are a block or 2 away. Concierge services are excellent; rooms beautifully appointed and excellently serviced; we travel to NYC a lot and really do not know why we have not stayed here before - though we have been to the cafe, restaurant and bar before. And by the way - why not celebrate your new year there? Plan now for 2013/14! The party/ball is absolutely splendid - and dancing to the wee smallies to the Duchin band.The experience is complete.

We stayed for 3 nights before Christmas. The location was fantastic as it was so peaceful after the madness of Christmas shopping on 5th Avenue. We really loved the contrast.Bemelman's Bar is one of my most favourite places ever. The atmosphere is amazing but at that time of the year the place is so busy so you need to time it to make sure you get a good seat.Our room was very large by New York standards and we really liked it although it felt slightly bare (no bedside lamps). It was very quiet and the bed was great, so we slept very well.Love the Kiehls products in the bathroom - great selection.We had dinner in the hotel restaurant one night and it was fantastic; so relaxed and the food was great. The Maitre D' was very charming and entertaining too. We will definitely eat in the hotel on our next visit.Overall I think this is a fabulous place but I would agree that perhaps some of the rooms need a bit of attention.

Second visit to NY this time to celebrate 3 50th birthdays. From the very start nothing was too much trouble including making sure our two rooms were close together, and were beautiful.guys working the lifts were brilliant Alan even sang to us on our last day. Stephanie the concierge was tremendous getting us tables at Daniels and Balthazar and the Cafe Carlyle all at less than 24 hours notice. The restaurant was very good we were spoiled with special birthday deserts and then had more in our rooms.A real highlight is Benelmans Bar. Especially the cocktails. Would only stay here if I came back and we did sample cocktails in a lot of top NY hotels.

The Carlyle is like staying with an old friend. While others have mentioned the somewhat dated facilities, I enjoy the classic ambience and old world service. It is definitely a Hotel that is appreciated by celebrities and world leaders seeking discretion. If you are looking for techno lounge music piped throughout the property, this is not the hotel for you.
user_name:
rqfnyc
New York City, New York

review_body: We found everything about this luxury hotel came up to expectations - service, rooms, decor, ambiance. If I had to find a criticism it would be that the scrambled eggs at the buffet breakfast were not hot, but probably this was because a previous guest had left the lid of the salver, so it would have been pointless to blame the staff and I am sure that they would have put things right if i had bothered to remark on this.Very pleasant short stay. No wonder this hotel has such a reputation!

Attended a wedding here (not mine!) in September last year and the food and service received were absolutely fantastic. Had a lovely three course meal. I'm not normally a fan of crab at all, but the crab starter was amazing. The beef fillet main was also excellent, and cooked spot on. The staff seemed very friendly and helpful, especially a barman (Nat I think his name was) who made me up a couple of brilliant drinks when I didn't know what I wanted, one of which I now make at home!Whilst I couldn't comment on the rooms as I did not stay here, everything that I did experience seemed first class. The decor in the bits of the hotel I did see seemed nice. Would certainly contemplate staying here the next time I visit New York (budget permitting!).

Stayed at the Carlyle recently for 3 nights on business because my regular NYC options were fully booked. There are aspects of this hotel that I love-- location, art deco design (particularly in the lobby), Bemmelman's bar, excellent service.That said, what I do not love is that the hotel-- and in particularly the rooms, hallways and elevators-- feel old, tired and threadbear.There have been some efforts made by laying new carpet in the rooms, updated beds and bed linens and a few other touches, but the overall feel is tired. The bathrooms are very old. They used top of the line materials when they were build, but after decades of use they look worn and outdated. Same goes for the old, rickety herringbone wood floor. Most of the furniture in the rooms looks cheap and very outdated (as opposed to fine quality, and antique).The Carlyle is pricey. There is a cost for all this history and prized location. But, as its long-time customer base ages, serious changes (upgrades) will need to be made if it's going to retain its position at the top of the market.

Beautiful property, well situated away from the bustle of the mid-town frenzy during holiday time.Service was good but rooms are just fair.Bathrooms are well equipped but a little ancient.Rates are exorbitant for this time of the year!

I didnt stay in the hotel, i actually live nearby but went to the spa for the first time yesterday. I have to say I have been to a million spas in NYC but this one took the cake. WOWService was 7 star if that was possible, decor is like youve stepped into an imaginary land. lobby was amazing. It was the best massage I'd had in years. A bit pricy but worth every penny.
user_name:
Nancy K
New York City, New York

review_body: This is a place where you truly get what you pay for. The staff are simply amazing. They always seem to know who you are, and no request is ever too trivial. All of the rooms are extremely comfortable, and views over Central Park are stunning. Simply the best hotel in New York

When i stayed at this hotel is was the best ever. Every day you got FIJI water instead of drinking tap water, they offer you there all and every night they come to open your bed up that is of course u want them to any how it was a wonderful stay there and i want to go back soon.

My girlfriend and I stayed at The Carlyle for nine nights in May 2010 having booked an excellent rate through Virgin Holidays.This is a first class hotel offering an authentic, traditional experience. The public areas, in particular the Lobby with its immaculate black marble floors and Bemelmans Bar with its beautiful murals, are unique and worth a visit in their own right. Service is discreet, proper and quite reserved but without being stuffy or pretentious. In fact we were made to feel quite welcome and the hotel felt like home very quickly.Our room (I think it was a ‘Classic Room’) was quiet, comfortable and very spacious with two walk-in wardrobes (amenities included the usual array of clothes hangers as well as a wooden clothes brush, full size shoe horn and golf umbrella) and a kitchen/private bar (fully stocked with top quality local products). Oak parquet floors were partially covered by a large, thick rug of high quality. Furnishings were antique but well-maintained with hardly a trace of wear and tear. The bed was large and extremely comfortable with linens, pillows and duvet of the finest quality. The bathroom was small but luxurious with powerful water pressure and excellent Kiehls products. Room service for breakfast was excellent as you would expect – superb coffee and croissants, beautifully presented.The only criticisms I would make of the room are that it didn’t have much of a view (the courtyard isn’t very attractive) and a surcharge was payable for WiFi, although the connection speed was very fast.A few problems occurred during our stay and they were handled competently by the staff. When we arrived at the hotel there had been an issue with the booking (Virgin had supplied incorrect dates) and a room had to be specially prepared for us. The receptionist escorted us to Bemelmans Bar where we were treated to a performance by a Jazz quartet and served excellent food and drinks on the house while we waited for our room to be prepared.Unfortunately I was substantially overcharged at check out only to notice upon returning home. The accounts department were quick to rectify the discrepancy and compensated me for the loss I incurred due to a change in the exchange rate.Overall this was a memorable stay in a unique, historic hotel.

We held our wedding ceremony, reception and party at The Carlyle - the day before Sandy arrived. It was truly magic. All arrangements were perfect, the rooms looked gorgeous, the staff was incredibly helpful (i.e. they managed to find a seamstress at 11 pm on Saturday night to help us out with an urgently needed alteration for a dress) and all very caring.During and after "Sandy", the hotel continued to provide outstanding service with staff members working round the clock, looking after the wellbeing of their guests.

I stayed at The Carlyle for a week at the end of August during the U.S. Open. My stay was absoultely wonderful. The hotel offers a true New York experience. Everything makes you feel like you are a resident in a high end apartment, not the guest in a hotel. The staff remembers your name, your room location & your preference for breakfast. Add to that rooms that make you feel truly at home & you've got a great hotel. Yes, the furnishings in the rooms do seem somewhat old-fashioned. The rooms are, however, immaculately clean & quite tranquil. I've stayed at lots of hotels in New York over the years. Some have been cheap & some have been ultra high-end. Without a doubt, The Carlyle was the most wonderful experience I have ever had at a hotel in New York. I would strongly recommend The Carlyle.

My mother and I stayed here in March 2012 and had the most fabulous stay. Nothing was too much trouble, the staff were very helpful and friendly - greeting us by name in the lobby and at breakfast etc (I had the french toast which was delicious) I was afraid it was going to be "snooty" but it was nothing like that in the slightest. Our room had a lounge room, bedroom, kitchenette (which we didn't use) and bathroom. Yes the bathroom was on the small side but it didn't bother us in the slightest as it was partially expected staying in an older hotel. The room was clean, with beautiful furnishings.Our most favorite thing to do after a big day walking through central park and lots of shopping was to sit in the bar and listen to the beautiful piano - great atmosphere and very attentive service (never had to remind which wine I was drinking and our table snacks never even got empty!) This alone is worth the stay - but certainly not the only great thing about this hotel.Would stay again in a heartbeat if the budget allowed another trip and would recommend it to anyone wanting to experience something special in New York!

I first stayed at the Carlyle in 1981 and have gone back 44 times since then. It goes from strength to strength. There is nothing to criticise about this hotel and the staff makes sure it stays that way. Great entertainment at the Cafe Carlyle. Great food in the restaurants. Excellent rooms and room service. The price is high but the experience is unsurpassed.

After a wonderful 3 night stay at the Plaza, we did not have too many expectations of the Carlyle. Our free upgrade to a suite created much excitement! The room was spacious and the amenities in the bathroom was first class. The service and attention from the time we entered to the time we left was very impressive. The cherry on the top was when we mananged to secure a table, at the already sold out Cafe Carlyle, where Woody Allen and his Jazz band were playing - we walked out with stars in our eyes! The food was brilliant and the music sublime!

Admittedly, when my room was upgraded to a huge suite with a piano (!!!) in it, I was probably going to be impressed... The service was as it should be for a world-class hotel and the room (more of an apartment) was a wow kind of a room. And a word on the food and the bar - class - not quite over the top but close enough to feel pretty good about you choice.

I have never been able to afford the price of the hotel rooms; however, I have been to Bemelmans Bar and it was just awesome. The pianist was great and the drinks were substantial. Worth going to to see the murals and to just be in the atmosphere of an upscale wonderful hotel.

We stayed overnight at the Carlyle last JUNE 2011 to watch Lea Salonga's New York in June at the Cafe Carlyle. We stayed at The Plaza the night before. Regrettably, it was a wrong decision to leave The Plaza for The Carlyle. For the same amount of money, The Plaza screams opulence in everything including SERVICE! I booked the Carlyle room through Oyster.com which came with free breakfast. On our check out day, I called front desk regarding the free breakfast. The lady denied that my accommodation did not come with the free breakfast. I informed her that it is contained in my email which she asked to have a copy of it. So, I went down to show her the said email which was in my iPhone. I was asked to forward the said email to a Carlyle email add. Then, I was asked to wait as she had to make calls first (most possibly to verify the veracity of the email in my inbox). She made me wait for almost an hour but still no action. I felt like we were beggars waiting for our rations in a corner. I felt humiliated deep inside knowing that I am not white and I could have been served better. My husband was telling me that we should just eat outside but I told the front desk lady that I wish not to wait any further and I will pay for our breakfast instead. We headed to the restaurant and we were seated by a staff and menus were handed to us. Then, the head waiter came to our table and told us that they could not accommodate our son because he was wearing shorts. I was completely aware of the dress code but overlooked his outfit. What was highly frustrating though was this young lady inside the restaurant was just wearing a very skimpy shorts and looking like a w____! Not only that, she was wearing flip-flops too but her Grandma is apparently a resident. I didn't say anything and so my son went back to our room and changed into pants. During check out, I was informed that my breakfast was already taken care of. She made it sound that it was a nice gesture from the hotel. Hah, as if that was a favor from them!I should NOT HAVE WAITED for almost an hour for something that should have been accorded to me because I PAID (and pre-paid with Oyster) for it in the first place. And, Mr. Manager, even if you reply to this complaint, I am advocating others not to stay in this hotel. The damage has been done and you could not rectify it. I urge others to go The Plaza instead, join their club (Fairmont President's Club) for free and check out the members' benefits. Free wifi, free limo ride, free parking, too. (Yes, I did not get charged for it!) Or go to any other hotels except The Carlyle.
