I stayed at The Carlyle for 5 days with my spouse. A pretty good stay compared to the other 5-stars hotels I've staying at. But ...The plus : great room with 2 walk-in dressing rooms, the extremely good overall service.The minus: fungus in the shower, extremely noisy air conditioning system (my wife couldn't sleep without air plugs even after 24 hours without sleep) and pretty old furnitures. The room we had on the 7th floor was looking in the court and thus very dark.Overall good experience, great location, but we probably won't come back. Beside that, I was disappointed by the spoilage of energy by letting the light the whole day on. Moreover the well known system that foresees that people let the towels they want to be changed on the ground wasn't possible at The Carlyle.

I have always wanted to say at the Carlyle. I went for a long weekend of theater at the end of June and booked there my first night. What a disappointment! Wonderful location, beautiful views but NOT a 5 star experience. The lobby on my tower floor room smelled moldy, there was a leak under the sink so that water flowed out when I opened the door, interior of medicine cabinet had been sanded but not painted, stain in the room carpet, ripped wallpaper above the bed. Breakfast in dining room was very average and service was indifferent. It felt like a lack of attention to detail by management. Yikes.I would not go there again and, I have to say, it makes me wonder about other Rosewood properties.

My wife and I stayed att Carlyle for three nights. The Hotel is very nice and the staff is very service minded and friendly. Its not one of those big hotels where no one knows who you are and there are lots of tourists. Stay at Carlyle if you want a good hotel, splendid service and a smile from everyone. The didning room where you also take your breakfast is one o the nicest I ever tried.

I staying at big names Westin and Marriott but it was special occasion and I decide to stay at The Carlyle. I hearing great things from me friend who stay last month and she love the workers and the hotel, it was easy for me to pick the carlyle. I and my wife celebrating a holiday after three years from our family and work, we really looking forward to this weekend.Our flight lated two times, I very tired and want to sleep. Doorboy |Victor was very nice he welcoming us really nice. He knowed we tired and worked very fast and get our bags to the check in desk. My wife and him right away start talking they both from the same country. Room had small problem but I call the check in desk and talk to Raul he so helpful and solve problem fast. If problem not stop I call again but he call me back and ask if all okay so nice of him. Service so far at the carlyle perfect. Beds and design of room too good. Feel like home and really good sleep.I come again soon. thank you

If you want to experience an old school NY moment, away from the hustle and bustle of midtown Manhattan, then the Carlyle is an ideal choice. It is elegant, but not pretentious. We had an older room on an upper floor with a corner view...windows looking out onto both the street and the park. Beautiful! If the walls could talk....the tales they would tell! There is a refined elegance to the Carlyle. The bar is fabulous, the breakfasts elegant and the service outstanding all around. The hotel is located on the upper east side and in a residential area, which is perfect for those of us who like to feel at home while traveling. I can't wait to go back!!!

Back to The Carlyle after a number of previous visits - this time for business. This hotel really never disappoints, it's elegant, charming, sophisticated and understated. I'm not averse to funky modern properties, but invariably you can never find the lights and they can be "all style over substance," not designed for guests’ comfort. Not The Carlyle. Apart from impeccable staff and accommodation and an historical bar, I love it for where it is. The madness of mid-town is left behind as you walk up Madison to a real (and safe and smart) neighbourhood. And yet I can walk to my NY office on 57th in just 10 minutes (weather permitting!) and window shop at the same time. 5 stars all round. I love it.

It really does not get much better than the enduring Carlyle Hotel. From the hotel entrance to the elevator operators, this is a first class experience on one of the finest upper east side streets.Our room was very spacious as we rented a private apartment. We had two bedrooms and two baths with a small kitchenette. We felt as if we truly lived on the upper east side of NYC. The location is a soothing retreat from the intensity of NYC.Every thing about the Carlyle is stellar, so if you can afford it....stay there, you will feel gratified.

Such a wonderful first time stay at the Carlyle. Your service and facility has a unique way of combining rich history and prestige with modern day amenities and ease. If you are looking for a spot that is away from the hustle and bustle of Midtown, this is your home away from home when traveling to NYC.We will definitely be back!

From the minute we arrive to the minute we leave the entire staff is professional and ever so friendly, always amazing and nothing but perfect memories to take home with us. Located in an area filled with gorgeous brownstones and the hottest shopping in New York. 2nd Avenue offers everything from Sushi to Italian to the best Deli you have ever eatten. But definately leave room for Room Service. The New York Cheese Cake is not to be missed!

We stayed at the Carlyle for a friends wedding in July, as the happy couple were also staying their. Initially the hotel wasn't my first choice but having stayed there, it is now!It's a very traditional hotel with the old world grandeur you expect from a 'Grand Dame'. We were staying in a Superior Room on the seventh floor. The room was very spacious with a walk-in wardrobe and the bed was a super King, so had loads of space! I read one review saying they had a problem with the aircon but it was absolutely fine when we were there on the back of the heat wave. The hotel is perfectly located by Central Park, which means you can grab a cab to Soho and shop 'till you drop and then retire back at the hotel. As luxurious as the hotel is, the staff really made the stay. From the housekeeper who has been working at the Carlyle for 25 years, to the gentlemen who operate the lifts who remembers who you are and will have a good chat and a joke with you. The concierge and bellman were also excellent and were very helpful. The only gripe I would have is sometimes the lifts took a while BUT that is not uncommon for any hotel. We will definitely be back to New York and we willbe staying at the Carlyle again.

My wife and I were travelling with two teenagers. Those with kids know it is hard to find hotel accommodations for 4 without getting two rooms. The Carlyle has a great two bedroom suite available that gave everyone enough room and privacy. We loved the Carlyle location. While we often found ourselves on the subway to downtown/midtown, it was nice in the late afternoon to return to the peace and quiet of the Carlyle. Perfect location for a run in Central Park. Loved the jazz bar. Breakfast buffet was very good, though expensive.Very traditional NYC hotel. Great service, friendly staff, great concierge. Some people may feel the environment is a bit stuffy, but we enjoyed the aesthetic.

After being enticed by an e-mail from Rosewood Hotels to book a suite at a special summer rate, I booked one through American Express Platinium travel at $540. Upon arrival I asked for a complimentary upgrade ususally available. The front desk indicated that nothing was available but did tell me that for $200 I could go up two categories. They subsequent indicated that the difference would be only $125 which I agreed to pay. After a brief wait I was brought to the suite on the third floor next to the Spa. This was explained as a recent rennovation. It contained a baby grand in the corner of the living room. The decor in the living room and bedroom looks quite out of date. Window drapes, sheers and roller blinds were drawn and after some assisitance the bellman got them opened to a 76th street view over the Hotel entry.Breakfast in the restaurant was exceptional in terms of service while the omlette was somewhat bland.Upon my departure I was excorted to the garage next door to pick up the car rather than being delivered to the door which I would have expected to be brought to the side door at a 5 star (diamond?) hotel.The staff suggested the next time I should book the higher suite and possibly be upgraded to a Carlyle Suite which they told me might satisfy my higher expectations.At the very least I would request a suite on a higher floor.

Of course, expense could be a concern, and if it is, don't even check in. But if you can afford it, there's no better indulgence in New York than to stay at The Carlyle. The rooms are sumptous, the food from room service and in the restaurants devine, and the entertainment in Bemelman's Bar and The Cafe sophisticated and spendid. Every shop you want is right outside the front door and there are more galleries within 10 blocks than you can possibly cover on one trip. The entire staff was concerned about our well being and remembered our names through our visit. We'll never stay anywhere else in new york.

My wife and I had the great pleasure of seeing Steve Tyrell perform at the Carlyle in December of 2011 (his Christmas Show). The venue is very small and offers great views from every seat. The intimacy of the venue allows the guest artist to interact easily and comfortably with the audience. This night was very special as Steve Martin and his wife were also in attendance (a classy gentleman that appeared to be shy and courteous to the artist who is a friend of his, and to the patrons that said hello to him; one asked for an autograph). Steve Tyrell of course, was awesome!Attending a show at this venue is quite expensive but a very special treat. If this is out of your budget then save your money and come for that special occasion. This is something to experience at least once in your lifetime.
user_name:
ChinaDuo
New York City, New York

review_body: We booked a last minute trip to New York and were surprised to see an excellent rate for the Carlyle when booking our flights on Orbitz. We had considered staying in mid-town (we usually stay at The London) or downtown as we had our teenager with us, but this deal was too good to pass up. Well, we are now spoiled for life! We don't ever want to stay anywhere else. We had an enormous room with windows that opened across one side of the room. There were curtains and shades for light control. It was beautifully decorated in blues and tan and was very quiet. Our son's room was also very large and nice, although it was a bit darker as he had fewer windows. The staff was very nice (although it is a bit awkward to have elevator operators) and helpful. The only downside (slight) was that the bathroom was on the small side and had a shower/tub combo rather than a separate shower. The concierges were good. One helpful concierge recommended that we find theater tickets online as they would be cheaper and we were able to find excellent seats for Book of Mormon that evening. We loved the location. There was a subway line close by and we enjoyed walking through the park. We will definitely stay here again.

very nice hotel, close to the subway, dead posh and a bit reserved. somewhere to stay if you want classy but not sassy. stayed with our teenage children who felt it was a bit stuffy. good room sizes with small bathrooms but not a bad price for such a prestigious hotel. we didnt eat here but chose a diner around the corner which was what we wanted, fun and typical New York. We liked it because it wasnt down town but was 4 minutes from central park and from Moma (which was amazing). dont think i would chose to stay here again but only because i like a change! its not a reflection on the hotel which is exceptionally good.

It was hot in NYC, and the AC in our room did not work, the staff was great and moved us. However, the new room was only two degrees (75 vs. 77) cooler, no cool air moving at all. The staff is wonderful, rooms over the top, but not being able to sleep because it was so hot spoiled the trip. For the cost and reputation, the AC should work

We stayed at the Carlyle because we were tired of the hustle and bustle of Midtown and were looking for something a bit quieter. The Carlyle certainly fit that bill. It was nice to return from a Broadway show or dinner and get away from the mobs of people. The residential streets of the Upper East Side were also a welcome change. Speaking of residential, the Carlyle itself is full of residents (perhaps 20 – 25% of the rooms are permanent residents). This fact makes the hotel feel more like a residence than a hotel. However, don’t be surprised when the elevator opens and a dog or two walks out! Speaking of the elevators, they are run by friendly white gloved operators. Stop by the lounge area after a show and be sure and try out the 20 layer crepe cake!

I agree with the earlier reviews. Being on-site over a weekend, with two wedding taking place, 90% occupancy, the hotel runs as smooth as silk. Having brides in the lobby simply steppped up the Carlyle's elegance factor. (It doesn't need much help.) If you're thinking of staying in midtown, rethink that idea. NYC is hard work... you'll love coming back to the Carlyle and the 76th/Madison neighborhood. Everything is steps away, including the Central Park entrances off Fifth. Thanks to Kim Manning, Director of Sales - who graciously meets your expectations. Don't miss the Gallery for lunch or afternoon tea!

We took advantage of a 3rd night free promotion and booked a room in the Towers on the 33rd floor.The room was very quiet and comfortable and we had a fabulous view looking uptown and at Central Park over the roof of the Met.The staff is fantastic, very attentive and friendly, but understated. Even though the Carlyle is known as an old school New York society venue, we felt perfectly comfortable coming & going in sneakers, shorts & t-shirts for our afternoon excursions, while getting 'dressed to the nines' for our evening outings, ending with a nite cap at Bemelmans Bar.Fabulous location - walk to Central Park, the Met & other museums, short train ride or cab to midtown. We felt so at home we didn't want to leave!
user_name:
MCtraveler1200
New York City, New York

review_body: This was our second stay at the Carlyle. We loved it. We had a corner room on the 8th floor. The room was impeccably decorated, immaculate and very comfortable. The staff was warm and gracious. The location provides an oasis in the midst of the city with easy access to everywhere. Just all very well done.

Our first stay here having previously used the plaza and Pierre in new York.Our room on the eleventh was very comfortable , the bathroom perhaps a little too small,after a days sight seeing it was so nice to come back to , a bit like home.The staff are as pleasant and efficient as you could wish for, the breakfast buffet knocks spots off both the plaza and the Pierre plenty of choice , lunch in the gallery a rather jewel like area with Excellent food , the gazpacho -much better than when we ever have it in Spain , the crab cakes A particularly new York speciality , very good indeed, these two dishes we had nearly every day.Then of course the dark and sexy bemelmans bar world famous , here it's forever night, with a Pianist and band in the evening -fun.Not forgetting the cafe Carlyle with it's cabaret , we were lucky to catch woody allens last night on june 18 , unforgettable experience in the delightful room with its pretty murals on the walls it's sharp service, and good food , not brilliant but acceptable.The location on Madison is just right a step away to central park to the frick etc.This is where to stay in new York .

I had the chance to stay in the City on a recent weekend and checked into the The Carlyle for the first time in about 10 years. It remains one of my favorite hotels. I had a north facing room on an upper floor in the tower with views of Central Park. The room (queen bed with great linens) was modest in size, but comfortable. Furnishings might have seemed dated, but recognizing that much of it was Dorothy Draper allowed an appreciation of the classic look. Everything was impeccably clean. Bathroom was well appointed with toiletries from Kiehl's and the house bar soap that I instantly remembered from years ago. The bathroom had no shortage of mirrored surfaces (to the point of being a bit much). Closet space was abundent. Service was great, from the front door to reception to the maids, elevator attendants (!) and bell staff. Suit and shoes pressed and polished in short order on Saturday afternoon. Climate controls worked nicely. Only drawback: the obnoxious charge for WI-Fi access. At this price point for a room, Ido not believe that one should not be asked to pay. But I suppose at this price point, one should not be thinking too much about another $15 per day. The hotel is well located at Madison and E. 76th. Not the best location if you want to do the usual tourist thing, but exceptional for shopping on Madison, access to Central Park (one block), museum mile, the 6 train at Lexington and E. 77th and only a few minutes walk to Sushi of Gari (not to be missed, reservations recommended). Room price for the weekend was comparable to Four Seasons and Peninsula, and while those hotels are more modern and attractive in their way, the same price would have yielded me an interior or adjacent building view at those properties, and nothing can beat an upper east side location with a good view of the park for a fun and relaxing weekend.
Stayed here for the weekend on a "suite Deal"The room was amazing, old world charm and furnishings, but with all needs for a modern traveller.The bed was ultra comfy!

We had a very enjoyable stay at this charming, traditional hotel. The location is fabulous and our room was very spacious with a really comfortable bed and two walk-in closets.We'd definitely recommend The Carlyle to anyone looking for a stay at an exclusive address in New York.

We stayed at the Carlyle from 6-11-12 to 6-14-12. Our 13 year old son was having major surgery at a nearby hospital and the Carlyle was the best place to stay during this time. Not only did they meet our every need and request but they went above and beyond. The staff were all truly concerned for our son. Each staff person was delightful and eager to help. We will be staying again at the Carlyle when we return for our sons next surgery.

My wife and i visited New York last week on a brief stay in the City. Having stayed at The Carlyle for our honeymoon last year, we were keen to revisit The Carlyle. The hotel and their staff were amazing as always, we were lucky to get upgraded to a room in the Tower and found the accommodations, service and dining to be of the highest order. If you want to stay close to Central Park and enjoy the quiet setting of the Upper East Side but close to the shopping of Madison Avenue, there is only one place to stay. We cannot wait to return soon.

I stayed at the Carlyle for a few days after I had surgery at one of NYC's top hospitals. The hotel staff could not have been nicer and more accommodating of my needs for a soft diet and refrigerator in the room to house my jello supply. The restful and no-stress atmosphere contributed greatly to the beginning of my recovery. While I enjoy staying at the Carlyle when I am able to take advantage of all of the amenities of the hotel and the neighborhood, I am particularly grateful that the hotel goes out of its way to help out-of-town patients take advantage of the world class medical care available in New York.
user_name:
pamstuart
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: The Carlyle is such a fabulous place to stay while in NYC. So close to central park and a short walk downtown. There is a wonderful local feel to this hotel. The hotel is in a fabulous upper east location which has suome other fabulous hotels accross the block so you don't have to travel far if you are looking to eat or drink elsewhere. The rooms are tired and the bathrooms are very small however the staff and charm of the hotel more than make up for it. There are escorts in the lifts to take you to your floor, always happy and friendly and the knowledgeable concierge recommended and secured some wonderful restaurants for us. We ran in the park and finished off our work out each day in gym which is well equipped and convenient. I would highly recommend the Carlyle and we will return!

We recently stayed at this wonderful small hotel for a birthday weekend. We booked through American Express Platinum on a whim and checked in later in the day. The moment we walked through the door we felt as if we had crossed into another era. A time when men were gentleman and women were ladies. The hotel stay greeted us with warmth and familiarity even though the last time we had stayed was years before. Without even asking Riley upgraded our room and when it was a little less than the view we desired, found us another room that gave us a view of the entire park and most likely three other states! It was mezmorizing. The view itself could have been the evenings entertainment. We decided however, to venture down to the Bemelman's Bar and have a light dinner and listen to the trio playing that evening. They were fabulous! The food was great, the music wonderful and the evening perfect. We have to thank Riley and the entire staff of the Carlyle for making this weekend so perfect. We also can't forget the wonderful men operating the elevators too. They also smile, make your feel important and show how happy they are that you have chosen their hotel for your stay in the city. Bravo!

I have stayed at this hotel many times while in NYC, and it is definitely one of my favorites.I love the lounge and Cafe Carlyle serves wonderful coffee and tea.The rooms are a little dated, but they are all in this style and in keeping with the hotels decor and heritage.

If you are looking for a low key, elegant, old school NYC hotel this is it. There's no flash here which considering what has happened to the Plaza is a good thing. Yes, the rooms are on the small side, it's NYC but the service is top notch. The Cafe Carlyle is wonderful (not the food, which is dreadful) but the entertainment. I like being on the Upper East Side it gives you the feel of how a very exclusive few live in the greatest city in the world.
Great staff. Excellent location. Phenomenal room service. WOODY ALLEN WAS PERFORMING JAZZ IN THE LOUNGE!! One of the coolest experiences On my life.

There are many fine hotels in New York and my wife and I have stayed at many of them, all of which included or were within walking distance of a nightclub, such as The Blue Note, Birdland, or Feinstein's, but our finest and most satisfying experiences have been at the Cafe Carlyle located in the Hotel Carlyle. The management and staff of this prestigious hotel are clearly dedicated to provide a most gratifying and luxurious experience for their guests, at a very reasonable price!

This updates my review in 2004. I must confess that I have threatened to go other places to stay in NYC, but we always end up at the Carlyle. I had some reservations when Rosewood bought the hotel, but,if anything, it is better than ever. The thing that separates The Carlyle from anywhere else, is the quality of the service. It is truly amazing. Bemelman's Bar and the Gallery have raised their prices, but that is good because it serves to discourage the Bridge and Tunnel people, who used to inhabit the place on weekend nights. The electricity went off during my shower in the AM one day and their response to this was incredibly professional.

Always enjoy my stay here. Won't stay anywhere else! Close to everything I enjoy in New York. Very impressed with staff's attention to detail. Men at the door were very kind to get me a cab too - much appreciated!!
user_name:
Heidi W
Salt Lake City, Utah

review_body: I would love to stay there again. Thanks and I love your service and your beautiful hotel!
Over priced and poor value. Snooty atmosphere. TV did not work, safe did not function. Treats in room past date and stale.

Without a shadow of any doubt this property in my personal opinion is the best property in New York. From the moment you arrive outside the building to when you leave, there is nothing that I have for the property, experience or team but praise. When you step inside you are in a different era, where service is of the upmost importance whether your checking in or getting the elevator with the lift attendant who remembers your name. The rooms are very chic with sophisticated touches and extremely comfortable. The sky loft is literally out of a movie although I didnt stay in this suite we had a 1 bedroom suite which for 2 people was perfect.I think you can tell what I think about the property.... dont just believe me! Experience it for yourself!!

I stayed at the Carlyle for a small meeting in NYC for a long weekend.The hotel was in a good location on the upper East side,quick walks to the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Frick Collection on 5th Avenue, and a block away from the Whitney. Great for window shopping on Madison Avenue. It seemed that a lot of Europeqns stay in this hotel. Service was excellent. Stephanie at the concierge desk gave some excellent restaurant recommendations. We got a group rate of $325 per night, which is incredibly inexpensive by NYC standards, let alone for a hotel of this caliber. Regular rates are in the $500-600 per night range. Many of us were also upgraded to suites. There was a small gym which had about 2 upright bikes, 2 treadmills, some weights, and other equipment I believe; it was clean and well kept.
Best hotel in New York City! Great location and feel. We felt like we were in another world.

The Carlyle Is a classic old New York hotel with lots of charm and a quiet upper east side location.Minuses are that rooms are typically small for Manhattan. Some rooms only have showers with no tub. Rooms are well appointed. Our room for which we paid about $900 per night had a beautiful panoramic view of central park and the city - alas the room itself was small.A potential minus is the location on the upper east side. Not convenient to mid-town or typical touristy spots. It is convenient to Central Park. We were looking for a low key place to celebrate the impending birth of our son - a quiet weekend together before parenthood - and this was perfect. The hotel arranged private car service to take us to dinner and shows, which was much appreciated by my very pregnant wife.All in, a good splurge hotel with a great old New York atmosphere.

Another fantastic stay at the Carlye. Excellent service, decor, food and comfort. Anything you could desire-for a price of course. The rooms vary quite a bit, just request what you want; a piano, quiet room in back, view $$$, the more recently refurbished rooms cost more, and everything a little a give and take one way or another. I love the suites and room service. The bar and restaurant are faulous. The Cafe Carlye is a bit of a rip off I thought, but it is a true NY experience. Best croissants outside of Paris! I love the doormen, maids, waiters, bartenders and front desk staff and elevator operator! Bring your bank account.

I worked in the hotel industry over 20 years and I can honestly say this was one of the best hotels I've ever stayed in. The lighting was 3-stage and bright, the shower had good water pressure and didn't seem flow restricted, the overall service of the staff was outstanding. We were in New York on vacation. The location was good in that it is just a short walk to Central Park or the Subway, yet still quiet and peacful. I would definately stay at this hotel again and tell all of my friends to stay here as well for a true New York classic hotel experience!

Unfortunately I did not write a review at the time of our visit because I rarely wrote reviews at that time. However, this one has been grating on me ever since.We stayed at the Carlyle for a weekend at Christmas 2009 as a present from our daughter. My biggest disappointment was the treatment we received from the staff. Because we didn't have bundles of money to hand out to staff in tips for bringing us a few slices of toast and opening a door, we felt that the service we received was non existent. In fact it felt like we were shunned. We did tip but obviously not enough.The first room we were booked into was nice but not the one that my daughter paid for. Our second room was also nice but some of the furnishings were old and worn (not something you would expect from a 5* hotel).On booking out, although my daughter had already paid for our room, we were still charged. After some discussion the bill was put right.The limousine that we booked to take us back to the airport did not turn up. We spoke to the receptionist who told us 'don't worry the hotel has a limousine that can take you' She was obviously new because , when the car did not turn up after another 15 minutes, she was no longer at the reception and we were told to go to the concierge and no further mention was made of the courtesy car. The concierge tried twice to make contact with the company supplying the Limousine but eventually offered to arrange a taxi. We paid out $100 for a 15 minute ride.So, if your Tony and Cherie Blair, John Malkovich or a Rock star, all staying at the hotel the same time as us, you would be ok. Anyone else - forget it.

We were lucky to get tickets to see Christine Ebersolle at the club inside the Carlyle. What a great find. The room is the perfect size to enjoy such a great talent. We were two tables back from the stage and you felt like you with a group of friends at a dinner party. The hotel has a great bar to enjoy before the show and they also have live music. Famous, romantic, fun!!!!!

If you are looking for a classic 5 star upper east side luxury experience - look no further. I always prefer upper east or SoHo locations when staying in New York. The Carlyle is my favorite NYC hotel. Whereas the Mandarin Oriental (second best 5 star in NYC) has got a fantastic location and nice rooms, the feeling of classic 5 star tradition blended with the difference in crowd means that the ambience is different in a positive way. From the head concierge that actually knows it all and has been around for a long time in the same hotel, bartenders that makes cocktails the hard way from scratch into perfection till the SPA that is somewhat smaller in size having been fitted into an old building, but designed by someone banned by any 5 star chain hotel due to their extravagance in spending cash on details - the hotel will impress you! Yes, some of the rooms are smaller than you might want, and some are older than I like (somewhat dated), but you feel good being there. There are lots of good local restaurants in the area that makes really good food frequented by locals rather than tourists and the hip crowd - the concierge knows them all...

The Carlyle is one of the last classic, top drawer hotels in Manhattan. Built in the 1930s, the hotel is now a blend of Art Deco, 18th century French and expensive modernism that somehow all comes together to create a uniquely luxurious environment. I stayed here for one night through Amex Platinum Card Travel which meant I was upgraded to a charming room on the 21st floor -- with terrace! Not large but tasteful, quiet and very comfortable, with every possible amenity. (My only complaint: a hair dryer so loud I had to put foam stopples in my ears to use it.) Very polite and attentive staff, from the front desk to the elevator operators to the dining room waiters. I ate dinner here and had the best coq au vin I have EVER tasted, France included. You really do feel you are in 'the lap of luxury' here, luxury as it should be: tasteful, thoughtful and discrete. The Carlyle remains what upper class used to mean.
We have stayed in many hotels in NYC including the best reviewed and highest priced. The overall experience at the Carlyle is superior to any of them.

This hotel situated in the smart upper east side of New York does everything to restore one's faith in proper hotel management and attention to detail. Everything works the way it should. You are taken up and down in the lift by a smart bell boy and service in every way is what this hotel is about! The rooms are large with incredibly comfortable beds with soft pillows and lovely linen and you can actually see to read at night unlike some of these ultra trendy hotels where it is so dark you need a torch to negotiate your way to the bathroom. We loved the bar area where you can have any form of meal or drink and the feeling is darkly Moroccan and very comfortable or the Cafe Carlyle where you have dinner and Caberet (if you are lucky Woody Allen performs) but if not, it's usually someone well known.This is definitely our favourite hotel in New York and the surrounding area is great fun too - very good coffee at Nespresso a few blocks down from the hotel.

I chose the Carlyle to propose marriage. What a wonderful evening we had -- the exquisitely appointed room with stunning terrace, champagne and strawberries, outstanding dinner and breakfast delivered to our door, bubble baths in the soaking tub, warm and friendly staff. All around a fabulous place to stay for a special night. And very gay friendly!!
user_name:
Lee B
New York City, New York

review_body: We stayed in a 2bd suite at the Carlyle for 10 days over Thanksgiving and left with mixed feelings. The Good: location, the quiet and sublime lobby, the concierge especially Dwight, the residential feel of the place, good mattress and pillows but not excellent, good cappucino's. The Bad: small bathrooms with zero luxury as in no heated towel bars, no heated floors, no oversized tubs, no counter space around the sinks, no dimmers on the switches. The closets : pretty good sized but mediocre layout, rooms are not very well decorated, ceilings are not high enough and the interior hallways are on the narrow side. The Ugly: every computer and iPad has to pay 14.95 a night for Internet which in my case meant 4 laptops and I was already spending a few thousands night for our suite. They alculated breakfast in our sitting room the most expensive possible way which meant 150$ for breakfast for 2 and I don't eat eggs. I enjoyed the Park view from the table and chairs on our wrap around terrace and I loved the linen sheets but both these were requested in advance and were expected and neither was there when we arrived and it took a few alls plus the intervention of our concierge travel Svc in NYC to get done. I think on my next trip I am going to stay at the Plaza Athenee. I still can't get over the pathetic gym with no bathroom and the sad bathrooms in our rooms of course it didn't help we had just left the Ritz in Madrid and the Berkeley in London which beat the pants off the Carlyle and the 2bd room suites were 20-25% less incl vat. The real problem with the Carlyle is it is not that luxurious.

We had a great two night stay at the Carlyle. We booked through Amex Fine Hotels and Resorts and were upgraded to a suite on the 10th floor when we checked in (Room 1020). It was a very spacious, elegant 2 room suite with 2 bathrooms and a teeny kitchen. The bed was very comfortable. The only drawbacks were no view to speak of and the bathrooms are quite small in this room. We had room service breakfast which was great though completely overpriced. A glass of oj for $11? Come on! Service was great-when I asked for a spoon through room service one was at our door in 1 minute. Not sure if we'll be back -there are so many great hotels in New York!

This hotel is classic old New York yet quite affordable. The staff treat the guests exceptionally well without looking at you blatantly for a tip after every service provided. The bar is a gorgeous and the spa is small but luxurious.

The Carlyle retaurant is hailed as one of the last bastions of traditional haute cuisine.Whilst there were small glimpses of good food the overall experience is mediocre at best.The beef wellington was excellent but my daughters lamb was overcooked and indeed dried out.The creme brulee was not caramalised but burnt.The vegetables were soggy.A dining experience is not just the food and this is were The Carlyle restaurant really fails-the staff were mostly snooty and reserved and we felt unwelcome from the moment we arrived starting with an unobserved/unacknowledged wait at the Maitre`d s plinth.Save your money-there are far better restaurants in New York City.
Great hotel with easy access to a lot of great spots for a tourist. Top notch service and beautiful rooms!! I will never stay anywhere else when traveling to the city!!

My daughters and I spent three nights here in October. Usually I stay at the Surrey, but I thought I would give this hotel a try, because I heard they had renovated the rooms. The photos on the website looked amazing. I booked some sort of suite and they upgraded me to, I guess, a bigger one--and it was huge, no doubt about it. There was even a grand piano. Unfortunately, it wasn't that comfortable...or clean. The furniture was old and sparse, and it was too small for the rooms. The couch in the living room looked downright manky. Through the holes in the radiator covers (which were large and very visible from the couch) you could see big piles of lint and scuzz. The bed was lovely and the bed linens were absolutely first quality, but the lumpy brown carpet made the room feel old. And the bathrooms (two full and one half) seemed either old or improperly cleaned. There were lines of black (fungus?) around the caulking. Where are they hiding the beautiful suites pictured on the website?! Were only some of the rooms renovated? Did they run out of money and do a more thorough job on some rooms than others? And why have people employed full-time pushing elevator buttons when there is such a problem with cleaning and maintenance? That seems truly bizarre to me.On the upside, the hotel has a great Upper East Side location, walking distance from the Met and other wonderful museums. The bar/restaurant is fun and very old New York. And the staff is sweet.But this hotel can't hold a candle to the newer or more thoroughly renovated luxury hotels in the city.

Stayed for three nights over Thnksgvg Day holiday. Wonderful old-style NYC hotel, top quality amenities (bed, soaps, etc etc etc) BUT . . . charging $15 per day for wi-fi access in a room costing almost $1,000 a night all in is too cheap for words. I think you simply have to adjust your expectations in NYC hotels. We thought we had and although we were taken aback at first with the tiny room (and especially tiny bathroom), we were won over by the top quality furnishings and the relative silence of the upper east side. The staff are almost TOO friendly (where do you see elevator attendants anymore, although I suspect they are required not so much as a luxury but more to keep the travelling riff-raff from running around on floors reserved for permanent residents). The view to the south from our 31st floor was almost worth the room price in itself, but as luxury hotels go, we have had more value for money at the Waldorf and the Standard, and the Peninsula in Chicago. Unfortunately, elevators are also very tiny (old-style) and apparently don't have room for the usual luggage trolleys, so the bell staff sort of work in teams to move your luggage by hand - kind of weird and inefficient, but unfailingly polite and gracious. Also, the old walls are very thin, so that you can easily hear a normal conversation the the adjacent room (and when you share your floor with the sort of inconsiderate boors who ought not to be staying there in the first place and can't grasp the concept of considerate quiet at 0700 on a holiday morning, then you REALLY realize how thin the walls are, but you can't blame all that on the hotel.)We might return for the location and the wonderful old-style class and charm, but we might also check out The Mark in the same location. Even though I didn't even use it - I had my own handheld - I was very irritated by the effrontery of charging extra for wireless in such an expensive hotel room but maybe The Mark is the same . . . ?

Stayed at the hotel for 4 nights in late september. The hotel itself is very beautiful. The rooms are very spacious and cozy. Everything about the hotel is trying to show it's class and it works. They even have men working in the elevator pressing the buttons for you (which I actually found annoying, especially since they only operate 1-2 elevators at a time instead of all 4 and sometimes you had to wait for the elevator a couple of minutes). The spa is nice. The location is spot on on upper east side and only few minutes walk to Central Park. The service level at the hotel is exceptional. This kind of hotel is perhaps not my first choice but I can understand why people like it. The biggest flaw was the sleep quality. Eventhough I was at the end of my floor I still could hear alot of noise during the night/early morning when people where walking to the elevators or their rooms. Considering how expensive the hotel is, not getting a good night sleep was a major let down.All in all a nice hotel at a great location.

I was on a business trip in New York which I combined with a family vacation, travelling with my wife, 3 kids and a nanny. The hotel is situated a block away from Central Park and along the shops of Madison Avenue. Our stay was great, the hotel staff really tried to look after us and surprised the kids with a special treat for Halloween, decorating the rooms with spider webs, pumpkins and the like. Best of all, when you're staying at the Carlyle, you have a porter in each elevator (which can be a bit slow when it's a busy time of the day), the Bemelman Bar had Paul McCartney show up when we were there, the Carlyle Cafe features Woody Allen performance every Monday. Rooms are good size for NY, although bathrooms only have one sink! I loved the hotel and will be back, very child friendly too!
Always a classic. Even interior rooms have alot of natural light. Wonderful beds. Great upper east side location. Feels like home.

This was my first time staying at the Carlyle. As someone who loves walking, the location is perfect for walking to the Metropolitan Museum of Art and Central Park. Everyone from the front desk staff to the doormen were always smiling, helpful and friendly. The rooms could use a little updating but the bathrooms were gorgeous. Overall a fantastic stay and would definitely return!

We spent a romantic weekend at the Carlyle on recommendation from a friend who raves about their service. Even though we were primed to expect the best, the hotel exceeded our expectations in all categories. The Carlyle is a European-style hotel decorated with a perfect, elegant blend of modern and classic -- everywhere you look it is relaxing and beautiful (and their floral arrangements, including gorgeous live orchids, are from one of the finest florists in Manhattan). Every single member of staff we encountered was not just courteous and helpful, but genuinely friendly, and happy to go above and beyond. We had bad weather our second night and needed to run a quick errand a few blocks away, so we asked them to call us a taxi -- instead, they put us in the hotel's courtesy car. The next day, we were running late for an appointment and needed something picked up about 10 blocks away -- they went and got the item and put it safely in my room. Our waiter pointed out the charming details in the hand-painted wallpaper in the dining area. The elevator attendants and front desk staff remembered our names. These are all just small examples of the seamlessly fabulous service they offer. Our room was superb -- comfortable bed, good water pressure in the shower, spotlessly clean. Room service was excellent. The location was perfect for us as well -- a quieter part of the city right by Central Park. All in all, a dream.

The Carlyle is one of a quickly vanishing breed...a hotel which lives up to its reputation for high quality service, accommodations, and ambiance. From the moment you step into the lobby, you know this is not the Marriott Marquis or the "W". From the marble floors to the art to the impeccable service, it is first class. The 'superior suite' was just that with large living room and large bedroom. The bathroom, although very modern and totally mirrored, was miniscule even by NY standards. The decor in the Carlyle Gallery (restaurant) is Moorish and lovely, not over the top like a lot of 'Bogart-wanna-be's. Serving lighter fare, the Gallery is the better place to eat at the Carlyle. The main restaurant's decor is also marvelous; however, the seating is crowded and there is no way to not be involved in the conversation next to you. The food is fairly over-priced and not that good. Location, Location, Location..that is the major problem. Unless you plan to go to Central Park and that is it, brace yourself for lots of taxi expense and long travel time to the theaters. This is not a hotel for a taste of Broadway.

When you book a refurbished junior suite do you expect a bathroom ? Well this hotel evidently doesn't feel the need to tell it's guests that a tiny shower with a basin is what's on offer .... Oh and of course we'll move you but to a dirty and depressing smoking floor which stinks . So we cut and ran ... Across the road to the Mark , a wonderful modern clean friendly hotel . The Carlyle is a disgrace and they had the gall to send us a computer generated letter thanking us for staying there!

Our double (2) bed room was more spacious than I had imagined an older NYC hotel would be. It was perfectly located in a great neighborhood. Close to restaurants, shopping, etc. Our room had a nice view. It was clean. The bathroom was spacious. There were not one, but 2 walk-in closets for our things! My only complaints about the room would be that the lingering smell of stale cigarette smoke was almost a deal breaker. And the neatly folded stack of expensive women's underwear left in one of the drawers was not my size.The staff is professional and friendly, from the elevator man to the front desk people. I found the world famous bar a bit dingy and stuffy (air), but the hotel in general is interesting and comfortable. And Zitamer's drug store is right across the street--they sell everything from aspirin to zebra stripe cashmere scarves, and just about anything else you can think of.I'd definitely stay again, and recommend it to friends.

We stayed in a superior room with view on the Madison Avenue on the 10th floor. The welcome from the reception was very nice and warm and the grooms in the elevators were also very attentionate. But we were first chocked by the rundown state of the room as we came in. We had very high expectations from the 5 stars rating of the hotel and the beautiful pictures on the hotel's website. Although the linen and the towels were excellent quality (and changed every day!) and the beds very comfortable, the rest of the furniture looked old and run down. The bathroom was the worst part: we think that this needs major renovation. For instance there were dark stains (fungus??) on the shower head and the corners of the bath tub. The paint on the ceiling of the bathroom was getting off. The closing of the bath tub was missing. Last but not least, the bath tub was not properly cleaned every day: it was simply washed with water and one could see that no soap or special product was used. Besides, we were awaken 2 times by the cleaning lady. Once she rang several times in the morning while she knew we were still in the room. She tried to give one of us a high pile of linen to put on the bed (we then politely asked her to put them herself inside!!) as she didn't feel like coming back for that later. We found it very inappropriate and disturbing. She just walked in and out while we were still busy getting ready for the day. We were basically happy with our stay in the Carlyle because: 1) the room was comfortable, 2) reception was nice, 3) location was excellent and safe. But the points mentioned above make this hotel not worth the 5 stars and regular prices for the quality offered.
This hotel may have a 5 star rating, but it does not have 5 star service with the exception of Dwight at the concierge who was a big help to me.

We had just checked into our hotel rm - about 20mins in when we felt the Aug23rd earthquake on our 10 floor rm, the hotel was very proficient at informing us. We felt totally safe. That night we went to a Yankees game, Rylie at the reception was kind enough to print up the directions via subway for us - very helpful for us first visit in the City. The next day we went to the Woodbury Commons Outlets and another very helpful reception staffer instructed us on how and where to get our bus tickets and coupon book which rocked! the lobby is reminiscent of the art deco movement. It was always great when descending into the lobby in the evenings you could hear the band in the restaurant cranking classics with a real NY/Sinatra high energy feel - wonderful for the ambience. We had dinner there one night and the food was great and the place was full of locals and tourists alike. All of the elevator conductors where adorable older men that always made quick great conversation. We were upgraded upon check in which is always a bonus and much appreciated. We stayed for 5 days, and were there for the Hurricane Irene as well - but were completely unaffected it by it in our area- even though the hotel was great at setting up an emergency plan "just in cast" The location was great for us, we could see CentralPark from our corner suite. The hotel is on the corner of 76th and Madison Ave so the shopping was fab! From Creed to JonathanAdler to Frette and all the big name designers Gucci, Valentino, E.Armani. I was worried that any room would be loud in NY, but soon as our rm door was closed it was silent in our room which I highly valued. All in all with all the options available re: hotels in NY I am satisfied with my stay at the Carlyle, the only thing I raised a brow to was the charges for wireless internet - that being said the reception staff was ALWAYS ready to print anything we every needed and the the business centre is comp as well. The rooms and paint could use some updating, it would only add to the charm of this great hotel and its staff. Oh by the way... the toiletries are Kiehls... for a product junkie like me... I thought I should mention that ; )

We splurged to stay here...usually we opt for a less fancy hotel in NYC..but we got a discounted price over labor day. This place wasnt worth the extra money. We found the room at the Carlyle quite scruffy...banged up old furniture...tired decor....nice linen though and a comfortable bed. Our bill had an error but that was corrected quickly by email.On the checkout day someone came into the room before check out time, while we were having breakfast and before we had checked out (our luggage was still there in the room) and dumped all the new linen and towels in the room and took the tip we had set out. That's tacky...made us feel rushed to leave...In the year 2011 a hotel should KNOW when guests have checked out and when they haven't...it's not rocket science.We wouldn't stay there again. We actually like a hotel in the 40's or 50's better anyway for shopping, theater, access to more than one subway line, etc.

We've stayed here a number of times and have always had lovely accommodations, whether in a regular room or a large suite. Dining room is lovely. Very old world, European type service. We've dined there for breakfast, lunch, and dinner and have been very satisfied. The bar is lively and fun. Would highly recommend!

It is always fascinating to sleep on pillows with your monogram and to be part of the history.Carlyle is one of those old school hotels rich of charm and tradition.The service is attentive, amenities in the room are cool, the staff is kind and nice, in one world the make feel you like home (that for me is really super important).I like the breakfast, maybe less the restaurant and the noise in the room, but at the end New York is the city that does not sleep!!!In a city crawded with fake super chic and cool hotel is nice to have a place that is still authentic and genuine

Having never travelled to New York, not knowing where to stay and being overwhelmed by the number of choices, it was just the luck of the draw that we ended up at the Carlyle. The location was PERFECT. Just steps from central park and a nice leisurely walk to all of the hustle and bustle, providing a quiet retreat to return to after a night of bright lights and honking cars. The service was IMPECCABLE. We were in and out quickly at both check in and check out and were even treated to a nice upgrade. We were celebrating a birthday and were welcomed to our room with a beautiful plate of fruit and a lovely birthday pastry with a chocolate birthday plaque. The view was AMAZING. We were facing Madison Avenue and got to enjoy it every morning from our enclosed patio room. The room was DAZZLING. Clean, crisp and all of the amenities one could possibly need. We got a great deal on one of the travel sites and will recommend this hotel time and time again and can’t wait to go back ourselves.

Stayed here with my family as part of our 25th Weddinng Ann. Had a great time. I had previously stayed here on a business trip some 2 years ago. Hotel met our expectations - comfortable, clean and great people working there. Nothing was too much trouble. They even had even put some cake in our room when we arrived to celebrate our anniversary. It was such a nice touch. I can't thank everyone at the Carlyle for a great stay - I cant wait to come back.

I recently stayed at the Carlye it is a lovely historic hotel, my room was huge with a beautiful marble bathroom. The hotel is located in a quiet location off Central Park, excellent for shopping on Madison Ave. I found all the staff to be very friendly and helpful.

This is the perfect New York hotel -- unpretentious outside, but delightfully deluxe inside. The place has an old-school, retro-glamour feel to it. I stayed there twice recently, and both rooms were extremely quiet, with nice big bathrooms and exceptionally comfy beds. Room service was very prompt, hot, and tasty. I booked through the AMEX Fine Hotels program, and was lucky enough to get an upgrade one night to a tower room (spectacular!) and I made good use of the $100 spa credit, too. (Antonina gave me the best facial ever.) One thing that really stood out about this hotel was the attitude of the employees. Truly everyone was cheerful and polite -- an elevator operator even broke into song on one occasion, and he was very good, too! If you are debating which high-end hotel to stay at in Manhattan, you can't go wrong with the Carlyle. For the dates I was in town, the rates were a lot less than the St. Regis, but the experience was just as good if not better.

Very caring staff when checking in. They offered me an upgrade to a deluxe room which was very enjoyable when travelling during 12 hours.My room was nicely decorated, had a beautiful entrance corridor and a full mirorred bathroom(which was great by the way)

We went to New York for a special occasion. To celebrate a 21st. A celebration type hotel was called for. Of course in the States the 21st is a big thing as alcohol becomes legal.Usually we have stayed in Midtown but this time we went to the posh end of town and the Upper East Side. We booked The Carlyle. Although we were a little concerned that it might be a little stuffy we plumped for it because of its history, its reputation, its fame for jazz and its proximity to Central Park which was condsidered a bonus bearing in mind we were going in summer. We were thankful that we had as the temperatures reached staggering highs and a stroll through the trees of the Park was welcome on more than one occasion.What then about the hotel itself. Quite simply it is, as the Americans would say, awesome. In a city which can at times be revolting in its brashness and ability to go completely OTT this is a place that is luxurious yet measured, restrained, and subtle. It is comfortable with being what it is - that is - pure class - and does not need to shout it from the its very high rooftop.We were greated by the special events manager who had responded to my request for adjoining rooms. She gave us only one room key on arrival however - saying some finishing touches were to be done to the birthday girl's room. We soon found out that these touches were the delivery of complimentary Champagne and cake to get the celebrations off to a wonderful start.We spent time in the bar - birthday girl showing that her 3 years of UK drinking practice had not gone to waste - as she sampled a number of fantastically executed cocktails. We listened to the relaxing jazz. We admired the extraordinary murals on the walls.We had breakfast in the Restaurant - once I had been sent back to the room as I was wearing shorts which were not acceptable - quite right too - I felt my self saying.We sampled the lounge where it is said the great and good of yesterday, the Hepburns and Kennedys would meet, and where the great and good of today clearly still do.The service throughout the hotel was impeccable, the food excellent, the drink better. The rooms old style proper total comfort with all the amenities you could need, the ipod dock and flat screen TV sitting well with the French influenced furniture and marble bathrooms. The hotel lobby and public areas understated in elegance with great art and objects and yet a well equipped and complimentary business centre..If you want urban cool and modern minimalism dont stay here.The Carlyle is a hotel of a different age, an age of classic beauty and refined living, but it retains its relevance in today's world by being exemplary in every way.It is an oasis from both the constant rush of the city that never sleeps and the world which seems never to even take a breath. It is marvellous.

We chose the Carlyle for its location and reputation. And it is a great location - only a few blocks from the Met and a stroll away from the shops on Madison. But it is living on a past reputation which it no longer deserves. We arrived too early to check in on a very wet day. We were promised a phone call when our room was ready but otherwise we braved the heavy downpour. Hours went by and no phone call. In desperation we returned to be greeted by reception staff who had no trace of us or our request for a call. Despite it being past 3pm (the normal check in time) there was still no room for us. We were given an upgraded room - which in fairness was just lovely. But the hotel's reception desk staff seem more interested in talking to each other than assisting. More than once we stood patiently waiting for attention only to be ignored. 'Hello??....' The last straw? On the last day we rang down to ask for assistance with baggage. 'Of course, someone will be up directly...' 25 mins later with a plane to catch we struggled downstairs ourselves. The reception was deserted except for the reception desk clerk filing his nails and two uniformed bellhops standing idly by ... chatting... Don't trouble yourselves gentlemen, we won't be back...

My family of three used our airline miles to book a room for one night. We asked for a non smoking room, that was our only choice given online. When we called to confirm, we asked to face the street and have a view. When we arrived way before check in time, to drop off our bags and sightsee, the very nice lady at the front desk asked us if we wanted to see if our room was ready at that time. It was not, but she even called our cell phone later when it was. She told us we had been upgraded and the room included a renovated bath. It was a terrific room and was enormous. VERY CLEAN! The bath had a separate shower and tub and good lighting. A little mildew along the caulk in the shower, but easily overlooked. The bed was the best thing about the room, no smell of any kind, it was like sleeping on a new mattress and pillow. I am really picky about odor, and my room was very fresh!!! The view was not so hot, just the building across the street, but the room was so pretty, I did not care. The staff was very nice and friendly. They stored our bags when we checked out for us. I would love to stay there again someday! Great location, very quiet at night, and right near the Met museum and in a great part of town.

Return to the era of elegance when you stay at the New York Carlyle Hotel. Family and I stayed in one of their large suites and the furnishings were terrific. Dinner at the Carlyle Restaurant was terrific as it had great food, terrific service and splendid atmosphere. Saw Woody Allen and the Eddie Davis jazz band in the Cafe Carlyle which was an absolute highlight, Having stayed in many of the very best hotels in the US I must say the Carlyle is right near the top of the list.

The Calyle is the type of place you expected the Vanderbuilts and Astors to stay at. The service was fantastic. We have brunch in their restaurant, I have to say that other than being in Europe I have not had a better brunch. Very very expensive - $500 per night is very common. Its a great experience and a real treat to be treated like royalty. Book it for a special occasion. Great restuarants for dinner nearby on the Avenues and the Met is a three block walk. Great stuff.
user_name:
Jomled
New York City, New York

review_body: We have just returned from a lovely trip to the Carlyle. It's a beautiful hotel with stunning deco and interiors. The room was comfortable. We had fantastic views over Manhattan and Central Park from our 23rd floor room.Breakfast was good but the service was a little slow and inattentive. Bemelman's bar was a great place to enjoy an evening listening to live jazz music. This was the best part of our stay at the hotel.The hotel had misplaced our booking of a car to pick us up from JFK, but they offered us a complimentary car on our return to JFK as an apology.Staff were always friendly and able. We had a very good time. We may return but may also try one of New York's other 5 star hotels. We have stayed at the Ritz and the Plaza previously and I would put it roughly on a par with those hotels, though the location is not as good in our opinion.

This is our second stay at The Carlyle. We stayed once in adjoining rooms with our kids, but this time went just the two of us for a weekend of theater and exploring the City. Both stays were excellent. The hotel itself from it's architecture, to the amazing art in the lobby, to the white gloved elevator operators is old New York at its best. The service is so polite and unobtrusive it seems to come almost from another era. We first stayed in 2 rooms with our kids and these rooms, called "Unrennovated" were absolutely enormous. We didn't even need 2 rooms. Each must have been 800 sq ft with a large walk-in closet and kitchenette. Great w/ kids. THIS time we stayed in one of the rennovated rooms, which was lovely but much much much smaller. THE LOCATION simply can't be beat. You are just steps away from the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Whitney, Central Park and The Guggenheim, also the Neue Gallerie. WE WILL DEFINITELY BE BACK.

We arrived early on sunday and were given a room within 1 hour, the room was very nice but that night we had a rest less night due to the loud ac unit.The next morning i made the desk manager aware and were given a choice of 3 different rooms to which we could move to very nice of them. We choseto moved to the 31first floor with a very nice view of central park. With this in mind i would recommend this hotel if you can get a deal as i did,a good deal.It is usually very high room cost $700.00 to $1000.00 search for under $ 500.00. For food deals and purchases head to second and third ave.s.Very helpful staff and elavator operators, bus lines are very close. Hope this will help you.

We had numerous special requests during our most recent visit to NYC. The staff of the Carlyle was outstanding in addressing these special needs: they exceeded our expectations in every way.This is an "Old School" hotel with genteel staff; manners are important. Ordering people about in a loud voice or being rude will not win you many fans here.The food service is very good: we ate in all the hotel restaurants and tried the patience of the room service staff many times: all was delicious! Spa services are very good too.The beds are top rate: very comfortable. Bed linens are Frette.The hotel interiors were designed by Mark Hampton - some are being converted (sadly) but the main public areas still remain his trademark.We have been won over by the service at the Carlyle and will make it our #1 choice in NYC.

I chose this hotel because it was near Central Park, the major museums I was planning to visit, and Madison Avenue shopping. I enjoyed staying here very much. The hotel is very quiet and comfortable. I listened to live music at the bar downstairs, Bemelman's. I was very happy to be able to walk right over to all the attractions that I was interested in, I didn't have to take a cab anywhere while I was in NYC. The hotel staff are helpful. The toiletries provided were great, the soap especially has a wonderful smell.The longer I was there, the more I liked the hotel, it really grew on me. I had to pay about $14.95 for internet per day.
The Carlyle is an Upper East Side tradition. The staff was friendly and efficient, and we especially enjoyed Bemelman's Bar with the Chris Gillespie Trio playing.

We recently spent 4 nights at the Carlyle in celebration of a birthday and wedding anniversary. Someone had tipped off the staff and every where we went we were wished happy birthday and anniversary, including a duet from the customer relations person and the floor manager singing happy birthday to my wife and bringing her flowers and a cake on the day. The staff was extremely attentive to all our needs and wishes and the room was lovely and quiet..we slept in till 10 am one day! An evening spent in Bemelmans' Bar was unforgettable and a long chat with Tommy the bartender was fun. We splurged on ourselves by staying here but it was well worth it and we would definitely return when we next visit NYC. Only minor complaint was a charge for in room internet access, but it is free in the business center downstairs.

This review updates my prior review of The Carlyle from July of 2006, and relates specifically to stays at the hotel in August and October of 2010. These were my 15th and 16th stays at the hotel, respectively.The Carlyle continues to be one of my favorite hotels, worldwide. This is a hotel of timeless elegance and gentility, with a high level of service and personal attention. It’s a hotel with staff continuity – some the bell staff, room service staff and doormen are the same as on my first visit in 1992. They remember me from stay to stay, and I am warmly greeted. That continuity provides something intangible, and very valuable.During the August, 2010 visit, my wife and I had a Premiere Suite on the 4th floor, overlooking 76th Street. The suite had a half bath, kitchenette, large living room (with grand piano) and bedroom with full bath. The “Deluxe” and “Premiere” suite categories seem to be exactly the same except that, in the Premiere Suite category, one of the two walk-in closets has been turned into a separate shower stall, allowing a separate soaking tub.The room was very well appointed. Each of the two easy chairs and sofa in the living room were inviting and comfortable. The easy chair in the bedroom was also very comfortable. I’m picky about lighting, and all of the seating locations were well lit. The grand piano was cool to look at, but didn’t serve much purpose for us. As is always the case at The Carlyle, the bedding and linen were of highest quality (Frette, I believe). The bed was excellent.I visited the hotel alone for the October, 2010 stay, and stayed in a tower room somewhere in the 20s – my first opportunity to stay in the tower portion of the hotel. My view was to the east – and was spectacular. The bathroom also had a window, and I could enjoy the same view while “seated”, so to speak.The tower room had a comfortable easy chair, with very good lighting nearby. It also had a walk-in closet. On the both stays, housekeeping was flawless. Everything happened when it was supposed to, and how it was supposed to happen. The door service and elevator service was friendly and prompt.As has always been the case at The Carlyle, the HVAC worked flawlessly during both stays, and both rooms were exceptionally quiet (this was a pleasant surprise for the 4th floor room, which I expected to pick up more of the Madison avenue traffic noise).I have some rules that guide my stays at The Carlyle.1) I like bright rooms. Because of that, with the exception of the Premiere Suite mentioned above that was on the 4th floor, I normally stay no lower than the 8th or 9th floors. I’ve found the lower floors much darker when it come to natural light.2) I follow my “old hotel rule” when I stay The Carlyle – which is, never stay in the cheapest room in an old hotel, because those rooms can be very very small and/or look into air shafts. From the floor plans, I do perceive that there is at least one room on each of the lower floors that would fit into that category.3) If breakfast is not included in my room rate, I eat breakfast elsewhere, since it is priced at a very high level. 4) I’m always very cautious about room service. Very thirsty during one summertime stay, I ordered a pitcher of Iced Tea (how much could it cost, I thought?). Thirty-nine dollars (before the tip), was the answer. I learned my lesson.The Carlyle is never cheap, although good rates can be had if one looks for them. The service has never disappointed over the past two decades. I’ve never had any failings of any the fundamentals – plumbing, noise levels, electrical, HVAC, bedding, lighting and the like. It has met all of my expectations consistently throughout all of my stays.I strongly recommend The Carlyle to anyone who looks for a classic, high service hotel stay with no surprises.

I got an amazing deal on the private sale site, SniqueAway, and stayed at the Carlyle over Valentine's Day weekend. I found the Carlyle to be the epitome of old New York style and grandeur. From the front desk to the white-gloved elevator operator to the cleaning staff, everyone we encountered was helpful and polished. The suite was the largest I've stayed in New York City. It had a large bedroom, living room, separate fully-enclosed kitchenette, full bath off the bedroom, and 1/2 bath at the entrance. It was larger than my 2-bedroom Back Bay Boston apartment! The location is wonderful, conveniently located one block from Central Park in the gorgeous Upper East Side.The few downsides were the kitchenette was very dated. Also, it was stocked with a few wine and champagne glasses, but after we used them the first night, the maid staff took them to be cleaned but never brought us a clean set.Full disclosure, if I had paid full price, I would have expected a more updated kitchenette and a better view. However, I feel I got a great value on this amazing hotel.

Thoroughly enjoyed the hotel and location. They have done a wonderful job maintaining the integrity of the history of the hotel. My room was HUGE by any city's standards. Kiehls bath amenities were to die for. Service was top notch.

Just got back from a 4 night stay in a Superior Suite at the Carlyle. I'm 60 and have stayed at fine hotels all over Europe and in major US cities. This is the worst hotel experience I've ever had. Off the entrance hallway to our suite was a kitchenette with Formica counter tops and appliances that had seen better days many years ago. The rug in the living area was stained and frayed at the edges. There was a jagged tear in the curtains that looked like it had been repaired by a child. The bathroom was completely walled in mirrors to disguise how incredibly tiny it was. I really doubt that 2 adults could have stood in the bathroom at the same time. After arrival, I called housekeeping to ask for a bucket of ice, since there are no ice machines on the floor, and finally, an hour later, on the third phone call, I just told them to forget it. Breakfast each morning in the restaurant was included in our room package and was about the quality one would expect at a Denny's. We asked to see another room and were shown a Deluxe Suite which was actually in worse physical shape than our first suite, so we just let it go. The Carlyle may have been the epitome of Art Deco splendor when it was built in 1931. In 2011, it's merely faded, tired looking, and cramped. If you really want to stay in a wonderful hotel, go stay in the Ritz Carlton in San Francisco. It, like the Carlyle, is housed in an older, historic building, but the difference in quality between the two hotels is like night and day. If you're in New York, anything would have to be better than the Carlyle.

Stayed here for a NY weekend of shopping and dinning. Positives - good value for 5 star in NY and good value for the location which is great, upper east side.Continued positives - Captures Old New York with some really nice old world touches, elevator guys were great and along with the bellstaff and resturant guys, the only real professionals.Room - was huge for NY standards, granted we were upgraded, but really was nice, hardwood floors and charming touches.Negatives - Front desk staff was a bit amatuer hour, young people with really not a whole lot of class, not especially friendly.Conceriege was a bit off too, younger, incurrate information.Common areas are a little worn down.Did not feel like I got a true 5 star service oriented group. Save for elevator operators, bellman, and resturant.Just not a place to fall in love with, disappointing to us because we really wanted to find our "address" in NY for return trips. I am going to stick with mainstream luxury groups such as Ritz Carlton or Four Seasons, perhaps a better reviewed botique hotels.But if your in your 30s and a well healed traveler, look elsewhere, the Carlyle will disapoint.

This hotel was recommended a perfect place to recuperate after a surgical procedure. When I spoke to a reservationist she assured me that they would have a renovated suite with a kitchenette for me. I was given a seemingly lovely renovated one bedroom suite with a minibar, no kitchenette. Minibar frig was broken so we had to have another delivered. The heat and air-conditioning did not work in the bedroom. I ordered toast and it arrived uncovered and ice cold. The phone in the living room malfunctioned.I complained to the night manager who said he was sorry the room was not to my liking. I guess it is my fault that I don't like to eat food after it has spent a few hours in a warm frig, my fault that I become uncomfortable in stuffy, hot rooms and my fault that I find cold toast unappetizing. He also mentioned that I had too many requestsAthough the hotel's night manager could use a rigorous retraining in customer relations , every service person who came to our room was polite, apologetic and helpful.

My first trip to New York and this hotel definately catered to us. It was my birthday and received two upgrades and a note from the chef. This is definately upscale and fits the east side venue. There was coffee service outside the cafe for those early risers with a few mini muffins. A few mornings we just eat breakfast sitting in the lobby people watching. The fitness center is very adequate and the business center has both a mac and windows computers. The front desk was very friendly. Everyone here knew who we were after the first night. The room was spacious, the bathroom large and the amenities top notich. Great location to walk Central Park and the Museums. We walked only a few blocks down and caught the subway for a ride to China Town, Brooklyn bridge...It was only about a $10.00 cab ride down to Times Square/Rockefeller CenterGreat staff and top notch service

I've stayed here five times. The hotel expresses the best of NY grace style, from the fabulous art deco lobby to the public rooms. Not too big but not boutique and with great staff, it's the best place to stay in New York (the St Regis is good to but not at all as personal or cosy).The rooms are spacious and well kitted out with lovely soap and toiletries. Try and get a renovated room - some of the basic rooms are awaiting refurbishing. It's expensive, but worth it; book a deal including breakfast and free internet (I like whatahotel.com) - you also save on rack rates and may get a room upgrade.

Beware the spider beetles in your bed at the Caryle. They look like bed bugs and they do bite. The one I found was examined by a "professional" and declared not bed bug. Took four days to be identified as said beetle, after repeated requests for information. 10 bites on torso and thigh.

spent a winter's evening at The Carlyle...dinner at Cafe Carlyle, cabaret show and overnight accomodation...using major credit card reservation service, had early check in, late check out, spa credit and breakfast....caliber of service was outstanding from start to finish...hefty price tag but generally worth it....gorgeous room, fabulous table for dinner, incredible performance by cabaret singer, outstanding service from start to finishone hitch: as hotel guest, surprised that we were hit up for 15.00/pp cover charge while standing at bar waiting for table (jazz trio on break) and were, subsequently, charged 30.00/pp to sit at table for 2nd round of drinks (this time, the trio performed)...our cover charge was greater than cost of drinks, as only 2 out of 4 had 2nd round.... ordered/picked up drinks at bar ourselves - no table service other than the bill being delivered to our table, with the added cover charge...just wasn't right...could understand if you were not hotel guest and stopping in for drinks...but, seemed excessive and definitely soured the feel of evening if you are looking for a special place for special evening, the Carlyle can be the place - just make sure you've got deep pockets... FYI: simple breakfast for two exceeded $85 -

We spent 3 nights at this wonderful, unique, small but beautifully run hotel.The service was exemplary. The staff were courteous, attentive and friendly. Nothing was too much trouble.Old fashioned style (if only other hotels would copy this).The lift attendants wore white gloves The flower arrangements were superp.The restaurants were fabulous,The bar was atmospheric with a great pianist.We experienced an utterly pleasurable stay.

Quite simply, there isn't a better hotel in New York if you're looking for old-world elegance and charm. The rooms are spacious and adorned with elegance. The beds are top-notch with some of the finest quality linens I have slept on at a hotel. The bathroom showers are fantastic with massive tubs for those who like to soak.
